Title: Chinese HIV+ family seek compensation
article: shanghai: a father and daughter infected with hiv from a contaminated blood transfusion are battling for compensation in a landmark court case, a report said today. they became infected after the man's wife, being treated for anemia during pregnancy at two different hospitals in suzhou, eastern china, was given an infected blood transfusion in early 1998. by the time she was diagnosed with aids (acquired immune deficiency syndrome) last year, her husband and daughter were hiv (human immunodeficiency virus) positive. the wenhui daily did not identify the family by name. the woman died in late 2000 and her husband is suing the hospital and blood treatment companies for 13 million yuan (1.57 million dollars). the paper said the man closed his barber shop when his wife fell ill and had spent his life savings on medical bills for his daughter, who is now three years old but may not live beyond five. the suzhou case is the first time a family infected with hiv has taken a case to court. if successful, it could pave the way for a stream of similar lawsuits, if infected people can find the money to take cases to court, the paper said. illegal blood transfusions have infected scores of people in chinese cities and hundreds more in rural areas where illegal blood banks roam the country taking blood from villagers using unsterilized instruments.

Title: NACO declares HIV, AIDS epidemics
article: patna: with the hiv infection affecting about 38 lakh people with no state remaining free from the virus, the national aids control organisation (naco) has been forced to declare hiv and aids as one of the most complex epidemics of the country. apart from recommending the inclusion of science of hiv in medical education including under-graduate and post-graduate courses, the naco has developed a comprehensive training programme to cover all the medical and para-medical workers functioning at different tiers of health care system for capacity building and development of sustainable systems to combat the disease, a senior official of the bihar aids control society said. medical colleges have been identified as the state level nodal institutinos for imparting training to staff working in different medical colleges as well as training of district core teams of trainers. in each medical college, a team of core trainers drawn from senior faculty of departments of medicine, surgery, paediatrics, obstetrics and gynaecology, pathology, microbiology, community medicine, blood bank services, social scientists, dentistry would be identified and trained. the project directors of state aids control societies have been directed to divide the districts among the exsiting number of medical colleges for imparting training to district core team of trainers, the official said. apart from conducting training, the core team members would also visit the districts alloted to them for ensuring quality control in training programme. in many states such training programme has already been started. the naco has asked all the medical colleges to establish hiv voluntary counselling and testing centres (vct) in the department of microbiology soon. they have also been asked to ensure that the drugs for the treatment of infections are made available to the hiv/aids patients free of cost. the naco has asked the authorities of all the medical colleges to encourage research work in hiv/aids related subjects. the union health minister, dr c p thakur, during his recent visit to patna had also said that medical colleges would be involved in the implementation of all the national health programmes.

Title: Levi's contributes to  HIV/AIDS awareness
article: bangalore: the levi strauss foundation on monday extended a helping hand to mother sharadadevi social service society (mssss), an ngo involved in education and social development with special focus on promoting hiv/aids awareness education programmes among various communities in south india. levi strauss (india) private limited managing director c.s. suryanarayanan handed over a demand draft of $36,000 to mssss, on behalf of the foundation for the year 2001, to help promote the project. the objective of this project is to educate the most vulnerable section of the community like commercial sex workers and truck drivers. ``levi strauss continues its efforts towards community development in the country and are committed to expand the reach of the community partnership programme,'' suryanarayanan said. levi strauss foundation based in san francisco, acts as a catalyst for positive change in communities around the world, tackling critical social issues through strategic alliances. the foundation has been working for more than three decades with participation over 1,700 employees across the world. this year, the foundation will focus on aids prevention and care, economic empowerment, social justice and youth empowerment.

Title: Mehta denies HIV blood given to Jamnagar boy
article: gandhinagar: state health minister suresh mehta on monday took strong exception to the manner in which the calling attention motion was raised by congress member usmangani devdiwala regarding the deteriorating health condition of a thalasemia patient after he was allegedly administered blood of an hiv-positive donor in jamnagar. as mehta tried to draw the attention of the chair towards the incident which had occurred in december last, opposition members said that when the speaker had admitted the motion for debate the minister should not challenge the speaker's decision. to this mehta asserted that he wanted to focus the attention of the house tom the fact that the state government has already clarified the matter after it was highlighted by the media in saurashtra. he said a matter raised in the assembly has to be of urgent nature, and should concern people at large and not just an individual as had been done here. "there are no ingredients of a calling attention motion in this case," he said. unmindful of the ruckus by congress members, mehta continued to rap the opposition for raising the issue for the sake of publicity and sought a ruling from the speaker. amidst heated arguments, mehta told the house that the patient was not given hiv-infected blood, and that there was no question of negligence and punitive action against any officials. mehta said the patient's father was given three bottles of blood by a blood bank in jamnagar, which had collected it from a donation camp jointly organised by guru govindsingh hospital and j h hathi memorial blood bank. of these, one bottle which contained hiv-positive blood was immediately destroyed, while the blood from two bottles was given to the patient.

Title: Three-in-one drug for HIV receives mixed reaction
article: mumbai: the launch of a capsule, a combination of three anti-retroviral drugs, gives hiv patients reason to cheer. specialists on hiv hail it as heralding a ``compact world order". though the capsule is a welcome relief to hiv patients, its welcome is laced with lots of caution. the good news first. the capsule, triomune, reduces the `pill burden' of hiv patients. they don't have to live with too many pills and schedules, says dr shashank joshi, a consultant with lilavati hospital. ``for sheer convenience and compliance, fixed dose combinations will be the order of the day," he says. the cost factor is gratifying (at about rs 1,800, i.e. less than $ 40), says a spokesperson of the people's health organisation, given that an international equivalent of this drug is available for $800 in the grey market. the centre's decision to exempt all hiv/aids drugs from customs and excise duties will bring the cost of triomune further down to rs 1,500, he says. launched by an indian pharmaceutical company last week, triomune combines three anti-retroviral drugs: lamivudine, stavudine and nevirapine. anti-retroviral drugs are reported to boost the immunological system of an hiv patient and prevent the virus from multiplying or infecting new cells, thus bringing down the viral load. apart from bringing hiv drugs within the reach of more hiv-affected people, the price reduction will also encourage many to keep away from quacks and dubious medicines, doctors say. while bringing down treatment costs of hiv infection, doctors are also wary of this instant, pop-easy culture that this drug signals. the medical community nurses some apprehension about its possible misuse by ``enterprising" doctors who may be emboldened to recommend this drug freely to patients since it makes prescription so much simpler. drug intake should be monitored and be given under ``careful medical supervision", dr joshi points out. otherwise, there is a very real risk of the drug getting misused, thanks to the way it has simplified medication. in the absence of a special branch dealing with hiv infection and treatment, the possibility of the drug being mis-prescribed or over-prescribed cannot be ruled out, he says. ``usually, doctors do not like to lose their patients and end up scribbling down some medicines even in hiv cases though they may not be trained. with the capsule, they do not even need to be informed," says an aids specialist who does not wish to be named. ``triomune rids doctors of the anxiety of determining the precise dosage of three different drugs," a doctor says. the capsule culture can work in the u.s. where patient compliance is monitored by giving them simulated drugs for the first two weeks and professional counselling is the norm, says an expert. ``here, there is no such thing as patient counselling or monitoring," another expert says. moreover, doctors fear that the low cost would also tempt one to self-medicate, apart from falling prey to doctors untrained in hiv care. the cost of treatment is anyway one component in hiv care. ``hiv cases require extensive monitoring. every three months, the viral load and cd4 count has to be tested. these two tests alone cost rs 4,000. if the drug is taking effect, the viral load will drop and the cd4 count will go up. however, after a while, the patient may develop drug resistance and record reverse results. in that case, he should be administered new drugs along with the ant-retroviral regimen. this pushes up costs considerably," an hiv counsellor says. ``very often, doctors recommend drugs to hiv patients even without these two basic tests when these tests are an absolute must," she points out. this could have serious repercussions since anti-retroviral drugs can have a few side-effects like nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, peripheral neuritis, itching, rash and even high liver toxicity. informed prescription is a must in a country where the patients, too, are, by and large, poorly informed about health matters. doctors fear that with cheaper drugs, patients may not want to go through tests which are costlier than a month's treatment. as it is, patients are reluctant to shell out the huge sums for tests. far from boosting immunity, this would create havoc with a patient's system. ``if random use of anti-retroviral drugs is encouraged, users may develop multi-drug resistance because of its liberal use as happened with tb, says dr joshi. price wars are no doubt good for the patient, but only when coupled with trained counselling. given the appalling ignorance on hiv even among the medical community and the fact that aids remains a grey area for medical practice, as there is no clear understanding as to who can and cannot treat the disease, the need for more training programmes for medicos cannot be over-stated, doctors say. ``we need rigorous continuing medical education (cme) programmes for all doctors so that they are better aware of the pitfalls of all kinds of drugs," adds an expert.

Title: Number of HIV-positive cases shots up to 142
article: patna: at least 53 people out of 170 tested hiv positive at the voluntary counselling and testing centre (vctc) in rajendra memorial research institute in only four months from april to july, 2001. with this, the total number of hiv positive case in bihar has soared to 142. whereas in november 2000, the number of people with hiv positive at eleven sentinel surveillance centres stood at 89. stating this at a press conference on tuesday, health minister shakuni chaudhary said that "the situation had become alarming for bihar as the figures reveal that out of the 35 women tested at the centre, 18 (i.e., more than 50 per cent) were hiv positive". "it's a matter of grave concern for us especially due to such an alarming rise in hiv cases among women", he said. "in majority of the cases the spouses of a large number of the hiv positive women were working outside bihar", he added. the truck drivers coming from outside the state are considered to be a potential career of aids virus and for this an ngo, adithi, has been assigned the job to test them, he informed. chaudhary said that a directive had been issued to conduct hiv test on the truck drivers at the borders of the state. in addition to this, money had been released to set up vctcs in all the medical colleges and hospitals of bihar. proposal for opening vctcs at kurji holy family hospital, patna, and duncon hospital, raxaul on bihar-nepal border, is under consideration, he added. he said that aids awareness programme would be paced up. the additional chief medical officers who also work as district nodal officers had been given training for aids detection. training programmes are also being held at government and non-government hospitals of the state. the paramedics of kurji holy family hospital, patna, and nazerath hospital in mokama had already been given the training. aids awareness programme and test camps will be held at all the bihar military police (bmp) headquarters. he said that the proposal relating to aids detection training to all mukhiyas of the gram panchayats and the chairman of zila parishads was under active considertaion. action had been taken to provide the training at high school level also, he said. the minister said that more than 2.31 lakh people of the state had been found to be suffering from sexually transmitted diseases (stds). also present at the press conference was the minister of state for health, akhilesh singh, who said that many people coming for the hiv test at the centre were biharis staying outside the state.

Title:
LIVING WITH HIV
Positive people pick up the pieces
article: new delhi: rama pandian, recipient of several awards for being a fine hospital laboratory analyst, is giving a matter-of-fact account of his life, when suddenly he breaks down. instinctively covering his face, he splutters a few sentences to describe a family life devastated by aids and the pain of being yanked from his job. but the depression is wiped away as determinedly as traces of tears from his face. the abrupt end to his vocation has made him take up a new mission: of helping others rebuild their lives through the wreckage left behind by hiv. as the head of an organisation called the tamil nadu network of positive people, tnp plus, he is working to restore optimism amongst those infected. and he is not alone. as hiv enters the confines of the middle-class, educated young men and women are trying to find a way to live. after first surfacing in chennai in sex workers 16 years ago, hiv is now infecting society's fittest and brightest ^ doctors, engineers, lawyers, bureaucrats, businessmen. away from the public eye, several of the infected are fanning out to different parts of the country to set up support groups with the help of doctors and ngos. apart from big cities, groups have emerged in districts such as namakkal in tamil nadu and small towns like nagpur in maharashtra. it is a measure of the spread of the deadly virus that each of these groups, despite their limited reach, has a membership of no less than a thousand. so, lilabanta, an engineer and deepak, a young businessman, teach hundreds in imphal how to overcome the fear of an impending death. elango, in bangalore, provides support to the countless who come to him from all over karnataka. abraham kurien of kerala shuttles between various city centres, coordinating activities and reaching out to the affected. and in mumbai, members of the support group rush to help distressed people wherever they want to meet them to ensure secrecy. women, usually victims of hiv after marriage, are also coming forward to hold the hands of those less courageous. so anita, infected after her marriage to an engineer, not only continues with her studies after the death of her husband and brings up her three-year-old daughter, but also rushes to the assistance of those who need her help in vishakhapatnam. kousalya in chennai provides the support of a group sensitive to needs of women from all parts of the country. it's a whole new world with hiv where life does not necessarily end with the four letters of aids. (names have been used with consent). facts file *hiv positive: a person carrying the virus with no apparent signs of illness. an estimated 3.8 million in india are infected. *full-blown aids: the immune system is completely ravaged by hiv. the person dies as a result of body being invaded by several diseases. (this is the first of a seven-part series that will appear on monday)

Title: 70,000 HIV positive patients in Kerala
article: thiruvananthapuram: an estimated 70,000 people have been tested hiv positive in kerala so far, state health minister p sankaran said on monday. talking to reporters on the eve of opening of the first voluntary counselling and testing centre at the public health laboratory here, sankaran said there were 856 full-blown aids patients in the state. the government would open eight more such centres in the state. they would be set up in the six medical colleges and in the two regional public health laboratories, he said. the centre was set by the kerala state aids control society as part of the national aids control programme.

Title: An epidemic of missing HIV patients
article: new delhi: at a missionary-run hospital in patna, dr ravi sahay has of late started getting a steady trickle of hiv affected patients. but instead of treating them, he turns them away for fear of contracting the virus. and he believes other doctors need to be warned as well. so, he refers these patients to a government-run set up, announcing their hiv positive status in red ink. the patients are never seen again. their records never show up in government hospitals or even in the annual surveillance figures handed out by the national aids control organisation for the past three years on the basis of the reports collected from states. but these patients do appear as cold statistics in the records of private testing centers. just one centre in patna, sen diagnostics, has 615 confirmed cases. but these are not even considered by the government. officially, bihar remains a low prevalence state, with only 44 reported cases. clearly the annual government count, which shows a gradual slowing down of the rate of infection over three years - from 3.5 million in 1998 to 3.86 in 2000 - is not measuring the epidemic accurately. even if bihar's example were to be attributed to inefficient overall governance, serious gaps remain in the annual surveillance exercise even in states with a strong administration. project director of the national aids control organisation, jvr prasada rao, admits there are problems. "pinpointed data from surveillance is not reliable. but over a period of time a trend is discernible. you have to have validation exercises by taking actual observations from a community nearby." so states are still trying to come up with an efficient system, even as surveillance, conducted over a three-month period, from august 1 to october 31, at 232 designated sites all over the country, forms the basis of future policy. as of now, sample collection remains faulty even at the best of centres. dr v. lakhshmi, at nizam's institute of medical sciences, hyderabad, who is also a regional coordinator for surveillance, agrees that some centres may not be able to collect the requisite number of samples. for instance, victoria hospital in bangalore could get only half the requisite number of std cases last year. there are other problems as well: in kerala, there were no kits for testing at some centres, even after the blood had been collected. these samples then had to be thrown away. in manipur, transportation of samples to testing sites is not easy. moreover, sample vials are not always properly sealed and their contents are known to spill. at several centres in bihar, sample collection is barely a tenth of what is required. even the capital city of patna collected only 46 samples from pregnant women against the stipulated 400. districts such as darbhanga sent only 33 samples from std patients, when the required number was 250. an important statement by the union health minister recently that the epidemic has plateaued off is based on such surveillance.

Title: A virus that can slow down HIV's growth
article: udupi: prof b.m. hegde, vice-chancellor of manipal academy of higher education (mahe), manipal and renowned physician said here recently, gb virus c or hepatitis g virus, that was discovered about six years ago, allowed aids patients to live much longer by slowing the progress of the disease. he added, two new studies, one at university of iowa, school of medicine with 363 aids patients and another at the hanover medical school in germany with 197 patients, had shown that concurrent infection with gb virus c, in those patients suffering from aids, had reduced the virus by nearly 99 per cent. ``this is also confirmed by invitro (done outside the human body) studies where the peripheral blood of aids patients was studied for their infected mononuclear blood cells. twenty-four hours after being inoculated with gb virus c, the aids patients' mononuclear cells had cleared their virus by 99 per cent'', hegde added. ``researchers knew the gb virus c for a long time but as it was not capable of producing any disease in human beings, it was not studied further. it belongs to the same family of viruses, like hepatitis c, yellow fever and dengue. the present research was taken up by sheer accident'', hegde said. ``when researchers discover more about the exact mechanism of this new virus, there will be many more options for treating aids patients''. hegde however cautioned, doctors and patients must not take the gb virus injection c to prevent aids.

Title: NGO contributes in fight against HIV
article: vadodara: while it is important to recognise the need to disseminate awareness and dispel myths about male semen loss and masturbation, the international symposium held at melbourne early this month has also added that masturbation should not be seen as an alternative to safer and healthier relationships. vadodara-based ngo the deepak charitable trust has worked in 27 villages around the city on the issue of male semen loss concerns and its role in hiv which was highlighted at a special symposium organised at the sixth international conference on aids in melbourne last month. aruna lakhani of dct says the international symposium was on 'males semen loss concerns in the hiv perspective' and was supported by the unaids and the ebert programme on reproductive health population council, ny. following the representation made by participants in the international symposium, experts have now agreed that dissemination of correct information on semen loss concerns, masturbation and nocturnal emissions is essential in all hiv-related communication, but it should not be seen as an alternative to safer and healthier relationships. the experts have agreed that "addressing semen loss concerns and anxieties about masturbation is essential, but should be postponed as an additional safe behaviour for hiv prevention. encouragement should be given to safer sexual practices with the partner". the trust has worked in several villages around vadodara where hiv and other std concerns were studied. the trust recognised the crucial role that men play in the hiv-prevention strategies. the focus of most hiv prevention programmes until recently was on women, and men's attitude and behaviour were overlooked. "the male concern over semen loss through masturbation and myths surrounding it lead men to look toward unsafe sexual encounters. however, dct doctors and volunteers organised group talks with men and created awareness to dispel myths about masturbation and nocturnal emissions. this helped in curbing such unwanted encounters," she said. the deepak trust highlighted its research projects in the international symposium which were followed by discussions and interactions between the participants and speakers.

Title: HIV positive man kills 5 family members
article: rajahmundry, andhra pradesh: in a gruesome incident, a person, who tested hiv positive, hacked to death five of his family members before attempting suicide at peravaram village in west godavari district of andhra pradesh on saturday, police said. fearing disastrous consequences for his family in the event of his death due to aids, peravali seenu (32), a casual labourer working at a factory at dowaleshwaram near here, decided to kill his parents, wife, three-year old son and two sisters, police said. seenu, who had lost his job last week, hacked to death his father muthyalu (60), mother nagaratnam (55), wife parvathi (22), son babu and sister ravana (30), while they were asleep. another sister, who tried to stop him from committing suicide, was injured in the attack. after killing the family members, he rushed out of the house and climbed an electric pole in a bid to electrolocute himself. he, however, slipped and fell down, police said, adding he had been taken into custody.

Title: HIV test centre opens at Kurji hospital
article: patna: the kurji holy family hospital has now a new voluntary counselling and test centre for hiv. opened at the initiative of bihar state aids control society (bsacs), the centre charges only rs 10 instead of the previous rs 200 for the service. bsacs project director c k anil on thursday inaugurated the new centre, the second in the state. speaking on the occasion, he thanked the hospital for taking up the project to offer this appropriate service. speaking about the new venture, sr sophie, the director of community health, said no one is forced to undergo the test. those who volunteer also get pre-test and post-test counselling free. hospital administrator sr joan lauded the efforts of bsacs which has sponsored all the facilities at the centre. the holy family has already launched a massive aids awareness drive and conducted workshops for the local youth groups, women's groups, domestic workers, religious groups and school children. vandana nair, the project coordinator for hiv, said so far in 2001, 30 cases of hiv positive have been detected among patients and blood donors in the hospital as against 31 cases last year. interestingly, 80 per cent of the cases are males and nair thinks that most women of the above infected men , too, may out positive, if tested.

Title: One per cent of pregnant women in Delhi HIV positive
article: new delhi: one per cent of all the pregnant women in the capital are hiv positive with chances that 30 per cent of the children from these births would get infected with the virus, indian academy of pediatrics said on thursday. "of 27 million deliveries every year in india, 1.3 lakhs occur in hiv positive mothers. hence to prevent transmission of hiv from mother to child it is important that all pregnant women be counselled for hiv testing," chairman of the committee dr panna choudhury told reporters here, quoting statistics from a survey by national aids control organisation (naco). research has shown that education on hiv/aids and sex reduces high risk behaviour among adolescents, thereby helping in controlling its speedy spread, he added. he said that now even students and teachers are demanding that education about sex, sexuality and hiv/aids be made a part of school curriculum. to sensitise the pediatricians about childhood and adolescent hiv/aids and to build consensus for care of pediactric aids, indian academy of pediatrics is organising a two-day national conference on pediatrics hiv/aids. experts from who, unicef, naco and unaids and about 300 doctors from india and abroad are expected to participate in the conference which will begin on november three, he said.

Title: State registers drop in HIV-positive cases
article: hyderabad:the state has registered a marginal decrease in the number of hiv-positive cases this year, according to an annual study conducted by the andhra pradesh state aids control society (apsacs). the prevalence of the virus in the annual sample study conducted at 13 centres for antenatal cases has fallen from 2.43 per cent in 1999 to the present figure of two per cent,apsacs additional project director nsr brahmachary told the times of india. the percentage of patients with sexually transmitted diseases (stds), who tested positive, has fallen from 30 per cent (1999) to 28 per cent. the apsacs collects data regarding the number of hiv-positive patients from 13 centres â€” nine for antenatal testing and four for std in the state.the tabulation of such data is done annually between august 1 and october 31 at these centres. the nine antenatal testing centres are located in vizag, guntur, kurnool, hyderabad, warangal, tirupati, khammam, anathapur, and karimnagar. the number of hiv-positive cases reported from voluntary blood donation testing centres has also dropped from 1.17 per cent in 1998 to 0.98 per cent. even though this is an encouraging sign, we cannot say that the spread of the virus has come down, brahmachary said. the first reason is that the study's sample covers only about 3,600 antenatal cases and about 800 std cases in the state. many people still live with the virus ignorant that they might have been infected as a person could lead a perfectly normal life after infection for years. another reason is that many people do not report and prefer to hide the fact that they are hivpositive due to social stigma and fear, the apsacs official said. even though there are an estimated 3.5 lakh hiv-positive people in the state, an exact figure cannot be arrived at as hiv testing is not mandatory according to the testing policy followed. these figures are based on voluntary testing and the annual study. another reason could be the three-antigen test that confirms the presence of the virus is not used at certain places and people are declared hiv-positive without proper testing.

Title: Dist level workshop on HIV/AIDS today
article: bellary: vidyanagar (jindal township) rotary club have hosted a district-level workshop on hiv/aids managements and updates, another unique programme arranged by the club to be inaugurated by veerabhadrachari, secretary, medical education, government of karnataka on sunday at the sports club, vidyanagar. j.k. tandon, joint managing director and ceo, jindal vijayanagar steels limited (jvsl) will be the guest of honour, said r.p. raichur, president, rotary club of vidyanagar. he told reporters on sunday at the indian medical association hall that about 200 doctors from seven revenue districts 3160 comprising of bellary, raichur, koppal, gulbarga, bidar, davanagere and chitradurga of karnataka and four districts - anantapur, kurnool, cuddapah and nellore from andhra pradesh are expected to participated in the workshop. raichur said the deliberations will be on topics like virology, epidemeology, psycho-social aspects of hiv and aids, safe blood transfusion etc and the workshop will conclude with panel discussions, he added. there will also be a street play on the subject and a case study as a part of workshop. sexually transmitted disease (std) clinics have already been set up on jindal project site a month ago, and made available to truck drivers who are considered the most vulnerable - carrying the virus. over 700 trucks are moving from and into the jindal project site and therefore the clinic will serve its purpose. dr sharad m. tanga, assistant professor of surgery, m.r. medical college, gulbarga will give an introductory address about the disease and speaks about epidemeology. dr k.s. satish, wockhardt hospital, bangalore will speak on virology and will also enlighten the medical line of treatment. dr k. lakshman, frcs, bangalore will throw light on universal precautions. sangamitra iyengar, director, samraksha, a non-governmental organisation, will speak on psychological aspects of hiv/aids. dr mrinalini chaturvedi will enlighten on safe blood transfusion. the workshop will end with a panel discussion at 5 pm. power tariff hike condemned: members of karnataka prantha raitha sangha (kprs) strongly condemned the government decision of 13 per cent hike in power tariff. v.s. shivashankar, president of district unit of kprs and u. basavaraj, secretary, heavily came down on the government for its decision terming it as draconian to further weaken the farmers interests. kprs members led by shivashankar and basavaraj organised a one-day token dharna on saturday squatting in front of the deputy commissioners office demanding the administration to supply uninterrupted power supply to farmers pumpsets for a minimum number of hours. they also urged the government to take concrete steps to supply irrigated water to high level canal till december end and pressured to write off all farmers crop loans immediately. they threatened the administration that if the official concerned from kptc would not turn up to listen to their demands, they would organise a rasta-roko at the royal circle in the town. however, acchanna, headquarter assistant, tahasildar, shivappa and executive engineer from kptc arrived at the dharna spot and received the memorandum on behalf of the deputy commissioner, addressed to the state power minister and irrigation minister. the officials assured the agitators that they would convey the demands to the departments concerned.

Title: HIV-at-birth cases rise alarmingly
article: pune: in one area at least it seems that the aids prevention policy that the government has been pursuing, has been a failure. pune has joined neighbouring mumbai and sangli as having the highest number of hivinfected pregnancy cases in india. according to dr sanjay mehendale, deputy director of the pune-based national aids research institute (nari), a government agency, the prevalence of hiv infection among pregnant women has crossed two per cent in the city. while cities like chennai, bangalore and hyderabad have over one per cent of hiv infected pregnant women, the rate is below one per cent in kolkata, delhi and ahmedabad. he cautioned the figures are likely to "increase substantially" in the next couple of years. dr mehendale, who delivered a lecture on 'epidomology of paediatric hiv infection/aids in india' at the 4th national conference on paediatric infectious diseases, organised by the indian academy of paediatrics, pune, said more and more infants are born with the deadly virus. "recent studies have shown that the rate of paediatric hiv infection in india and some african nations is as high as 15-20 per cent compared to two per cent in the developed countries," he said. the reason he says is the higher prevalance of hiv among women of child-bearing age. "even at a presumed rate of 30 per cent vertical transmission, nearly 37,500 infants could acquire hiv infection from their mothers in india every year," he added. he attributed the increasing paediatric hiv cases mostly to lack of screening and other diagnostic facilities of pregnant women.there are also no proper guidelines from national agencies for prevention of mother to child transmission. "there is poor access to antiretroviral medicines and safe breast milk substitutes," he added. "there is a clear need to fame guidelines and get more evidence and data regarding issues like treatment, breast feeding and need for a caesarean delivery," he said. a sad comment on government's ineffectiveness in tackling this deadly disease for well over a decade.

Title: 60 test HIV positive in Kerala this year
article: thiruvananthapuram: as many as 60 people were tested hiv positive in kerala this year, health minister p. sankaran informed the assembly on thursday. replying to questions, the minister said the state aids control society, which is coordinating various aids awareness activities, had tested 1,270 blood samples this year. according to official sources, an estimated 70,000 to 100,000 people in the state were infected with hiv. this estimate was worked out on the basis of periodic surveys conducted among pregnant women in the state. there were 869 reported aids patients in the state, but the actual number would be much higher, the sources added.

Title: No guidelines for treatment of HIV-infected women
article: pune: despite all the money and attention lavished on aids 'awareness' and control programmes, there is no standard guideline for treatment of pregnant women infected with hiv. this, despite the fact that pune,along with mumbai and sangli have, together, the highest number of hiv-infected pregnancies in the country. doctors are thus awaiting results of a feasibility study being conducted at the national aids control organisation (naco) on how to reduce the chances of viral transmission from the infected mother to her baby. findings of the study, conducted at 11 centres across the country, including the sassoon hospital here and two centres in mumbai, are expected to be out soon. the study is examining the effects of a prescribed anti-retro viral drug on infected women.while most city hospitals prescribe zidoviudin or nevirapine, some others, for instance the armed forces medical college, administer lamivudin to hiv-infected pregnant women. naco, which earlier recommended zidoviudin for hiv-infected pregnant woman, later switched to nevirapine, which was cheaper. ratna yashwante of nari said zidoviudin used to be given twice a day for a month from the beginning of the 36th week of pregnancy.the total cost of this therapy proved to be too costly for patients in the low income group as a single tablet costs rs 60, she said. nevirapine, on the other hand, is given only once, at the onset of labour pains. aids specialist dr sanjay pujari, who is equally anxious about the findings of the study, said there is utter confusion amongst doctors, particularly in government-run hospitals about the correct treatment since there are no standard guidelines. some countries have made it mandatory for doctors to administer a common anti-retroval drug to patients, he said. the prevalence of hiv infection among pregnant women in the city has crossed two per cent, he says, due mainly to lack of screening and diagnostic facilities for pregnant women, compounded by poor access to retro-viral drugs and breast milk substitutes. it makes matters worse when there is no standard procedure laid down for handling mother-to-child transmission. dr kapila bharucha, head of the obstetrics and gynaecology department, sassoon hospital, also calls for a common set of guidelines in the present context of mother-tochild transmission of the killer virus, which has assumed dangerous proportions. dr sanjay mehendale, deputy director, nari, said studies have been recently carried out in thailand and abidjan (africa) by adminstering doses of zidoviudin, and it showed 50 and 37 per cent reduction in the rate of transmission respectively from the infected mother to the child. another study with nevirapine was conducted at uganda where the risk of transmitting the disease from the mother to baby was reduced by 47 per cent. he said the rate of paediatric hiv infection in india, along with some african nations, is as high as 15-20 per cent, compared to two per cent in the developed countries.

Title: In India, drug price tip of HIV iceberg
article: new delhi: when krishna rao went to a hospital in visakhapatnam with symptoms of hiv, the doctor handed him a prescription for three medicines, one of which was an anti-retroviral drug. the total cost of medicines for a month was rs 1,943. krishna rao, who earns rs 2,000 a month as a farm labourer, sold his belongings to buy the medicines, believing they would cure him. little did he realise that taking the drug for a month and stopping abruptly would only increase his problems. he also did not know that a combination of anti-retrovirals needs to be taken to allow the drugs to prolong life. even as a concerted campaign is launched on world aids day on saturday for affordable drugs, ensuring proper therapy still remains way down on the list of health priorities. a majority of the 3.9 million living with the virus in india continue to die early of hiv not only because anti-retrovirals are unaffordable but also because health professionals are not adequately trained, wrong combinations of drugs are prescribed, and monitoring of these highly toxic drugs is inadequate. as a result, hiv at 20 may have become a manageable, chronic disease with the help of these drugs, but only for those who also have access to a proper health infrastructure and effective monitoring system. as purnima madhivanan at yrg care points out: ''it seems to be common to give two drugs called azt and d4t together. they don't work if they are given together because of their antagonistic effects on each other. even an anaesthetist was on these drugs for a long time.'' as the therapy works by reducing the load of hiv in the body so that the damage to the immune system is minimised, the viral load needs to be checked from time to time. but while the therapy costs about rs 2,000 a month, a single test to determine the hiv load in the body costs rs 6,000. compliance to the complicated regimen of drugs is necessary to avoid drug resistance. president of the international aids society stefano vella has already stated that resistant strains have started emerging all over, including in mumbai and chennai, as a result of the indiscriminate use of the therapy.

Title: IndoFrench research project study on HIV infection
article: pune: an indofrench research team is monitoring the high rate of mothertochild hiv transmission, with the ultimate aim of trying to minimise the large and growing numbers of mothertochild hiv transmissions in the country. the national aids research institute (nari), in collaboration with parisbased pasteur institute, embarked on the project on march 8 this year, at the pune municipal corporation (pmc)run kamala nehru hospital. the project assumes special significance in light of the fact that the city recently attained the dubious distinction of having one of the highest mothertochild hiv transmissions in the country. in a shocking discovery, a recent report stated that the rate of such transmission of the disease is as high as 35 per cent in the country. although it's early days yet, researchers have realised that babies can be infected many days after birth too. "so far, we have examined 40 hivinfected pregnancy cases. none of the 19 babies was born with the virus," a source said, but adds that the babies are at risk of developing the virus till they are 18 months old. "the babies are prone to the infection as long as they are breastfed," the source said. the project is aimed at studying infections at all the three stages: antinatal; during delivery; and after delivery when the child is breastfed. samples of placenta and breast milk of the infected mothers are being sent to the nari laboratory to study the pattern of the virus as well as the mode of transmission to the baby. dr madhuri thakkar from nari, who has undergone six months of specialised training under the french experts, will be testing the samples. several factors can influence maternal transmission of hiv in infants: an infection in the uterus, exposure to maternal blood or the presence of the virus in the mucosa of the birth canal during labour and delivery, and breast feeding are all possible infections routes. newborns who are part of the project take the confirmatory polymerase chain reaction (pcr) test to determine whether they have the virus, whereas the enzymelink immuno sorbent assay (elisa) test is conducted on infected mothers. in some cases, the women take a cd4/cd8 test which gives an exact clue to the mode of transmission and the lifespan of the infected person. all tests are administered free of cost at the nari laboratory as part of the project. dr ramesh s. paranjape, officer incharge, nari, said the project is aimed at understanding the virological or immunological factors that may influence mothertochild transmission. dr sanjay mehendale, deputy director at nari said considering the large numbers of mothertochild transmissions in the country, it is of utmost importance to explore the extent to which biomedical maternal factors like viral load, nutritional status, breast milk or placenta can influence the disease in newborns. dr raman gangakherkar, who heads the project, was unavailable to comment.

Title: Entire families in HIV trap
article: chandigarh: the death of two hiv-positive children in the city, during the year, foreshadows the looming tragedy of families being helplessly wiped out by the fatal virus. six fresh aids cases were reported from the city this year, taking the number to 19.with more and more people volunteering for the hiv test, the real magnitude of the problem is being realised. an isolation room in pgi's advanced paediatric centre is almost constantly occupied by an hivpositive child. the story of twoyear-old ashish is no different from that of many other children who occupied the room before him. with both young parents suspected hiv-positive, one child already dead, the other suffering from aids and another one on its way, the fatal virus is a death knell for the entire family. ashish has been admitted to apc for the past almost a month with severe brain damage. for his father, 30-year-old sushil sharma (name changed) and mother26-year-old geeta (name changed) the news of the family being hiv-positive is a bolt from the blue. the family learnt of their medical status three weeks ago, when they admitted their son to pgi.''twice in the past has he been given his parents' blood. both times, the blood sample had passed elisa test. but only when we reached pgi were we told that the blood is hiv positive. subsequently, our blood has also been screened and is suspected positive,'' said ashish's father, a science teacher in shimla. his wife, a staff nurse at a government hospital in shimla, has been in a stupor ever since the tragic news was broken to her. ''sleep and food are the last things on our mind.when our first child died of bronchitis, we never thought he could be hiv-positive. the baby, who has not yet entered the world, is also doomed,'' he says breaking down. ''nobody thinks even for a single moment that they could be hiv positive,'' laments a doctor. the number of people proving hivpositive is on the rise. in 1998, 6,003 people were screened and 279 were found hiv positive. in 1999, although only 4,537 were screened, 326 were found positive, while in 2000, 4,620 were screened and 346 found positive. in 2001, 4,153 people had been screened till october 31 and 364 yielded positive results. the tragedy striking families is only becoming grimmer as the maximum number of people falling prey to the disease, primarily through sexual transmission, are in the most productive years of their lives, that is, 30 to 44 years of age.

Title: HIV/AIDS cases up in Delhi
article: new delhi: the number of hiv/aids cases in the capital have gone up from 45 in 1993 to 624 this year, a study has said holding lack of awareness largely responsible for it. people had incomplete information regarding the disease and several myths, such as transmission of hiv through mosquito bite, sharing clothes and kissing, prevailed, the report, "hiv/aids communication in delhi", brought out by the centre for media studies and released here today said. the report recommended interactive communication since the mass media had already done the ground work on creating awareness and said that private channels should be encouraged to take up messages related to hiv/aids. iec (information, education and communication) should be made more simple and pictorial and mass awareness should be created in schools and colleges, it said. the report said that the spot on aids which features shabana azmi has high viewership but people pay greater attention to her than the message sought to be conveyed. joint director (iec), national aids control organisation (naco), neelam kapoor, said a school aids education programme, being started with the help of unesco and unicef, would cover all schools in the capital in next five years in a phased manner. speaking on the occassion, controller of programmes, doordarshan (dd), usha bhasin, said to create awarness on aids, dd had initiated a three-way project with naco and bbc world service trust.

Title: 1.7% of pregnant women found HIV positive
article: new delhi: a recent survey conducted by national aids control organisation (naco) in the major hiv infested states in the country have found 1.7 per cent of pregnant women to be hiv positive, a member of parliament said on saturday. "the survey was conducted in major hiv infected states of maharashtra, tamil nadu, karnataka, andhra pradesh and manipur. in all 1,03,681 women in 11 medical colleges/ hospitals were either screened or blood tested for hiv," a release quoting the mp, kirit somaiya, said on saturday. out of the total affected pregnant woman, 1,724 or 1.7 per cent of them were found to be hiv positive, he said, adding "this is a very dangerous signal." he said in maharashtra, particularly, mumbai, pune and sangli, were the most dangerous and vulnerable areas as per the survey, the release said adding 3.51 per cent of the women were found hiv positive in mumbai alone while pune and sangli accounted for 4.2 per cent. somaiya said the socio-economic impact of the problem of hiv/aids would be disastrous and appealed to the various social, business and religious leaders to study and understand the problems arising out of the dreaded disease, it said. "this is the stage which african cities like nairobi faced during the early nineties. if proper awareness and care is not taken, in the next five to ten years, mumbai will become another african city from the viewpoint of hiv/aids," the release quoting him said.

Title: Experts debate HIV dynamics
article: lucknow: a symposium on 'dynamics of hiv and aids', a major threat to the policy planners and present environment, was held at sgpgi here on monday. the symposium was organised under the 19th annual conference of indian society for medical statistics. prof madhulekha bhattacharya, who is an active consultant to national aids control organisation (naco) chaired the symposium. prof ak sharma dwelt on issues related to present reported prevalence of hiv and high risk groups like sex workers and social stigma attached to this problem. he stressed the need of considering social values attached to the problem suffering from these problems, collecting region specific levels and trends of the problem and looking into its behavioural aspects. dr raj mani pandey said that retaining moral values and knowing healthy behaviour might go a long way to prevent these problems. dr (ms) m. thomas discussed some models and their applications in projection of hiv/aids in india, jointly worked out with prof arvind pandey, director, institute of research in medical statistics, new delhi. prof bhattacharya summarised and highlighted the issues related to spread of hiv/aids through sexuality. she reported detailed methodology followed under naco programme and informed that high risk cases were reported from goa, andhra pradesh, karnataka, maharashtra, nagaland and tamil nadu. she said that except kerala, almost all states in the south fall under high prevalence. up however falls under low prevalence, she said. a session on clinical epidemiology was organised which discussed various articles dealing with trend and determinants of various health problems like cancer, acute myocardial infarction, anaemia etc

Title: Growing numbers of HIV-positive women
article: pune: jamuna, 20 years old and recently married, lost her husband a few days ago. he died of aids and, subsequently, tests showed that he had passed on the deadly hiv-virus to jamuna. she is now in a hospital in chinchwad, shunned by her in-laws, and packed off with rs 2,000 by her own parents. "what is my fault?" she asks in pain. and fear. she has no idea who she should turn to for help and whether her future is to lie shackled to a hospital bed. the plight of 25-year-old shevanti, wife of a truck driver, is no better. her husband died six months ago after contracting the disease. but not before transmitting it to her. she does not blame her husband, though, and faces her bleak future with fortitude though she has no support from friends and family and knows her life will probably end like her husband's did. vimal naidu, the second wife of a construction labour is looking after her husband who is in the last stages of aids at a hospital in pimpri. she is aware that her elder sister, the first wife of her husband, died of aids and she might too. "what can i do, ab to sab uparwale ke haath me hain" (it's now all in the hands of god). wives who are hiv-positive, having usually caught the virus from their husbands, suffer worse than men because though they invariably support their menfolk, there is no one to support or look after them. "they are still at the receiving end," says dr suhas mate, pimpri chinchwad municipal corporation's (pcmc) aids control division in-charge. it is the worst sort of injustice, but in the industrial township of pimpri-chinchwad, with its migrant population, it is not uncommon. dr mate says 2.6 per cent of pregnant women coming to pcmc hospitals are hiv-positive. he admits this is "a significant percentage". the pcmc's talera hospital is the main aids treatment centre and has seen an increase in the number of patients in the last eight years. twenty-nine per cent of hiv/aids cases that come in are women, of which 26 per cent are housewives. traditional indian attitudes to men and marriage are responsible for this outrageous situation where women are the worst victims of a disease that was foisted on them - sometimes probably knowingly. in traditional indian society, a wife has little say in sexual activity. "she cannot deny her husband sex even if she knows he is hiv-positive," dr mate says. then, the husband is often treated at a sophisticated private hospital while the wife is referred to a government hospital. "the discrimination between men and women is highly visible even in such a pathetic situation," dr mate points out. while the woman invariably nurses her ailing husband, and his family usually rallies around, she gets no such care or sympathy, being ostracised by the family. dr mate says there is an urgent need to educate grown up girls and married women from the economically disadvantaged groups about hiv/aids. but it is society at large, and men in particular, who really need to be educated. the response of the authorities needs to be much more aggressive and procative than it is. for example, on december 1, which was observed as world aids day, the pcmc sponsored a poster and rangawali exhibition among college students. perhaps more useful was an essay competition for ninth and tenth standard students in which 500 students took part and many of them wrote about their own first-hand experiences of hiv/aids in their family environment. however to make a real difference in both the figures and the plight of women, a great deal more deeds to be done in practical terms. picture.. pcmc has organised a poster and rangawali exhibition on aids in kaladalan, at santa tuaram commercial complex, nigdi by pcmc. a rangawali creations are being made by rohini modak and roopali jitkar from abhinav kala vidyalya.

Title: HIV testing centres to be set at PHCs
article: hyderabad:the state government proposes to set up hiv testing centres at the primary health centres and anti-natal counselling centres in all the assembly constituencies, according to chief minister n chandrababu naidu. intervening in a discussion under rule 304 on aids, naidu urged the mlas and religious leaders to extend a helping hand to the government in containing the menace. he said the government has decided to further streamline the blood banks and sensitise local bodies to pay special attention to create awareness among the villagers. government would also introduce sex education in the curriculum at the intermediate level, he added. naidu appealed to the religious and political leaders to speak about the need to control aids at the end of every programme they participate in.

Title: Naco plan to combat HIV in Bihar from April
article: patna: encouraged by the feasibility study of administering short-term azt (ziduvudine) drug to hiv-infected pregnant mothers to prevent mother-to-child transmission (pmtct) of the disease in five states of the country, the national aids control organisation (naco) and the centre have decided to develop it into a programme for implementation across the country. the feasibility study of the azt intervention was conducted among pregnant women at 11 institutions located in five states - maharashtra, tamilnadu, andhra pradesh, karnataka and manipur. these states have reported a high prevalence of hiv infection during annual sentinel exercise. it was conducted by the naco and union health ministry in collaboration with the unicef between april 2000 and july 2001. three of these institutions were in mumbai. although 751 hiv-infected women had accepted azt intervention in the feasibility study, only 658 of them were actually followed. the azt intervention among 658 women helped in averting mtct of the virus among 151 babies. it brought down the mtct of hiv from 33 per cent (mumbai study) to 8.4 per cent at birth and 10.1 per cent at the age of two months. mtct constitutes two per cent of the total hiv/aids cases. the trial of azt was conducted in the usa in 1993, where hiv-infected pregnant women, between 14 to 34 weeks of gestation, were given azt orally till the time of delivery. they also received intravenous azt during labour. subsequently, the newborn received azt for six weeks. the transmission was reduced to 7.9 per cent from 27.2 per cent among the azt group. the trial was prematurely stopped due to significant reduction in transmission efficiency. the only side effect reported was mild transient anaemia among their children, which led to recommendation for prophylactic use of azt among hiv-infected women and the protocol was approved for use in the us as a public health policy. a recent study conducted in thailand reported 50 per cent reduction in the mtct rate. in this study, azt was orally administered after 36 weeks of gestation to women in the dose of 300 mg twice a day and 300 mg every three hours during delivery. though the overall prevalence of hiv infection in general population was alarming in the country, there were indications of rising trend of infection among pregnant women in the high-prevalence states posing a threat to child survival, necessitating steps towards control and prevention of the mtct, the study report said. the total number of hiv infections in the country is second highest in the world because of its large population. the thailand study involving short course azt regimen indicated that it can be successful in resource limited settings, if effectively implemented. the bihar state aids control society will launch the azt intervention programme from april, according to its project director c k anil. he said that the azt will reach here in march.

Date: OUT OF COURT/SOLI J SORABJEE,Jan 5, 2002, 23:42 IST
Title: Information, discrimination of HIV-positive and the Euro
article: freedom of information legislation by the centre has not yet been enacted. however, our supreme court had declared way back in 1981 that the right to know and the right to information are implicit in the freedom of speech guaranteed in our constitution. of late, the right to information has been exercised vigorously, at times extravagantly. bright young tv anchors burning with enthusiasm seek wide-ranging information from our ministers regarding our country's future plans of action. will these actions be overt or covert? will the loc be crossed? are the options restricted to limited military strikes against terrorist camps or something more? where are the terrorist camps located and when will they be attacked? they were rightly reminded by ex-army chief malik of the utter inappropriateness of such questions. next, we witness the bizarre spectacle of the police, who have in their custody one of the main suspects, revealing their plans about the places he will be taken to in kashmir and elsewhere, the persons who will be interrogated thereafter and so on. people of india can live with temporary withholding of information which can only alert inimical forces. and then we have dear george in his characteristic frank and forthright manner, enlightening us and the world that as things stand, we are vulnerable in rajasthan as it is a long march for us. logistics are a problem. pakistan can just drive into the area''. perhaps, there is some method in this information mania, which escapes my naive mind. i am all for freedom of information but do believe that there are occasions when silence is not merely an option; it is a compulsion. --- hoffman applied for employment in south african airways as a cabin attendant. he was found suitable but was refused employment on the sole ground that his blood test showed that he was hiv-positive. the action of the airline, which is a state instrumentality, was challenged as discriminatory before the south african constitutional court. the airlines conceded on the basis of its own medical evidence that an asymptomatic hiv-positive person could competently perform the work of a cabin attendant but relied on legitimate commercial considerations and practice of other airlines to justify its action. the constitutional court ruled that the fact that some people who were hiv-positive might, under certain circumstances, be unsuitable for employment as cabin attendants did not justify their blanket exclusion. the court observed that persons living with hiv constituted a vulnerable minority and were victims of intense and extensive social prejudice. treatment of people who were hiv-positive had to be based on reasoned and medically sound judgments and not by ill-informed public perception of persons with hiv. the impact of discrimination on them was devastating in the context of employment since it denied them the right to earn a living. the court held that although legitimate commercial requirements were as important consideration stereotyping and prejudice could not be allowed to creep in under the guise of commercial interest. it ruled that reliance on practice of other airlines who were not subject to the discipline of the bill of rights was misplaced. in the unanimous opinion of the court hiv-positive persons had to be treated with compassion and understanding and could not be condemned to economic death by the denial of equal opportunity in employment, which in the instant case constituted unfair discrimination. the court struck down the action of the airlines and directed it to employ hoffman as a cabin attendant. a path breaking and compassionate judgment indeed. --- the year 2002 will be historic for the incredible monetary revolution brought about by the euro. three hundred million people in 12 countries have switched to euro currency and 15 billion notes are estimated to have changed hands. the united kingdom, along with denmark and sweden, is not yet in the euro zone. popular opinion in the uk is not generally overwhelmingly favourable to the euro. the tories think euro will affect the country's sovereignty, the liberals want it as soon possible. france and germany have hailed it as the dawn of a new era''. to the italian prime minister it is a time of pure joy''. this sentiment is endorsed by italy's red light ladies in rome, who believe that the euro is good for their time-honoured trade. indeed, one of them has offered to give a discount to her customers. what further proof is needed of the euro's attraction and versatility.

Title: New kit makes HIV test much easier
article: lucknow: now hiv test is possible within minutes without having the intricacies involved in the laboratory testing. the answer is a new hiv neva-aids kit developed by prof vk chaudhary, university of delhi, which could perform the test in two minutes by using a drop of blood instead of using plasma and serum. prof chaudhary exhibited his neva (naked eye visible agglutation test) in the plenary session on ''diagnostic techniques of today and tomorrow'' on sunday. the concept of the test is based on the fusion of blood cells and antibodies. the blood drop is put on the slide and if agglutination takes place then it is confirmed that the sample is hiv positive. an antigen of rbc antibody gene is fused with the hiv antigen gene and the 'resultant' fused gene is expressed in e-coli bacteria, which forms a protein. this protein is then used for creating the reagent for the kit. prof chaudhary has already filed for the patent of the kit. it took five years of research to develop this 'genetically engineered' technique, which is in no way inferior to the normal serum test for hiv, aids, he said. the kit will be commercially launched in jaipur later this month in collaboration with a pharmaceutical company. a pack of 50 kits costs roughly around rs 2500, he said. dna finger printing expert, director ccmb hyderabad, said that scientists are developing dna computer and dna chip technology, which will be smaller and faster and would offer high accuracy. dna is quite stable and its patterns remain the same irrespective of from where it is isolated because a person takes birth and dies with the same dna, he said. while delivering his lecture on 'a diagnostic technique for molecules to human and beyond', prof cl khetarpal, sgpgims, said that nuclear magnetic resonance, magnetic resonance imaging and spectroscopy had developed into valuable diagnostic tools. he said that the technique was a success because it involved a low energy radiation on molecular structure. the use of low energy made it non invasive. it also helps to understand not only the molecular structure and the diseases in human beings but also to understand the metabolic and other changes in the body.

Title: Nursing homes violating HIV test norms
article: hyderabad: a number of people in the city and the state are being confirmed as hiv positive by diagnostic centres and certain private nursing homes without following proper testing procedures, according to the national testing policy (ntp). according to dr m v ramana rao, director in charge of blood safety at the andhra pradesh state aids control society (apsacs), the confirmation reports issued by these centres and clinics are based on a single eliza, rapid or simple (ers) test that confirms hiv positive result only upto 23 per cent. for a person to be confirmed as hiv positive, a set of three eliza or rapid or simple tests or a combination with three different antigens have to be done. these types of tests confirm hiv positivity up to 99 per cent. a western blot test, which costs over rs 1,500, can also confirm a hiv positive result. dr ramana rao said a single eliza test is carried out only at blood banks on donors, along with hepatitis-b, hepatitis-c, malaria and the venereal disease research laboratory (vdrl) test, after which blood units are accepted or discarded based on the results. another test for hiv is carried out during the annual sentinel survey of apsacs and is called the surveillance test or the two ers test in which hiv positivity is confirmed up to 95 per cent.this test is used to estimate the number of people who are likely to be hiv positive in a given population. the three ers test is a confirmatory test and can be done only after written consent is obtained from the person, pre-test and posttest counselling is done and confidentiality of the result is maintained. however, according to dr ramana rao diagnostic labs and certain private nursing homes do the three ers test without getting written consent, without pre-test and post-test counselling.they also do not maintain confidentiality. this is a violation of the national testing policy under the national aids control organisation (naco) guidelines,'' he said. apscas conducts the three ers test at the 26 voluntary counselling and testing centres in the state at rs 10 per test. at other centres, the test costs a minimum of rs 600. the biggest worry is that many people think they are hiv positive after undergoing the single ers test that is issued by many clinics and diagnostic clinics, when actually they may not be positive, ramana rao said. this causes unnecessary trauma and tension.

Title: Drug reduces HIV transmission: Report
article: patna: a feasibility study of short-term azt (ziduvudin) drug intervention in the case of hiv-infected mothers to prevent mother-to-child transmission of the disease has clearly brought out that the union government should have a firm policy on infant-feeding practices of such mothers. the study was conducted under the joint aegis of the national aids control organisation and unicef. the study report said the policy should be framed keeping in view the high risk of mortality associated with replacement feeding under unhygienic conditions and poverty situations vis-a-vis risk of hiv transmission through breast feeding by infected mothers. the report said it can be concluded that exclusive breast feeding for the first four months of life, gradual weaning between fourth and sixth months and termination by the end of sixth month would be the best possible option. the report is based on the result of short-term azt intervention in the case of 658 hiv-infected women from april 2000 to july 2001. the report claimed that azt intervention brought down the mother-to-child transmission of hiv from 33 per cent to 8.4 per cent. the report maintained that 40.4 per cent husbands reportedly had multiple sex partners while only 6.2 per cent wives had similar case history. women despite the knowledge of their husbands having multiple sex partners were unable to protect themselves due to low level of empowerment. about 34.4 per cent husbands took alcohol while among the wives only 4 per cent were addicted to it. so far as smoking was concerned, 33 per cent husbands were addicted to it while among the wives only 3 per cent smoked. the bihar aids control society (bacs) will hold a two-day conference starting on january 28 at every district headquarters to create awareness among the functionaries of three-tier panchayati raj bodies about aids and hiv. bacs project director c k anil said so far 92 confirmed aids and 1,200 hiv cases have been detected in bihar. in darbhanga, he said, 500 persons have tested hiv positive of which 80 per cent have the history of working as migrant labourers in mumbai.

Title: Research on HIV will help treat other viral infections too: Expert
article: vadodara: the money spent on hiv research comes with a large spin-off. its research focuses on viral infections, and therefore drugs which are developed for hiv are now helping understand various other types of viral infections such as hepatitis b and common cold, said dr jeff naddler here. dr naddler is professor infectious diseases department at university of south florida and was one of the pioneer investigators who identified the aids epidemic in 1981 in new york. he is currently working on 16 types of clinical trials of hiv drugs. he is in city as a part of the chart (centre for health and hiv/ aids research and training) india project undertaken by the usf in association with the indu health research foundation trust ihrf and the shaktikrupa charitable trust motafofalia sinor. "hiv is a disease related to the immune system. as it is a viral infection, scientists have discovered that drugs effective against hiv can be effective against hepatitis b. in some cases, they could be better than the existing drugs for hepatitis b as they would be more effective, less toxic and cheaper," he said. according to dr naddler, the government of india and drug companies here should direct more resources into the research on hiv. "at present, many effective and cheaper drugs for hiv are available in india, but more research on newer drugs is required," he said. according to him, india should have its own research on hiv as there are different types of hiv prevalent in different regions. "in the us, hiv type 1 and subtype b is more common. our researchers are working with the type of hiv prevalent there, and though research aims to find a universal solution to hiv we need special research in communities where different types of hiv occur. in india, hiv of type i and type ii are common and subtype c is also observed," he said. there is a need to find different types of drugs with fewer side effects and drugs that would be useful to root out the virus. as of now, no such drug is found, but many retro viral therapies have been able to control hiv, and patients detected early and are on drug therapy live with hiv for more than 25 years. "we can improve the quality of life of an hiv patient, and it is not a death sentence," he said. according to dr naddler, the areas of hiv research the world currently focuses on is improved drug treatment, development of a vaccine to prevent further spread of the disease and education in public health research. "research also includes education in public health as changing human behaviour towards unprotected sex can go a long way in control of infections. if more countries invest in research on hiv, it would be cost-effective as the spin-offs are quite high. it provides newer drugs for other viral infections. control of hiv is important as on an average this disease affects the population that is the most productive in the economy," he said. according to dr vijay shah of ihrf, ongoing research amongst doctors and blood banks conducted in vadodara as part of the chart project has revealed that many doctors were unaware about hiv and misconceptions persist. blood banks screen blood of healthy donors, but those whose blood is found to be hiv positive are not informed and they spread the disease. "we therefore plan to approach the government regarding this policy. as a part of the chart project, we organised a talk on new drugs and treatment of hiv on sunday." dr naddler interacted with physicians, gynaecologists, skin and vd specialists and others specialists of vadodara about hiv prevalence in the city. he also discussed the new drugs and hiv treatment options that are available in other countries and how these could be used more effectively here.

Title: The New Cupid: No-HIV certificate for couples
article: the times of india

Title: HIV-positive children get short shrift
article: hyderabad: innocent victims of the dreaded hiv, especially orphans who acquire the disease from their parents (vertical transmission from mother to child), are facing an uphill task in the battle against the scourge. the state does not have a holistic child-oriented programme and lacks hiv-positive child care centres. a one-week old hiv-positive baby was found on the roadside in nalgonda district and was handed over to the freedom foundation's hiv centre by the andhra pradesh state aids control society (apsacs) last week. abandoned by her parents, she is one of an estimated 30,000 babies falling prey to the virus every year. the mother of a month-old baby was thrown out of her village in karimnagar by the village sarpanch and her family when the child tested positive at a government health centre. the baby was brought to us in a malnourished state as breast feeding is not advisable and the mother could not afford quality baby food, freedom foundation counsellor madhusudan reddy said. one-year-old deepak, who was deserted in a hospital, and threeyear-old raju and his mother, who have no place to go due to poverty, are just a few of the 22 children who have been under the care of the centre. as of now we are in good hands, but i do not know what the future holds for my child, raju's mother said. the apsacs in association with unicef launched a programme to prevent vertical transmission of the virus with the administration of the nevarapine drug last month. even we are looking at starting this drug therapy, freedom foundation executive trustee karl sequeira said. however, this policy needs a holistic approach as it only reduces the chances of transmission of the virus, but does not look at child care after the inevitable death of the hiv-positive parents, he said. moreover, there are no child care centres in the state nor in the country that will ensure that an hiv-positive child can live a normal life by providing the child with a healthy environment, facilities to play and education.once the child's parents succumb to the virus, there is no one to look after the child due to social stigma, he said. even, if a mother wants to give the child a nutritious diet, baby food is expensive. moreover, most people do not sterilise feeding bottles, which can lead to infection by opportunistic diseases.the highly active anti-retroviral therapy (haart), that has proved to be effective even when administered to children, cannot be given due to lack of funds with the government, freedom foundation centre in-charge dr troy cunningham said. in the state, two per cent of the ante-natal cases tested positive during the sentinel survey conducted by apsacs and an estimated 16 lakh deliveries take place every year.

Title: Workshop on HIV held
article: bangalore: city-based asha foundation in collaboration with british council, chennai and university of madras conducted a workshop on hiv on thursday. justice m. saldanha expressed concern regarding the increase in the number of persons affected with hiv and the resultant ostracisation of patients in hospitals. he also expressed concern about the need to sensitise the staff regarding this disease. many doctors gathered from various countries and spoke about the infection, environment, global epidemiology and counselling involved with hiv disease including the mentally challenged who also suffer from this disease.

Title: False HIV report sparks off protests in Bellary
