article: bellary: an alleged false report by a diagnostic centre declaring a person hiv positive, resulting in his death, sparked off protests here on friday. it all started after bangle siddappa was declared hiv positive by the diagnostic centre. subsequent tests of his blood sample in other labs showed negative. but the damage was done. he could not stand the tension, and died on feb 7. after his blood was tested in other medical centres including speciality ranbaxy limited lab in mumbai, it was found he tested negative each time, members of the district pragathipara sanghatane vedike said here. the gandhinagar police arrested over 100 activists as a preventive measure. the arrests were made after members of the vedike laid seige to the diagnostic centre and tried to lock it up. mundaragi nagaraj, bangle mallikarjuna, a.manaiah, aleswar gowd, shivji inglia and v.s. shivashankar led the protest. other members from various organisations including the dalit sangharsha samiti (dss), bahujana samaj party and the cpm also staged a protest rally against the diagnostic centre. a rally protesting against the doctors working in government hospitals and the visiting doctors in some of the private medical consultancy units and nursing homes in the district was also staged. other organisations under the bellary district pragathipara sanghatane vedike banner organised protest rallies and staged a dharna against the diagnostic centre. on friday, members of the vedike demanded action against such irresponsible medical units. mundaragi nagaraj, a.manaiah, shivaji inglia and shivashankar also spoke. as for the diagnostic centre, all that it did was close shop. that too, for a day. the vedike members said it was done so that they could avoid confrontation with the activists.

Title: HIV/AIDS high on agenda on Manipur parties
article: imphal: politicians in manipur have a new constituency. hiv-infected and aids patients and high risk groups like drug users and sex workers. and every political party has put hiv/aids awareness and control on their "priority lists" and in their manifestos. the lead, however, was taken by the newly formed democratic peoples party (drp), a child of the post-ceasefire violence that rocked manipur in june. the dpp that has refused entry to anyone who has won elections in the past has put hiv and aids prevention as one of their focus areas. y.khemchand, the general secretary of the party, said, "it's a major bomb that may do more damage than any militants. blood samples given by blood donors to the blood banks are increasingly found to contain hiv, the number of cases has shot up and funds are lacking." the dpp, in its manifesto, promises maximum autonomy to the manipur aids control society, subsidising medicines and allotting more funds to ngos working in the sector. in fact, the dpp has invited leading ngos like manipur network of positives. even parties like the samta party and the bjp have made token mentions and say when asked that the "matter is serious". "even such lip service was missing earlier. now no party can ignore this problem," says leading human rights activist yambem laba. a quick look at the manifestos of the parties. samta party - "we will do all that is required for aids and hiv control," congress - "top priority will be given to aids prevention and control," manipur peoples party - "a definite timeframe will be set to tackle the hiv, aids problem," bjp - "we'll recast the aids and drugs programme to make it more efficient." statistics are alarming. by december 2001, 12,817 out of 82,399 samples tested were found hiv positive. of this, 1033 have full blown aids. the number of confirmed deaths due to aids is officially 193. but this is only official. and there is nothing official about the aids in manipur. from the moreh border adjoining myanmar drugs are smuggled in. the latest and gruesome technique is to stuff packets of heroine down the throats of pigs, cows and dogs and bring them to imphal. here, the animals are slaughtered and the drug packets taken out of their bodies. from sex workers to drug users, hiv has entered homes of even comman man. and it makes good political sense to address this. but even now the problem has not been addressed systematically. amarjit langlam is a young man in his early thirties. he sits in the office of the manipur network of positives (mnp+), an organization of hiv positives started in 1997. a drug user, he got himself tested in 1999 and discovered he was hiv positive. he then joined the mnp+. "i hope to live for sometime now, but we need to save lives on a war footing. mnp+ is working towards awareness and the use of drugs to control the virus. we feel that hiv positive people can live. our secretary was tested positive ten years ago. and he is still healthy. but political parties need to take us into confidence before chalking out any aids programme," langlam said. "we need drugs at no cost or at subsidised rates. hospitals don't have the necessary testing equipment," he added. the wining party or coalition has to move from its manifesto to real time management of aids and hiv. if the problem grows, tacking militancy would seem like a teddy bears picnic in comparison to the aids bomb.

Title: HIV test for Rs 10 only
article: hyderabad: rupees 10 is all it costs to get a three elisa test done in andhra pradesh for a confirmation of hiv positivity or negativity at the 26 voluntary counselling and testing centres (vctc) set up by the ap state aids control society. the three elisa test confirms hiv positivity upto 99 per cent. private hospitals and diagnostic clinics in the state however, charge between rs 400 and rs 600 for the same. the vctcs are located in the 10 government medical colleges and the district hospitals where no government medical college is present, apscas additional project director nsr brahmachary said. all the 23 districts in the state are covered by the vctcs, brahmachary said. he said, many people are not aware of this facility in the state and continue going to private hospitals and diagnostic centres.

Title: HIV test now only costs Rs 10
article: hyderabad: rupees 10 is all it costs to get a 3 elisa rapid simple (3ers) test done in andhra pradesh for a sure confirmation for hiv positivity or negativity at the 26 voluntary counselling and testing centres (vctc) set up by the andhra pradesh state aids control society (apsacs). the 3 ers test, using three antigens, confirms hiv positivity upto 99 per cent. incidentally this test costs anything between rs 400 and rs 600 in private hospitals and diagnostic clinics in the state. the vctcs are located in the ten government medical colleges in the state and district hospitals where a government medical college is not present, apscas additional project director n s r brahmachary said. the ten government medical colleges where the test can be done are the colleges located at visakhapatnam, kakinada, kurnool, guntur, tirupati, warangal, anantapur, vijayawada and gandhi and osmania medical colleges in hyderabad. all the 23 districts in the state are covered by the vctcs, brahmachary said. he said many people are not aware of this facility in the state and continue to go to private hospitals and diagnostic centres to get the test done, which a majority of the population cannot afford. the test done at the vctcs set up by the apscas includes pre-test and post-test counselling, written consent from the person who wants the test done. the centres maintain the confidentiality of the person who is hiv positive after he is issued a test result. this is mandatory under the national testing policy of the national aids control organisation (naco).

Title: HIV positive couple relates experiences
article: lucknow: it''s only a matter of positive thinking and one can overpower serious ordeals in life. sheila and ferdie, a couple infected with hiv, have made it true. they shared their experiences with the participants at the four-day seminar on ``methodist women and hiv aids in india'''' held at the isabella thoburn college on sunday.addressing the gathering, the couple said that being hiv positive did not mean the end of the life. relating their experiences as how initially they were rebuked by the society, they said that finally they overcame all the hurdles and were now working for spreading awareness about aids in the society. they said that hiv-infected persons could also lead a normal life if given support and cooperation by the society and friends.,the seminar is being jointly organised by wscs methodist church in india, general board of global ministries, the united methodist church and the it college. it is aimed at spreading awareness among methodist women as to how they can deal the problem with a positive approach. a literature package containing awareness material was also released on the occasion.,special guest of the event, anita khenka, a photographer and social worker, said that an hiv-infected sex worker friend inspired her to work for the cause. an exhibition of photographs taken by khenka is also on display.,dr s chand and sandra ferguson also addressed the inaugural session.,the resource material has various things, including a book mark with ten commandments and 10 pastoral care tips, a newsletter and a `snake and ladder game'' teaching people about hiv\aids and challenges in the 21st century.

Title: Sonagachiâ€™s HIV clinic impresses UK minister
article: kolkata: this one visit made all the difference to sonagachiaâ„¢s morale. ben bradshaw, the british foreign office minister, was all praise for the clinic set up as part of the std/hiv intervention programme. the clinic, set up by the durbar mahila samannay committee, an ngo working for the well being of sex workers in the area, is a model project of the world health organisation. in fact, the three-member british team, including high commissioner rob young and deputy high commissioner john mitchiner, said they hadnaâ„¢t seen a better-managed centre. the visit did much to boost the spirit of sex workers and social activists. the excitement generated by the british team was palpable, as tv crews, photographers and journalists rushed to capture the mood. sex workers shut business for sometime and seemed touched by the fact that bradshaw was taking interest in the clinic and their condition. aÅ“he is taking so much interest in our well being, we have decided not to take clients till the visit is over, in his honour,aï¿½ said meena, a sex worker, who joined hundreds of her colleagues to get a glimpse of the british team. bradshaw said that he was clearly impressed by the way in which aids and hiv awareness has percolated to this red light area. aÅ“nowhere have i seen women themselves forming a team to spread awareness among their fellow workers about the risks involved in their trade and ways to prevent aids from overpowering them.aï¿½ he said prevention is the key to success in the war against aids and sonagachi women have proved it. aÅ“in my country, the aids or hiv positive scenario is much more grim and those affected are on severely toxic medicines that cripple their system permanently. i will certainly carry back the success story of these women with me. i was happy to see that sex workers here are aware of their rights and cannot be exploited, thanks to dmsc.aï¿½ the team left amidst enthusiastic farewell chants, leaving behind a ray of optimism in the dingy lanes.

Title: They are positive despite HIV
article: pune: shabana, ujjwala and neha don''t look any different from other women of their age - healthy, happy and brimming with enthusiasm. and yet, there is a big difference. they are hiv-positive and they have learnt to live with it. underneath their smiles lie the tales of extreme tragedy and spirited comebacks. they came out in public for the first time to share these stories on wednesday, in the run-up to the international women''s day (march 8), at a dialogue organised by the network of maharashtra by people living with hiv/aids (nmp+). the idea, in their own words, was to teach others like them "to feel empowered and to live with dignity". there is another common thread in their stories. they tested positive after they got married. "but we don''t like to discuss how we got the virus," says 30-year-old ujjwala. despite efforts to educate people about hiv/aids, it continues to be a stigma, especially for a woman, ujjwala says. "i discovered that i was hiv-positive when i was five months pregnant in 1996. i did not know what hiv/aids was all about, and was really scared when the doctor told me that i would die within three months. my maternal uncle is a gynaecologist yet he refused to admit me for delivery. my son too turned out to be hiv positive," she recalls. a situation that should have elicited enormous compassion, got none. after her husband died of aids, her father-in-law, a lawyer, forced ujjwala to sign papers relinquishing her rights to his property. "my husband was a manager in a reputed company and yet the company harassed me before releasing his dues. even the insurance company dragged its feet when they came to know how my husband died," ujjwala adds. the situation worsened when her in-laws spread the word about her hiv status and it was only because of her parents'' support that she pulled herself out of depression. thirty-year-old neha''s story is equally poignant. "i was working as a nurse in a reputed mumbai hospital and came to know about being hiv-positive when i miscarried. i was bleeding profusely, but the gynaecologist refused to even touch me. i was shifted to a municipal hospital, but had a similar experience there," she recalls. after her employers came to know of her hiv status she was promptly kicked out. "it took me time to come to terms with the situation. my in-laws started humiliating me, the neighbours abused me and it was only my parents who stood by me," she told the times news network. now she has got enough courage to send her employers a legal notice for discriminating against her. shabana, 24, had to leave her husband''s house in 1998 when she tested hiv-positive. "it was thanks to the counselling i received at the national institute of virology (niv) and later at the national aids research institute (nari), that i recovered from the shock," she explains. shabana, ujjwala and neha have now picked up the threads of their lives and are actively involved with nmp+ and its activities. "we help and give counselling to the 60-odd women members and also go thrice to sassoon hospital for counselling hiv/aids patients. we have also started thinking about creating self-employment opportunities for women members, so that they can support themselves," says shabana. another activity they plan to start is a crA"che for children of women who have tested hiv-positive.

Title: Project to prevent HIV transmission to foetus
article: bangalore: india has the highest number of aids-infected people (as on march 1 1999). 10,000 new infections happen each day. thousands of newborns are getting infected through transmission from the mother. speaking about the present trend, dr nanda gopal m.d. of vani vilas hospital elaborated on the determinants and the measures to be taken to prevent transmission of hiv/aids to the child through its mother. the determinants could be of two types. one is maternal__such as unprotected sex during pregnancy, low vitamin level in mother''s blood which increases the risk factor of transmission by four fold, and smoking of illicit drugs. second type is foetal__the capacity of the foetus to absorb the virus, umbilical blood sampling and through breast feeding. one of the handicaps to prevent transmission of the virus is that failure to detect the infection in time among the infants as infection can occur anytime during the pregnancy, labour or breast feeding. other than taking good care of the aids-infected mother, there are some medicines which can reduce the risk of transmission, which is nearly 14-56 per cent. a joint project with unicef and naco, has identified 11 centres in india, the one in karnataka being the vani vilas hospital in bangalore. as part of the project, all pregnant women are given free hiv testing and are also treated with medicines such as zidonine and nevirapine if found positive. ``this project will be extended upto the grassroot level which will help the rural masses to avail these facilities'''' said dr nanda gopal.

Title: 10 HIV cases in Muzaffarpur district
article: muzaffarpur: at least 10 confirmed cases of hiv positive have been detected in this district during a 15-day-long swasth yauvan mela ending on february 28, according to reports received here till tuesday from 14 out of 16 blocks of the district. five cases of hiv have been found in aurai, three in bochaha and one each in minapur and motipur, according to civil surgeon dr jagdish singh. special medical camps were organised at 320 places during the fortnight at the rate of 20 camps in each block or under every primary health centre (phc). reports from kurhani and saraiya phcs are yet to be received. as many as 11,927 women and 4,069 men were examined by doctors and para-medical staff. of them, 1,612 persons had reproductive tract infection (rti), 789 sexually transmitted infection (s t i) and 58 with ulcer or wounds in private parts. medicines worth rs 1.70 lakh had been purchased for the treatment of examined patients and the entire stock of drugs is claimed to have been distributed at the camps.

Title: 3.9 million people in India have HIV infection: Survey
article: new delhi: over 3.9 million people in the country are carrying hiv infection, according to the hiv sentinel surveillance round - 2001. the number of added hiv infections in india during the last year has been estimated to be about 110,000 as against 160,000 during 2000, the survey said. the estimated number of adults living with hiv in the country for 1998, 1999 and 2000 was 3.5 million, 3.7 million and 3.8 million respectively, while last year total number of hiv infection was 3.97 million, according to an official release. the report said that in view of the fact that coverage of the target population was still less than full and certain sections like migrants and young people need to be adequately addressed, the national aids control organisation would strive for further capacity building and resource mobilisation towards multi-sectoral response. the goal was to reach the statewide scaled up programme for the high prevalence states and to maintain the prevalence rates in the populous northern region at the current level. the annual round of hiv sentinel survey was conducted in 320 sites in all the states and union territories during august-october 2001.

Title: HIV among pregnant women is rising
article: jalandhar:a genetically abnormal child is a major problem for the child, family and society. the commonest way to tackle this problem so far has been to conduct tests on the foetus around the fourth month and to go in for an mtp if it is found abnormal. however, lately pre-implantation diagnosis (pgd) has offered a new alternative by enabling genetic disease to be diagnosed in the gametes. this will enable parents to know if the baby will be free of inherited disorder that is prevalent in the family. aÅ“at present clinical pgd has been done on a very limited number of couples worldwide as it is a very complex and precise technique. however, as a clinical procedure it has a lot of potential,aï¿½ said hrishikesh pai, scientific director of the babies and us fertility, ivf and icsi, lilavati hospital, mumbai. paiaâ„¢s paper was among a number of eye-opening research papers read out at the north zone fogsi conference of obstetricians and gynaecologists here on sunday. the doctor warned that aÅ“care must be taken to protect this technique from misuse.aï¿½ aÅ“worldwide approximately 2.2 million women and 6,00,000 infants are infected with hiv virus each year. the majority of infected women are in their reproductive years. pregnancy in hiv infected individuals was not recognised as an important problem initially because of predominant presence of hiv in males. but now hiv is almost equally distributed in both sexes, so that scientific attention is now being increasingly focused on hiv infection in pregnancy and its consequences,aï¿½ said bimal garg, consultant physician, ggs medical college and hospital,faridkot. garg warned,aÅ“the rise in prevalence of hiv among women attending ante natal clinics is a cause of concern as this is an indicator of the disease having spread to the general population from the highrisk sections of society. in india, the hiv epidemic is quite heterogeneous in distribution. a look at the sentinel surveillance data from ante natal clinics in the seven metro centres of the country shows that hiv infection has crossed 2 per cent in mumbai, over 1 per cent in hyderabad, bangalore, and chennai and is below 1 per cent in kolkata,ahmedabad and delhi.aï¿½ he added, aÅ“mother to child transmission (mtct) of hiv remains the main mode of acquisition of the infection for children. over one and a half million infected women become pregnant every year, a majority in africa and asia, with more than half a million children infected.aï¿½

Title: Drug prevents mothers transmitting HIV to newborn
article: washington: medical professionals from the us and south africa have agreed that the drug navirapine is a safe and effective way to prevent transmission of hiv virus from pregnant mothers to their nowborns. the physicians agreed at a videoconference sponsored by the us state department on march 26. physicians from the two nations discounted a variety of recent reports that have cast doubt on whether the drug is reliable.

Title: Make HIV test mandatory: Sena
article: mumbai: the state government should make premarital hiv tests mandatory, shiv sena mlc shishir shinde has suggested.he told the legislative council last week that maharashtra accounts for over 50 per cent of the hiv/aids tests in the country. ``more than half of these affected persons live in mumbai,'''' said mr shinde, who retires from the upper house on april 24. ``if you want to check the spread of this dreaded disease, the most effective way is to make premarital blood tests compulsory.'''',hauling up the government for its failure to tackle the aids menace, mr shinde said that steps should be taken to check bogus doctors who use non-sterilised syringes.,mr shinde said there would be no opposition to the idea because hiv tests are already mandatory for women undergoing caesarean operation and for patients before angiography.,``an amendment should be carried out in the hindu marriage act first and then to other acts to provide for such tests,'''' he said. he added that religion should not be allowed to interfere with such a sensitive issue.,``maharashtra has a legacy of social reforms and reformers. therefore, it is only logical that we should take the initiative in making such a legislation,'''' he said.,meanwhile, the economic survey of maharashtra has reported that there were 92,665 hiv-positive cases in the state as of november 2001. in the same period, there were 10,330 aids cases and 996 deaths. similarly, the state registered 73,347 elisa reactive cases with 1.4 per cent reactivity.,the survey said the prevalent rate of sexually transmitted diseases (std) in the 15-45 age group was between five and 10 per cent. as timely treatment could reduce hiv transmission by 40 per cent in std-related cases, four campaigns were conducted over the past two years and more than 4,00,000 patients were treated after they were found to be suffering from stds. ,``mumbai has a large floating population, besides its own with many complexities. hiv/aids has become a serious issue in mumbai,'''' the survey noted.,to combat the epidemic, the mumbai aids control society implemented the national aids control programme in greater mumbai in association with 13 ngos in 13 locations.,the state''s health expenditure as a proportion of total expenditure has been declining over the years, falling to 4.5 per cent or rs 172 per capita in the year 2000-''01. while administrative costs are going up, there has been a reduction in expenditure on medicines and health services, the survey observed.

Title: Awareness camp on HIV, AIDS
article: hyderabad: aasha, a city-based voluntary organisation conducted an aids awareness camp at choutuppal (nalgonda district) on the occasion of world health day on sunday. aasha president naval kishore agarwal addressing the camp said as per the data available, india had the largest number of hiv infected people in the world. hence it was necessary that awareness about the virus is spread to all sections of society.

Title: HIV cases in Bihar far exceed govt figures
article: patna: although the official figures say that there are only 1,350 hiv positive cases in bihar, experts feel that it is just the tip of an iceberg since a large number of people suspected to have the infection are still unwilling to undergo pathological tests to ascertain their status mainly due to the social stigma attached to hiv positive and aids patients. national aids control organisation (naco) consultant rajiv sadanandan, who was here to attend the three-day workshop on project implementation programme, said the official figure for hiv positive cases in bihar does not reflect the actual position. aÅ“it is just the tip of an iceberg. very small number of hiv positive patients know their status,aï¿½ he added. for a period up to six months after the infection the virus is not detectable. the naco consultant said in view of the existence of a large number of infected people, the state is urgently required to take steps to prevent spread of the infection. it would have to concentrate on the risk zones like patna, muzaffarpur and darbhanga where the infection appears to have already reached alarming proportions, he observed. sadanandan, however, said a large number of people are coming to the voluntary counselling and testing centres (vctcs) set up by the bihar state aids control society (bsacs) due to the assurance of confidentiality. attempts to identify hiv positive persons may not be the best strategy as it would have an adverse impact on the prevention efforts. aÅ“if these persons are followed up by the government machinery, the confidentiality would be lost and such people would be discouraged from coming to the testing centres,aï¿½ he maintained. sadanandan said even if such people are to be identified and prevented from having sex or donating blood, others who are not aware of their status would continue to have unsafe sex and spread infection. the best policy for the state would be to presume that any act of unsafe sex would lead to infection and persuade people to keep away from sex outside marriage or protect themselves by using condoms during the sexual act. the experience has shown that people having tested hiv positive generally follow the advice received at the vctcs on infection control and desist from high-risk behaviour, he added. sadanandan said the naco wants the hiv infected people to form an association of their own to prevent spread of the infection besides taking care of the members. bsacs project director c k anil said on sunday that the society has decided to extend financial help to such bodies. hiv positive people have formed their associations in maharashtra, manipur, nagaland and tamil nadu.

Title: â€˜3.5 lakh HIV cases in APâ€™
article: hyderabad: as many as 3.5 lakh people in andhra pradesh are infected with human immunodeficiency virus (hiv), health minister n janardhan reddy said on sunday. according to a press release, the minister, addressing catholic health association of india (chai) team, said a survey conducted by the health department revealed that 2.2 per cent of pregnant women admitted to various hospitals in the state were infected by hiv. on an average, out of 16 lakh deliveries, 32,000 children are born to infected mothers in a year. aÅ“the government is coming out with intensive programme to prevent mother-to-child transmission of hiv by introducing life skill education in high school considering the early exposure to sex by adolescents,aï¿½ janardhan reddy said. the minister complimented the chai for organising a aËœtruck-yatraaâ„¢ from rajasthan to bangalore in order to spread the message of awareness on aids. he said the government took initiative to launch a massive campaing on aids awareness throughout the state. he also appealed to the ngos to take care of the hiv-infected, the press release added.

Title: Anti-HIV messages: Too frank for comfort
article: lucknow: the aggressive anti-hiv campaign launched by the government is leading to a mixed reaction among the city folks. while no one doubts the importance of public education and awareness over the issue, the avalanche of explicit verbal or written messages flooding the city of late, is beginning to make the more conservative lot, specially parents, squirm in embarrassment. aÅ“the government must know how much is too much,aï¿½ says suneeta mishra, a house-maker from sapru marg. aÅ“every city bus has the messages with words and picture,aï¿½ she says. driving her children back from school, she complains, has become quite an embarrassing exercise as aÅ“the older one who can read would insist upon reading the messages aloud, while the younger one would enquire about the pictures.aï¿½ similar is the case with nidhi tiwari, another young mother from gomtinagar who has not been able to explain the concept of aËœsafe sexaâ„¢ to her 11-year-old daughter. the child she recalls created quite a flutter in the household by making the enquiry at the dinner table in presence of her grandparents. tiwari also wonders what good will the exposure do to the young ones who have still not learnt about the birds and the bees. aÅ“what makes it worse is that the message will be missed by the target populace. how many construction labourers or rickshawpullers do you think can read? moreover, the kind of words are used would make the comprehension difficult even for the semi literate segment,aï¿½ she argues. shakuntala rawat, wife of a senior army officer has objections to the information coming on the air. aÅ“the fm programme have relegated the hiv awareness to a mockery. it is actually jarring to hear the message right in the middle of a programme.aï¿½ rawat claims to switch off the set promptly in order to avoid the awkward silence which follows such announcements. moreover, the std awareness fortnight launched from april 1 has come as an added menace to some, like veera shrivastava, a city lawyer who complains about the graphic details aÅ“healthy and straight people can do withoutaï¿½. dr rk ratan, programme officer, of the drive concedes that he has been receiving complaints from a number of people. the messages, he admits, can be too frank for comfort at times. aÅ“the choice is between guarding sensibility or saving lives, and there is just no other option,aï¿½ he says.

Title: 76  more HIV positive at Darbhanga
article: darbhanga: with the detection of 76 hiv positive cases between january 1 and march 31, 2002 at two local private pathological centres and at darbhanga medical college hospital (dmch)-based voluntary counselling and testing centre (vctc), the total number of people tested positive at darbhanga has gone up to 705. the highest number of hiv positive cases was detected at "sharma diagnostics", a private pathological centre here. according to dr jagdeo sharma of the sharma diagnostics, from january 1997 to december 2001, 479 people tested hiv positive at his clinic. another 40 hiv positive cases were detected between january and march this year, bringing the total number to 519 at his clinic. at the pathological unit of the local r b memorial hospital, till december last year, 150 people had tested hiv positive, said dr b n mishra of the hospital. between january and march this year, another 12 hiv positive cases were detected, bringing the total number to 162. according to dr vcs verma, principal of dmch, the vctc, sponsored by naco, started functioning on the dmch premises from january 1 this year. till march 31, 209 people came to the vctc for test, out of which 24 tested hiv positive. however, according to some doctors, the number of hiv positive cases would be much more, as wives and children of many of those tested hiv positive had not come for the test. at all the three centres, it has been found that majority of those detected hiv positive were working in mumbai, followed by kolkata and delhi. most of the detected cases belonged to the rural areas of darbhanga, madhubani and samastipur districts, said the doctors at the three centres. when contacted, dr mani bhushan shrivastav, civil surgeon of darbhanga, was unable to give the correct figure of those tested hiv positive, but said that the number of infected hiv positive case must have exceeded 700. he further said that awareness about the preventive aspects of the disease was being created by the district health administration.

Title: A positive voice in an HIV wilderness
article: new delhi: ashok pillai, the 34-year-old president of the indian network of people living with hiv/aids, inp plus, passed away in chennai on friday. ashok was a symbol of positivism for the hundreds and thousands of people infected with hiv in the country. he was the first to start spreading the message that hiv was not just about dying: it was about making the best use of oneaâ„¢s limited years. which is indeed what ashok set out to achieve once he had come to terms with his infection and learnt to face the stigma and humiliation of being hiv positive. he not only built up a positive peopleaâ„¢s movement in the country but also brought together diverse groups to present a united voice on the issues of positive people. even for ashok it took several years before he could come to terms with his mortality. after being found infected in 1989, when he was a radio operator in the navy, he battled the stigma and discrimination that accompanies the infection, for many years. in 1991, discharged by the navy, he came back to his home, and waited for death to come. he had been given a maximum period of survival of three years by the doctors. he would wake up in the morning thinking he would be dead by the evening and go off to sleep that he would be dead by the morning. this pattern continued for months when he finally realised how wrong the doctors were. there was, after all, life after hiv. and that is when he joined a group of other young men like him to form the first positive peoplesaâ„¢ network. quite courageously, he announced his status publicly, so that others could learn from him. a poster brought out by him, showing a confident and cheerful ashok, saying,aËœaËœ i have a successful career. i enjoy music. i like to workout at the gym,aâ„¢aâ„¢changed the mindset around hiv/aids. before that posters on hiv showed horrific images of emaciated bodies and dying people. in the 12 years that ashok survived after detection of his infection, he not only built up a movement of positive people, but also brought together different smaller groups under an umbrella network. aËœaËœa positive attitude makes the biggest difference,aâ„¢aâ„¢ he would say, aËœaËœif i am living under stress, i will not eat properly, perhaps stop going to work as well, my immune system is bound to suffer.aâ„¢aâ„¢ he wanted to work till his last day. and he did. though he had been taken ill by a rare infection of late, indicating that his immunity levels were dangerously low and that he had entered the final stages of aids, he did not give up. he was a soldier; he died like one; just the way he had wanted it.

Title: Curbs on HIV positive tourists likely
article: hyderabad: the centre is considering restrictions on the entry of hiv positive tourists into the country, union health minister dr c p thakur said on sunday. thakur told reporters here that a proposal of this nature was under consideration. aËœaËœhowever, the decision cannot be taken by the health ministry alone. the external affairs, tourism and other ministries will have to be involved in the process,aâ„¢aâ„¢ he said. if converted into a decision, then tourists and other visitors to india would have to carry a certificate declaring their status either as hiv negative or hiv positive. on the aids scenario in the country, thakur said that a sentinel survey had revealed a decline in fresh cases of hiv infection and aids. aËœaËœthis is due to the awareness campaigns on the disease,aâ„¢aâ„¢ he said. the minister, however, said that building awareness about aids was a continuing process .

Title: HIV-positive convict deprived of therapy
article: BANGALORE: Venkatesh (name changed), a convict from Bangalore jail admitted to Bowring and Lady Curzon Hospital a fortnight ago, is a HIV victim. Although doctors are attending to his ``opportunistic infections'''' (such as tuberculosis), the antiretroviral drugs meant mainly to tackle the HIV virus are not being given.,Reason: The state government is not subsidising the prohibitive cost of antiretroviral drugs which works out to Rs 2,000 per month.,Venkatesh is the tenth of the 12 HIV patients admitted to Bowring Hospital, who have been deprived of these due to the expense involved. Antiretroviral therapy for HIV infected people is known to transform this near fatal illness into a chronic, but stable one.,Bowring Hospital Medical Superintendent L. Chandramma told , that guidelines of the National AIDS Control Organisation (NACO) the nodal agency for policy formulation and programme implementation stipulate issue of antiretroviral drugs to only two groups: pregnant mothers and those under post exposure prophylaxis (those who come in contact with a needle prick or with sputum or blood of HIV patients).,Chandramma, who is also the physician recognised by NACO for AIDS management in Karnataka, said her repeated petitions to the government for supply of free antiretroviral drugs to all HIV patients had been turned down on the ground that NACO guidelines do not permit this. ``It is depressing to see that out of 12 cases only two can avail the drugs. Antiretroviral drugs cannot cure AIDS, but like hypertension or diabetes, it can be kept under check,'''' she said.,Health and Family Welfare Minister A.B. Maalaka Raddy blamed the Centre for the situation. ``The Centre''s allocation of the drugs is a mere 0.9 per cent, when Sri Lanka''s is 9 per cent. The total turnover of pharmaceuticals manufactured in Karnataka is Rs 800 crore, but only Rs 70-80 crore can be purchased within the state,'''' he said.,Raddy said states depend on the Centre for devolution of funds. ``Funds are earmarked for TB and other diseases but AIDS has been neglected,'''' he added.,Karnataka along with Maharashtra, Tamil Nadu and Manipur has been bracketed in the `high incidence'' category. In fact, Congress President Sonia Gandhi expressed concern at Karnataka''s rating at the party CMs'' conclave in Guwahati recently. Aware of this scourge, Chief Minister S.M. Krishna has taken charge of the Karnataka AIDS Prevention Society, earlier headed by the Health and Family Welfare secretary.,Chandramma said most cases are from Dakshina Kannada and Udupi, attributed to the strategic locations of these districts on National Highway 17 and migration of people to Mumbai for employment.

Title: 25 HIV cases detected at Gorakhpur AIDS centre
article: GORAKHPUR: Twenty-five HIV positive cases have been detected at Voluntary Counselling and Testing Centre for HIV AIDS, Gorakhpur, in the last five months.,The centre was established at the district hospital by the National AIDS Control Organisation in December last year. ,Out of the 96 patients, who approached the centre for getting conducted the HIV test, 25 were detected positive, said Dr RS Misra, senior pathologist and incharge of the centre, while talking to Times News Network on Monday. ,He added that 10 HIV positive cases were from Gorakhpur district, four from Deoria, eight from Kushinagar district, two from Azamgarh and one from Sant Kabirnagar district.,Dr Misra said that of these 25 patients 22 belonged to rural areas and all of them shifted to big cities, including Mumbai, Delhi and Chennai, for earning livelihood. ,While 18 of them contacted the deadly virus through causal sex, two inherited it from their parents. ,Besides, two got the HIV virus through blood transfusion and three by using infected syringes, he said adding that the remaining patients were drug addicts.,Among the HIV positive cases detected at the centre nine are women and four children and all are below 30. ,According to the centre incharge, over 25 per cent of patients, who got conducted HIV test here, were detected carrying the deadly virus. aÅ“It is an alarming situation,aï¿½ he added.,The centre has two counsellors Pramod Kumar Tripathi and Archana Srivastva, one technician and a pathologist.,Suspected cases are first referred to the counsellors. Later, after confirmation of the infection by the pathologist patients are again sent to the counsellors who explain them the necessary precautions. ,To maintain secrecy, patients are identified by code numbers and not by their names.

Title: Doctor stabbed by HIV-positive patient
article: MUZAFFARPUR: A physician, Dr Ashok Kumar, was stabbed four times here on Monday when an HIV-positive patient, Aklu Shah (25), belonging to Patepur under the Vaishali district attacked the doctor at his Juran Chhapra clinic with a dagger. The assailant was captured and brutally assaulted by the clinic staff and mohalla people. The injured doctor has been admitted to a private nursing home where he is stated to be out of danger. His violent patient has been referred to the S K Medical College for treatment, According to SP R K Singh, the assailant has told the police that he had become fed up with the wrong treatment the doctor was providing to him. His health was steadily deteriorating in spite of regular check-up by the doctor. As the doctor was being operated upon for stab injuries on his chest, back and hands, his version could not be available why he failed to refer the HIV patient to an appropriate hospital.

Title: Parenthood help for men with HIV
article: NEW YORK: When Sally Morrison and Paul Corser of Manhattan decided that they wanted to have a baby, they went to local fertility doctors for help. But everywhere they went they were turned down, for Corser was infected with HIV.,Many clinics still will not help couples like them, who arrive there in a quandary: if the men, with HIV, have unprotected sex, they risk infecting their partners and their babies. Yet if the men use condoms, they are infertile. But with sophisticated fertility methods, they hope, it should be possible to minimize the risk by separating sperm from the virus, which is in the seminal fluid.,Helping men with HIV have children is one of the last taboos for specialists, who now routinely offer services to patients with advanced cancer, gay men who use surrogate mothers, single women who pick sperm donors from catalogs and women well past menopause. ,In the competitive world of fertility centers, at least one clinic, at Columbia University, sees providing treatment to men with HIV as a way of helping unserved patients while gaining a market niche. It was at Columbia that Morrison and Corser eventually found help. ,The clinicaâ„¢s director, Mark Sauer, said he knew he was taking risks. But he decided a few years ago that he could greatly reduce the chances of transmitting the virus by using a technique called intracytoplasmic sperm injection, injecting a single sperm into an egg.,Sauer said his clinic had treated 54 infected men. He has made more than 103 attempts at producing pregnancies. So far, 29 women have become pregnant and have had their babies or are more than halfway through pregnancy. Thirty babies have been born, with nearly half the women having twins, as is typical in fertility treatment. ,Sauer noted that published reports from Europe indicated that about 1,500 attempts at creating pregnancies with sperm from people with HIV, using a different method, had resulted in 250 successful pregnancies and no viral transmission. Sauer acknowledges that he has treated too few patients to judge the odds of infection. But he knows that many men with HIV want help in having children. (NYT News Service)

Title: Ayurveda comes to the aid of HIV-hit
article: PUNE: Even as all eyes are set on the first AIDS vaccine being developed in the country, a group of vaidyas is silently carrying out an ayurvedic treatment programme on HIV-infected patients to explore cost-effective alternative to expensive allopathic medicines.Launched in 1993, in collaboration with the Armed Forces Medical College (AFMC), the group is currently in the process of analysing the outcome of the second phase, involving 50 HIV-infected patients.,According to Dr V.V. Doiphode, the head of Department of Ayurved at the University of Pune, the results of the first phase, involving a group of an equal number of patients, have shown satisfactory results.,While the group of 50 was divided into two categories with 25 members each a" the study group and the control (placebo) group a" Doiphode said that the idea was to compare the effectiveness of both the ayurved and therapeutic drugs like nuceloside analogue and potease inhibitors.,aÅ“Evaluation of clinical parametres in the first phase revealed that nine patients (36 per cent) in the study group actually gained weight as compared to only three patients in the control group,aï¿½ he said, citing a case where a serious HIV-infected patient from the first group is still in good condition.,Enthused at the weight gain, which according to him, is unprecedented in cases of HIV patients, a joint decision was immediately taken to extend the clinical trial for a second phase.,As he explained, a key feature of the trials is to study the efficacy of the ayurved drugs like Sanjeevani and Sookshmatriphala, having antiviral properties, to minimise the chances of opportunistic infection.,aÅ“The drugs consisted of Guduchi, Shatavari, Amalaki, Bhui Kohola, Makaradhwaja, Vagna Bhasma and Abhrak Bhasma, and are considered to build general immunity.aï¿½,The entire module is based on rasayan chikitsa and panchakarma, the two lines of ayurved treatment, which restores and rejuvenates the immune system in the body. As another member in the group, who did not want to be named, said that the second mechanism is based on the elimination therapy.,aÅ“During this period, we administer such dosages of medicine which enables the body to get rid of the impure blood, full of fending agents,aï¿½ he said, pointing out that besides the cost factor, ayurved medicines do not have the problem of side-effects.,Doiphode said that once the second phase results are analysed, an attempt will be made to conduct a clinical trial using both ayurved and modern medicines simultaneously.,aÅ“We are also in the process of arranging some funds for further research,aï¿½ he said, adding that a representation will soon be made to the Indian Council of Medical Research. aÅ“But first,we want to make sure that this treatment is effective,aï¿½ he added.,When contacted, AFMC commandant Air Marshal S.K. Dham, however, claimed that director general of the Armed Forces Medical Services, has turned down a proposal to further extend the trials. aÅ“The first phase was conducted during Col. S.K. Syalaâ„¢s days and a report was subsequently sent to the AFMS,aï¿½ he said, adding that the objective parametres were not found to be very satisfactory.

Title: HIV patientâ€™s tale on film
article: Kolkata: The heart-rending story of a 26-year-old woman, who contracted HIV from her husband, and eventually passed it on to her innocent baby, has been captured on celluloid as a testimony of an AIDS patient daring to come out in the open. Called aËœA Day With Jahnabiaâ„¢, the 27-minute documentary narrating the life of young Jahnabi Goswami, was officially released on Tuesday by West Bengal health minister Surya Kanta Mishra in Kolkata. It would be translated into other Indian languages for countrywide circulation. Directed by Saswati Bandopadhyay and co-funded by DFID, British High Commission, it portrays Goswamiaâ„¢s zest for life and crusade against AIDS that kept her going. ,Goswami is working to spread awareness about the dreaded disease in Assam. A resident of Nagaon, the bubbly teenageraâ„¢s ordeals began when she tied the knot with a Guwahati-based businessman carrying the deadly strains. Goswami lost her husband and only child in quick succession within two years and was mercilessly thrown out by her in- laws. ,aËœaËœI was married at 16 and did not know that my husband was HIV positive. I was in class IX and could not even complete my studies,aâ„¢aâ„¢ says Jahnabi. aËœaËœBy then, my husband was dead and I did not know what to do. Then I decided that I would help HIV positive people to live life in a dignified manner,aâ„¢aâ„¢ she says.,Sex should be made a transparent issue instead of being concealed, she says. aËœaËœSex is not something to shy away from. It is natural to get attracted towards anything where there is a ban. If we can spread the message about safe sex and implications of unsafe sex, that is going to help,aâ„¢aâ„¢ she explains.,aËœaËœIt is quite difficult to make them understand the dimension and the intensity of the problem. It is best to communicate through street plays, folk music and theatre,aâ„¢aâ„¢ she feels.,aËœaËœThe crusade against the disease is providing me the strength to live,aï¿½ she says confidently.

Title: Turning the tide on HIV
article: Pune: More than two decades after AIDS replaced cancer as the most dreaded disease on the planet, millions of people, including nursing professionals, find themselves in two minds while dealing with HIV-AIDS patients.In a bid to tackle some of this stigma and discrimination associated with the killer, the Ruby Hall Clinic here, recently conducted a workshop for the people who are among the first to deal with an HIV patient - chief nurses of city hospitals.,The workshop was held under the aegis of the Centre for HIV/AIDS Research and Training (CHART) - a collaborative effort between the University of South Florida and the Ruby Hall Clinic.,Naturally the message of the workshop coincided with CHARTaâ„¢s mission statement -to sensitise nurses and social workers to bring about a change in the quality of life of those infected with HIV.,According to Dr Sanjay Pujari, director of the HIV project at the hospital, CHART has is a two-tier approach.,aÅ“The participants in todayaâ„¢s programme would go back to their respective hospitals and organise similar activities there.,aÅ“Apart from the fear of contracting the virus and becoming sick and dying of the disease, the nursing community has to witness the stigma, isolation, marginalisation and discrimination of the patients,aï¿½ Dr Pujari explained.,One of the key factors of the training, according to him, is to awaken the nursesaâ„¢ emotional support and counselling techniques toward affected persons.

Title: Over 22,000 people in Delhi HIV positive
article: NEW DELHI: Over 22,000 people in the national capital are HIV positive, Delhi Health Minister A K Walia said here on Tuesday.Of these 670 are full-grown AIDS patients, he said addressing a symposium on ''HIV/AIDS: Legal and Humanitarian Perspective - Preparedness for tomorrow''.,Stating that the Delhi government had decided to observe this year as AIDS Preventive Year, Walia said the administration was trying to spread awareness in a systematic manner at village, block and district levels with the help of other departments and NGOs.,He said the Delhi government had set up a number of voluntary test counselling centres in various medical colleges and hospitals.,Delhi High Court Chief Justice S B Sinha said illiterate people easily fall prey to the HIV virus and stressed the need for creating mass awareness to make people take precautions.

Title: New home for HIV patients in Hennur
article: BANGALORE: Keshav would lay chained to a pole all day and lived in inhuman conditions. All because the 16-year-old''s parents discovered he had AIDS.Rajan, a 25-year-old graduate, was chased out of his house by his parents when they discovered he was infected with the terminally ill HIV virus.,These boys are not alone. All over India, many are put through humiliating and barbaric treatment, all because of AIDS.,It was these and other shocking cases that inspired Raju K Mathew to act: he started the AIDS Counselling, Care, Education and Prevention Training society (ACCEPT) in 1999.,The organisation on Tuesday opened a care home at Agara Horamavu, off Hennur Road, which was inaugurated by Chief Minister S M Krishna. The latter is also the chairman of the AIDS awareness programme in Karnataka.,The home accommodates 20 people and provides counselling and treatment free of cost. ``Since we had telephone counselling services for the last three years, more and more HIV patients were asking for a place to stay. Hence, we decided to open a small home for now and will later expand it,'''' Mathew said.,ACCEPT helps people to detect AIDS and then provides them with the support they need to overcome emotional and physical trauma.,Other activities include holistic care to patients and their families by providing medical and psychological relief, offering moral and value-based education to bring a behavioural change in their lives and conducting health awareness education to eliminate ignorance on HIV/AIDS.

Title: HIV-positive manâ€™s desire to marry sets debate
article: KOLKATA: This is a story of hope and courage a" a fight between a manaâ„¢s search for happiness and a clash between human rights and the law.Mr X, an HIV-positive 37-year-old executive from Delhi, advertised in the matrimonial columns of two English dailies on May 26. Sources in the newspaper offices confirmed that he had booked space for the next three weeks as well.,The advertisement opens up several legal and ethical questions. A Supreme Court verdict in 1998 clearly says that while an HIV-positive person cannot be sacked from any job because of his medical condition, aÅ“sex with them or possibility thereof has to be avoided as otherwise they would infect and communicate communicate the disease to others. The Court cannot assist a person to achieve this objectaï¿½.,The Lawyers Collective, a national organisation whose HIV/AIDS unit provides legal aid to those afflicted, is fighting at present for Mr X and many others like him, ensuring they get the right to healthcare, housing, employment and marital rights relating to maintenance and custody.,aÅ“Courts have no jurisdiction to abridge or suspend the fundamental right to life and liberty. Furthermore, restricting or suspending the right to marry for HIV-positive persons is arbitrary, unjust and discriminatory in nature, and violative of Articles 14 & 16 of the Constitution of India,aï¿½ said a senior senior lawyers and a member of the Collective, speaking to TNN over telephone from Delhi. ,He pointed out that if a man admits to his health condition and a woman agrees to marry him, the court order is not violated. But doctors donaâ„¢t agree. Speaking to TNN in Kolkata, physician Pratim Roy of the aËœSTDHIV-Intervention Programmeaâ„¢ project said, aÅ“We advise couples not to get married if one of them is HIV+. And if they do, sexual contact should be strictly banned, since even usage of protection is not fool proof.aï¿½,Justice D.K. Basu agreed. aÅ“The law will not permit them to get married. But I suppose it depends on whether someone takes a couple to court for marrying despite being HIV-positive,aï¿½ he said.

Title: Can an HIV positive person marry?
article: KOLKATA: This is a story of hope and courage a" a fight between a manaâ„¢s search for happiness and a clash between human rights and the law. Mr X (real identity protected), an HIV positive 37-year-old executive from Delhi advertised in the matrimonial columns of two national English dailies on Sunday a" seeking the hand of a woman in marriage. Sources in the newspaper offices confirmed that he had booked space for next three weeks as well. The ad on May 26, reads: aËœWanted for HIV+ man, 37/5.7 working in Delhi, an educated, working, unmarried/widow/divorcee woman below 35. Confidentiality of HIV status assured. A box number is given as is e-mail ID: writetome@justice.com There is just one problem. A Supreme Court verdict in 1998 clearly says, that while an HIV positive person cannot be sacked from any job because of his medical condition, aÅ“sex with them or possibility thereof has to be avoided as otherwise they would infect and communicate the disease to others. The Court cannot assist a person to achieve this object.aï¿½ The Lawyers Collective, a national organisation whose HIV/AIDS unit provides legal aid to those afflicted, is fighting at present for Mr X and many others like him, ensuring they get the right to healthcare, housing, employment and marital rights relating to maintenance and custody. aÅ“Courts have no jurisdiction to abridge or suspend the fundamental right to life and liberty. Furthermore, restricting or suspending the right to marry for HIV-positive persons is arbitrary, unjust and discriminatory in nature, and violative of Articles 14 & 16 of the Constitution of India,aï¿½ said a senior lawyer and a member of the Collective, speaking to TNN over telephone from Delhi. He pointed out that, if a man admits to his health condition and still a woman agrees to marry him, the court order is not violated. But doctors donaâ„¢t agree. Speaking to TNN in Kolkata, physician Pratim Roy of the aËœSTD-HIV-Intervention Programmeaâ„¢ project said, aÅ“we advise couples not to get married if one of them are HIV+. And if they do, sexual contact should be strictly banned, since even usage of protection is not fool proofaï¿½. Justice DK Basu agreed. aÅ“The law will not permit them to get married. It depends on whether someone takes a couple to court for marrying despite being HIV positive,aï¿½ he said.

Title: Sangli figures high on HIV-hit list
article: SANGLI: The number of HIVpositive persons in Sangli district is feared to be several times higher than the registered cases. Dr Subhash Salunkhe, state health director general and project-director of Maharashtra AIDS Control Society (MACS), has said.,Speaking at a workshop, organised by the health division of UNICEF and MACS here on Saturday, Salunkhe said that the district is among the areas in the country with a large population of HIV patients.,Salunkhe said that according to studies, the number of HIV patients was normally more in poverty-stricken areas. aÅ“However, Sangli does not belong to this category and, therefore, it is surprising to find a large number of HIV cases here,aï¿½ he added.,Sangli district civil surgeon Dr Dhanpal Ainapure said that a survey conducted showed that there were 70 per cent males and 30 per cent females among the HIV-hit.

Title: 19 fresh HIV cases in Gorakhpur
article: GORAKHPUR: Nineteen more HIV positive cases were detected at the Voluntary Counselling and Testing Centre (VC&PC) in the district hospital here last month. Forty-three such cases have been identified at the centre in the last five months.,Giving this information to Times News Network here on Thursday, senior pathologist of the centre RS Misra said that out of the 125 cases referred to the centre in the last five months 43 were found HIV positive. Out of these patients, 28 were male, he said and added that the maximum HIV positive cases (15) were reported from Gorakhpur followed by Kushinagar (11), Deoria, Sant Kabir Nagar (four each), Maharajganj (six) and Mau (three). ,Among these HIV positive cases four were children who inherited the virus from their parents, Misra added.,Claiming that the deadly disease was fast spreading in eastern districts, he said that the detection of HIV virus in children clearly indicated that AIDS patients were transmitting the disease to the next generation. He appealed to people to get themselves examined at the centre.

Title: 50 tested HIV positive at health camp
article: PATNA: The five-day national family welfare and health mela, organised under the aegis of Bihar chapter of Indian Medical Association (IMA) at the ESI Hospital, Phulwarisharif, concluded on Wednesday.About 50,000 patients, including 21,506 women, got themselves registered at the five-day health mela and underwent various tests at the 40 stalls set up there. Medical education and family welfare minister Shakeel Ahmad was the chief guest at the valedictory function.,Giving this information, IMA state secretary Dr Shahjanand Prasad Singh said that while 9,000 patients registered themselves at the mela on the inaugural day i.e. on Saturday, 12,000 patients turned up on Sunday, 13,000 on Monday, 10,200 on Tuesday and 5,800 on Wednesday. Singh said that 1,390 pathological tests, 500 X-rays, 300 ECGs and 300 scans were conducted during the five-day mela. About 50 persons tested HIV positive while 98 persons were found suffering from malaria, 44 persons from leprosy and 190 from filaria after various testes conducted at the mela, Singh added.,Singh said that the doctors from Delhi and Patna also examined 527 patients referred to from the Indira Gandhi Institute of Medical Sciences, 72 cases from the Indira Gandhi Institute of Cardiology, 332 patients from the PMCH and 272 patients from the NMCH.

Title: Condom crunch affects AIDS/HIV drive
article: PUNE: Inadequate supply has hit the condom distribution programmes carried out by non-government organisations (NGOs) in the city, consequently jeopardising their HIV/AIDS control drive.Various NGOs working in the cityaâ„¢s red light area say they have been facing an acute shortage of condoms for the past one month.,aÅ“In the past one year, we wrote around 30 letters to the officials concerned, highlihting the problem of irregular supply of condoms. Moreover, the issue was raised last year in the Lok Sabha, but the officials continue to turn a blind eye to the problem,aï¿½ complained Tejaswi Sevekari, project in-charge of the Peopleaâ„¢s Health Organisation (PHO), Pune. ,The organisation has been spearheading the crusade against HIV/AIDS among commercial sex workers (CSWs) in the Budhwar Peth are since 1991.,Although there is no official figure, the NGOs said there are approximately 6,000 CSWs in and around Budhwar Peth. ,They complained that the Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) was not even meeting half their requirement of 14 lakh condoms per month.,Speaking to TNN, state health minister Digvijay Khanvilkar assured that he would make necessary arrangements of condom boxes, provided the NGOs and authorities concerned sent him a request through.,PMCaâ„¢s assistant health officer Dilip B. Pardeshi, who is also secretary of the Pune AIDS Control Society, confirmed the shortage and said the PMC depended solely on the state for the supply.,On an average, the PMC distributed approximately 1.5 lakh condoms every month, in addition to the 46 condom vending machines installed at vantage points in the city, stocking 100 condoms each, Pardeshi said.,However, the NGOs have a different story to tell.,Trustee-cum-HIV/AIDS counsellor Seema Waghmode of Kayakalpa, an NGO carrying out the distribution programme, said they required around 25,000 condoms per month, but got only 18,000 condoms. Likewise, Sevekari complained that last month, they did not receive a single condom.,Vanchit Vikas joint secretary Meena Kurlekar said that as against a monthly requirement of five lakh, it received only 75,000 condoms.,Apart from the HIV/AIDS awareness and prevention programme, the Vanchit Vikas also runs a sexually transmitted disease (STD) clinic for the CSWs.

Title: HIV duplicity cases rise
article: Hyderabad: The Andhra Pradesh Womenaâ„¢s Commission is handling an increasing number of cases in which women discovered that their husbands kept their HIV-positive status secret before marriage.The discovery usually happens when the women realise they are themselves infected with the virus when they undergo tests for pregnancy. Consequently, the number of HIVpositive new-born babies has been increasing: there are an estimated 36,000 HIV-positive babies born every year in the state.,Andhra Pradesh Womenaâ„¢s Commission chairperson C Susheela Devi said the commission has received nine such cases of postmarital HIV-positive discovery, all from the districts. At the Andhra Pradesh State AIDS Control Societyaâ„¢s interpersonal counselling centres, the number of such cases reported is on the rise. Between May 22 and June 27, seven such cases were reported at the Koti centre alone.,There seems to a pattern to these cases. Some of these men got married in spite of knowing they are HIV-positive because they wanted a aËœnurseaâ„¢ to look after them, Susheela Devi said. Before marriage, if the groom is too ill to attend pre-marital rites, the womanaâ„¢s parents are told that he has a minor ailment but the fact that he is HIV-positive is not disclosed, not even after the wedding, said Susheela Devi citing one of the cases.

Title: 12 Indians with HIV at AIDS conference
article: BARCELONA, Spain: K K Abraham, an HIV patient for the past 10 years, on Monday created history by sharing the dais with the UNAIDS executive director, Dr Peter Piot at a press conference. Abraham heads the Indian Network of People living with HIV (NIP). He told TNN that 12 HIV patients, all belonging to his organisation, were attending the conference. ,Milly Katana, member of an internationally known Ugandan woman associated projects launched to fight disease and a member of Global Fund Board, also said that she was suffering from HIV for the past few years. Ralf, a 27 year youth from Amsterdam too declared that he was an HIV positive case. Ralf said that the disease had made him more determined to provide a youth HIV environment.

Title: Spurt in HIV cases in the city
article: HYDERABAD: The number of HIV-positive cases is on the rise in Hyderabad, if the data available with the Municipal Corporation of Hyderabad (MCH) is any indication. Records show that HIV-positive cases have risen from 0.16 per cent of the samples tested in 1989 to 0.99 per cent till April 30, 2002.The Urban Community Development (UCD) wing of the MCH has screened as many as 3,55,275 blood samples. Of them about 2,750 were HIV-positive and 551 were full-blown Aids cases. As many as 78 Aids-related deaths were reported during 2000-2001.,The sero-positivity rate during the year 2000 was 0.68 per cent, and during 2001, it was 0.98 per cent. According to a survey conducted by the UCD, it was revealed that high prevalence of paid sex, a strong network of commercial sex workers and proportionately lower rates of consistent condom use were the contributing factors to the increase in Aids.,Speaking to The Times of India, additional commissioner (UCD) G Malsur said the disease is more prevalent in Hyderabad, Vijayawada and Tirupati. aÅ“The migration of labourers, who leave behind their families, and a strong network of sex workers are posing dangers,aï¿½ he said.,The MCH, in association with the Indian Red Cross Society, has launched a year-long awareness programme in 792 slums in the city.,They have identified high school students, adolescent girls and link volunteers of the health department as the target groups to create awareness.,According to Malsur, the personnel engaged in the awareness programme are facing several challenges such as translation of awareness into behaviour change and ensuring the availability of condoms to cover 80 per cent of the high-risk population.,Presently, the UCD wing of the MCH was training 90 medical officers, 80 slum development officers, 184 public health nurses, and 1,584 resident community volunteers.,Survey reveals 2,750 HIV-positive cases, 551 full-blown Aids cases Hyderabad, Vijayawada and Tirupati hub of HIV infection Awareness programme to target school students, health workers.

Title: New TB vaccine ineffective in HIV cases
article: PUNE: Doctors associated with SIIL have advised not to administer doses of the newly-launched BCG vaccine to those children whose mothers have tested sputum positive and HIV positive. According to SIIL medical director Dr S. Bharadwaj, the chances of protecting an HIV-infected child from tuberculosis are minimal.,While pointing out that the efficacy of the indigenously-developed vaccine is 83.8 per cent compared to other BCG vaccines with 80.3 per cent efficacy, he said the newly-launched vaccine is best suited for children under six years of age.,"The effects of the vaccine given to a child above six years may not show the desired results," he added.

Title: STD clinics to get HIV-testing kits
article: HYDERABAD: The sexually transmitted disease (STD) clinics of the stateaâ„¢s 10 teaching hospitals will receive HIV-testing kits to facilitate better screening of patients.As on date, HIV testing is done at the voluntary counselling and testing centres (VCTCs) at these teaching hospitals. A total of 88 VCTCs are functioning in the state at the area, district and teaching hospitals. However, the problem that STD clinic doctors often face is that though they were treating patients who are potential HIV carriers, they do not have a facility to test the patients immediately and have to refer them to the VCTCs functioning in the teaching hospitals.,This proved to be a problem as the VCTCs are located in the microbiology department of the teaching hospitals and hence there was no follow-up as to whether the patient went for the test at all. Moreover, the difficulty of locating the microbiology department in a teaching hospital deterred many patients from going for further tests. It was also noticed that many of the patients referred to the VCTCs never reported back with results and doctors were not able to keep track of the status of patients who came to the STD clinic, AP State Aids Control Society project director K Damayanti says.,It is also possible to give better care to patients once a HIV kit is available at the STD clinic as results can be obtained and suitable treatment administered to the patient immediately, the project director added. Though the problem does not exist in area and district hospitals, in teaching hospitals it is a major problem because of the sheer size of the hospital.,Incidentally, the state has the highest per cent of STD prevalence in the country with 7 per cent in males and females according to a National Aids Control Organisation study.

Title: Hospitals say no to HIV+ children
article: HYDERABAD: Two orphan children, who are HIV-positive, were turned away by two city hospitals recently. Both the premier institutions claimed they did not have the facilities to treat such cases.The children, one six and the other four, are suffering from HIV-induced tuberculosis. They are now left in the care of Freedom Foundation, the NGO that recommended their cases to the government hospitals. ,Relatives of these children had abandoned them at the foundationaâ„¢s office and by the time they were taken in, they had symptoms of HIV-induced TB. ,aÅ“It was only when their condition deteriorated and they needed further tests that we decided to move them. But both the Niloufer Hospital for Women and Children and the Osmania General Hospital slammed their doors on them,aï¿½ said Karl Sequeira, Freedom Foundation executive trustee.,On August 2, the condition both children turned grave. Lawrence S Simon, a counsellor from the foundation, took them to Niloufer.,At the outpatient department, the supervising doctor referred them for admission. That was at 9 am. They were even issued food cards and bystander cards. ,Simon was carrying a letter from foundation doctor Troy Cunningham. The missive spelt out the condition of the patients, the treatment they needed and tests to be conducted.,When Simon and the children reached the ward, the doctor there went through the letter and said he was in no position to admit the children. His hospital, he said, did not have the facility to treat AIDS cases. ,He referred them to Osmania General Hospital. Simon was also asked to sign a aÅ“discharge on requestaï¿½ slip, which he refused.,He took the children, by then showing signs of acute exhaustion, to Osmania hospital.,There, he found the outpatient department closed. So, he contacted the resident medical officer (RMO). He referred them to the counsellor at the hospital.,At this point, Simon told the RMO: aÅ“I can do without the opinion of another counsellor, for at Freedom Foundation this is the job we do.aï¿½ ,Nonetheless, the doctor was not convinced and Simon met the counsellor, who agreed to admit the children the next day.,Just when Simon was feeling relieved, the counsellor got back to him and said would not be possible to take the children in. They were referred back to Niloufer.,By then Simon had run out of patience. It was getting late and the children were very ill. So he decided to rush back to the foundation offices, where Dr Troy put them under medication. They are responding to treatment.

Title: Treat all HIV patients, govt tells hospitals
article: The Times of India

Title: Govt programme to prevent HIV in newborns
article: NEW DELHI: The Delhi state government launched its mother-to-child HIV prevention programme in Guru Tegh Bahadur, Deen Dayal Upadhyay and Girdharilal Jain maternity hospitals on Tuesday.But the programme has not made any provisions to ensure that those who undergo the therapy also attend follow-up clinics. As a result, doctors may not be able to know how many really benefitted from the programme.,Of the 1.5 lakh babies born in government hospitals, very few come back for follow up.,Delhi state health minister A K Walia said, aËœaËœOur counsellors will make it clear to the HIV positive mothers that they need to come back with their babies after the delivery.aâ„¢aâ„¢,Within a couple of months, the programmes will spread to seven other hospitals in Delhi.,A doctor said, aËœaËœUnless such programmes make arrangements to ensure proper follow up, its effect cannot be realised. Even counselling may not be enough as almost 50 per cent of deliveries in hospitals are unbooked.aâ„¢aâ„¢,According to statistics, about 30 per cent of all children born of HIV positive mothers get the deadly virus. The nevirapine therapy reduces the transmission rate to half a" about 15 per cent.,Guru Tegh Bahadur Hospital head Dr D K Srivastava said, aËœaËœVery poor patients come to our hospitals and of the 30 deliveries every day, about 15 are unbooked.aâ„¢aâ„¢,Walia said the programme will soon be extended to private hospitals also.

Title: 9% slum women surveyed test HIV positive
article: NEW DELHI: A series of health camps for women in slum clusters have detected an alarmingly high incidence of HIV. In three camps held since June so far, almost nine per cent of women were found positive.The camps known as aËœStree Shaktiaâ„¢ are held simultaneously in all nine districts. These have been planned specially to cater to the health needs of women living in slums. Besides the usual check-ups on haemoglobin and blood pressure, women coming to the camps can also get an HIV test done.,The Delhi State AIDS Control Society (DSACS) puts up its stall in these camps and assist in carrying out the HIV Elisa test. ,A doctor not wanting to be named said, aËœaËœOn August 11, about 2,200 women were tested for HIV in the nine camps throughout the city. Of them, 250 tested positive. In the previous rounds of camps on June 5 and July 7, the HIV incidence was found to be seven per cent.,Top officials are tight-lipped about the findings. DSACS head N C Ray denied any knowledge about the number of HIV positive in the camps. He told The Times of India that since he was on leave he was not aware.,Delhi state health minister A K Walia said he was not sure. He said, aËœaËœI do not have the findings with me right now. But I do not think the incidence was found to be so high.aâ„¢aâ„¢,But the doctors actually working with the camp have a different story to tell. A doctor said, aËœaËœThe average incidence comes to about 8.7 per cent. The camps have tested only women. The actual number of positive persons would be much higher. The children and spouses of these women would also be positive.aâ„¢aâ„¢,About 40 per cent of the population in the city is said to be residing in slum clusters and unauthorised colonies. A conservative estimate puts the number of slum dwellers at about 30 lakh.,The doctors also spoke of a camp organised in Nari Niketan on July 7 in west Delhi. In this camp, 30 rescued G B Road sex workers were tested for HIV.,Seven of them were found to be positive. aËœaËœThe incidence among them is almost 25 per cent. There are hundreds of such workers still in the brothels of G B Road. So far not a single reliable study has ever been conducted to find out the extent of HIV among them,aâ„¢aâ„¢ he said.,Alarmed by the figures, the city government ordered a survey by an independent company in the aËœaËœhigh-riskaâ„¢aâ„¢ areas.,The company would try to find out the HIV prevalence by interacting with the NGOs already working in the areas. The government would pay the company Rs 9 lakh for the job.,Overall India HIV incidence is about 0.1 per cent. And according to the National Aids Control Organisation, Delhi is said to have 22,400 HIV positive people.

Title: HIV inhibiting factor opens up possibilies of new drugs
article: Nature

Title: Govt rules out law for pre-marital HIV tests
article: PUNE: The Maharashtra government has categorically ruled out mandatory HIV tests before marriage in the state, saying that it would only add to the social and ethical problems associated with Aids.State health minister Digvijay Khanvilkar pleaded ignorance about the recent announcement by his Andhra Pradesh (AP) counterpart of introducing a legislation to make such a test mandatory for all people of marriageable age in AP.,Khanvilkar said such a test would amount to a violation of the National Aids Control Organisation (Naco) guidelines. aÅ“The Naco guidelines do not allow forcible testing,aï¿½ he said. Goa is the only state in the country which has made HIV tests before marriage compulsory.,While Maharashtra figures among the top three states in India with about 1.5 to 2 per cent of the adult population falling prey to the disease, mainly due to their sexual behaviour, Khanvilkar said the state government would concentrate on voluntary counselling and testing.,Andhra health minister K. Siva Prasad Rao was quoted by the media last week about the proposed legislation in the coming session of the state assembly. Rao had justified the decision, saying that the state has four lakh HIV positive cases, out of which half of the victims are in the marriageable age.,Elaborating the problems anticipated with mandatory testing, the health minister said such an act does not guarantee that the disease would be confined to only the high risk behavioural groups. aÅ“The virus has already spread to the general population,aï¿½ he said, also pointing out to the window period where the virus may not be detected despite the person undergoing a test.,Meanwhile, secretary of the medical education, G.S.
