Gill, said that apart from the social and ethical problems, the government cannot afford to annoy the funding agencies, both the Centre and the World Bank, which has funded a whopping Rs 110 crore under the second phase of its Aids project, particularly in Mumbai.,Aids experts Sanjay Pujari and Vinay Kulkarni said efforts should be made to popularise voluntary testing on a case-to-case basis. aÅ“No doubt, the women populace are at a high risk as the virus is mainly spread by the male population, but then in India, getting a false certificate is no big deal,aï¿½ said Pujari. Kulkarni said that an HIV test needs a lot of counselling and infrastructure.

Title: Clinical trials of HIV vaccine from 2004
article: CHANDIGARH: A piece of good news for the estimated four million HIV infected people in India: enthused by the positive outcome of tests conducted on mice, scientists studying the genomic diversity of HIV in the country are all set to begin clinical trials of the DNAbased HIV vaccine on human beings from 2004.The vaccine has been developed by a team of experts headed by Dr Pradeep Seth, Microbiology department head at All India Institute of Medical Sciences, New Delhi, under the Prime Ministeraâ„¢s Jai Vigyan Mission programme. ,Dr Sethi is in Chandigarh to attend the two-day meeting of the northwest chapter of Indian Association of Medical Microbiologists, being held at PGI.,A breakthrough in the field of medical science, the vaccine, which experts hope would show positive results on humans too, would go a long way in filling up the void in the treatment of HIVaffected persons owing to the nonavailability of vaccines in India.,Speaking to Times News Network on Saturday, Dr Seth said, aËœaËœClinical trials have already been performed on mice and the results have been extremely encouraging. The trials are now being conducted on monkeys at two places, one in Bangalore and the other at the University of California. The final results of these tests are expected by the end of 2003, after which we would start trials on human beings in 2004. ,"The DNA-based vaccine has been developed after cloning genes from human strains from which constructs were developed. These have shown excellent results in mice and we are optimistic of a very positive outcome of the trials conducted on humans.aâ„¢aâ„¢,Commenting on the incidence of HIV in India, Dr Seth noted that the sub-type of HIV-1 which leads to infection here is very different from the sub-type which leads to the disease in Europe and elsewhere in the world.,aËœaËœNearly 90 per cent of the infection in India is due to sub-type C while sub-type B is the primary causal factor abroad. Though in both cases the resultant infection is the same, the target cells are slightly different. Most of the kits available in India are made in the West from sub-type B. Therefore they either fail to detect HIV infection or the detection is effected at a later stage,aâ„¢ he said.,aËœaËœThe vaccine that we have developed is targeted at Indians among whom sub-type C is predominant,aâ„¢aâ„¢ he observed.,Funds for conducting clinical trials on human beings have been allocated by the Centre.

Title: HIV-positive women defy the virus
article: MUMBAI: They tested positive for the HIV virus over a decade ago, but refused to accept it as a death sentence.Today, these women are a living testimony to the fact that HIV-positive persons can live well and long, given the right support. The so-called AIDS epidemic in Mumbai, it seems, is not following its predicted course.,aÅ“Over 90 per cent of our patients are healthy, many for the past 10 to 12 years,aâ„¢aâ„¢ said Nagesh Shirgoppikar, a medical consultant at the Salvation Armyaâ„¢s AIDS clinic in Mumbai. aÅ“If we can see them through the next three to five years, we will be able to show that even without the AIDS drugs (Anti Retro Viral Therapy), Indians who test HIV-positive and receive the right combination of care, can remain asymptomatic and do very well.aâ„¢aâ„¢,A group of 12 women, who had lost their husbands to AIDS, took time off from their tailoring class last week to share the secret of how they remain aÅ“long-term non-progressorsaâ„¢aâ„¢ as theyaâ„¢re know by medical experts. ,Set up in 1995, Salvation Armyaâ„¢s clinic regularly follows up on around 600 HIV-positive patients, providing them a range of services, including tailoring classes in an effort to make them economically independent.,The AIDS widows are candid about their husbands, who, they believe, passed on the virus to them. They believe it was not AIDS that led to their husbandsaâ„¢ early demise, but their addiction to alcohol, gutka or cigarettes coupled with a careless attitude to medication, and failing to adopt changes in their lifestyle. ,They extend this logic to their own situation. When they were declared as HIV-positive (through a single Eliza test), their vulnerability to infections such as cold, cough, fever, diorrhea and dizziness increased. They also suffered from weight loss. ,But the women believe that their physical vulnerability was more an outcome of their tension, fatigue after caring for their sick husbands and economic burden rather than AIDS-induced infections.,According to Lata, who was diagnosed HIV-positive 12 years ago, aÅ“It took us around two to four years to come to terms with our HIV status. We needed time to work out the anger we felt towards our husbands, the rejection of our families and to think quietly about how to deal with the fear.aâ„¢aâ„¢,Counselling gave her hope. She came across the Salavation Armyaâ„¢s AIDS clinc where all her questions about AIDS were answered, and got access to good doctors whose detailed and regular check-ups caught infections early.,She also found a support group of sorts among women with similar afflictions. Thereafter, a aÅ“positive attitudeaâ„¢aâ„¢ became the buzzword in their lives, she said. Lata and other women have learnt in the past decade that it is important to take care of their health. Sharda, another of this group, says that she does not eat out and carries her own drinking water whenever she goes. This has greatly helped in reducing bouts of diarrhoea, cold, cough and fever.,The group members are no longer careless about medication, and do not sit alone and mope at home. If they cannot find paid work, they volunteer for service to other AIDS patients.,aÅ“What kills people is the lack of hope, tension, the absence of family and social support and our economic plight. With all other illnesses, even TB or cancer, everyone wants to help and support. HIV, this one word, makes everyone turn away. At this time, if you find even one person who can help you stand on your feet, you have a chance,aâ„¢aâ„¢ said Sharda.,Too proud to beg refuge in their parentsaâ„¢ homes, and shunned by their inlaws, these women are determined to fend for themselves, but it extracts a heavy price. One of them has been forced to put her two children in a staterun home for a year as she cannot look after them. Their diet primarily consists of dal and rice. Seasonal fruits and leafy vegetables that they desperately need to eat are a luxury they can ill-afford.,While innumerable studies point to the vital role nutrition plays in supporting the health of HIV-positive patients, the mega bucks spent in the name of AIDS has never reached them for even this basic need.,The Salvation Armyaâ„¢s efforts to help these women stand on their own feet is bearing fruits. The first batch of ten women will soon complete their tailoring module and a businessman has promised them their first order. The AIDS widows say that addressing some key issues would make a difference in the care and support of those afflicted.,One is ensuring access to TB drugs through the DOT centresa"the problem here is that lack of motivated health staff and their constant absenteeism forces patients to miss out on medication routine. The second is the presence of well-trained doctors, particularly in the rural areas. ,At present, patients need to make trips to the city for consultations on tratement. The third is security for their children and organisational support in solving legal and other disputes with family members.

Title: Garba to raise funds for HIV testing centre
article: VADODARA: aËœTechnology meets traditionaâ„¢, was the message of the Garba Mahotsav organised last year by the Baroda Information Technology Association (BITA). This year round in association with city based NGO, Indu Health Research Foundation (IHRF), they have planned a special Garba for an HIV free society. The BITA-INDU Garba Mahotsav, this year, aims to raise funds for setting up a Voluntary Counselling and HIV Testing Centre (VCTC) in the city to provide free HIV testing and counselling to patients. ,aÅ“We received initial help from Dr Kiran Patel, an NRI doctor, to set up VCTC, which would provide free pre-HIV and post-HIV test counselling for any patient who comes to the centre. But to sustain the programme for all patients we needed funds, which we plan to collect through the BITA-INDU Garba Mahotsav,aï¿½ said Dr Vijay Shah. ,Former president of BITA, Dinesh Patel, said that they wanted to give the city traditional garbas and at the same time wanted to help the society, therefore they joined hands with IHRF. ,aÅ“We did not want our venture to be commercial. We thought of joining hands with IHRF after we were apprised of the plan of VCTC,aï¿½ added Patel,According to Shah, the HIV VCTC would start operations in November. City based psychiatrist Dr Sandeep Shah would head the counselling wing of the centre. Dr. Sandeep Shah said that he has approached the M S Universityaâ„¢s department of psychology students to volunteer their services for the centre. They would be trained and then would help in counselling the patients, who come for the HIV tests.,Commenting on the timings of the festival Patel said that the state government as yet had not fixed a deadline but if the limit was till 10 pm then they would abide by it. aÅ“This year we have made special security arrangements to avert an untoward incident. Though we plan to abide by the early deadline if imposed, I believe that there should be no deadline. ,If we have a deadline, then it would be a fulfilment of the wishes of the terrorists who attacked Akshardham. The BITA-Indu Garba would be organised at the Ajit Nagar grounds near Akota stadium.

Title: Gates to visit India on HIV/AIDS mission
article: NEW DELHI: Microsoft chief Bill Gates will visit India from November 11, leading a high-level delegation of ''Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation'' to see on-going projects on AIDS, funded by the Foundation.Co-founder Bill Gates will be in India during November 11-14 to see first-hand some of the challenges and exemplary initiatives underway to prevent HIV transmission, a statement by the Seattle-based Foundation said here on Sunday.,Gates is expected to announce a long-term strategic commitment to support the country''s efforts to check the spread of HIV/AIDS during his four-day visit, it added.,Gates will visit sites of Foundation''s $25-million grant to the Partnership Project in Andhra Pradesh, a venture between Children''s Vaccine Programme at PATH (Programme for Appropriate Technologies in Health) and the state government.,The project aims at introducing hepatitis B vaccine and strengthen the overall immunisation programme in the state.,Foundation''s Global Health Programme focuses on reducing health inequalities by speeding up development, deployment and sustainability of health interventions that would save lives and reduce disease burden in developing countries.,The Foundation is dedicated to improving people''s lives by sharing advances in health and learning with the global community.,The Foundation has an endowment of $24 billion and is led by Bill''s father William H Gates.

Title: Bill Gates to visit city on HIV/AIDS mission
article: NEW DELHI/ HYDERABAD: Microsoft chief Bill Gates will visit India from November 11, leading a high-level delegation of the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, to take a look at ongoing projects on Aids funded by the organisation. He is likely to visit Hyderabad on Nov 14 and the state government is preparing to roll out the red carpet for him.A statement by the Seattle-based Foundation said in New Delhi on Sunday that co-founder Bill Gates will be in India during November 11-14 to see first-hand some of the challenges and initiatives underway to prevent HIV transmission. ,The foundation has an endowment of $ 24 billion and is headed by Gatesaâ„¢ father, William H Gates.,He is expected to announce a long-term strategic commitment to support the countryaâ„¢s efforts to check the spread of HIV/Aids during his four-day visit, it added.,Gates will visit Andhra Pradesh to tour sites of the foundationaâ„¢s $ 25 million grant to a partnership project between the Childrenaâ„¢s Vaccine Programme at Path (Programme for Appropriate Technologies in Health) and the state government. ,The government is expected to give Gates royal treatment during his one-day visit. It is learnt that Gates would spend half-a-day at the Microsoft India Development Centre in the city. The rest of the day he will be visiting the health projects funded by his foundation and attend the programmes arranged by the government.,Chief minister N Chandrababu Naidu, who has been inviting Gates to visit Hyderabad for more than a year, will either host a lunch or dinner in honour of the visiting dignitary. Later, the government will showcase the developments on the information technology front in the state before Gates. ,The government is seeking greater participation from Gates in the information technology initiatives of the administration. According to informed sources, the government was sounded more than a fortnight ago on the possible visit of Gates. ,A Microsoft India release from Bangalore said Gates would be spending a day each in New Delhi, Mumbai, Bangalore and Hyderabad. The itinerary of his third visit to India includes meetings with key government officials, academics, leading corporate houses and industry associations. ,aÅ“It is a testimony to the growing importance of India in Microsoftaâ„¢s overall game planaï¿½, the statement said. According to Microsoft Indiaaâ„¢s managing director Rajiv Kaul, India is a aÅ“big betaï¿½ for Microsoft. aÅ“We are growing rapidly and we are undoubtedly one of the fastest growing subsidiaries for Microsoft in Asiaaï¿½.

Title: No mandatory HIV test for  foreigners now
article: PATNA: The Centre has decided to dispense with the requirement of mandatory HIV test for foreigners, including students, with immediate effect. In this regard, the Centre has sent the revised guidelines for HIV/Aids test of foreigners to all the states and Union territories (UTs).In a communication to the health secretaries of all the states and UTs, Union ministry of health and family welfare director A K Jha has informed them that the guidelines and existing policy for HIV test of foreigners, including students, have been reviewed recently.,During the review it was found that in the present scenario of HIV/Aids prevalence in the country, there was no justification in continuing with the mandatory HIV test of foreigners, both scientifically and epidemiologically, Jha added. Union health ministry has asked all the states and UTs to communicate the same to the officials concerned.,The copies of the letter have also been sent to the Union ministry of home affairs (foreign division), ministry of foreign affairs (coordination division), director general, Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR), joint director, National Aids Control Organisation (Naco) and additional director general (ADG), directorate of health services, government of India.,The Centreaâ„¢s decision to stop the mandatory HIV test appears to be influenced by the opinion of World Health Organisation (WHO) on the issue. WHO feels that the requirement of mandatory HIV test of foreigners in any part of the world goes against the concept of voluntary test and counselling of affected persons. World Bank, which finances the Aids control programmes across the world, and UN Rights organisation have also opposed the mandatory HIV test.,When contacted, project director of the Bihar State Aids Control Society (BSACS) C K Anil admitted that the state government had received the revised guidelines for HIV test of foreigners. He, too, felt that the HIV test should not be coercive.,He, however, said that several Islamic countries have made it mandatory. Anil said that in Bihar the immediate beneficiaries would be more than 300 foreigners visiting Gaya during the ongoing aÅ“pitripaksha melaaï¿½.,A senior official of the health department said that although the HIV test was mandatory in India until the Centre decided to dispense with it recently, in practice no foreigner visiting Bihar was ever forced to undergo the test.,Meanwhile, Naco consultant Rajiv Sadanandan reviewed the progress of Aids control programme in Bihar during the current financial with Anil and other senior officials of the BSACS on September 26.

Title: Noida patients being sent to Meerut for HIV tests
article: NOIDA: The absence of facilities for HIV (human immuno-deficiency virus) testing at district hospitals and other state government health facilities in Gautam Budh Nagar and Ghaziabad, is forcing people to visit expensive private laboratories or sometimes even quacks.Patients with tuberculosis (TB) or sexually transmitted diseases, or others who need to be tested for HIV infection, are usually referred by government health agencies to the Meerut district hospital, which is the divisional AIDS surveillance centre.,Recently, a TB patient in the Dadri area had to spend Rs 350 for a basic HIV screening at a local pathology lab. He tested positive. ,The elite government-run primary health centre running in the area, close to Badalpur, Chief Minister Mayawati''s paternal village, did not have the basic screening kits. Following his death two months ago, his wife had to return to the same private laboratory. Again she paid Rs 350 for the test. "It was better than travelling to Meerut and back in my state of health," she said.,But there have been other sufferers. On June 15 last year, Noida''s Sector 20 police arrested 20 alleged sex workers. A local court ordered that the women should be tested for HIV while in judicial custody. ,But since there were no testing kits in Noida''s state health facilities, the undertrials were kept in judicial custody for over two weeks. The women had to be sent to Meerut for the tests to be carried out and then wait for the results to arrive.,There are also instances of quacks running private pathology labs. "In one case about three years ago," said an official, "a former Ghaziabad laboratory technician started his own blood bank and laboratory. On receiving complaints, a medical team raided the facility. And it turned out that the man did not even have the qualifications to be a laboratory technician.",Noida district hospital chief Dr Daya Prakash confirmed that hospitals and PHCs in the area did not have HIV testing kits, because the district did not have a blood bank yet. ,"Right now, we are referring suspected cases either to the Meerut surveillance centre or to a Central government facility," he said.,But Dr Prakash agreed, "No routine surveillance of HIV can properly be carried out without the testing kits.",In Ghaziabad, chief medical officer Dr Vinod Kumar said, "We will soon set up a voluntary HIV testing centre here. So far, we mainly test the blood samples at the district hospital''s blood bank. We are also doing some random voluntary testing of STD patients, with kits provided by the National AIDS Control Organisation. If there is a special case, we use the blood bank kits. But our main testing facility is still in Meerut."

Title: HIV law may face legal roadblocks
article: HYDERABAD: The state governmentaâ„¢s move to make pre-marriage HIV tests mandatory will be next to impossible to implement as Andhra Pradesh lacks adequate testing facilities and the National Aids Control Organisationaâ„¢s (Naco) guidelines do not permit the same.Further, according to legal experts, such a legislation infringes on the fundamental rights of a citizen guaranteed under the Constitution.,Even if the state government manages to get a legislation passed, Andhra Pradesh does not have adequate HIV testing facilities, as the 88 voluntary counselling and testing centres (VCTCs) of the state Aids control society are only at the district level and not at mandals.,In addition, Nacoaâ„¢s testing policy initiatives state, in section 5.6 (1), that no one should be forced to undergo an HIV test.,aÅ“The state Aids control society cannot undertake mandatory testing even at the existing centres, as Naco guidelines do not allow for the same and Naco funds cannot be used for this,aï¿½ Andhra Pradesh State Aids Control Society (Apsacs) officials said.,Naco guidelines also state that pre and post-test counselling is a must before a person undergoes an examination to find out whether he has Aids. If a person tests positive for the virus , the result must be kept confidential and should be revealed only to him or her. It can be revealed to his or her family, but only after obtaining the HIV positive personaâ„¢s consent.,Legal experts are of the opinion that if the legislation is enacted, it will go against Article 19 of the Constitution, which guarantees an individual the right to privacy. It will also infringe on an individualaâ„¢s right to livelihood, provided by Article 21.,In most personal laws of marriage, registration is not required, hence a policy for mandatory testing is impossible to implement and will not prove to be beneficial in controlling the spread of the virus, say the legal experts. ,Moreover, similar initiatives around the world have failed even in countries where awareness about the virus is very high, such as the United States. ,The American Civil Liberties Union report of March 1998 stated that mandatory pre-marital HIV testing was a failure after such an initiative was not accepted by any of the states.

Title: Only foreign students undergo HIV tests
article: HYDERABAD: With foreign students flocking to Hyderabad to pursue higher education, the number of students going for HIV tests at the Voluntary Counselling and Testing Centres (VCTCs) is on the rise. However, for them, these tests are not voluntary.A HIV test is mandatory for these foreign students to get admitted into Indian universities and students are referred to the VCTC by the universities.,The city has a sizable number of foreign students from various countries, including Saudi Arabia, Yemen, Somalia, Uganda, Nepal and Tanzania.,Interestingly, native students are staying away from VCTCs, as a HIV test is not mandatory for them to get admission into a university.,Students from the state do not opt for testing at the VCTCs though the test costs only Rs 10. According to counsellors at the VCTCs in the city, the idea of going for a HIV test does not occur to a native student as it is not mandatory. ,Incidentally, according to a behavioural surveillance study report, 13.2 per cent of the male university students said they had sex with a non-regular, non-commercial partner in the last six months of which 37.3 per cent reported condom use. However, condom usage was as high as 74.3 per cent among male university students who had sex with commercial partners.,According to statistics at the VCTC located at the Institute of Preventive Medicine, 177 students, almost all of them foreigners, underwent HIV tests in August and September.

Title: HIV tests given short shrift at nursing homes
article: HYDERABAD: With no regulations in place to monitor the National Testing Policy norms on HIV testing, nursing homes and diagnostic centres are openly flouting rules.The Drugs Control Administration DCA) and AP Aids Control Society (Apsacs) are mute spectators as they are not empowered to initiate any action for violations.,It has come to the notice of the APSACS that nursing homes and diagnostic centres are issuing HIV test results on the basis of a single Eliza, rapid or simple test, which is about 23 per cent accurate.,According to the National Testing Policy, a set of three different Eliza, rapid or simple test needs to be done or a combination of three different antigen tests need to be undertaken as these are 99 per cent accurate.,Moreover, the three ERS test can be done only after written consent is obtained from a person, pre-test and posttest counselling done and confidentiality maintained, however, this is not always the case at these nursing homes and diagnostic centres.,Incidentally, the DCA has no provisions under its rules and acts to launch prosecutions against these centres, if faulty testing procedures are brought to its notice, DCA joint director (in-charge) M Venkata Reddy said.,Further, the Apsacs has also issued notifications to testing centres and diagnostic centres about procedures to be followed. "What is of utmost concern is that many people are given positive certificates without proper confirmation at these diagnostic centres and nursing homes," Apsacs additional director incharge Dr M V Ramana Rao said.

Title: Hivare Bazar village to make HIV test mandatory
article: PUNE: Even as the Maharashtra government has ruled out mandatory HIV tests before marriage, the village elders of Hivare Bazar, 16 km off Ahmednagar, have decided that any outsider tying the nuptial knots with any one from their village will have to undergo an HIV test before marriage.While all the 225 families at Hivare Bazar have unanimously agreed to the mandatory Enzyme Link Immuno Sorbent Assay (Elisa) test before marriage, a final decision will be taken by the gram sabha. Once approved, the decision will be strictly enforced from April next.,The primary reason for initiating such a measure, as the village sarpanch Popatrao Pawar explained, is to save the villagers from the killer virus. "We donaâ„¢t want our children to become victims of HIV/Aids," he said, adding in a lighter vein, "prevention is always better than cure, and in the case of HIV, there isnaâ„¢t any cure".,He, however, said the decision was taken after detailed consultations will all members in the village. When referred to the National AIDS Control Organisation (Naco) guidelines, which doesnaâ„¢t allow mandatory HIV testing, Mr Pawar only said, "Our state now figures among the top three states with about 1.5 to 2 per cent of the adult population falling prey to the virus, mainly due to their sexual behaviour".,Pointing out to the alarming rise of HIV cases in the state, he said there were many boys and girls from the village who get married to people outside Hivare Bazar every year. "There have been many such cases in our neighbouring areas where innocent women have been infected with the virus by their promiscuous husbands," he said, adding, " fortunately, our village hasnaâ„¢t had a single positive case so far".,According to him, the idea was conceived when a college-going girl wrote to the village elders if there could be any mechanism to prevent the spread of Aids in the village. "We had asked a group of the village youngsters to write what do they feel about the village and the measures that need to be taken for betterment of its people," Pawar told TNN from his office at Ahmednagar. Mr Pawar, who helped transform a poverty-stricken and crime-ridden Hivare Bazar to prosperity through watershed management, said that efforts are already on to involve the district administration.,"We are just awaiting a final approval in the gram sabha, following which we will approach the district collector and other medical authorities," he said, adding the plans are also afoot to give some concession to the poorest families in the village to undergo the test.,State health minister Digvijay Khanvilkar, in a recent interview to TNN, had categorically ruled out mandatory HIV tests before marriage in the state, saying that such an act would only add to the social and ethical problems associated with the killer disease.,When pointed out that his Andhra Pradesh counterpart had announced plans to introduce a legislation in his state to make such a test mandatory for all people of marriageable age, Mr Khanvilkar said that such an act would amount to violation of the Naco guidelines.

Title: Village makes HIV test a must before marriage
article: PUNE: Going against the National AIDS Control Organisation (Naco) guidelines, villagers of Hivare Bazar near Ahmednagar have decided to make it mandatory for outsiders wanting to marry their children to undergo HIV tests.Only recently had the Maharashtra government ruled out mandatory HIV tests in the state. All 225 families in the village have unanimously agreed to the mandatory Enzyme Link Immuno Sorbent Assay (Elisa) test before marriage. Once the gram sabha approves of the decision, it will be strictly enforced from next April.,The primary reason for initiating such a measure, village sarpanch Popatrao Pawar said, was to save their children from the killer virus. "We donaâ„¢t want our children to become victims of HIV/AIDS," he said, adding in a lighter vein, "Prevention is always better than cure, and in the case of HIV, there isnaâ„¢t any cure." ,He said the decision was taken after detailed consultations with all villagers. When pointed out that the move was in violation of the Naco guidelines, Pawar only said, "Our state now figures among the top three states in India in terms of HIV-infected population. About 1.5 to 2 per cent of the adult population is afflicted with AIDS, mainly due to their sexual behaviour.","There have been many cases in neighbouring areas where girls have got the infection from their promiscuous husbands," he said, adding, "Fortunately, our village hasnaâ„¢t had a single positive case so far." ,The idea was conceived when a girl wrote to village elders, asking if there could be any mechanism to prevent the spread of AIDS.

Title: Aids/HIV to be a notifiable disease in Bihar
article: PATNA: The state government on Friday decided to declare Aids/HIV as a notifiable disease, making it mandatory for even private clinics and pathological labs to report the detection of every new Aids/HIV positive case to the appropriate authorities. A decision to this effect was taken by the health department at the second meeting of the health promotion council.The meeting was presided over by health commissioner Ashok Kumar Chaudhary. The health department will issue a notification in this connection shortly. National Human Rights Commission (NHRC) chairman J S Verma, during his three-day visit to Patna in October last, had told the state government that the official figures for Aids and HIV positive cases did not reflect the real picture of the disease in the state. Verma had made this observation during his meeting with the top state government officials on October 23. Chief secretary S N Biswas, DGP R R Prasad, Chaudhary and the home commissioner were prominent among those attending the meeting. The official figure for confirmed cases of Aids has remained pegged at 133 in the state for the last six months though the number of HIV positive cases has increased to 1,700. Addressing a press conference on October 24, Verma said the lack of a sound health care system, particularly for mental cases, lack of facilities for the treatment of Aids/HIV positive cases and the trafficking in women and children too constitute violation of the human rights.,He asked the Bihar government to strengthen the health care system in the state. During his meeting with the state government officials, the NHRC chairman had expressed his serious concern over the social boycott of an Aids-affected family at Sahilarampur village in Muzaffarpur district. An Aids-affected person of Narkatiaganj in East Champaran district had shot his wife, three children and himself dead due to the social stigma attached to the disease.,A senior health department official said Bihar is probably the first state in the country to declare Aids/HIV a notifiable disease like kala-azar, TB, malaria and cholera. The government earlier hesitated to declare Aids/HIV a notifiable disease fearing that it would breach the confidentiality of such patients, he maintained. The official, however, said that despite the government decision to declare Aids/HIV a notifiable disease, the confidentiality of such a patient would remain intact as only top officials of the health department and Bihar State Aids Control Society would be knowing about it. The official denied that the government is suppressing information regarding the new Aids cases.

Title: HIV-affected child shunned by all
article: PUNE: The discovery of an eightyear-old HIV-positive child, found abandoned in an ailing condition at the Shivajinagar bus stand, has brought into focus the deadly mix of AIDS, poverty and ignorance.It has also highlighted repeated warnings from experts about the growing spread of HIV across various strata of Indian society and the poor care and counselling support available for HIV patients and their relatives.,Anuradha Sahasrabuddhe of Dnyanadevi, the non-governmental organisation (NGO) which rescued the child, told TNN that it was 15 days ago that the boy was found abandoned.,She then related a series of frustrating attempts to find shelter for the child as most homes for destitute children refused to co-operate, saying they were filled to capacity.,"Our volunteer rescued the boy and put him in a shelter run by an NGO, Sakshi. Since the boy was very sick, Sakshi officials admitted him to a private hospital, where we learnt about his HIV status," Sahasrabuddhe,who runs the Childline telephone service for children in distress, said.,Childline was also shocked to learn that the state has just one destitute home for HIV-positive children at Sangli, which cannot accommodate more than 25 children.,She said the boy could not give his name, address and could barely tell Childline volunteers that his father had abandoned him. "His father left a new blanket and some medicines with him," Sahasrabuddhe said.,After learning that the boy was HIV-positive, Childline got in touch with Manavya, a private shelter started for HIV-positive children and children of commercial sex workers, by noted social worker Vijayatai Lawate.,While Lawate could not accommodate the child due to lack of capacity, the social welfare commissioner suggested that the boy be taken to the Bhagini Nivedita Pratishthan (BNP), a governmentaided shelter for HIV-positive children at Sangli, Sahasrabuddhe said.,The BNP, too, refused to admit him on the grounds that they were already caring for 28 children as against a sanctioned capacity of 25. The child was finally accepted by Lawate on the condition that Childline would find an alternative shelter for one of the "healthy" boys at Manavya.,Fortunately, the Janseva Foundation, another local NGO, offered to accommodate the healthy boy, Sahasrabuddhe said. R.D. Shiudkar, assistant commissioner, social welfare department, admitted that Maharashtra has just one government-aided shelter for HIV-positive children.,"We will shortly sanction two more such shelters, one of which will be in Pune," he said.

Title: 2,001 HIV cases in Bihar
article: PATNA: The health department, Bihar state Aids control committee (BSACC) and the state health and family welfare institute (Sheikhpura) have decided to celebrate December month as "Aids awareness month" while observing December 1 as the World Aids Day.According to a press note issued here on Saturday, about 40 lakh persons in the country are affected by HIV at present, but as per a US report, the number will cross 2.5 crore in India alone by 2010. In Bihar, the number of such cases is more than 2,001. ,A health camp/condom fair, voluntary advice and blood-test programme will be held in Transport Nagar, Patna (NH 19), on Sunday.

Title: Kalam for scientific estimate of HIV affected
article: NEW DELHI: In what could be seen as scepticism towards available government figures, President Abdul Kalam has said that a scientific estimate of the number of people living with HIV needs to be done to know the trend of the AIDS epidemic.President Kalam was speaking at an interaction for the development of an AIDS vaccine specific to the Indian strain at the request of the International AIDS Vaccine Initiative (IAVI) on Monday. He stressed on cross-pollination of ideas and research from across the globe to speed up the development of an AIDS vaccine.,He said for developing an AIDS vaccine, there was a need to free the scientific community from bureaucracy and empower young scientists to carry out the research.,At the meeting, which lasted almost an hour, the President said there was a need for a multi-pronged approach to vaccine development. He said research and development of several vaccines should be pursued simultaneously through several collaborators.

Title: Hope in sight for children of HIV positive couples
article: MANGALORE: Finally there is hope for new-borns whose parents are HIV positive. The UNICEF''s Prevention of Mother to Child Transmission (PMTCT) programme, being implemented in 17 medical colleges in Karnataka and which will be extended to 21 districts soon, is offering a ray of hope to the unborn.Dr K.T. Ratnamma, consultant for UNICEF''s Prevention of Mother to Child Transmission (PMTCT), told The Times of India that the programme laid emphasis on the bondage between parents and the child and urged them to go in for ''profalaxis'' a" which would, in most cases, prevent transmission of the virus to the new born.,The foundation for the programme was laid in January 2000, when a batch of doctors were sent for a 10-day training to Thailand. The programme was launched at the Vani Vilas Hospital in Bangalore, a few months later. Rajamma asserted that the results were already showing with 60 per cent success rate.,The babies born under the programme are under observation for 18 months and after that period they are tested again for HIV status. So far, of the 19 babies born at the Vani Vilas Hospital, 12 were HIV negative, five were positive and two did not return for a follow up.,Rajamma said earlier that the profalaxis was done using multi-drug therapy ''AZT'' (anti-retro viral drug), which required intervention from the last four weeks of pregnancy. This, was cumbersome and many did not return for a follow-up.,A new drug ''Nevirapine'' has been introduced from October this year, where the intervention is only during labour. Rajamma said that this was an ultra short-term regimen where a single tablet (200 mg) was given to the patient in early part of labour and a single dose of suspension to the baby within 72 hours after birth.,This therapy will help in attending to emergency cases, which was not possible with AZT therapy, she said asserting that the National AIDS Control Organisation (NACO) guidelines a" that the patient should be informed about the therapy was strictly followed.,Prior to the intervention, the UNICEF used bondage issue to convince parents (if found HIV positive) to take drugs to save the new born from the disease. Rajamma maintained that it would help new borns to be healthy citizens as medical data suggested that 60 to 75 per cent of the transmission occurred during labour.,The incidence of transmission was only 10-15 per cent in the womb and 10-25 per cent after delivery. "Hence, labour plays a crucial part in transmission and the new drug is working wonders," she added. ,In Mangalore, the programme is being implemented at KMC, Attavar and Fr Muller''s Charitable Institutions. Rajamma said another unit may be opened at Lady Goschen Hospital.

Title: HIV cases on the decline in state
article: HYDERABAD: Prevalence of HIV in the state has fallen from 2.02 per cent to 1.60 per cent as per the latest sentinel survey conducted by the Andhra Pradesh State Aids Control Society (APsacs).This was disclosed by health minister K Sivaprasada Rao on Tuesday at a zonal workshop on Aids awareness conducted by the Directorate of Field Publicity of the Union ministry of information and broadcasting.,This is the first time the figure has fallen below 2 per cent among the general population since APsacs started the sentinel survey in 1998 in August, September and October.,According to National Aids Control Organisation (Naco) guidelines, a state has a high prevalence if the percentage of HIV in the general population is below 2 per cent. Andhra Pradesh is considered a high-prevalence state and is next only to Maharashtra in the number of HIV positive cases.,Though the results of the survey are yet to be analysed, a decline in the percentage of cases both at the 23 ante-natal clinics and 11 sexually transmitted disease (STD) clinics that were included in the survey has been recorded, according to APsacs additional director M V Ramana Rao.,The figure announced by the health minister only pertains to the ante-natal clinics which represents the general population and the results from tests taken at the STD clinics that was 26.9 per cent last year is yet to be ascertained, though the figure is likely to fall.,The successful social marketing of condoms and increase in awareness of HIV and AIDS is what APsacs officials attribute this declining trend to.,The rural condom market grew from 25 lakh to 42 lakh in 2000-2001 and 82 per cent of this growth can be attributed to the social marketing programme, according to Anant Kumar, manager, AP Social Marketing Programme.

Title: Mother to child HIV transmission preventable: Expert
article: MUMBAI: Transmission of virus from an HIV positive mother to her new-born child is preventable to a large extent by using the short-term, single drug therapy, according to a leading US doctor. "Use of short-term, single drug therapy can cut transmission (of HIV) from mother to child by half," Dr Raymond Powrie, associate physician of obstetrics and gynaecology at the Women's Infant Hospital of Rhode Island, said while talking to medical students and paramedics staff of Nair Hospital here on Saturday. "Use of highly active anti-retroviral therapy (HAART) has led to reduction of mother to child transmission rate in the US to one to two per cent from 25 per cent a decade ago," he said, adding, "in my own town state of Rhode Island, virtually no baby is born with HIV". Powrie said for many women, not having a baby and use of contraceptives was the right choice. "But those women, who decide otherwise, should know that there are medications available to protect the child from the virus," he said. Powrie, who is also the member faculty of Wockhart-Harvard Medical Institute HIV/AIDS Education and Research Foundation (WHARF), said however, the multi-drug HAART is costly and not affordable to a vast majority of the people in India. "However, short-term, single drug therapy is cheaper and has been shown to cut down transmission rate from 25 to 12 per cent," he added. Welcoming Maharashtra government's decision to screen pregnant women for HIV and make drugs available, Powrie said, "the clinical claims have been validated by several studies in the US, Thailand and African countries and drugs are routinely used in Europe and the US among pregnant women". Earlier speaking at another training programme for care givers in Sion Hospital, Powrie said breast feeding increased the risk of transmission of the virus from mother to child. He said the Indian experts concurred with their US counterparts that the benefits of providing nutrition through breast feeding overweighed the risk of transmission. "Breast feeding among HIV positive mothers should be restricted to the first four to six months when the baby is able to take to solid foods," he cautioned. Acknowledging the fact that women were apprehensive in taking medicines during pregnancy, Powrie said, "HIV positive mothers should take medications because of the baby's vulnerability". Talking about women in US, he said, "the challenge in US is how do we make sure every women gets tested for HIV."

Title: Homeopathy found useful for those with HIV
article: NEW DELHI: Alternative systems of medicine are now seen to be helping those living with HIV. Arogya-2002, an exhibition on good health and living, inaugurated on Wednesday, showcases the results of trials conducted on people with HIV.While there is no cure as yet for the virus, the Central Council for Research in Homeopathy says that patients showed an improvement in their overall physical condition. The trials were conducted at three places a" Delhi, Chennai and Mumbai.,All the patients selected for the trials were those who had not started showing any symptoms of the disease. During the trials, says the Central Council, it was observed that the number of CD4 cells a" which control immune responses and decrease in people with HIV a" showed a significant increase.,This also helped in delay of onset of infections as the immune system was strengthened. The Council also said that there was an improvement in all vital physiological functions of the patients.,Other than HIV, homeopathic drugs have been found to be helpful in several other diseases as well. Research work, on display at this exhibition, also shows how malaria, in its early stages, can be cured by this method of medicine. The Homeopathic Research Institute at Jaipur is currently doing more research on malaria.,Studies conducted at the Homeopathic Drug Research Institute, Lucknow, have shown the anti-diabetic action of homeopathic drugs. A drug, Cephalandra Indica, when tested on animals, found it could produce a significant fall in blood sugar.,Of course, like all other systems of medicine, this method too has its limitations and cannot be tried for every ailment, especially those requiring surgery. Certain diseases such as skin problems may respond well to the treatment.,To ensure that good quality homeopathic drugs are available, the government is working towards standardising them. Standards have already been fixed for 916 drugs out of a total of 2,100. There are about 1,500 homeopathic drugs that are of plant origin and about 600 that are extracted from natural chemicals produced by animals.,However, the availability of some of these plants may itself be difficult at times. Therefore, the department of Indian Systems of Medicine of the health ministry now cultivates its own exotic medicinal plants so as to drastically reduce the need to import them. A number of these plant varieties are found in the Nilgiri Hills. The department has set up a special research garden in Ooty for growing some of these plants.

Title: HIV infections may raise infant mortality rate
article: MUMBAI: Mothers transmitting HIV to their babies could neutralise a five decade-old effort to reduce the infant mortality rate, paediatricians say. The infant mortality rate stands at 62 per 1,000 births today, down from 130 per 1,000 births 50 years ago.aÅ“But with the rising number of children being infected by HIV while in the womb, it will not be surprising if the rate begins rising again,aâ„¢aâ„¢ warned a member of the Indian Association of Paediatrics Dr Rohit Agrawal. He was briefing mediapersons on Monday on a forthcoming annual conference of the IAP, at which issues such as these will be discussed.,The infant mortality rate is among the most sensitive indicators of a nationaâ„¢s development. Many international organisations use a nationaâ„¢s infant mortality rate to gauge its developmental status.,Doctors said nationwide vaccination campaigns, the promotion of breast feeding and the use of oral rehydration solutions to combat diarrhoea had in the past few years been effective in checking most ailments of infants. This has reduced the number of children dying before reaching their fifth birthdays. aÅ“But now, we have another problem,aâ„¢aâ„¢ said paediatrician Dr Nitin Shah.,aÅ“Around 200 HIV-positive children are born every year in the country. Of these, 40 per cent do not live to see even their first birthday.aâ„¢aâ„¢
