Title: HIV rate up in the city
article: HYDERABAD: The rate of prevalence of HIV in the adult population in Hyderabad and Warangal has shown a sharp rise compared to last year.The test results of blood samples collected from pregnant women attending ante-natal clinics (ANCs) a" which is used as an indicator for the general population a" have shown an increase of 200 per cent in Hyderabad and over 300 per cent in Warangal.,In Hyderabad it has gone up from 0.5 per cent last year to 1.5 per cent, while in Warangal it has gone up from 1.5 per cent to 6.75 per cent. This is according to the latest sentinel surveillance study conducted between August and October 2002 by the State Aids Control Society to measure the level of prevalence in Andhra Pradesh.,The study was conducted in all 23 districts taking samples from teaching, district and area hospitals. However, only the preliminary report of the study has been published and it is yet to be approved by the National Aids Control Society.,Further, in Andhra Pradesh HIV positivity in pregnant women is more than one per cent, which indicated that it has become a ''generalised epidemicaâ„¢, according to the report.,However, the report states that there is a slight decline of HIV prevalence among the general population, as it has fallen from 2.02 per cent last year to 1.62 per cent this year. The prevalence rate has also fallen in seven districts: Anantapur, Guntur, East Godavari, Vizianagaram, Chittoor, Kurnool and Adilabad.,In the case of those attending sexually transmitted disease clinics, 23 per cent of them tested HIV positive in the state. Warangal tops again with over 40 per cent of STD patients testing positive followed by Tirupati at 39.20 per cent, Visakhapatnam at 35.60 per cent, Vijayawada at 33.20 per cent and Hyderabad at 31.60 per cent.,HIV prevalence in Visakhapatnam, Hyderabad and Khammam have come down among STD patients who are 10 times more susceptible to the virus. In Chitoor, however, there has been a sharp rise. Of the 40 lakh HIV positive cases in the country, the report estimates 4 lakh are in the state, making AP second only to Maharashtra.

Title: Rape accused is HIV positive
article: BANGALORE: The nightmare for this 17-year-old Kolkata girl has only got worse. The Times of India is in possession of medical reports confirming that her assaulter is HIV positive.,At NIMHANS for treatment of bipolar disorder (manic depression) since November 14, 2002, this mentally challenged minor was sexually abused on Jan. 12 by a former de-addiction patient, L. Balu (30) of Shivajinagar in Bangalore. Though the accused was apprehended on Jan. 13, NIMHANS filed a complaint only on the 27th. NIMHANS has now constituted a committee headed by Dr Shobha Srinath to probe the incident. Police have sent the fingerprints of the accused to all police stations to check his antecedents. ,The statement recorded by the duty doctor on the day the incident has eye witness accounts of hospital sub-staff Venkatesh and another patient Ila Devi, who brought the girl back to her ward in a state of shock. But police sources say that ward records have gone missing and so has Venkatesh. Medical tests on the victim, said to be conducted by psychiatrists at NIMHANS, rule out evidence of rape. But the shattered mother says that aÅ“there are marks on the victimaâ„¢s body and she is suffering acute pain. She has been raped. I have lost confidence in the doctors treating her.aâ„¢aâ„¢ She alleges that the hospital authorities are going slow on the treatment due to police investigation.,However, as per her request, they have decided to shift the victim for treatment to a different unit soon. aÅ“Millions of people like us across the country are dependent on this premier institution for mental health care. But a few basic facts appear to have been distorted in the depositions made by the NIMHANS authorities before the Disabilities Commissioner perhaps to suit their administrative convenience,aâ„¢aâ„¢ an outraged Ravi Shankar, the patientaâ„¢s guardian said.,The Commissioner of Disabilities has addressed letters to the Director of NIMHANS Nagaraja and Police Commissioner M. D. Singh to ensure that the patientaâ„¢s treatment goes undisturbed. On request, the case has been handed over to the all-womenaâ„¢s police station at Ulsoorgate. DCP (Central) Gopal Hosur said, aÅ“Results of the medical tests are awaited and we will speed up investigation.aâ„¢aâ„¢

Title: Legislators push HIV to back seat
article: BANGALORE: It was to be a first of its kind of forum for politicians, launched with great fanfare in May last year. But for over nine months since its launch, the Karnataka Legislatorsaâ„¢ HIV/AIDS Forum has conducted no business. ,The reason, nay, excuse: distractions in the form of the Nagappa kidnap and the Cauvery dispute. HIV/AIDS being a sensitive issue, the Forum was meant to help legislators understand the disease and spearhead campaigns in their constituencies. ,At the inaugural ceremony, Chief Minister S.M. Krishna, also chairman of Karnataka State Aids Prevention Society, said the Forum would act as a pressure group aÅ“to keep HIV/AIDS on the political agendaaâ„¢aâ„¢. ,aÅ“It was hoped the Forum would bring out issues that cannot be raised in legislature.We also wanted legislators to start talking about the disease in their constituencies,aâ„¢aâ„¢ says a senior health department official. But since its launch, neither the legislators nor the CM have had the time to talk about HIV/AIDS. ,aÅ“The Nagappa episode and Cauvery row took up legislatorsaâ„¢ attention for a major part of the year,aâ„¢aâ„¢ said the health official. Karnataka, incidentally, ranks among the high HIV/AIDS incidence states in the country. ,Districts like Bellary, Belgaum, Dharwad, Bijapur, Gulbarga, Udupi, Dakshina Kannada, Mysore and Chamarajnagar are the worst affected, along with Bangalore Urban.With Karnataka lacking a strong NGO network, except for the Bangalore region, it is considered imperative that the effort to create awareness about HIV/AIDS be shared by other sections of society. ,A recent study a" Behavioural Surveillance Survey for Karnataka a" has found that a mere 5 per cent of the population in the state had received any inter-personal communication on HIV/AIDS and its prevention. ,aÅ“The Forum needs a working structure first of all a" a head and a secretary. We are hoping they will meet before the legislature sessions this year and start functioning soon,aâ„¢aâ„¢ said the health official.

Title: Special school for two HIV-infected siblings
article: THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: In an attempt to wriggle out of the tangle resulting from admission of two HIV-infected children at Kaithakkuzhi Lower Primary School in Kollam District, the Kerala Government today announced setting up of a "special school" for the siblings at their home to continue studies.,The decision, announced by Education Minister Nalakath Sooppy here, followed the failure to reach a settlement on the issue at a meeting of parent teachers association, elected representatives and social workers convened by the district administration at Kaithakkuzhi today.,While social workers and nominees of NGOs including one from Belgium argued vehemently in favour of allowing the kids to remain in the school, most parents stiffly resisted the idea of their children sharing a classroom with the siblings. ,The school remained closed for the last few days after the hapless Bency and Benson were admitted to the school at the intervention of Chief Minister A K Antony as parents of other kids in the school refused to send their wards to classes at the fag end of the academic year.,The Chief Minister directed that the children be admitted to school after they staged a satyagraha in front of the Secretariat last month.,In a statement here, Sooppy said the special school was being set up for the children on humanitarian grounds and they would be given financial and medical assistance as well. The government would also find teachers willing to impart lessons to the kids, he said.

Title: Wanted: Counsellors for Puneâ€™s HIV-hit
article: PUNE: The naked truth of Pune city, with its estimated 30 lakh population: 1 per cent of the total young adult population (18 to 45 years) is HIV-positive; 50 per cent of the 6,000 commercial sex workers in the cityaâ„¢s red-light area are HIV-positive, and approximately 0.8 per cent of the total blood units collected by the 22 blood banks in the city is HIV-positive.,AIDS experts in the city say that these numbers could result in disturbing consequences unless effective intervention and awareness programmes are implemented on priority.,To begin with, some HIV experts say that a person whose blood has been found to be HIV-positive should be informed of this reality. According to Janakalyan blood bank director Dileep Wani, what the city desperately needs are voluntary counselling and testing centres (VCTCs) so that blood banks could refer HIV-positive donors to the VCTCs for proper counselling and diagnosis.,While one such centre is being planned at the B.J. medical college, currently there is not even a single centre in the city.Wani said that there has been an amendment in the national policy to inform donors about their HIV-positive status with comprehensive pre-test and post-test counselling and diagnosis from February 6, 2002.,City-based HIV/AIDS expert and Ruby Hall clinicaâ„¢s AIDS project director Sanjay Pujari said that personally he wanted that all HIV-positive blood donors should be informed about their status to curb the epidemic and bring about awareness.,However, Pujari said, there were number of complex issues involved, such as the absence of expertise for pre- and post-test counselling and diagnosis centres and the costs involved for the confirmatory testing.,Wani told TNN that of the 85,000 blood units collected by the 22 blood banks in the city, nearly 1.2 per cent was HIV-positive. aÅ“We discard infectious blood units by two methods a" physical method (autoclaving) and chemical method (sodium hypochloride solution).aï¿½,Pune City AIDS Control Society (PCACS) secretary and the municipal corporationaâ„¢s deputy health officer Dilip Pardeshi told TNN that during 2000-02 the prevalence of HIV-infected blood units collected from various blood banks was 1.5 per cent, which reduced to 0.8 per cent during 2002-03.,Testing of all blood units used in the blood banks for malaria, HIV, hepatitis-B and syphilis has been made mandatory all over the country.

Title: Fearful schools bar HIV positive children
article: BANGALORE: Seha, 9, wants to become a teacher. But this little girl cannot even go to school because she is carrying the deadly human immuno-deficiency virus (HIV), and has been denied admission by many schools in Bangalore, including government-aided ones. ,There are thousands of HIV-positive children like her in Karnataka, in the 5-16 age group. They are denied a good education, for there is a low level of awareness on AIDS and HIV among people. Sadly, a majority of these children have lost their parents to AIDS and have inherited the legacy of HIV. ,The Freedom Foundation, which is looking after some HIV-positive children, is exasperated over the attitude schools have adopted. "We approached both aided and unaided schools, but no one wants to take them," Ashok Rau, member of the National AIDS Control Organisation said. ,Some school managements got back to parentsaâ„¢ associations, which decided against admitting HIV-positive children. The children are at present studying in a Tamil-medium school in the city. But in fear. ,Commissioner for Public Instruction VP Baligar said the government will initiate action against schools that discriminate against children with HIV. "We have been telling school managements not to discriminate. Though no one has complained to us so far, if aided and government schools refuse admission, we will take direct action, including recommending disaffiliation. But we can only advise other schools not to discriminate," he said. ,School managements, however, prefer not to discuss the issue. "It is a sensitive subject. If HIV children seek admission, we have to necessarily get back to parents and seek their opinion too," the principal of a prominent school in the city said. ,As for the orphans, they feel ostracised by a society which blames them for no fault of theirs. "When I grow up, I will become a policeman and take to task all those who look down upon orphans like me," says Tushar, 13, from Mumbai, who lost both parents to AIDS. ,While Rani and Sreeja want to become computer engineers, Rishi wants to be a pilot and Sapna a doctor. Will their dreams remain just that?

Title: LIC considers insurance for HIV-infected women
article: MUMBAI: Life Insurance Corporation (LIC) will consider extending insurance cover to HIV-infected women under its newly introduced aËœJeevan Bharatiaâ„¢, a money back policy for women with critical illness benefits.,aÅ“We will need national level data on AIDS/HIV infection and relevant statistical information to take any decision on extending insurance cover to women affected by this disease,aï¿½ LIC chairman S.B.Mathur said here on Saturday during the launch of the policy on the occasion of International Womenaâ„¢s Day.,Studies relating to insurance coverage for HIV-infected persons were on in South Africa and aÅ“we will consider their findingsaï¿½, LICaâ„¢s appointed actuary N.S. Sastry said.,Mathur said LICaâ„¢s 1.6 lakh female agents would actively market the policy throughout the country. LIC executive director S.R. Krishnaswamy said the insurance major planned to sell one lakh policies with a premium income of Rs 100 crore in this year ending March 31. The policy is available to women in the age group of 18 to 50 years. The policyholder would get tax rebate under Section 88 of the Income Tax Act.,Free risk cover for basic sum assured for three years in case of premium defaults and option to receive maturity proceeds in annuity forms are other features of the policy. The plan offers accidental and disability benefits up to Rs 25 lakh.

Title: HIV/AIDS helpline by Bangalore University
article: BANGALORE: The Population Education Resource Centre (PERC), Bangalore University, in association with the United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA), is running a telephone helpline service for HIV/AIDS related information and adolescent problems.,Information, counselling on sexually transmitted diseases, reproductive and child health, emotional and adjustment problems or any other required help will be provided.,The telephone number of this services is 321 2548. The service is available from Monday to Friday between 10 am and 4 pm.

Title: Legal Cell to help HIV+ individuals
article: HYDERABAD: The right to education of a HIV-positive child, the contradictory HIV test results given for a one year-old child at three laboratories in the city and the refusal by hospitals to perform surgery on an HIV-positive person are some of the issues the newly-formed aËœLegal Cellaâ„¢ for HIV/Aids patients will take up.,The first Legal Cell exclusively for HIV-positive persons and Aids patients in the state was established at Bolarum by Freedom Foundation, a care and support centre for HIV-positive people. ,Talking about the basic rights denied to HIV-positive people, especially children, Freedom Foundation legal consultant Shirley Philip said last year two children a" six-year-old Kalvari and 10- year-old Chandana a" were denied admission in city schools when the managements were informed about their HIV status.,Though a public interest litigation was filed last year, the matter was still pending in courts. Freedom Foundation executive trustee Karl Sequeira said one of the purposes of setting up the cell was to ensure that the rights of HIV positive are not put on the backburner.,The Legal Cell will take up the issue of disparity in test results done at three leading laboratories in the city on a eleven-month-old girl recently. The PCR test results were contradictory, with one lab declaring the child to be HIV positive and others negative.,The Legal Cell was also considering sending notices to the Osmania General Hospital and Gandhi Hospital for not performing surgery on a HIV-positive patient from Karimnagar, Ravi.,However, after getting a letter from the state Aids Control Society director on Wednesday, the foundation was able to get him admitted in the Gandhi Hospital. According to Ravi, who is suffering from hydrocele, an ailment that results in fluid collection in the scrotum, both the hospitals at first refused to treat him. ,According to sources, the Legal Cell would only charge for the administrative cost, up to Rs 1,000 for those who could afford it and nothing for those who cannot pay.

Title: 65 Bihar children among HIV cases
article: PATNA: In spite of the widespread high-pitch campaign by the Bihar State Aids Control Society (BSACS) against unprotected and multi-partner sex, these accounted for a large majority of new Human Immuno Deficiency Virus (HIV) cases detected in the state last year.,According to official figures, unprotected, multi-partner sex accounted for 690 of the 894 HIV cases. The official figure is based on the data collected by 18 voluntary counselling and testing centres(VCTCs) operational till last year in the state. Of the total HIV cases, 285 were women. A senior official of the health department said the figure indicated that a large number of women had contacted the disease due to their low social and economic status and dependence on men. The official said that a majority of the HIV victims a" 668 out of 894 a" were in the age group of 20-39 years. Youths in the age group of 20-24 years accounted for 126 cases, those in 25-29 year age group for 214 cases and those in the 30-39 year age group for 328 HIV cases. Of the 542 HIV cases in 25-39 year age group, 165 were females. HIV, it may be recalled, destroys the immune system of the body.,The available figures reveal that children and teenagers have not escaped from the scourge of HIV. Sixtyfive children, including 21 females, below the age of 14 years tested HIV-positive in Bihar last year. It constituted 7.3 per cent of the total cases. Mother to child transmission accounted for 59 of these cases. The data compiled by BSACS revealed that 30 youths, including 15 females in the 15-19 years age group, had also tested HIV positive last year. Children in the O-19 year age group accounted for 10.6 per cent of the 894 HIV cases. Youths in the age group of 20-24 years, accounted for 126 cases, constituting 14.1 per cent of the total.,The official said that the number of VCTCs in Bihar had now increased to 20 and that 14 more VCTCs would be established by March-end. He said that the National Aids Control Organisation (Naco) released Rs 2.67 lakh annually to each VCTC. The official said that the VCTC located at Nalanda Medical College was being shifted to Nalanda Medical College Hospital.

Title: HIV cases cross 2,500-mark in state
article: PATNA: In all, 57 persons, including three children, have tested HIV positive during the last three months at the well-known pathological centre run here by Sen Diagnostics Private Ltd. One-third of these cases have developed symptoms of Aids.,The Sen Diagnostics centre has screened 282 suspected cases of HIV since December 2002. A majority of the HIV positive cases were in the age group of 20-50 years.,Sources in the health department said that out of 80 persons screened at the Sen Diagnostics centre in December last, 20 turned out to be HIV positive. In January this year, 61 persons were screened at the centre of which eight tested HIV positive. ,In February last, the centre screened 80 persons of which 17 tested HIV positive while 12 of the 61 cases screened during the current month have tested HIV positive, the sources added.,The chairman of Sen Diagnostics, Dr Dilip Sen, said on Friday that a majority of the persons testing HIV positive belonged to the lower middle class. ,Similarly, a majority of these persons had contracted the disease due to unprotected sex with sex workers either outside Bihar or within the state. ,In one case, the person concerned had contracted the disease during his visit abroad. He is a businessman. Mother-to-child transmission and transfusion of infected blood accounted for three cases each, Sen added.,A senior official of the Bihar State Aids Control Society said the Society would include the aforesaid HIV positive cases in the number of such cases detected in Bihar and send the same to the National Aids Control Organisation (Naco).,Replying to a query, the official admitted that the number of HIV positive cases detected so far in the state has crossed the 2,500 mark with unprotected multipartner sex accounting for more than 77.2 per cent of these cases. In 2002 alone, 894 persons had tested HIV positive in the state.,Meanwhile, the official figures for Aids continue to elude the state as Naco stopped releasing its monthly bulletin after September last. The Society official, however, admitted that the number of Aids cases increased to 162 till last month.

Title: Healthy diet will retard growth of HIV
article: NEW DELHI: A healthy diet may retard the growth of the deadly HIV and help the infected people live a better life by boosting their energy levels and immune system, two UN agencies said.,By strengthening the immune system and boosting energy levels, balanced nutrition could help the body defend against the ravages of the disease, WHO and Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) said in a joint manual. ,Those affected by HIV/AIDS need more protein to rebuild muscle tissue, more energy-rich food for weight gain, immune system-boosting vitamins and minerals and water to combat dehydration, the manual said adding despite blunted appetites and difficulties in eating, people living with HIV/AIDS need to eat considerable more food to fight the illness and make up for weight loss. ,Recognising the relationship between infection and nutrition, the manual offers simple and practical dietary suggestions for the estimated 42 million people living with HIV/AIDS, a US embassy release said.,Developing countries which are home to about 95 per cent of people with HIV/AIDS do not have adequate healthcare resources to fight the disease. So the best way for them to respond to the illness is to maintain as balanced a diet as possible, director of the FAO''s Food and Nutrition Division Kraisid Tontisirin said.,"The nutritional aspect of HIV/AIDS has been ignored for a long time. The attention was always focussed on drugs," Tontisirin said. ,"Food isn''t a magic bullet. It won''t stop people dying of AIDS...But it can help them live longer, more comfortable and more productive lives," William Clay of FAO''s Food and Nutrition Division said.,The report says that AIDS creates a vicious circle of physical decay - the disruption of nutrient absorption suppresses the appetite and metabolism that leads to a deterioration of muscles, organs and tissues, thereby creating a susceptibility to secondary infections and other stresses that increase bodily demands for energy and nutrients that can''t be absorbed. ,"The relationship between HIV/AIDS and malnutrition is a particularly extreme example of the vicious circle of immune dysfunction, infectious disease and malnutrition," WHO executive director for Sustainable Development and Healthy Environments Dr David Nabarro said.,The manual focuses on ways of easing the symptoms of HIV/AIDS such as lack of appetite, tiredness, soreness of mouth by suggesting recipes for soups, teas and stews using fruit and vegetables that grow in the rural areas of the developing world. ,"We hope this guide will be a building block, that it will be adapted by AIDS-affected communities and that it will make people aware of the vital role played by nutrition for someone living with HIV or AIDS," Clay added.

Title: HIV cases add to TB burden
article: BANGALORE: The World Tuberculosis Day was observed on Monday with a mandatory public function to highlight the TB control programme a" at the SDS TB and Rajiv Gandhi Institute of Chest Diseases.,Despite the brave front put up by medical experts, the battle against one of mankindaâ„¢s oldest scourges is still only half won. The Revised New Tuberculosis Control Programme introduced in 1998 has been effective in controlling TB but little over 50 per cent of population in Karnataka has been covered by it.,With HIV/AIDS cases increasing, there are signs the TB burden is increasing simultaneously, say experts. aÅ“With the prevalence of HIV/AIDS, chances of extra pulmonary TB cases increasing are high,aâ„¢aâ„¢ says Dr Prahlad Kumar, director, National Tuberculosis Institute.,aÅ“HIV will add to the TB burden,aâ„¢aâ„¢ says Dr Shashidhar Buggi, Superintendent, SDS TB and Rajiv Gandhi Institute of Chest Diseases. In Bangalore, according to the corporation a" which implements RNTCP programme a" the number of TB cases detected has almost trebled from 1,743 in 1999 to 4,464 in 2002.,Unlike in 1999 when only 70 per cent of patients were being cured, currently 87 per cent of patients are being cured, thanks to RNTCP treatment, where patients have to undergo medication under supervision.,aÅ“A few years ago, we did not have resources - drugs, staff, infrastructure - to tackle TB. Now, thanks to international funds, we have plenty,aâ„¢aâ„¢ says Dr Prahlad.,aÅ“RNTCP has helped detect more cases. Another indication that RNTCP is working well is drop in TB hospitalisation from 90 per cent to 70 per cent,aâ„¢aâ„¢ says Dr Buggi. The RNTCP with the directly observed treatment system (DOTS) was introduced following discontinuation of treatment by patients leading to fears of emergence of drug-resistant varieties of TB bacteria.,There are plans to expand RNTCP to allow private clinics, hospitals, general practitioners, medical colleges to participate as patients treated in these places are not drafted into the DOTS/RNTCP treatment system.,aÅ“One great aspect of the RNTCP is it is effective even in curing HIV-related tuberculosis,aâ„¢aâ„¢ says Dr Prahlad. Incidentally, nearly 40 per cent of general population carry the TB bacteria. However, only 10 per cent develop the disease. Since HIV suppresses the immune system, the disease incidence tends to increase.

Title: An effort to stamp out HIV stigma
article: VIJAYAWADA: When she first visited Kandrika and Rajiv Nagar on the outskirts of Vijayawada to study the plight of HIV carriers, P Deeksha had to return empty-handed as none of the families came forward to share any information.,Knowing fully well that these localities were HIVendemic, Deeksha did not give up. She made repeated visits to the colonies with a team of five volunteers. Gradually, the HIV-affected families opened up to her.,A dermatologist by profession, Deeksha comes from the Gora family, known for its social service activities. Once she had the information she wanted, she launched the Care and Support programme at Kandrika and Rajiv Nagar with the intention of removing the social stigma attached to HIVaffected. It was a demanding mission.,Once they got to know more about the dreaded virus, the victims and their families were prepared to counselled. aÅ“The counselling programme helped us remove the stigma, and now more than 200 HIV carriers are undergoing medical treatment offered by us,aâ„¢aâ„¢ Deeksha told The Times India.,Deeksha built a strong volunteer network involving Development of Women and Children in Rural Areas group women. She also formed a peer education system which the victims themselves counsel others. Based on success of her efforts, Deeksha later took up a similar work with street children Vijayawada by initiating HIV\STD prevention programme.,aÅ“Our project also includes skill development programmes for street children and finding them the right kind of jobs,aâ„¢aâ„¢ Deeksha explained.,Another major task Deeksha has undertaken relates to the aid of police torture victims who are rehabilitated through income-generating activities.

Title: Media insensitive to HIV patients: NGO members
article: KOLKATA: aÅ“Insensitivityaï¿½ of the media in the coverage of HIV/AIDS issues was the prime grouse of NGOs working with HIV-positive people at a panel discussion in the city on Wednesday.,Many of them felt the media aÅ“unnecessarilyaï¿½ oversimplified and over-sensationalised the issues.,The discussion accompanied an ongoing exhibition of photographs at the Indian Museum showing haunting images of people living with HIV/AIDS. The travelling exhibition, Positive Lives, has come to India for the first time.,aÅ“We are undertaking a unique exercise to make the exhibition as interactive as possible,aï¿½ said Apne Aap Worldwide executive director Ruchira Gupta. The exhibition has been brought to India by Apne Aap which seeks to end sex trafficking and Drik India, a network of photographers. According to some NGO activists, the media hound those affected with HIV/AIDS and try to rake up their past lives.,aÅ“These people are trying to lead as normal lives as possible and it is not fair to keep on interrogating them about how and why they contracted the disease,aï¿½ said a representative of Sanlaap, which has a rehabilitation home for trafficked and HIV-positive women.,The media were also said to be insensitive about revealing names of victims. aÅ“Each media house should have a code of conduct, created at a common forum where there are representatives of NGOs, affected persons and the media. This should be adhered to,aï¿½ felt a member of Sparsha, a group working with positive people.,Social activist Shabnam Hashmi felt NGOs and other such organisations should encourage those affected to come out and spread awareness about the disease.

Title: Gates Foundation's anti-HIV project to begin this year
article: HYDERABAD: The Frontiers HIV Prevention Programme (FPP), funded by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation and implemented by the International HIV/AIDS Alliance, is scheduled to commence in the state during the last quarter of this year.,The Andhra Pradesh State AIDS Control Society (APSACS), the nodal agency in the state, will oversee the project and will be intimated as and when interventions are taken up. Lepra India, an NGO that is in the process of collecting baseline data for this project, will be the implementing and coordinating agency in the state, the health department officials said.,Strengthening of intervention capabilities of local non-governmental organisations and community-based organisations in specific geographical areas, identified as high HIV transmission areas in the state, will be done under the project.,aËœKey populationsaâ„¢ in these identified sites -commercial sex workers, people living with HIV and AIDS, men who have sex with men and injecting drug users - will be made aware of HIV and sexually transmitted infections.,The transformation under the FPP is aimed at key populations expressing hope or desire to avoid infecting others with HIV or sexually transmitted infections (STIs), developing skills to reduce risk of HIV and STI transmission and becoming motivated to use sexual health services.,The FPP, which is using the phrase aËœempowerment for preventionaâ„¢, will also emphasise the importance of ensuring an enabling environment for HIV prevention and accessibility of related services.,The key hypothesis of the FPP programme is that the empowerment of key populations in a aËœrelativelyaâ„¢ low prevalence environment, will not only reduce the spread of HIV among the aËœkey populationaâ„¢, but will also slows the spread of HIV more widely.,Individually focussed health promotion to support the empowerment will include, focussed information, education and communication (IEC) activities on HIV, AIDS, STIs and sexual health. Educational theatre, pamphlet distribution, video shows and one-onone discussions will also be part of the focussed health promotions.

Title: Gates to foot the Bill for state HIV projects?
article: BANGALORE: Karnataka may soon be a beneficiary in sharing the $100-million aid announced by Microsoft giant Bill Gates for HIV/AIDs projects in India.,The Bill Gates Foundation has deputed two teams to study HIV/AIDs prevalence in the state.Karnataka is one of the high-risk states. The team has held two meetings with state health department officials to work out modalities.,aÅ“With Karnataka being one of the six high-risk states, we have outlined our requirements to the foundation. They are in the process of preparing a project design for Karnataka,aâ„¢aâ„¢ Karnataka State AIDS Prevention Society (KSAPS) director Vandana Gurnani told The Times of India. Official estimates put the number of HIV positive persons in Karnataka at 5 lakh.,In January, 750 people tested HIV positive; so far, 186 persons have died of AIDS. KSAPS, headed by chief minister S.M. Krishna, has found HIV prevalence high among young women in the state. Over 70 per cent of the women with HIV in care and support homes are housewives, abandoned and isolated by their families.,Low age of marriage (in rural areas), limited control over fertility, economic dependence coupled with illiteracy are some of the factors making women with HIV more vulnerable than her male counterpart, says the KSAPS surveillance report released last week. Take the case of Meena (27) from Harihar, who married a truck driver and contracted the virus.,aÅ“My family began to blame me for my husbandaâ„¢s death and accused me of spreading the virus. I have put my children in a hostel because I am not sure of surviving,aâ„¢aâ„¢ She is staying at the Freedom Foundation, a care centre for HIV patients.,Left with little children to support and widowed two years after marriage, HIV-afflicted Reema (23) assumes the role of breadwinner for the family. aÅ“I have lost my eye-sight too. I hope my parents take care of my children.aâ„¢aâ„¢,Following the surveillance which has exposed vulnerability of women afflicted with the disease, KSAPS has begun using folk media to generate awareness in villages.,aÅ“These troupes have been trained by song and drama division of the publicity department. Each district has a troupe which performs in villages to educate women on HIV and AIDS,aâ„¢aâ„¢ Gurnani added.

Title: Circumcision deters HIV spread: USAID
article: WASHINGTON: Circumcised men are at least 50 per cent less likely to contract the virus that causes AIDS during unprotected sex than uncircumcised men, according to a soon-to-be released report by the US Agency for International Development.,The Agency (USAID) said that this conclusion is based on a systematic review of 28 scientific studies by the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, the Washington Times reports.,"A sub analysis of 10 African studies" said USAID, "found a 71 per cent reduction among higher risk men".,Anne Peterson, Assistant Administrator for Global Health at USAID, said: "There is really an incredible preponderance of evidence. There is really a strong association between circumcision and HIV protection".,According to the scientific studies, the skin on the inside of the male foreskin is "mucosal," similar to the skin found on the inside of the mouth or nose. This mucosal skin has a high number of Langerhan cells, which are HIV target cells, or doorway cells for HIV. The rest of the skin on the penis is more like the outer skin of the rest of the body, a barrier that protects against germs. ,Edward G Green, senior researcher at Harvard University who has been looking at circumcision and HIV in Africa for 10 years, said that it is better to be circumcised as a baby than as a teenager in a "rite-of-passage" ceremony, because many teenage boys in Africa are already sexually active. ,Green said that if all males in Africa were circumcised, the HIV/AIDS prevalence rate could be reduced from 20 per cent in some regions to below five per cent.

Title: Circumcision deters HIV spread: USAID
article: WASHINGTON: Circumcised men are at least 50 per cent less likely to contract the virus that causes AIDS during unprotected sex than uncircumcised men, according to a soon-to-be released report by the US Agency for International Development.,The Agency (USAID) said that this conclusion was based on a systematic review of 28 scientific studies by the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, the Washington Times reported.,"A sub-analysis of 10 African studies" said USAID, "found a 71 per cent reduction among higher risk men.",Anne Peterson, assistant administrator for Global Health at USAID, said: "There is really an incredible preponderance of evidence. There is realy a strong association between circumcision and HIV protection.",According to the scientific studies, the skin on the inside of the male foreskin is "mucosal," similar to the skin found on the inside of the mouth or nose. This mucosal skin has a high number of Langerhan cells, which are HIV target cells, or doorway cells for HIV. The rest of the skin on the penis is more like the outer skin of the rest of the body, a barrier that protects against germs. ,Edward G Green, senior researcher at Harvard University who has been looking at circumcision and HIV in Africa for 10 years, said that it was better to be circumcised as a baby than as a teenager in a "rite-of-passage" ceremony, because many teenage boys in Africa were already sexually active. ,Green said that if all males in Africa were circumcised, the HIV/AIDS prevalence rate could be reduced from 20 per cent in some regions to below 5 per cent.

Title: Alang ship-breakers face AIDS-wreck with 38 HIV cases
article: ALANG (BHAVNAGAR): Alang, Asiaaâ„¢s biggest ship-breaking yard, could be sitting on a ticking AIDS bomb, waiting to explode. There are so far 75 confirmed HIV cases reported at Bhavnagaraâ„¢s Sir T Hospital, the only voluntary counselling and testing centre in the district. And, the agencies active in Alang-Sosiya yard have identified 38 HIV cases from Alang alone.,Dr Niloo Vaishnav, chairman of Bhavnagar blood bank, which runs Project Aids Alang (PAA) with the help of Gujarat State Aids Control Society (GSACS) says, aÅ“The incidence of HIV cases is very high in Alang. Of the 3,500 people who have come for voluntary blood testing in the last four years, nearly 38 of them have tested positive.aï¿½,According to GSACS officials, the cases recorded with them are only those tested at government hospitals and the final figure could certainly be much higher.,Dr Vaishnav said on the basis of these statistics, a projection report carried out by an AIDS expert from New York-based Albert Einstein School of Medicine, showed that the prevalence of the infection could be as high as 5 per cent in Alang. This is perhaps the highest prevalence of HIV anywhere in Gujarat.,Alang has a population of around 40,000 male migrant labourers coming from Orissa, Bihar, Uttar Pradesh and West Bengal. Most of them leave their families behind to come here to earn a living. Also, almost all of them belong to the sexually active age group of 18-45 a" around 39 per cent are between 18-25 years and 46 per cent belong to the 25-45 age bracket.,aÅ“The problem is compounded by the fact that there are very few women in the area. This makes the area even more trouble-prone as far as passing the infection is concerned,aï¿½ says Mahesh Jani, project officer of PAA.,According to him, besides a high occurrence of multiple partner sexual activity, unorganised prostitution and rampant homosexuality too are the important factors.,aÅ“It has been observed that sex workers from surrounding villages come here, many of them under the pretext of selling vegetables, fruits and other goods. But this is just a camouflage for their illegal activity,aï¿½ says Jani. According to a rough estimate, around 7.5 per cent people who have come for voluntary blood tests suffer from Sexually Transmitted Diseases (STD). The STDclinic in Alang gets around 50-55 patients every week.,According to Y P Deulkar, port officer, besides spreading awareness, the authorities should be given more teeth to curb prostitution. aÅ“The area supposed to be guarded is a huge 10 square miles, which is difficult with the existing number of hands,aï¿½ he says. The police station too does not have more than half-a-dozen personnel.,However, officials of the GSACS maintain that use of force will only worsen the situation. aÅ“The situation could have been very bad without timely intervention of the concerned agencies. But at present, it is not alarming. The incidence of HIV positive cases surely is high in Alang, but the use of force will only destroy the rapport which we have created with the affected people and some sex workers over a period of time,aï¿½ says Dr D M Saxena, additional project director, GSACS.,The society is planning to start an aËœEnabling Environment Projectaâ„¢ in Alang along with 10 other centres. aÅ“The programme funded by United Nations Development Programme aims at helping the affected,aï¿½ says R B Deshmukh, project director, GSACS.

Title: Hospital goes without HIV test kits
article: HYDERABAD: A woman who had been admitted at the Gandhi Hospital on Thursday was asked to go to a private clinic on Friday to undergo HIV and HBs tests as the hospital reportedly did not have the kits to conduct the tests.,However, the woman, Visala, 22, could not afford to pay for the tests which cost Rs 300 and continues to be admitted in the hospital awaiting the microbiology department of the hospital to acquire the required kits.,Visala, from Arkaram village in Medak was admitted with burns and as a routine procedure was asked to undergo a HIV and HBs test. It was then she was referred to a private diagnostic centre.

Title: Vadodara has 6,000 HIV positive cases
article: VADODARA: If India has approximately about 40 lakh HIV positive cases, Vadodara has a startling 6,000 cases, according to a recent survey conducted by a state government-funded project. Gujarat, being an industrially-developed state, is highly vulnerable to AIDS owing to its floating population, mostly comprising of migrant labourers, said Dr Yogesh Marfatia, a skin specialist, during a training programme for doctors organised by the People's Training and Research Centre. The alarming number of HIV cases is an indication that only a negligible portion of the population in the city practices safe sex, he said. Unless we control sexuallytransmitted diseases, we can't contain the spread of HIV, Marfatia said, adding that a decade ago, the city did not have even a single case of HIV. PTRC, a voluntary organisation, is working towards prevention of HIV among industrial workers in the city. PTRC workers have so far mapped about 10,000 workers in the industrial belt of Makarpura. Industrial workers are among the high risk groups for HIV like truck drivers, commercial sex workers, migrants, etc. We have identified about 15 slum pockets in the Makarapura area, where we conduct awareness and health camps, said Suresh Parmar, a project officer. Training of medical professionals from all streams â€” be it ayurveda, homoeopathy or allopathy â€” we are providing a wider choice to industry workers for whom treatment is never affordable. The latest strategy is to have a single approach to tackle all endemic diseases, including the sexually-transmitted diseases (STDs), said PTRC director Jagdish Patel.

Title: BCC doctors aid HIV women deliver
article: BANGALORE: When the occasion demands, it is the BCC medical staff who show they have a heart. Here is some positive proof. At a time when private nursing homes shun pregnant women who test HIV-positive, BCC hospital doctors delivered babies of four HIV-positive women over the last four months. Proving critics wrong, they have gone about their jobs, and without media fanfare too. The BCC has initiated HIV awareness programmes and roped in Freedom Foundation, an NGO working with HIV patients. Free counselling centres have been set up at the BCC's three referral hospitals â€” on Siddaiah Road, Ulsoor and Hosahalli. The 'special cases' were delivered in Ulsoor and Siddaiah Road hospitals. Now, blood samples of all pregnant women are tested. If found HIV-positive, the women are counselled. We have trained our medical staff to handle such patients,'' additional health officer, east, Dr M. Vijaylakshmi, said. Medical staff use universal precautions to avoid coming in contact with the patient's blood or body fluids â€” they wear double gloves, glasses, cap, mask and gum boots. The linen is disposed of after the delivery. Since all were normal deliveries, there was no problem. Even the Class 4 employees cooperated,'' Dr Vijaylakshmi said. Before delivery, the women were administered anti-retroviral drug to prevent mother-to-child transmission of HIV. Later, the infants were subjected to C-reactive protein test. All babies tested HIV-negative. I personally attended the first case at Ulsoor. It was a great feeling. All our staff wished for was a normal delivery, and rejoiced to know the babies were normal, Dr Vijaylakshmi said. While the mothers were advised not to breast-feed the newborns, one woman opted for it. Tests are being conducted on the child, who is under observation. All laboratory investigations are funded by the Freedom Foundation and patients are not charged. We do not make it known to patients about their co-patient's status, nor do we isolate her. Only during the delivery, we take extra precautions,'' stressed additional health officer, south, Dr D.L. Nagaratna. Three HIV-positive pregnant patients are now waiting at Ulsoor hospital.

Title: Gates Foundation aid will target high-risk HIV groups
article: NEW DELHI: The 100 million dollar Gates Foundation grant to reduce HIV transmission in India will be primarily used to address high-risk groups in the 100 `high prevalence' districts. The disbursal of the money will begin from July. Laying down a road map for an effective utilisation of the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation assistance, director, India AIDS Initiative, Ashok Alexander, told Times News Network that the Foundation has worked on a programme of action that is scaled, focussed and integrated and could well present a new model on prevention. The Foundation would work with a district focus as also have a national highway programme. To begin with, it has identified two partners -- the Indian Oil Corporation and the Trucking Corporation of India. Alexander said the IOC, with 2,000 retail outlets on highways would provide the points for communication as well as treatment for sexually transmitted infections. The Trucking Corporation of India, again with a tremendous reach all over India, would provide 50 to 75 halting points for trucks where interventions could be reached. The Foundation would help set up mobile clinics for treatment of STI and also create a national STI franchise whereby quacks could be encouraged to refer people to MBBS doctors. Alexander said while the AIDS virus may have moved into the general population, there was still a need to focus on the high risk groups, such as commercial sex workers, intravenous drug users, truck drivers and other identifiable clients of sex workers. He said the high-risk groups had still not been sufficiently covered. As for not going to states where the infection rates are still not known to be high, Alexander said, ``we're not leaving them out. We're just deferring them by six months or so. We need to have some research on these states so as to have intelligence on how to approach them.'' Alexander said the epidemic in India is still localised with about 100 odd districts which account for about 70 per cent of the infection. The populations most at risk are identiable and so are the national highways around which the infection rates are high. And even as the Foundation has yet to decide on most of its partners, Alexander said, the funds would be monitored very closely. ``We will bring sound private sector nations and termination of contracts where partners are found not performing.'' As for monitoring, a third party, ``highly credible'' will be engaged. The aim eventually is to create a programme based on Indian ownership and an Indian face. Alexander said the Foundation hoped that the Indian corporates and Indian NGOs would take this programme forward. A special focus in this intiative, therefore, would be to include ``Indians for India'' where ``high-potential'' graduates with an interest in HIV and development would be encouraged to take up work.

Title: High percentage of Sura's sex workers have HIV
article: SURAT: Around 43.2 per cent of sex workers were found to have sero-prevalence of HIV or were HIV positive, according to a recent study. The findings were on the basis of a cross sectional study among sex workers in a health camp over a period in the year 2000. The study was conducted by the department of community medicine, Government Medical College in Surat, under a project sponsored by Department for International Development (DFID) of the UK. Though the HIV tests were done secretly through administration of behavioural questionnaire followed by clinical examination of sexually transmitted infections (STIs), laboratory tests were conducted over a period of time from February 2000 to September 2000 after obtaining the consent of the participants, report said. Out of 600 sex workers in the red-light area, 124 in the age group of 16 to 50 â€” with about two-thirds being below 30 â€” opted for clinical tests, the report revealed. Notably, among the sex workers in the red-light area here, three were locals, over 33 per cent were reported to be from Nepal and the rest had migrated from other states, the report said. In all, over 80 per cent were illiterate, and about 95 per cent reported to use condoms during sex. The range in the number of different partners per day varied from two to 25, the mean being five clients per day in each case, according to the report. Since sex workers being one of the core groups for transmission of STDs (sexually transmitted diseases) and HIV as a 'bridge group' to the general population, a comprehensive intervention is being focussed on, said Dr Vikas Desai of department of community medicine in the Government Medical College here. "We had some data base on a survey done in 1992 which has been effective as a baseline for the prevention of STDs and HIV among sex workers," she forwarded. HIV cases have been on increase here, but source of transmission by the sex workers or by the clients need to be examined thoroughly for a comprehensive intervention, she said. For the purpose of creating awareness, 17 peer educators and about 34 link workers have been working among the sex workers. Even through social marketing for distribution of condoms have been intensified, but due to lack of adequate trained manpower along with proper financial resources, the intervention for the targeted group is yet not up to the mark, she said. Though the report was based on the targeted group of sex workers in the redlight area here, but no such surveys have been conducted in the case of over an estimated 5,000 sex workers operating from different parts of the city, Desai said. Many of them, in fact, come from Mumbai on regular basis, she said. The World Health Organisation (WHO) has emphasised on a syndromic approach for case measurement and management, particularly in high prevalence areas with inadequate resources for surveys, according to Dr H Thakore who works for WHO and had been associated with this report. For continuation of prevention among the HIV positive cases, a similar one-year project has been sponsored by the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), Thakore informed. Interestingly, one wellequipped voluntary counselling and testing centre (VCTC) at the New Civil Hospital here is functional since January, 2000, but even services being free-ofcost, hardly anyone other than those referral cases, come here, Desai said. Even toll free number 1097 for free tele-counselling at the hospital has been without much of use, she informed.

Title: Police cannot force HIV tests: Judge
article: NOIDA: Upholding a revision petition filed by a Noida physician, former Gautam Budh Nagar district judge Allah Reham had, on July 7, 2001, ruled that a dozen women arrested for alleged prostitution in "massage parlours" could not be forced to under HIV tests. Noida's Sector 20 police station, which arrested 8 women in allegedly similar circumstances on May 15, has again sought that the accused take HIV tests. Their bail applications were disposed of because the Noida police has not provided an escort for the accused to be taken to the district hospital. Dasna Jail official, Rajbir Singh, confirmed that a Noida magistrate had directed jail authorities to get HIV tests done for the accused. We have asked the Noida police to provide an escort."

Title: HIV high among Surat sex workers
article: SURAT: A staggering 43.2 per cent of sex workers in Surat have seroprevalence of HIV or are HIV-positive. These are the findings of a cross-sectional study of sex workers in a health camp in 2000, conducted by the Department of Community Medicine, Government Medical College in Surat, under a project sponsored by the Department for International Development (DFID) of the UK. Though the HIV tests were done secretly through behavioural questionnaires followed by clinical examination of sexually-transmitted infections (STIs), laboratory tests were conducted over a period of eight months, after obtaining the consent of the participants. Out of 600 sex workers in the red-light areas, 124 in the age-group of 16 to 50 â€” with about two-thirds being below 30 â€” opted for clinical tests, the report said. Notably, among the sex workers in the red-light areas, only three were locals. Over 33 per cent were reported to be from Nepal and the rest had migrated from other states, the report said. In all, over 80 per cent of them were illiterate. Ninety-five per cent claimed that they used condoms during sex. The number of partners varied between two and 25 per day, stated the report. Sex workers are one of the 'core groups' for transmission of STDs (sexually-transmitted diseases) to the general population. They form a 'bridge group' for the transmission of HIV. For the purpose of creating awareness, 17 peer educators and about 34 link workers have been working among the sex workers.

Title: 'Diya' children's HIV-care struggles to remain afloat
article: HYDERABAD: The first specialised care centre for HIV-positive children in the state, Diya, is struggling to cater to the increasing number of children arriving at its doors.,The centre has 20 beds and takes care of as many HIV-positive children. With two more children, one from Bellary, expected by Friday, the centre will have more children than it can handle. The centre was established by the Freedom Foundation at Bolarum in November last.,With hardly any support from the government, Freedom Foundationaâ„¢s executive trustee Karl Sequeira is worried. aÅ“It is high time the government realised that HIV-positive children need specialised care as their needs, including diet, medicines and recreation, are different from those of HIV-positive adults,aï¿½ he said.,The Andhra Pradesh State Aids Control Society (Apsacs) sponsors 10 beds at the Freedom Foundationaâ„¢s HIV and Aids Centre for Adults at Bolarum. Freedom Foundation has 40 patients, including the 20 children.,The childrenaâ„¢s centre has infants as young as four months, many of them orphans. These orphans cannot be turned away and once admitted they have to be at Diya for a few years.,aÅ“It is time the government established or at least supported such specialised centres before it is too late,aï¿½ Sequeira warned.,The Apsacs shells out only Rs 8,000 a month, while it costs the centre nearly Rs 50,000 for three doctors it employs. Moreover, the Rs 75 per day allotted per patient for medicine is insufficient when the patient falls sick.

Title: J&K mulls law for HIV tests on tourists
article: SRINAGAR: Concerned over the increase in HIV positive cases in Jammu and Kashmir, the state government intends to bring a legislation for carrying out HIV tests on tourists arriving in the state.,Health Minister Choudhary Lal Singh told the state Assembly that 24,000 HIV positive cases had been detected in the state and of them 1,200 were in the age group of 12-24. ,"We are happy with the arrival of tourists, but we must not get carried away by the tourism economy. We will have to take necessary steps to prevent the increase of AIDS cases in the state," he said, adding government intended to bring a legislation for conducting HIV tests on tourists.,Mere holding of stage shows for creating awareness against AIDS would not do, he said, adding care should be taken to address the problem at the grassroots level.,Replying to debate on the demands for grants for his ministry, Singh said that Jammu and Kashmir rated as the third best state in the country in the health care sector as per a recent survey. ,Singh termed the purchasing committees set up at various levels to purchase the medicines for the hospitals as a group of mafia, who had been looting the state exchequer. In the last financial year they caused the state exchequer a loss of Rs 15 crore, he said.,Singh said that his government was committed to set up a corporation for purchasing quality drugs and material from standard firms.,Announcing launching of a health card scheme for children in the state, Singh said that the scheme had been introduced from Baramulla. Even legislators would be given health cards that would be supplied to them on the last day of the current session.,The Health Minister announced that while Jammu would soon get a dental college, post-graduate course in dentistry would be introduced in Srinagar Dental College along with increasing the BDS seats by 50.,Later, the House passed the grants amounting to Rs 4,991,425,000 for the year 2003-04 for health sector.

Title: Patna tops the list of HIV-positive cases
article: PATNA: If the results of the tests conducted at 16 voluntary testing and counselling centres (VCTCs) opened by Bihar State Aids Control Society (BSACS) are any indication, Patna district tops the list of people testing HIV-positive.,Of the 1,397 persons testing HIV-positive at these centres between January 2001 and April 2003, 398 persons belonged to Patna district followed by East Champaran district with 185 HIV-positive persons while Darbhanga and Muzaffarpur districts accounted for 127 and 112 HIV-positive cases respectively.,The break-up for the other districts is: Vaishali 78, Nalanda 66, Gaya 63, Begusarai 44, Saran 41, Samastipur 37, Bhagalpur 31, Sitamarhi 30, Jehanabad 23, Bhojpur 21, Katihar 19, Madhubani 17, Siwan 15, Lakhisarai 11, Gopalganj 11, Nawada 8, Aurangabad 7, Khagaria 7, Buxar 7, Araria 6, Rohtas 6, West Champaran 5, Sheikhpura 5, Sheohar 4, Jamui 4, Munger 4, Banka 3, Purnia 3, Madhepura 2, Arwal 1, Kaimur 1 and Supaul 1.,A senior official of the health department said that the VCTCs had succeeded in their objective. He said that between January 2001 and April 2003, as many as 13,563 people were counselled at these 16 centres, of which 12,132 underwent test.,Of the 1,397 persons testing HIV-positive, 884 had tested positive at the four VCTCs located at Rajendra Memorial Research Institute (RMRI-652), Nalanda Medical College Hospital (NMCH-25)), Patna Medical College Hospital (PMCH-162) and Kurji Holy Family Hospital (45) in Patna, a BSACS official said. He said that so far 3,365 persons had undergone test at the VCTC located at RMRI while 2,967 persons underwent such test at the Kurji Hospital and 1,353 at the PMCH centre. ,The official said that an analysis of the pre-test assessment data from RMRI revealed that majority of people testing HIV-positive were migrants and got the infection through the sexual route.,The BSACS began VCTC services in the state in the year 2001 by establishing a centre at RMRI. Since then the NACO has sanctioned 34 VCTCs in the state, the BSACS official said, adding that 21 of these centres had become functional. Results of the test conducted at the remaining five centres were, however, not yet available as all of them were new centres. The BSACS official said that these centres were very important from the point of view of prevention of HIV infection and providing care and support to those already infected.,The BSACS official said that the high cost of up to Rs 300 charged for the HIV test at private clinics and lack of counselling services discouraged people from going in for testing. The official said that at the VCTCs, this test was being conducted at Rs 10 each only while counselling was provided free of cost and people were encouraged to opt for the test voluntarily.

Title: Law to punish HIV-positive grooms sought
article: HYDERABAD: The Andhra Pradesh government has, on the advice of its womenaâ„¢s commission, asked for an amendment of the Indian Penal Code, to severely penalise people who marry without telling their partners if theyaâ„¢re infected by the HIV virus.,The proposal has been sent to the National AIDS Control Organisation (NACO) of the Union health ministry. After NACOaâ„¢s comments, the proposal will have to be converted into a formal legislation and put before Parliament by the Union government.,A dozen cases have come to the notice of the AP Womenaâ„¢s Commission, where marriages have been fixed without the bride knowing that the groom has been infected by HIV. She comes to know this only when she is herself infected by her husband. Later, when he dies, her in-laws refuse to keep her at home and also take control of her property.,The only punishment under the IPC at present are the two sections (269 and 270) on punishment for those who aËœaËœmalignantlyaâ„¢aâ„¢ do something which spreads a life-threatening infection. The punishment specified is a fine, with/or jail term for up to six months in one case and up to two years in the other. The AP Womenaâ„¢s Commission is proposing jail up to 10 years and also punishing those who act only aËœwilfullyaâ„¢ in spreading the infection.

Title: Ranbaxy gets nod to market anti-HIV drug
article: BOMBAY: India''s top drug maker by sales, Ranbaxy Laboratories, has got an approval from the US Federal Drug Administration to manufacture and market anti-HIV drug ''ganciclovir'', the Bombay Stock Exchange said on Monday.,It said the approval was for 250 mg and 500 mg capsules of ''ganciclovir''.

Title: Law to get tougher for HIV cheats
article: HYDERABAD: With scores of cases of women unknowingly getting married to HIV+ men coming to light, the state government plans to amend two sections of the Indian Penal Code to make punishment for the guilty more severe.,Several cases have come to the notice of the Andhra Pradesh Womenaâ„¢s Commission where the women were kept in the dark about their spousesaâ„¢ HIV+ status. The truth came out only when the women themselves tested positive.Worse still, following their husbandaâ„¢s death, many were thrown out of their houses and their property grabbed by the in-laws.,The culprits have been let off lightly until now, as punishments under sections 269 and 270 of the IPC have not been deterrent enough. aÅ“To deter people from wilfully and unlawfully spreading the virus, the commission has proposed amendments to both the sections,aï¿½ commissionaâ„¢s chairperson C Susheela Devi said. Under Section 269 IPC, the guilty are imprisoned for only six months or imposed a fine or both.,The proposed amendment to this extends the term of imprisonment to ten years and also a fine.,Section 270 IPC punishes the guilty with imprisonment for a term which may extend to two years or with fine or with both. This may be amended to imprisonment for life or for a term which may extend to ten years and also a fine.,The state government has sent the proposal to the National Aids Control Organisation for comments following which it will be made a bill and would be put before the Assembly, a health department official said. Once the bill is approved by the assembly, it will be forwarded to the Centre for ratification.

Title: J&K has 24,000 HIV-infected people: Minister
article: SRINAGAR: Jammu and Kashmir Health Minister Choudary Lal Singh has said that there were around 24,000 HIV positive cases detected in the state, 50 per cent of which were in the age group of 15-35 years.,Inaugurating a three-day training programme on AIDS here, the minister held politicians and bureaucrats responsible for "sexual adventurism" and exploiting the fair sex of the state. ,Singh said that the government was thinking of passing a legislation to introduce AIDS awareness as a compulsory subject in the school curricula. ,He cautioned that if the society did not wake up to the fact that up-holding inherited values and moral teachings were the only prevention against the deadly disease, the state would face disaster.,Lamenting over the fast degradation of morals in the state, the health minister said, "some politicians and bureaucrats having licentious tendencies were indulging in sexual adventurism and exploiting the fair sex in Jammu and Kashmir.",He suggested enactment of stringent laws to check such practice in the state.

Title: 40 lakh afflicted with HIV: Expert
article: RANCHI: About 40 lakh people in the country are afflicted with HIV virus and the disease is in an epidemic form in Maharashtra, Tamil Nadu, Karnataka, Nagaland and Andhra Pradesh, said S M Afsar, national programme co-ordinator of International Labour Organisation (ILO).,Speaking at a workshop on prevention of HIV/Aids in the world of work, he said that HIV virus is spreading fast in rural areas from urban, with majority of the victims being men. ,The workshop was organised jointly by the Central Board for Workers'' Education, ministry of labour, Union government, Jharkhand State Aids Control Society and International Labour Organisation.,Afsar said though Aids proves fatal sooner or later, it does not mean immediate death. With proper management, an HIV-positive person may survive for between eight and ten years. He stated that lack of awareness is the main reason of this disease. Describing the role of ILO at workplace, Afsar said that the organisation is working as an agency for providing technical tools and materials to state Aids control societies and NGOs working for Aids awareness programme. ,These materials include operational manual, step by step guidance to run Aids awareness programme, posters and films. Afsar also emphasised the involvement of people living with HIV virus and also those with positive mindset.,Snehanshu Bhaduri, a youth of Kolkata, who was detected HIV-positive in 1990, recounted his experience as a patient. He stressed on maintaining confidentiality of the disease and proper treatment support to ensure a longer lease of life. He also said that despite being an Aids patient, he can work as efficiently as a normal man can.,Rajeev Arun Ekka, project director, Jharkhand State Aids Control Society, Ranchi, outlined the activities and achievements of the society. He said three voluntary counselling and testing centres (VCTCs) have been set up at RMCH, Ranchi, MGM College, Jamshedpur and PMCH, Dhanbad, where people can get themselves checked for HIV virus by paying just Rs 10. One more VCTC is going to be opened very soon at Baharagora primary health centre, Jamshedpur.

Title: India to receive US aid on HIV/AIDS
article: NEW DELHI: In an effort to provide affordable anti-retrovirals to people living with HIV, the US government has decided to go in not just for a global sourcing of these drugs but to also allow exports of generic drugs from developing countries to countries which do not have adequate pharmaceutical facilities. ,US deputy assistant secretary for health and science Jack C Chow, told reporters on Thursday that the US was seeking ``multi-level solutions'''' to the patenting of life-saving drugs. However, in the absence of an immedaite solution, it had been decided that exports of generic medicines of diseases of global importance, such as HIV, malaria and tuberculosis would be allowed. ,Chow, who is in New Delhi to look at potential pathways for health sector cooperation also emphasised that HIV/AIDS is at the top of global political agenda. The global pandemic, he said, has killed ,more people worldwide than several global conflicts combined. ,In fact, Global AIDS diplomacy, he said, is on the top of the US foreign policy agenda. ``it''s a way of uniting the world to transform the epidemic and to defeat it, he said. Chow said all governments need to take urgent action now. There is a need for prevention strategies, public health strategies, robust communication and political commitment. ,The US government has decided to put $15 billion to be spent in 14 countries, mostly from Africa, over the next five years. India would benefit from a $5 billion amount that it proposes to spend globally to control AIDS.

Title: HIV positive woman died a natural death
article: TIRUPATI: A report that an HIV-affected woman was stoned to death in the chief ministeraâ„¢s constituency Kuppam last week was denied by Kuppam special officer Sharath on Friday.,An HIV-affected woman Pavanamma, 30, was reportedly stoned to death on July 4. A police inquiry on Thursday revealed that the woman had been sick and died a aËœaËœnatural death.aâ„¢,Sharath said that during inquiry Pavanammaaâ„¢s mother Sharadamma told him that there she had been attending on her ailing daughter for the past year. ,He also said this fact was confirmed by the womanaâ„¢s relatives and fellow villagers.,A laboratory technician of the area hospital also confirmed that Pavanammaaâ„¢s ondition had been aËœaËœvery badaâ„¢aâ„¢ when she came to the hospital the day before she died.

Title: HIV positive is stoned to death
article: CHITTOOR: A woman suspected of being HIV positive was stoned to death in Kuppam village in Andhra Pradesh.,Though the incident happened on July 5, it came out only on Wednesday. Chief Minister N Chandrababu Naidu reportedly took serious note of the killing and sent a special team to probe into the incident.,The thirty-two old woman, M Pavunamma, hailing from BC Colony in Kuppam was married to Munuswamy from Tamil Nadu 10 years ago. After her husband died, Pavunamma was allegedly living with some one in Guntur.,When she came to her native village recently she underwent some routine medical tests and reportedly tested positive for the virus. ,Pavunammaaâ„¢s relatives confined her to a room in the house and asked the panchayat to expel her from the village. The elders decided to expel her and reportedly demanded Rs 600 from the relatives. But then the villagers reportedly stoned Pavunamma and she died of her inujuries.

Title: HIV-positive children denied schooling
article: HYDERABAD: It has been a year since four-year-old Ravi, 10-year-old Chandana and seven-year-old Kalaivari sought admission in local schools and were sent back by the managements who were against accepting HIV-positive children.,Ravi succumbed to the virus over the year. Chandana and Kalaivari are now armed with an order issued by the government that educational institutions under the school education department should not discriminate against and must admit HIV-positive children without objection.,However, it seems that these children are likely to lose one more academic year as school managements have not admitted them into the institutions. Two private schools at Bolarum, where the children sought admission last year, have refused to admit them this year too, despite the government order. The case is all set to come up for a final hearing at the high court.,According to Shirley, the legal consultant for these children, both schools were not too keen to admit the children. The first school initially said the admissions for the year were full while the other replied that they had to consult the trustees before admission could be given.,A couple of days later, the second school refused to admit the children. These children are now being taught at the Freedom Foundation, a care and support centre for HIV and Aids,where they have being residing for over a year. According to Freedom Foundationaâ„¢s executive trustee, Karl Sequeira these children should not be discriminated against and it is their right to have a normal schooling.

Title: Schools deny admission to HIV positive
article: HYDERABAD: It has been a year since four-year-old Ravi, 10-year-old Chandana and seven-year-old Kalaivari were denied admission to local schools because they were found to be HIV positive. ,Ravi succumbed to the disease over the year. Chandana and Kalaivari are now armed with an order issued by the government, which states that educational institutions under the school education department should not discriminate against HIV positive children and must admit them. Now, it seems that these children are likely to lose another year as managements of schools they have approached have refused to admit them this year too.,According to Shirley, the legal consultant for these children, both the schools were not too keen on admitting the children. The first school said the admissions for the year were over, while the other tried to postpone the decision initially, but later refused to admit them.,The children are now being taught at the Freedom Foundation, a care and support centre for HIV and AIDS patients.

Title: PM calls for greater openness on HIV/AIDS
article: NEW DELHI: Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee suggested that the country should become more open about discussing AIDS epidemic.,Inaugurating the two-day convention of the Parliamentary Forum on HIV/AIDS here on Saturday, he pointed out that those countries, which had succeeded in reversing the gloomy picture on that front had been open about the problem.,"We need to demonstrate this openness and a complete absence of prejudice towards affected persons," the PM said in an apparent reference to reservations earlier about any admission of the dismal scenario. ,He expressed ''particular concern'' that of the 40 million HIV/AIDS infected people in the world, four million lived in this country alone. "In Andhra, Tamil Nadu, Karnataka, Maharashtra, Manipur and Nagaland, HIV prevalence has reached over one per cent among women attending antenatal clinics," he said.,He regretted that "issues pertaining to public health do not normally find a place on the nation''s political agenda."

Title: Many additions to state's HIV+ cases
article: PATNA: The number of HIV positive cases is increasing at an alarming rate in the state despite the efforts being made by the Bihar State Aids Control Society to prevent the spread of such infections with the help of Family Health Awareness Campaigns.,According to official figures, the number of HIV positive cases has gone up to 3,439 in Bihar. The first such case was detected in Nawada district of the state in 1992. The state government had recently informed the Bihar legislative assembly that there were about 2,500 HIV positive cases in the state.,The state government set up the Society in July 1999, but it had created an Aids cell in the health department in May 1992 itself. The Centre has released more than Rs 8.21 crore to the Society for the current financial year to undertake HIV prevention work, including targeted interventions for groups at high risk, preventive interventions for general community and institution strengthening schemes.,A senior health department official said out of the 3,439 HIV positive cases detected so far, 1,865 were detected at the 26 voluntary counselling and testing centres (VCTCs) established by the Society in different districts between March 2001 and May 2003, 1,000 at the Sen Diagnostics, a private testing centre in Patna, between 1995 and June 2003 and 574 at the Sharma Diagnostics, a private testing centre at Darbhanga, between July 1997 and September 2002.,Dr Sandip Sen of Sen Diagnostics said his laboratory employs the P24 antigen test for detecting HIV positive cases within seven to 10 days of infection.,The official figures suggest that the detection of HIV positive cases was very poor before 1995 though it got accelerated after the establishment of VCTCs.,Project director of the Society C K Anil admitted that the spurt in HIV cases is a matter of concern. He, however, said 20 more VCTCs would start functioning within a month increasing the total number of such centres in the state to 46. Apart from the six medical college hospitals, VCTC facilities would now be available in all the 38 districts of the state.,Anil said while the establishment of VCTCs would help detect hidden HIV positive cases, the counselling being done at these centres free of cost would definitely bring down the number of such cases in future. The government recently informed the state legislature that the Society has decided to establish at least one licensed blood bank in every district.

Title: MTV gives pep talk on HIV to young minds
article: MUMBAI: The trick, says Georgia Franklin of MTV, is that we donaâ„¢t talk aËœtoaâ„¢ the youth but aËœwithaâ„¢ the youth. aËœaËœWe donaâ„¢t say donaâ„¢t have sex. And we donaâ„¢t use scary words like aËœabstinenceaâ„¢ a" we use a word like aËœdelayaâ„¢ instead.aâ„¢aâ„¢,As head of the social arm of MTV international, Franklin may talk the MTV talk, but the red loop pinned onto her dress suggests deeper concerns. For the past five years, she has nurtured the aËœaËœStayin Aliveaâ„¢aâ„¢ show, an ongoing project to spread Aids awareness in 18 different languages in countries across the world. Franklin is in India to talk to NGOs and give the campaign an added push.,India has provided the Aids campaign with its brand ambassador a" Cyrus Broacha a" who moderated the Aids conference at Barcelona. Franklin is hoping to influence Bollywood and local TV programmers to weave the message into their scripts. One of the most interesting aspects of the campaign is the partnerships that MTV has struck up. For starters, there is the almighty World Bank.

Title: HIV+ve? Don't 'bank' on them to tell you!
article: PUNE: We might just be letting a dreaded and elusive enemy get away scot-free when it''s showing up at our doorstep. This is exactly what we seem to have been doing while dealing with HIV/AIDS. ,Around 85,000 blood units are collected by the 17 banks in the city annually and HIV appears in 1.2 per cent of samples during preliminary screening. Although the infected blood is discarded, blood banks stop short of doing the next important thing a" telling the donor his/her HIV status. ,When this could well prevent the spread of the virus,what stops the blood banks from informing such HIV-positive donors? Blood bank sources cite "practical and technical reasons". ,First, they want to avoid running into legal problems by disclosing such sensitive information. Second, they do not have the counselling facilities. ,Says a blood bank source, "We cannot inform without confirming the HIV status of the donor. The test carried out in our lab is only a screening test and not a diagnostic one. It requires repeated tests, using other kits, to confirm the same, which we don''t do here." ,A doctor at a blood bank who declined concern is to decontaminate and store blood. How can we follow up on every HIV-positive donor?" A blood bank in-charge says that informing a donor of his HIV status can be tricky. ,"A letter from a blood bank can be disturbing for the donor, especially if his/her family members or acquaintances learn about it.
