There have been cases before of people committing suicide after learning that they were infected. It could land us in legal problems if something happens to the donor," he says. ,Blood bank officials say that the best they can do is to inform the donor if he/she asks for the test results and then send him to a government voluntary counselling centre. Most blood banks, however, do not have trained counsellors. ,Some blood bank managers say such cases are too few to deserve appointing a counsellor. Significantly, the National Blood Policy, under the national AIDS Control Programme allows disclosure of the HIV status of a person if pre-test and posttest counselling could be made available.

Title: APSACS grapples with HIV test kit shortage
article: HYDERABAD: The National Aids Control Organisationaâ„¢s (Naco) failure to supply HIV test kits has resulted in a situation wherein the Andhra Pradesh Aids Control Society (APSACS) APSACS is struggling to meet the demand for these kits from blood banks.,Naco has failed to fulfil its supply commitments to APSACS for the April-June and July-September quarters.,According to a senior APSACS official, the society was initially unprepared to meet the shortfall. But now kits were being outsourced from local manufacturers on the basis of a tender. Sources at the Gandhi General Hospital said that there has been a shortage of HIV test kits on more than one occasion over the past two months.,As per Naco guidelines, it is mandatory that five tests, including an HIV one, be done on all samples collected at blood banks. There are 172 licenced blood banks in the state, 52 in the twin cities.,APSACS officials said that steps were being taken to tide over the shortage. According to a senior official, superintendents of government hospitals and blood banks have been asked to procure HIV test kits from other sources until the supply from Naco resumes.,Supplies from local manufacturers are likely to begin arriving by the end of this week. APSACS has undertaken to reimburse the money spent by blood banks on procuring these test kits.

Title: State leaves donors in dark on HIV status
article: MUMBAI: Six months after the central government allowed blood banks to disclose the HIV status of donors, Maharashtra hasnaâ„¢t been able to implement the path-breaking policy change. ,Tied down by a host of infrastructural problems, the stateaâ„¢s blood banks are still discarding blood samples that test positive without informing the donors.,The centreaâ„¢s decision to inform donorsa"if they so desire, and after counsellinga"about their HIV status was a major change from its earlier policy of keeping the disease under wraps. But as state blood bank officials have come to find out, the new policy isnaâ„¢t an easy one to implement.,Informing donors about their HIV status was supposed to help early detection of the virus and check its spread. But in Maharashtra, blood bank officials explain that not enough tests are done on a blood sample to confirm the virusaâ„¢ presence.,aÅ“We throw out a sample that tests positive even once, but one test is not enough to label a person HIV positive,aâ„¢aâ„¢ explained Alka Gogate, director of the Maharashtra District Aids Control Society. Usually, testing centres conduct three tests before confirming the presence of the virus, she added.,Another hurdle is the fact that counselling institutions are not attached to blood banks. aÅ“Donors have to be counselled before the HIV status is revealed. Otherwise, they will get a big shock,aâ„¢aâ„¢ said Dr Neelam Nijhara of the Federation of Bombay Blood Banks and head of the blood bank at the ESIS,Worli. ,Added a state government health department official, aÅ“Counselling has to be done before testing and after, even the union government has stipulated that.aâ„¢aâ„¢,Only the central government-assisted voluntary blood testing centres are equipped with counselling institutions to disclose HIV status to donors, a state health department official said. aÅ“As of now, we direct individuals who are in the high risk category (for AIDS) to these centres. We are strengthening these centres,aâ„¢aâ„¢ he added.,But experts point out that there are not enough voluntary testing centres in the state in the first place. Of the 72 government-run blood banks in the state, only 35 have voluntary test centres.,In any case, disclosing a donoraâ„¢s HIV status is not high up in the state blood councilaâ„¢s charts. As a council official said, aÅ“We have to increase the number of blood donations and the safety and the quality of blood first.aâ„¢aâ„¢,Added Dr Jayashree Sharma, in-charge of KEM hospital blood bank at Parel, aÅ“Informing donors will mean setting up counselling institutions and conducting confirmation tests, for which money and staff will be required.aâ„¢aâ„¢ It could become an additional burden on blood banks too, she pointed out.

Title: State govt to spread anti-gutka, HIV message
article: PUNE: The Maharashtra government has decided to use the forthcoming Ganesh Utsav as a vehicle to its ongoing anti-HIV and gutka campaigns. ,While a cash incentive to the Ganeshutsav mandals in each district of the state has already been announced by the health department for the best anti-Aids campaign, the government has also appealed to the mandals to say no to advertisement offers from gutka manufacturers and dealers during the 10-day festival. ,According to the additional project director of the Maharashtra State Aids Control Society, Dr Subhash Dodwad, this first-of-its kind cah incentive to the mandals in an attempt to create awareness amongst the public and sensitise them on prevention of the deadly disease.,He said the idea of involving the Ganeshutsav mandals was taken keeping in view the latter''s role in promoting the spirit of social harmony. ,The government felt that these mandals can play a pivotal role in spreading the message to all sections of the society, he added.,While the best campaigner will earn a prize of Rs 30,000, Dodwad said there will also be a second and third runners-up with Rs 20,000 and Rs 10,000 cash awards in every district. ,"Ganesh festival is one such occasion which attracts people of all caste, creed and religion to the mandals," said MSACS nodal officer, Dilip Pardeshi.,He said the government has already deposited the cash amounts at the disposal of the respective district collectors. "The collector has also been asked to form a committee which will decide the winners," he said. ,The mandals can collect an application form from the respective health department offices in the district, and the last date of submission is fixed at August 31, Pardeshi said, pointing out the participating mandals will have to use the anti-HIV campaign as a theme in the decorations of the pandals.,On the other hand, Maharashtra food and drug administration minister Anil Deshmukh said that all mandals have been requested to lend a helping hand to the government''s efforts in its anti-gutka campaign. ,"We have appealed the mandals to refuse offers from gutkha manufacturers/dealers in the form of the advertisements or any exhibits promoting such vicious products, through sponsorship during the festival,'' he said.,Deshmukh further added that a meeting has been convened in Mumbai next week to discuss the issue with heads of the mandals and others concerned.

Title: Scan on hospital role in HIV case
article: KOLKATA: It was meant to be a life saving act, but when a Burdwan youth donated blood to his mother for an operation in July 2000, he unwittingly infected her with the HIV virus. The son died of AIDS a few months later and the woman has been detected with HIV.,The Calcutta High Court will now decide whether Burdwan Medical College and Hospital (BMCH) neglected basic blood transfusion safety measures.,The womanaâ„¢s husband, a smalltime trader of Ara village in Burdwan, has filed a writ petition in high court and lodged a complaint with the state government accusing the hospital of not testing his sonaâ„¢s blood before the transfusion. He has also demanded compensation from the government.,aÅ“I have been ostracised in my locality,aï¿½ he said.,His ordeal started on July 6, 2000, when his wife, aged 45, was admitted to BMCH with a gall bladder stone.,Hearing that she needed operation, one of her sons, who worked in Delhi, rushed home to donate blood. He and his brother gave blood on the same day, July 14. The woman recieved the transfusion the next day on the operating table. About six months later, the womanaâ„¢s Delhibased son suddenly fell ill and was admitted to a nursing home in Burdwan. The doctors sent blood samples of the youth and his mother to the School of Tropical Medicine in Kolkata. On March 1, STMaâ„¢s department of virology confirmed that both son and mother were carrying the HIV AIDS virus. Eight days after the detection of AIDS, the son died and the mother fell seriously ill.,As the shattered family struggled for answers, the womanaâ„¢s husband wrote to the Burdwan Federation of Consumeraâ„¢s Association and then to the chief minister, seeking justice. He then filed a writ petition before the high court accusing the BMCH of negligence.,Justice Pranab Chattopadhaya has asked the director of health services to appoint a medical officer of the rank of deputy director of health services or superintendent of a medical college (other than Burdwan) to investigate the complaint and submit a report before the court by September 15.

Title: HIV testing centres down shutters early
article: HYDERABAD: If one goes after 12 noon to a voluntary HIV counselling and testing centre a" where a screening test is done for Rs 10 a" in all probability it will be closed. This is in spite of a directive that these centres have to be kept open from 9 am to 4 pm.,At the Malakpet Hospital where a Voluntary Counselling and Testing Centre (VCTC) is to function till 4 pm, a visit on Thursday showed that it was closed by 2 pm. According to an attender at the hospital, the VCTC centre shuts down as soon as the out-patient department closes.,There are nine VCTCs in the twin cities. At the Andhra Pradesh Vaidya Vidhana Parishad (APVVP) King Koti Hospital, the VCTC was found to be functioning till 4 pm, where on an average 130 people volunteer for the HIV screening test. However, the counselling for VCTC attendees is done in the same room where group counselling for prevention of mother-to-child transmission (PMTCT) for women is conducted.,aÅ“Counselling of VCTC and PMTCT attendees should not be conducted in the same room. All medical institutions that have both PMCTC and VCTC must ensure that both counselling centres are not housed in the same room,aï¿½ Andhra Pradesh State Aids Control Society (APSACS) project director K Damayanti said. The VCTC at the Gandhi Hospital, Secunderabad, is another popular destination for those who voluntarily want to get themselves tested for the virus. However, drawing of blood and counselling at this centre stops at 1 pm.,Further, on Wednesday afternoon upon visiting the centre it was found to be locked. According to a senior doctor of the microbiology department, drawing blood and counselling is done till 1 pm, after which the lab technician has time only to sort out and label the large number of samples before they are tested. aÅ“All VCTCs must be open between 9 am and 4 pm for testing and counselling and notices have been issued to all medical institutions,aï¿½ APSACS project director said. On an average in the state, each VCTC centre attends to 140 people a month, an increase over the monthly average of 115 attendees last year A view of an HIV testing centre in the city.

Title: Cost of drugs hinders HIV treatment: Expert
article: PUNE: The prohibitive cost of antiretroviral drugs and the lack of laboratory infrastructure needed to monitor virologic and immunologic responses are the primary road-blocks in developing countries in the cure of HIV/Aids, said the president of the Maharashtra chapter of Indian association of medical microbiologists, Dr Preeti Mehta. ,Delivering the presidential oration at the 9th conference of the association held at the Armed Forces Medical College on Saturday, Mehta said that although developed countries have successfully translated the benefits of Highly Active Anti Retroviral Therapy (HAART) in HIV treatment, developing countries have so far not been able to reap its benefits, because of its cost factor and lack of adequate infrastructure, required to monitor the effects of the drugs. ,She said that in developing countries, the diagnosis of HIV infection is often delayed and patients are already in an advanced stage of the disease when they are identified as HIV positive and treatment is initiated. ,"Due to the high cost of the antiretroviral drugs, the complexity of regimens and the rapid emergence of resistant viruses when treatment regimens are not optimal, reliable laboratory diagnostic and monitoring services have to be in place when initiation of therapy is to be considered." ,She also said that it is equally important to make sure that in addition to HIV, there are no undetected serious illness, which could be treated or which may influence the choice of treatments that should be offered later. ,"Tuberculosis screening is vital to identify people who can benefit from curative or preventive treatment for TB," she explained. ,Mehta also called upon the microbiologists to identify and develop appropriate alternative approaches for laboratory monitoring of antiretroviral therapy where laboratory monitoring is limited.

Title: Cost of HIV drugs affects treatment
article: PUNE: The prohibitive cost of anti-retroviral drugs and the lack of laboratory infrastructure needed to monitor virologic and immunologic responses are the primary roadblocks in developing countries in the cure of HIV/AIDS, according to Preeti Mehta, president of the Maharashtra chapter of the Indian Association of Medical Microbiologists. ,Delivering the presidential oration at the ninth conference of the association held at the Armed Forces Medical College on Saturday, Mehta said that although developed countries have successfully translated the benefits of highly active antiretro-viral therapy (HAART) in HIV treatment, developing countries have, so far, not been able to reap its benefits because of its cost factor and the lack of adequate infrastructure required to monitor the effects of the drugs. ,She said that in developing countries, the diagnosis of the HIV infection is often delayed and patients are already in an advanced stage of the disease when they are identified as HIV positive. ,She also said that it is equally important to make sure that, in addition to HIV, there are no undetected, serious illnesses, which could be treated or which may influence the choice of treatments that should be offered later. ,aÅ“Tuberculosis screening is vital to identify people who can benefit from curative or preventive treatment for the disease,aï¿½ she explained. ,Mehta also called upon microbiologists to identify and develop appropriate alternative approaches for laboratory monitoring of anti-retro-viral therapy, where laboratory monitoring is limited.

Title: HIV infection on the rise in colonies
article: NEW DELHI: The spectre of HIV appears to loom extra large over several residential colonies in the city with a recent survey confirming a sharp rise in the density of HIV positive cases in these areas.,A sample survey conducted by the Delhi government recently and the regular inputs received by the Delhi State AIDS Control Society (DSACS) from hospitals and blood banks have indicated that colonies like Rohini, Sangam Vihar and Prem Nagar in Najafgarh are fast turning into hubs of HIV cases.,aËœaËœThe survey suggests that there are one or two high density areas for the virus in almost all the the nine districts of the city,aâ„¢aâ„¢ said a health department official.,The findings of the survey have come as a surprise to officials as till now the cityaâ„¢s main red-light area, G B Road, and some slums in Yamuna Pushta were considered to be the danger zones as far as HIV cases were concerned.,Delhi has more than 25,000 HIV-positive individuals. The overall HIV incidence in the country is about 0.1 per cent. ,Health minister A K Walia maintained that a close watch was being kept on HIV cases in the city. aËœaËœResidential colonies are also being covered by our teams. Through focused strategies, we are reaching out to those living with HIV or those who are at a high risk of acquiring it,aâ„¢aâ„¢ he said.,Walia claimed that experts from the DSACS were counselling people, distributing condoms and carrying out medical check-ups in all the vulnerable areas.,While the Delhi government claims to be in control of the situation, officials of other government agencies said that the true picture on HIV cases in the city is yet to come to light.,Like all other states, the Delhi governmentaâ„¢s figures for HIV cases is calculated using sample surveys conducted on residents between 15 and 49 years of age.,aËœaËœThe figures quoted by the Delhi government are based on sample surveys and there is always scope for error,aâ„¢aâ„¢said an official working with the National Aids Control Organisation.,A confidential survey carried out by the Delhi government last year had kicked up a controversy recently when its findings showed the HIV cases in the city are much higher, he said.,Soon after the confidential survey, Delhi government officials had dismissed its findings as erroneous, the official added.,In one health camp, 30 rescued G B Road sex workers were tested for HIV. Seven of them were found positive. aËœaËœ There are hundreds of such workers still in the brothels of G B Road and so far not a single reliable study has been conducted to find out the extent of HIV infection among them,aâ„¢aâ„¢ he said.,Officials admit shortage of authentic data on HIV cases. aËœaËœThere is very little detail available on how many of those living with HIV are minors or how many are males and females,aâ„¢aâ„¢ said an official.,aËœaËœAn HIV/AIDS test cannot be conducted without the consent of an individual. And if found HIV positive, he or she needs to be offered counselling,aâ„¢aâ„¢ said an official, citing these as major problems in collection of data.

Title: HIV+ve man seeks NHRC's help
article: NEW DELHI: An HIV+ve kidney patient has sought help from the National Human Rights Commission after several city hospitals shut doors on him. Ashok (name changed) has dangerously high levels of urea in his body as he has stones in both his kidneys. Though he needs dialysis urgently, doctors in most government hospitals are afraid of treating him allegedly because of his HIV+ve status.,aËœaËœI have been running around in circles with no result. The Commission is my last hope for justice,aâ„¢aâ„¢ he said.,Besides the Delhi governmentaâ„¢s LNJP Hospital, he has also knocked at the doors of RML Hospital, AIIMS, Safdarjung Hospital and GTB Hospital. He was admitted to the LNJP Hospital earlier this month after a senior official from the Delhi State AIDS Control Society pushed his case. But he alleged that he was discharged hurriedly without dialysis. aËœaËœLNJP doctors say that I donaâ„¢t need a dialysis but medical reports suggest otherwise,aâ„¢aâ„¢ he says.,aËœaËœThe doctors in the hospital have offered to get me financial help from an NGO if I continue to get myself treated in a private hospital. I have been paying over Rs 5,000 per dialysis to a private hospital whereas it costs just around Rs 1,500 at LNJP,aâ„¢aâ„¢ he said.,As part of the much-hyped AIDS campaign of the Delhi government, LNJP was supposed to have got a separate dialysis facility for treatment of HIV+ve patients an year ago. However, new dialysis machines have not been purchased yet.,Ashok tried to seek help from Delhi Health Minister, A K Walia, but his agony continued. Walia said: aËœaËœWe have arranged for his treatment at a private hospital. We have asked the hospital to treat him under the poor patient category and we will try to arrange funds for him.aâ„¢aâ„¢,Walia admitted that setting up of special facilities for HIV+ve patients at LNJP Hospital had been delayed. aËœaËœWe are in the process of buying new dialysis machines. A separate dialysis machine for such patients will be available soon,aâ„¢aâ„¢ he said.

Title: 'Living condoms' to block HIV
article: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences

Title: Aid for economically weak HIV cases
article: LUCKNOW: UP State Aids Control Society (UPSACS) known largely for its "communication and condom war", is now seriously considering a proposal to provide economic assistance to the economically deprived HIV positive cases in the state. ,Bringing about the paradigm shift in the policy could be Mehtaab (name changed) a young widow with two sons from Ferozabad district, who lost her husband to the killer virus recently.,Life became tougher for Mehtaab after her father-in-law lodged a complaint to the National Human Rights Commission (NHRC), Delhi to "stop her from spreading Aids in the town". Alleging that she was HIV positive, the complainant alleged that Mehtaab - promiscuous by nature- had several liaisons and could pose a grave health hazard for public at large.,The NHRC directed UPSACS to carry out investigations in the case. The inquiry officer found all charges baseless and reported that the widow was in dire need of financial assistance for her own treatment and survival.,And this probably made the project director UPSACS Anil Kumar wonder if the young woman could be provided any monetary help within the guidelines of NACO.,Kumar has already shot off the request to NACO head office and awaits its clearance. If the answer is positive, the case could pave the way for the NACO sponsored treatment of other economically deprived HIV patients here.,The move may come as a big relief to the 1085 odd Aids patients most of whom are too poor to afford the anti retro viral drug therapy anyway. While the therapy has brought about a revolutionary change in the quality and quantity of life of Aids patients in Maharashtra, Gujarat and Tamil Nadu the number of those lucky enough to afford the therapy known popularly as the cocktail therapy would not even cross ten per cent in UP. The expensive drug regimen may cost anything from Rs 2000 to Rs 15000 a month something the physicians don''t usually prescribe. And the result could be early and painful death.,In fact, the class is known to wage a dual battle -- one, with the disease, the other with the official apathy. Their list of woes runs from indifferent and callous government doctors to the departmental tussle between the UPSACS and the health department over funding the treatment. While the former shifts the onus on the government the latter maintains that all issues pertaining to Aids are UPSACS responsibility.,Significantly, much depends on the decision of Supreme Court in the PIL : Voluntary Health Association Punjab versus Union of India which has made NACO and all state Aids societies parties, say sources in the health department. The writ has demanded free and equitable access to anti retro viral treatment to the HIV patients by government under the public health system. The bold step taken by the UPSACS could only be a prelude to the anticipated decision, they claimed.

Title: Govt to assist needy HIV persons
article: LUCKNOW: UP State Aids Control Society (UPSACS) known largely for its aÅ“campaign and condom waraï¿½, is now seriously considering a proposal to provide economic assistance to destitute HIV positive cases in the state.,Bringing about the paradigm shift in the policy could be Mehtaab (name changed) a young widow with two sons from Ferozabad district, who lost her husband to the killer virus recently.,Life became tougher for Mehtaab after her father-in-law lodged a complaint to the National Human Rights Commission (NHRC) Delhi to aÅ“stop her from spreading Aids in the townaï¿½. ,Alleging that she was HIV positive, the complainant alleged that Mehtaab had several liaisons and could pose a grave health hazard for the public at large.,The NHRC directed UPSACS to carry out investigations in the case. The inquiry officer found all charges baseless and reported that the widow was in dire need of financial assistance for her own treatment and survival.,And this probably made the project director UPSACS Anil Kumar wonder if the young woman could be provided any monetary help within the guidelines of NACO.,Kumar has already shot off the request to NACO head office and awaits its clearance. If the answer is positive, the case could pave the way for the NACO-sponsored treatment of other economically deprived HIV patients here. ,The move may come as a big relief to the 1085-odd Aids patients most of whom are too poor to afford the anti retro viral drug therapy anyway. ,While the therapy has brought about a revolutionary change in the quality and quantity of life of Aids patients in Maharashtra, Gujarat and Tamil Nadu, the number of those lucky enough to afford the therapy known popularly as aËœcocktail therapyaâ„¢ would not even cross ten per cent in UP. ,The expensive drug regimen may cost anything from Rs 2000 to Rs 15,000 a month, something the physicians donaâ„¢t usually prescribe. This in turn results in early and painful death. ,In fact, the class is known to wage a dual battle: one, with the disease, the other with official apathy. ,Their list of woes runs from indifferent and callous government doctors to departmental tussle between UPSACS and the health department over funding the treatment. While the former shifts the onus on the government, the latter maintains that all issues pertaining to Aids are UPSACS responsibility. ,Significantly, much depends on the decision of Supreme Court in the PIL: Voluntary Health Association Punjab versus Union of India which has made NACO and all state Aids societies parties, say sources in the health department. ,The writ has demanded free and equitable access to anti retro viral treatment to HIV patients by government under the public health system. The bold step taken by the UPSACS could only be a prelude to the anticipated decision, they claimed.

Title: Centre to sponsor HIV+ kids' treatment
article: THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Union Minister for Health and Family Welfare Sushma Swaraj on Sunday announced a five-year special treatment package for the two hapless AIDS-infected siblings, Bency (8) and Benson (6) from the state.,Swaraj, who met the children at the Press Club here, said public sector Hindustan Latex Limited would meet the costs of their treatment for the next five years.,She held a meeting with the state health and education secretaries and efforts would be made to see that the two children continued their studies by attending regular school.,Now the children are given coaching at a separate rented building in their native place at Kaithakuzhy near Kollam following resistance from parents of other children of the government LP school, where the children were admitted. Bency is studying in the third standard and Benson in the second.

Title: Workshop on HIV/AIDS
article: MANGALORE: A one day workshop to discuss the status of AIDS/HIV infected persons, would be held at Sneha Sadan, Gurupur near Mangalore on Thursday.,The workshop has been organised by Karavali+ Women and Child Network (KPWCN), in association with AIDS/HIV organisations, NGOs, voluntary bodies, Zilla and taluk Panchayats.,Veenadhari from Karavali Plus stated that though the government has evolved programmes to create awareness and for the control of HIV/AIDS, there were no measures in place to stem social ostracisation of the affected.,She said the objective of Karavali Plus was to instill a sense of confidence, give the affected good nutritious food and medical facilities. Experts who will be attending the workshop will deal with the problems faced by AIDS infected, nutritional facts.

Title: Job reservation for HIV infected women demanded
article: MANGALORE: The condition of HIV infected women in the state is pathetic. To improve their living condition, they should be given job reservation, said Sumathi, a HIV infected woman, who is employed as a nurse at a private hospital.,She was speaking at the one day workshop to discuss the status of AIDS/HIV infected persons held at Sneha Sadan, Gurupur near Mangalore on Thursday.,The workshop has been organised by Karavali Plus Women and Child Network (KPWCN), in association with AIDS/HIV organisations, NGOs, voluntary bodies, Zilla and taluk Panchayats.,Sumathi contended that the HIV positive women were being targeted by the society as awareness was lacking and were being socially ostracised. aÅ“If such women have to be self confident, she needs to be self reliant. In this direction job reservation is necessary,aï¿½ she added.,Reliving the moments ever since she contracted HIV, Sumathi said though she was a nurse the doctors treated her as an untouchable and removed her from the job. aÅ“To get the job backaï¿½, she said, aÅ“I had to wage a waraï¿½.

Title: Swarajâ€™s move on HIV treatment draws flak
article: MUMBAI: Many eyebrows were raised as Union health and family welfare minister Sushma Swaraj announced that the government would provide treatment free of cost to HIV-positive children below 14 years of age. ,The programme is slated to be implemented by the National Aids Control Organisation (NACO) in three to six months.,The anti-retroviral treatment costs between Rs 1,200 and Rs 5,000 per month per patient, putting it out of reach for many. Of an estimated 4.5 million HIV-positive cases in India, 2 lakh are estimated to be children. ,Health activists believe that while the total annual health ministry budget is Rs 225 crore, the new policy alone could cost about Rs 600 crore annually. Says Amar Jesani, founder of the Centre for Enquiry into Health and Allied Themes (CEHAT), aÅ“It is inconsistent to have a health policy where you canaâ„¢t get free treatment for a cold at a public health centre because it lacks basic drugs, but can get free antiretroviral treatment for HIV. ,If the government is ready to provide universal health care, it must cover all diseases, including AIDS. But if it is selective, it raises doubts as to its motivations. One wonders if the interests of pharmaceutical companies was a considerationaï¿½.,For other doctors, the lack of infrastructure to administer such a policy is of greater concern. Says Sanjay Pujari, director of the Department of HIV Medicine, Ruby Hall Clinic, Pune, aÅ“The infrastructure required for safe and effective delivery of health care for paediatric patients is not yet in place.,We need physicians trained in paediatric HIV care and regular monitoring and testing of response to treatment. All these will cost much more than the drugs.,They have become more cheaper now, so there is not much of a profit margin for pharmaceutical companiesaï¿½.,The singling out of children for free treatment is being seen as an irrational decision in public health circles. As Pujari points out, aÅ“It is not rational to exclude adults. ,Children with HIV usually have one or both parents with HIV, and if they are excluded from the therapy, who will look after the child? ,It makes more sense to treat families with HIV. Frankly, after the mother and child patients, it would be more cost-effective to prioritise adults who can be economically productive and on whom the family dependsaï¿½.,Meanwhile, the policy can only be music to the ears of the pharmaceutical industry. Says Amar Lulla, joint managing director, Cipla, key manufacturer of antiretroviral drugs in India, aÅ“It is a welcome move.,We hope it is a first step in making HIV care free for all patients, as it is in Brazilaï¿½.

Title: HIV+ kids wish Kalam on his b'day
article: THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: President A P J Abdul Kalam, who spared some time to spend with two HIV-affected children during his recent Kerala visit, on Wednesday received an affectionate message from them on his 73rd birthday with a prayer for a long life for the President.,Benson and Bensy of Chathanur from Kollam district, who were forced out of school after testing HIV positive, had met Kalam when he came to Kochi to attend the 50th birthday celebrations of Mata Amritanandamayi. ,The President had then directed authorities to take care of the children who are now staying with their grandfather after their parents died of AIDS. ,"Dear grandpa Kalam, our grandfather told us October 15 is your birthday. We pray to God that you live for a very long time," Benson and Bensy said in the message. They also sent an invitation to the President to participate in their birthday celebrations being arranged by local people on October 19. The children''s birthdays fall on October 16 and 21.,Union Minister for Health Sushma Swaraj, who met the children recently at Thiruvananthapuram, had arranged for their treatment by the public sector Hindustan Latex Limited.

Title: ILO: Marriage main route in HIV cases
article: NEW DELHI: It is not just family, employers and society at large that discriminate against those suffering from HIV/ AIDS, but even institutions like hospitals, which are supposed to be care-givers, says a study organised by the International Labour Organisation (ILO) here.,The study covered some 292 people living with HIV/AIDS in Delhi, Tamil Nadu, Maharashtra and Manipur. Interestingly, the study was conducted by those affected with HIV/ AIDS. The report was released here on Tuesday by additional secretary, ministry of labour, Baleshwar Rai. ,aËœaËœAn encouraging trend is that more and more positive people are trying to mobilise infected people to fight for their rights and increase social acceptance. They are attempting to reduce the stigmas and the consequent discrimination,aâ„¢aâ„¢ said S M Afsar, ILOaâ„¢s national project coordinator, aËœPrevention of HIV/AIDS in the world of work: a tripartite responseaâ„¢.,The study revealed that HIV-infected women have faced more discrimination and hardship and had to assume more responsibilities to run their households once their husbands died of AIDS. Also, women are getting infected at a very young age - the mean age of women at the time of HIV testing was just 24.4 years.,Nearly 90 per cent of the women got the infection from their husbands clearly showing that aËœaËœmarriage is the biggest route of transmission.aâ„¢aâ„¢ While the reported instances of discrimination at the workplace (only 6.1 per cent) was fairly less, it could be because many HIV positive persons hid their status for fear of losing their job.

Title: Marriage biggest route of HIV transmission: ILO
article: NEW DELHI: It is not just family, employers and the society that discriminates against those suffering from HIV/AIDS, but even institutions like hospitals, which are supposed to be care-givers, says a study by the International Labour Organisation (ILO) here.,The study covered some 292 people living with HIV/AIDS in Delhi, Tamil Nadu, Maharashtra and Manipur. Interestingly, the study was conducted by those affected with HIV/ AIDS. The report was released here on Tuesday by additional secretary, ministry of labour, Baleshwar Rai.,aËœaËœAn encouraging trend is that more and more positive people are trying to mobilise infected people to fight for their rights and increase social acceptance. They are attempting to reduce the stigmas and the consequent discrimination,aâ„¢aâ„¢ said S M Afsar, ILOaâ„¢s national project coordinator, aËœPrevention of HIV/AIDS in the world of work: a tripartite responseaâ„¢.,The study revealed that HIV-infected women have faced more discrimination and hardship and had to assume more responsibilities to run their households once their husbands died of AIDS. Women are getting infected at a very young age - the mean age of women at the time of HIV testing was just 24.4 years. Nearly 90 per cent of the women got the infection from their husbands clearly showing that aËœaËœmarriage is the biggest route of transmission.aâ„¢aâ„¢,While the reported instances of discrimination at the workplace (only 6.1 per cent) was fairly less, it could be because many HIV positive persons hid their status for fear of losing their job. Denial of promotion and being forced to take voluntary retirement were some of the reported instances of discrimination at the workplace.,HIV/AIDS also seriously changes oneaâ„¢s financial situation, the study found. The average monthly income of aËœpeople living with HIV/AIDSaâ„¢ (PLWHA) families is Rs 1,117, while expenditure is Rs 3,185.,Children usually face the brunt of the financial crunch, with about 35 per cent being denied basic amenities and about 17 per cent having to take up small jobs. About 70 per cent respondents received pre- and post-HIV test counselling, mainly at government hospitals and not at private institutions providing HIV-testing.,After counselling, 78 per cent took precautions to protect their partner/child from getting infected. However, most realise they have HIV/ AIDS quite late, and have by then already infected their spouses.

Title: Uncircumcised Indian men at higher HIV risk
article: BALTIMORE: Uncircumcised men have an eight-fold higher risk of becoming infected with the human immunodeficiency virus that causes AIDS compared to circumcised men, according to a study of 2,298 Indian men.,The finding was presented last Thursday at the 41st Annual Meeting of the Infectious Diseases Society of America by Steven Reynolds of Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore.,The research was part of a larger study investigating risk factors for HIV-1 infection based on men attending one of three sexually transmitted diseases (STD) clinics in Pune, India. ,Between 1993 and 2000, 2,298 men who tested negative for HIV-1 were enrolled in the study. During subsequent visits (an average of three visits in 11 months), two of 191 men who were circumcised and 165 of 2,107 who were uncircumcised tested positive for HIV.,Demographics, sexual risk behaviour (including having sex with a prostitute), and condom use were remarkably similar between both groups, said Reynolds. Despite the similarity in risk profiles, researchers determined the incidence rate of HIV-1 among circumcised men it was 0.7 per cent, whereas among uncircumcised men it was 5.5 per cent, an eight-fold increase. ,However, the study did not find circumcision to be protective against other sexually transmitted diseases, including syphillis, genital herpes and gonorrhoea.,Circumcision was not totally protective and might not be culturally acceptable or safe in some settings, so regular condom use was still the best way of protecting against HIV and other sexually transmitted diseases, said Reynolds. ,Condom promotion remained a key strategy in the current fight against the spread of AIDS, he said.,"Circumcision as a potential prevention strategy requires confirmation by randomised clinical trials, which are the gold standard in evaluating medical interventions," he said. ,Three clinical trials are currently underway in Uganda, Kenya and South Africa.

Title: India gets $ 2.6 mn from Global Fund to fight HIV/TB
article: NEW DELHI: India has received US $ 2.6 million in grants from the Global Fund for a two-year period to fight AIDS and TB.,Meeting in Thailand the Board of the Global Fund last week approved $ 623 million in new two-year grants to programmes in different countries to fight AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria. ,"In less than two years the Global Fund has become a leading force in the fight against these three deadly diseases," said Tommy G. Thompson, US secretary of health and human services.

Title: Care as important as prevention for HIV, says Sushma
article: NEW DELHI: In a significant shift of focus in the war against AIDS, health minister Sushma Swaraj has emphasised that care is as important as prevention.,Addressing the MPs on her ministryaâ„¢s consultative committee on Tuesday, she announced her ministryaâ„¢s decision to look after the children born with HIV because of infection from their mothers. ,Swaraj said the current campaign for preventing AIDS did not have an adequate emphasis on looking after the victims and children orphaned by the disease. aËœaËœIf we can provide care to an infected mother she will be able to take care of her children,aâ„¢aâ„¢ she remarked. Swaraj said the new focus would be on treatment of mothers and children to increase their life span.,aËœaËœIn our new campaign we have taken an infected person as one of us and this should be our approach,aâ„¢aâ„¢ she said. She said the new approach would call for treating the full-blown cases as well as preventing the epidemic. The minister said though 80 per cent of AIDS cases were attributed to sexual contacts it should be kept in mind that there were other routes as well. She said there was an urgent need to look after children from homes devastated by AIDS. ,Her ministry had already directed the public sector Hindustan Latex company to adopt two such children in Mysore. She suggested that the publicity drives be sensitive to the HIV problem and called for looking at it as a human issue.,aËœaËœWe should take utmost care in our campaign and must not brand the disease with guilt,aâ„¢aâ„¢ she said. Observing that too much importance was being given to condoms in the AIDS prevention publicity, she pointed out that it was a lifestyle disease and said that an effort should be made to inform young minds about the HIV danger and consequences .

Title: Clinics at government hospitals to prevent Aids, HIV
article: PATNA: With a view to preventing parents to child transmission of Aids and HIV, the Bihar government on Wednesday directed the superintendents of all the six government medical college hospitals of the state to set up an anti-natal clinic (ANC) at each of the hospitals.,The ANCs are to be established under the programme for prevention of parents to child transmission of Aids and HIV. The National Aids Control Organisation had directed all the states to establish ANCs at all the government medical college hospitals under the programme.,The six government medical college hospitals of Bihar will receive Rs 2.17 lakh each for establishing the ANCs. Each of the ANCs will be under the administrative control of the superintendent of the concerned medical college hospital while the head of its obstetrics and gynaecology department will be the nodal officer of the programme.,Project director of the Bihar State Aids Control Society C K Anil, in a communication to the superintendents of all the six government medical college hospitals on October 22, directed them to set up the ANCs near the outdoor patient wings of obstetrics and gynaecology departments of the hospitals. The blood samples to be collected there will be sent to the voluntary counselling and testing centres (VCTCs) already established at the hospitals for HIV test. The nodal officers will have to send their reports to the Society on the 5th of every month.,Each of the ANCs will have a woman counsellor and a lab technician to be appointed on contract basis for one year by a three-member committee headed by the superintendent of the hospital concerned. The heads of the obstetrics and gynaecology and microbiology departments of the hospital will be the other two members of the committee. Anil has directed the hospital superintendents to start the process of appointment of women counsellors and lab technicians within a month.

Title: Doctor sues top lab for wrong HIV test
article: KOLKATA: A drop of blood brought the world crashing down on Dr B Krishnan (not his real name); a jumble of white blood cells that said he had contracted HIV.,Pity is, it wasnaâ„¢t his own. Or someone had goofed up the tests. But by the time the error was detected, Dr Krishnanaâ„¢s life was shattered beyond hope.,Only in 1999, he was a successful gastroenterologist attached to a premier private hospital in south Kolkata. He had an impeccable reputation in the cityaâ„¢s medical fraternity, and patients swore by him.,However, the doctor himself was nagged by a recurring fever and weakness.When regular treatment didnaâ„¢t work, his colleagues suggested that he get himself admitted in the same hospital for some routine tests. The disease still eluded diagnosis. At this juncture, another doctor suggested, quite gently, that Krishnan go for a western blot test to check for the presence of HIV. Krishnan agreed, in all the stoicism of his medical profession.,A collecting agent of a pharma major took his blood samples but instead of conducting a western blot test, the lab went in for a PCR (polymer sensitive chemical resistance) test. aÅ“These are very advanced tests and have to be conducted in a highly controlled environment. Even the slightest glitch can mean the test can go horribly wrong,aï¿½ explained Krishnan.,Within a day Krishnan was told that he was HIV positive. aÅ“My whole world came crumbling down.aï¿½ he confessed. Whataâ„¢s worse, the news leaked out despite the fact that labs are supposed to maintain complete secrecy. aÅ“The news spread like wildfire. Everyone in the hospital, even my colleagues and patients, came to know about the results. I was pained and humiliated,aï¿½ he recalled. Then, Krishnan was asked to leave the hospital. He shifted bag and baggage to one of the southern states, where he consulted another AIDS specialist and undertook a battery of confirmatory tests.,Each of the tests revealed that he didnaâ„¢t have a trace of the deadly virus in his system.,The bewildered and elated doctor began picking up his life, but he also vowed to pull something out of his wasted years. He has since moved the state consumer redressal forum, claiming damages of Rs 20 lakh against the pharmaceutical company.,The hearing has already begun. aÅ“Nothing can compensate me for the mental anguish I went through, but no one should suffer a similar predicament because of the negligence of a pharma major,aï¿½ he said.

Title: HIV-affected swallow bitter pill
article: MUMBAI/PUNE: Six Indian HIV positive passengers, including a Puneite, returning from the 11th International People Living With HIV/AIDS conference held in Uganda, were allegedly humiliated and detained by health officials at the Sahar International Airport in Mumbai on Saturday morning. ,The six a" one woman and five men a" are members of non-governmental organisations across the country working in the field of HIV/AIDS. ,One of the detainees, Vijay Nair, who is the vice-president of the Udaan Trust in Mumbai, told TNN, aÅ“The health officers asked us to produce certificates proving that all of us have been inoculated for yellow fever. I took the officers into confidence and showed him our HIV positive status certificates, which stated that vaccination of yellow fever may be waived off as some of us cannot take yellow fever vaccination on health grounds. However, the officers refused to listen.aï¿½ ,The six are currently under quarantine at the Yellow Fever Hospital near Sahar airport slums. When contacted, SIA health officer M.R. Tambare told TNN that they were simply abiding by rules laid down by the World Health Organisation. ,aÅ“All passengers coming from African countries are kept under quarantine for six days. We will issue a certificate and discharge all of them on November 6,aï¿½ he said. ,When contacted on Saturday, state health minister Digvijay Khanvilkar told TNN, aÅ“I was not aware of the incident. I will immediately direct the authorities to make necessary changes and arrange for medications for the six HIV positive people,aï¿½ he said. ,Pune-based social worker Celina Daâ„¢-costa, a member of NGO Pathway, said they were humiliated in front of all the people at the airport. ,aÅ“The authorities did not even show the decency of keeping me in a separate room. I have been put up in a room already occupied by two other men. What kind of a treatment is this,aï¿½ she asked. ,Joint director of the Mumbai District Aids Control Society (MDACS), Dr Shantha Sankaranarayanan, said she has ordered a detailed report of the entire incident in order to take necessary action.

Title: Harassed HIV victims to sue govt
article: PUNE: Condemning the ill-treatment and public humiliation meted out by the Sahar International Airport authorities to six Indian HIV positive passengers on November 1, non-government organisations from all across the country have unanimously decided to file a petition in the Mumbai High Court on Thursday. ,Udaan Plus Trust vice president Vijay Nair, who is one among the six persons under quarantine at the Yellow Fever Hospital, told TNN on Wednesday that the petition would be filed immediately after their release on November 6. ,"We have asked the Lawyer''s Collective to draft the petitions which will be filed against the Union health ministry, civil aviation ministry, Maharashtra State Aids Control Society and the Mumbai District Aids Control Society for their lackadaisical coordination which put us at the receiving end for no fault of ours," Nair said. ,The six passengers were returning from the 11th International People Living With HIV/Aids conference in Uganda. They were humiliated in public and eventually kept under quarantine at the YFH in Mumbai by the SIA authorities for not possessing yellow fever vaccination certificates.,Pune-based Ruby Hall Clinic project AIDS director Dr Sanjay Pujari told TNN that it was wrong on the part of the airport authorities to seek to know the HIV positive status of the passengers. ,"I see no reason why the six HIV positive persons are under quarantine for yellow fever. If CD-4 count of these HIV positive patients goes below 200 then the live yellow fever vaccine could lead to some other health complications," Pujari said, adding the SIA authorities have violated rules laid down by National Aids Control Organisation.,The six detainees are from the following NGOaâ„¢s a" Pathway from Pune, Udaan Plus Trust from Mumbai, Care Foundation Manipur, Trivandrum district HIV/Aids Network Organisation, Global Network of sex-workers living with HIV/Aids from Kolkata and an individual HIV/Aids awareness volunteer from Mumbai. ,Pune based social-worker Celina D''costa told TNN that they had referred the matter to the International Human Rights Commission and the National Human Rights Commission in Delhi. ,"We have asked the state health department to provide us with previous records of HIV+ve patients who were quarantined for yellow fever," Daâ„¢costa said. ,Nair said that they had made the following demands in the petition to the union and state government: ,Â• Initiate judicial inquiry over the humiliation incident,Â• Suspension of the concerned SIA authorities,Â• Declare a social audit for the public to know the HIV/Aids work carried by the health ministry,Â• Maintain complete transparency with respect to HIV/Aids funds received from World Bank and Global funds and draft clear guidelines for PLWHAs and quarantine procedures in the next 30 days.,Medical certificates issued by the respective state governments had clearly stated the HIV positive status of the six individuals and said vaccination of yellow fever may be waived off as some of them have low immunity. ,"It is dangerous for us to take the vaccination as our immunity is low, it can lower our CD-4 count. However, the officers refused to listen," Nair alleged.

Title: Study gives new hope to HIV/AIDS patients
article: PUNE: The recent findings of the first and the largest-ever study in India of HIV/AIDS patients taking a fixed-dose generic combination by two tertiary referral setups, one of them from the city, has raised hopes of aÅ“a safe and effective treatmentaï¿½ for the patients. ,Speaking to TNN, city-based AIDS expert Dr Sanjay Pujari, who along with Dr Atul Patel of the Ahmedabad-based Sterling Hospital undertook the study involving 1,253 patients three years ago, said, aÅ“The use of a three-drug generic combination, involving nevirapine, has shown considerable impact on the clinical status of the patients.aï¿½ ,aÅ“Not only have the patients shown an improvement in their CD counts a" a clinical test done to measure the strength of the immune system of an infected person a" but they also recorded a healthy clinical status,aï¿½ Pujari said. The findings of the study were released at the second international AIDS conference in Paris recently. ,aÅ“This is the largest-ever study on HIV/AIDS patients in India, and the largest across the globe, using a generic combination,aï¿½ Pujari said. ,According to him, a significant part of the study is that about 150 patients have completed two years of treatment on the formulation. ,Generic drugs are identical, or bioequivalent of a brand name drug in dosage form, safety, strength, route of administration, quality, performance characteristics and intended use, but are typically sold at substantial discounts, making them ideal for developing countries.,Also, a report published by the American Foundation of Aids Research in October stated that Pujari and Patilaâ„¢s study has revealed a aÅ“good safety and lasting immunological improvement on HIV patients, administered with the fixed-dose nevirapine-based highly active ART formulationaï¿½. ,Not surprising then that, in December, the World Health Organisation has invited Pujari for a aÅ“consultation meetingaï¿½ on the use of generic drugs by HIV patients in developing nations.

Title: Experts want amendment in laws to curb spread of HIV
article: VADODARA: A group of lawyers from Mumbai and Delhi have blamed gaps in Indian laws as a major impediment to curb the spread of HIV in the country.,aÅ“We have at least Rs 3,000 crore at our disposal and more funds are bound to flow in considering the fact that India is still the obvious choice for manpower hunters across the world. A major part of the funds is being utilised for infrastructure upgradation instead of developing and distributing vaccines,aï¿½ says Mumbai-based advocate Anand Grover, while addressing the national conference on AIDS held in Vadodara on Saturday.,Grover discussed the legal and ethical issues related to HIV and appealed to the medical fraternity to be sensitive to the needs of HIV patients.,aÅ“A sea change in attitudes is necessary to tackle the issue. If qualified doctors practice strict confidentiality and donaâ„¢t discriminate, we can put an end to the quack menace,aï¿½ says Grover, who is the director of HIV/AIDS Unit of Lawyeraâ„¢s Collective in Mumbai, which advocates a comprehensive law that could strengthen public health services.,Advocating a law that respects consent and confidentiality of individuals, protect people from discrimination based on HIV status, Grover said, aÅ“We seek to provide a safe haven to the marginalised sections of the society like homosexuals, drug addicts and commercial sex workers. This will encourage them to seek medical intervention.,Now, we are at loggerheads with law as distribution of fresh needles and condoms is banned.aï¿½,A major social transformation is possible with legal modifications.,HIV is no more restricted to high-risk groups but has filtered down to the general population.,This has made amendments to the existing laws inevitable. Perhaps, a change of law regarding marital rapes, amendment to IPC Section 377 (which bans unnatural sexual behaviour), Immoral Trafficking Prevention Act and the Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances (prevention) Act, will create a congenial atmosphere for radical improvements in public health, feels Grover.,aÅ“Our proposals are only peoplefriendly laws that are already implemented in the UK, Australia, Hong Kong, Philippines and US. They will only act as a catalyst to improve public health rather than attack our ethical values,aï¿½ says Grover, underlining the importance of safety of health care workers.,aÅ“Incidence of HIV infection due to occupational exposure though negligible needs to be addressed. Every health care worker should be provided gloves, vaccines and safer working environment and equipped with knowledge and understanding of diseases.,An insurance cover will be a boon,aï¿½ says Grover.,Referring to the practice of subjecting all patients to HIV tests at private hospitals and making HIV test for employees compulsory at private companies, Grover says, aÅ“The law needs an immediate amendment as private sectors can still evade prosecution for discrimination on the basis of HIV status.aï¿½,aÅ“This will glorify the stigma attached to the disease, thus crippling the HIV treatment services.,And HIV tests, prior to surgeries, are like a double-edged sword. If the patient tests positive, he might be deprived of the health services. But if he tests false negative, the doctor is at a great risk as he will falter on caution assuming it to be risk free,aï¿½ he added.
