The findings of the study were released at the second international AIDS conference in Paris recently. ,aÅ“This is the largest-ever study on HIV/AIDS patients in India, and the largest across the globe, using a generic combination,aï¿½ Pujari said. ,According to him, a significant part of the study is that about 150 patients have completed two years of treatment on the formulation. ,Generic drugs are identical, or bioequivalent of a brand name drug in dosage form, safety, strength, route of administration, quality, performance characteristics and intended use, but are typically sold at substantial discounts, making them ideal for developing countries.,Also, a report published by the American Foundation of Aids Research in October stated that Pujari and Patilaâ„¢s study has revealed a aÅ“good safety and lasting immunological improvement on HIV patients, administered with the fixed-dose nevirapine-based highly active ART formulationaï¿½. ,Not surprising then that, in December, the World Health Organisation has invited Pujari for a aÅ“consultation meetingaï¿½ on the use of generic drugs by HIV patients in developing nations.

Title: India to kick start HIV vaccine development next year
article: VADODARA: If South Africa tops the list of countries with 4.5 million HIV positive people, India is right at its heels, coming in second, with four million HIV cases. ,But when it comes to developing vaccines among the developing countries, it is Thailand, Brazil and Uganda, who take the lead. In the wake of the global emergency declared by the US, India has taken the plunge in developing preventive vaccines. ,aÅ“Under the prime ministeraâ„¢s initiative programme, a chain of research units in India would join hands to develop vaccine for the subtype C, which is prevalent in India. The project will begin in May 2004,aï¿½ R Gangakhedkar, assistant director of the National Aids Research Institute (NARI), Pune, one of the institutes to be involved in the vaccine development programme said. ,The other reputed institutes include NIV, NICED, AIIMS, IISC and NCCS. Addressing the three-day national conference of the Indian Association for the study of STD and AIDS held in Vadodara on Friday, Gangakhedkar said, aÅ“The virus causing AIDS has global variations or sub types a" America and Europe have aËœBaâ„¢ type, while Asia and Australia have aËœCaâ„¢, aËœeaâ„¢ and aËœbaâ„¢ types. This compels India to develop its own vaccine as we cannot benefit from the vaccines developed in the West.aï¿½ ,Vaccine development is a tough task, admits Gangakhedkar. aÅ“We cannot bank on the assistance of the developed countries as they would target diseases endemic to their regions and in this case address subtypes prevalent in their region. ,Second, it is difficult to produce vaccine for HIV as the genomic sequence of the virus is error- prone and has a tendency to change its form each time it multiples,aï¿½ he says. ,Elaborating on the clinical trials that will be carried out in the region, which will focus on preventive, therapeutic and perinatal vaccines, Gangakhedkar said, aÅ“As drug trials on animals have been considerably successful, we need to conduct human trials. For this, we have a three-phase investigation where safety of the drug, immunogenecity (ability to boost immunity response) and the efficacy (effectiveness) will tested before the vaccine is finally approved.aï¿½ ,aÅ“We intend to rope in doctors, NGOs, media and other outreach workers to create awareness among people about AIDS prevention and also the need to extend co-operation for clinical trials,aï¿½ says Gangakhedkar, pointing at the hindering factors like ethical, legal and social implications of the research.

Title: 36 HIV cases in one month in city
article: PATNA: As many as 36 new HIV-positive cases were reported last month at the voluntary counselling and testing centre being run by the Bihar State Aids Control Society at the Rajendra Memorial Research Institute, Agamkuan, Patna.,The detection of so many fresh HIV-positive cases at one centre, that too in a single month, has surprised the BSACS authorities. A senior official of the health deparment said that out of the 36 new HIV-positive cases detected at the RMRIaâ„¢s VCTC centre, 21 were males and 15 were females. Moreover, another 22 new HIV-positive cases were detected at Sen Diagnostic, Patna, last month.,The project director of BSACS, C K Anil, said that as many as 123 persons had undergone voluntary test at the RMRI centre, of which 36 tested HIV-positive. He admitted that it was a disturbing development as almost 30% of those who had undergone test had tested HIV-positive.,It may be noted here that till September in the current year, 30 VCTCs were functional in the state. The health department official said that 7,528 persons had undergone voluntary tests at these centres till September, of which 791 had tested HIV-positive.,With the detection of 36 new cases at the RMRI centre, the total number of HIV-positive cases detected at the 30 VCTCs during the current year had increased to 827 till October. ,The total number of HIV-positive cases in Bihar had increasaed to 4,288. This figure could, however, go up further when the figure for 29 remaining VCTCs for October was made available to the health department, the official added. He said that the number of Aids cases in Bihar had increased to 159.,Anil said that by the end of the current financial year, 46 VCTCs would be operational in the state. As of now, 52 trained counsellors, including 23 females, are manning the 30 functional VCTCs in the state.,With a view to creating awareness about Aids and HIV, the BSACS had got printed one lakh postcards in collaboration with the department of post, the health department official said. Apart from it, he said, Aids awareness messages were also being written on state-run buses. ,But, the BSACS was able to spend only Rs 1.36 lakh on Aids awareness and information, education and communication (IEC) till September this year against an allocation of Rs 10 lakh under this head.

Title: NIMHANS denies conducting HIV test on Telgi
article: BANGALORE: No HIV test was conducted on the main accused in the stamp paper racket, Abdul Karim Telgi alias Kareem Lala, at the National Institute for Mental Health and Neuro Sciences (NIMHANS), hospital sources stated here on Thursday.,Contrary to claims by his lawyers, prison records and the NIMHANS test report indicate that Telgi has been HIV positive for some time now.,aÅ“Telgi was not tested for HIV at NIMHANS. There was only a CD4 blood lymphocyte count that was carried out earlier this month,aâ„¢aâ„¢ sources at the hospital said on the condition of anonymity.,The NIMHANS report dated November 10, 2003 only provides information on the aÅ“absolute CD4/CD8 countaâ„¢aâ„¢ in Telgiaâ„¢s blood and does not discuss his HIV status.,A letter to NIMHANS dated November 9, 2003, from the chief medical officer and senior specialist at the Bangalore prison, requesting for the CD4 count, states that Abdul Karim Telgi is HIV positive.,aÅ“Telgi has tested positive on three HIV confirmatory tests a" Eliza, Combi Aids and Tenolot a" please investigate CD4,aâ„¢aâ„¢ states the medical officeraâ„¢s letter to NIMHANS.,A CD4/CD8 test is conducted to measure the strength of the immune system of a person already diagnosed with HIV infection. NIMHANS is the only centre providing the test in the state.,aÅ“The CD4 count is usually sought when a person has been HIV positive for some time and when he or she shows signs of a weakened immune system. It gives an idea as to whether treatment should be started,aâ„¢aâ„¢ NIMHANS director Dr D. Nagaraj told aËœThe Times of Indiaaâ„¢.,Telgiaâ„¢s CD4 count has been found to be low by the NIMHANS test conducted on November 11 and the report advises Telgi to contact his doctor for treatment.,A normal count in a healthy, HIV negative adult can vary, but is usually between 600 and 1200 CD4 cells per cubic millimetre. Telgiaâ„¢s count is 219. Telgiaâ„¢s lawyer M.T. Nanaiah has claimed his client turned HIV positive after he was injected with the virus by the police while in custody.

Title: Stamp paper scam hit by HIV virus
article: BANGALORE: Fake stamp paper kingpin Abdul Karim Telgiaâ„¢s counsel M.T. Nanaiah has charged the police team probing the case with injecting the HIV virus into his client. The police have denied it outright, and said Telgi contracted the AIDS virus much before.,aÅ“Telgi had tested HIV-positive much before his arrest in November 2001 and allegations made by Telgiaâ„¢s counsel Nanaiah that his client has been injected with the virus after his arrest, are false,aâ„¢aâ„¢ R. Srikumar, ADGP and Stampit chief in Karnataka, told The Times of India.,aÅ“We have evidence to this effect and we will prove it in a court of law at an appropriate time. Let Nanaiah sue us. We will face him in court,aâ„¢aâ„¢ Srikumar maintained.,Justifying his statement, he said: aÅ“Some time ago, a few newspapers had carried reports that Telgi is an AIDS patient and had contracted the virus before his arrest.aâ„¢aâ„¢,Earlier in the day, Nanaiah had claimed before reporters that he was in possession of a medical certificate issued by doctors of the National Institute of Mental Health and Neuro Sciences (NIMHANS), Bangalore, that Telgi had tested HIV-positive. Medical tests conducted when Telgi was taken into custody had not indicated that he was HIV-positive, he said.,Nanaiah said he had on Wednesday served a notice to the Parappana Agrahara Central jail authorities, seeking copies of the medical certificate, to sue Stampit.,Nanaiah said the jail authorities referred Telgi, a chronic diabetic and cardiac patient, to NIMHANS to undergo various tests on November 6. The doctors submitted a report on November 9, which noted he had tested positive for HIV.,The NIMHANS doctors also recommended that Telgi undergo further treatment, but the jail authorities neglected this, Nanaiah charged. Not only did they keep the medical report under wraps but did not provide necessary treatment to Telgi, he said. ,They had also ignored a recommendation by doctors to bring Telgi in for further tests on November 12, he alleged. Nanaiah claimed that Telgi, who has been in judicial custody since November 2001, was in police custody for 10 days a few months ago. aÅ“Then, doctors from a government hospital were administering insulin and other injections to my client. There is a possibility that the virus was injected to eliminate him,aâ„¢aâ„¢ Nanaiah said.,On November 11, he had filed an application before the high court that there was a conspiracy by the police to eliminate Telgi, and his suspicions have come true.,Meanwhile, Jayaramaiah, DIG (Prisons), Karnataka, refused comments on the issue.,Police officers handling the case alleged that Telgi is a womaniser and had moved in the company of several women before his arrest. aÅ“Telgiaâ„¢s personal doctor in Mumbai is aware that Telgi has contracted the HIV virus in 2000. His lawyer is making empty noises to ensure that his client is out of jail and kept in the comforts of a hospital, where the threat to his life is higher compared to prison. In prison, he is treated as a high-risk prisoner and kept in an isolated cell.aâ„¢aâ„¢

Title: ABC way to HIV prevention
article: LUCKNOW: Follow the aËœABC approachaâ„¢: A- Abstinence (delay sex till marriage), B- Be Faithful (avoid multiple partners) and C- Condom Use (practise safe sex). ABC is the new mantra to stay away from dreaded HIV (Human Immuno-Deficiency Virus), say experts.,With the theme Live and Let Live, a two-day national workshop is being held in the city on Monday and Tuesday, in preparation for the World AIDS Awareness Day on December 1. ,aÅ“Information, education and communication are necessary to inculcate a positive attitude towards those who have tested positive. The aim of this workshop is to increase awareness about HIV/AIDS, its causes, prevention and treatment. The target audiences of this programme are women from rural and urban areas of the country as well as eunuchs because their level of awareness is very low,aï¿½ said RK Mittal, principal secretary, Health and Medical Services, UP while inaugurating the workshop. ,To support this, several public service advertisements have been produced. One of them shows a woman Panch informing the other women of the village about their right to say aËœnoaâ„¢ to unsafe sex and being forthright with their spouses.,Clarifying several misconceptions, Dr Sadhana Rout said that HIV did not spread through sharing toilet seats or social contact. Moreover, mosquitoes are incapable of transmitting HIV infection as HIV is not able to survive or replicate inside their intestine.,HIV/AIDS is transmitted through infected blood and needles, indulging in unsafe sex, injecting drug abuse and from infected mother to her baby before birth. Surveys show that in India, 85 per cent of the cases, HIV spread through sexual contact. ,HIV transmission in late teenagers is rapidly on increase but it is most prominent in the age group of 30-44 years. ,HIV can be diagnosed on the basis of blood tests which are now available in all cities.

Title: Another 3 lakh added to India's HIV population
article: NEW DELHI: With India adding three lakh infected people to its HIV population of 45 lakh, the countryaâ„¢s generic drug manufacturers have been assigned a big role in the anti-AIDS campaign.,Amidst a bleak scenario with high prices of anti-retroviral drugs and an estimated 14,000 people being infected the world over every day, the agencies see a ray of hope in the manufacture of generic drugs in India and their exports to low-income countries.,aËœaËœGeneric drug manufacturers in low and middle-income countries (notably Brazil, India and Thailand) are producing certain anti-retrovirals, and are offering them in their domestic and, in some cases, export markets,aâ„¢aâ„¢ the latest UNAIDS report on the epidemic has satisfactorily noted.,The report mentioned the recent dialogue with the pharmaceutical industry to make high-quality generic medicines more affordable in poorer countries. ,To assign a larger role to the generic drug manufacturers in the anti-AIDS campaign, it referred to WTOaâ„¢s Doha Declaration. The declaration agreed that countries with insufficient manufacturing capacity in the pharmaceutical sector be given freedom from the compulsory licensing regimen.,The report argues that these countries should be given greater access to cheaper HIV-related drugs. aËœaËœAs a result, developing countries will be able to source generic anti-retrovirals and other HIV medicines more easily in exporting countries,aâ„¢aâ„¢ it said.,This has become urgent in the context of a new wave of HIV epidemic threatening India, China, Indonesia and Russia due to HIV transmission through injecting drug use and unsafe sex.

Title: HIV test in PMC maternity homes
article: PUNE: With World AIDS Day being observed on Monday, the Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) has decided to provide facilities to conduct HIV tests on pregnant women at its maternity homes in the city. ,Presently, of the 15-odd PMC-run maternity homes, only the Kamala Nehru Maternity home has this facility. Beginning Monday, it will be extended to other hospitals as well.,PMC health department chief Pramod Dhaigude said the city-based National AIDS Research Institute (NARI) was making preparations to test the AIDS vaccine.,Dhaigude divulged that the 46 condom-vending machines in the city, set up at a cost of Rs 15,000 each, were not in operation. He said the machines had provisions for dispensing condoms packed in a particular manner, but the company concerned had stopped its production. ,Condoms manufactured by other companies cannot be used in the machines, hence the PMC was planning to replace the machines. The PMC health department distributes around 6 to 7 lakh condoms, free of cost, in the cityaâ„¢s red light areas every month.,Though it is compulsory to test blood for HIV virus after it is donated, however, there are no facilities to counsel the HIV-affected. Counselling would be provided by the PMC soon, Dhaigude said.,To mark the World AIDS Day, the PMCaâ„¢s Pune city AIDS control society has lined up a number AIDS-awareness programmes between December 1 and 7. The civic body will organise a poster exhibition and street play in the PMC main building.,And, the PMC, in association with the Rachana Society and the John Paul Slum Development Project, will launch an awareness drive among truck drivers at the octroi posts on highways.,Social organisations like Saheli, Vanchit Vikas, Kayakalpa and the Akhil Budhwar Peth Devdasi Sanghatana will hold an awareness programme for commercial sex workers. ,The corporation, in association with Disha Foundation, plans to hold an essay competition for VIII to XII standard students on the topic aËœLive and let liveaâ„¢, from December 1 to 3.,Cash prizes of Rs 500, Rs 300 and Rs 200 will be awarded to the top three contestants. An elocution competition on the same them will be held for college students. ,The Disha Foundation, jointly with the University of Puneaâ„¢s National Service Scheme (NSS) unit, will hold a poster competition on the above theme for junior and senior college students from December 2 to 5. ,The focus of the competition will be on the need to treat the HIV-/AIDS-affected humanely. Prizes of Rs 5,000, Rs 3,000 and Rs 2,000 will be awarded to the winners.

Title: 'HIV infection by transfusion falling in state'
article: HYDERABAD: The World AIDS Day campaign for 2003 on the theme ''Reduction of stigma and discrimination'' will be marked by a huge rally from Dr B R Ambedkar statue at Tank Bund to People''s Plaza, Necklace Road on December 1.,The main objective of the campaign will be to prevent and ultimately eliminate the HIV/Aids related discrimination in all its forms, health minister Dr Kodela Sivaprasada Rao told reporters on Sunday. The slogan for the campaign will be ''Live and let live''.,Chief minister Chandrababu Naidu will launch the campaign along with ''Colleges talk Aids programme'' and ''Yuvachaitanyam'' programme, he said. ,With one-tenth of the global infections, the country has the second highest number of HIV positive persons, next only to South Africa, he said. ,The sad part is that 90 per cent of the HIV infected persons are in the age group of 15-44 years and more than 4 lakh people are living with HIV in the state, he said.,AP State Aids Control Society project director K Damayanthi said the HIV infection through blood transfusion has come down from four per cent to one per cent in the state. ,Aids prevention awareness programme had been launched at 11,464 schools. To prevent parent-to-child transmission, the programme has been in implementation at 14 medical college hospitals and 23 district hospitals, she said.,The state government is promoting awareness programmes among high-risk population including persons in slums, sex workers, truckers, street children, he said. ,Special awareness programmes had been taken up in the highly prevalent districts by involving all the departments, NGOs and women''s groups, he added.,Though there has been an increase in the Aids cases from 1998 to 2001, rate has come down over last two years from 26.9 per cent in 2001 to 20.76 per cent in 2003, health, medical and family welfare principal secretary S Bhale Rao said.

Title: Getting a firm grip on HIV fright
article: LUCKNOW: Getting tested for HIV might prove to be a relief. After all, one surely would not want to know about it once one actually is in the grip of the deadly AIDS.,Here for conducting a five-day training programme for education officers of Central Board for Workers Education (CBWE) on prevention of HIV/Aids, programme officer, International Labour Organisation (ILO), P Joshila said that while education was the only means to eradicate Aids, people must get themselves tested for the virus to live a longer and healthier life.,Even routine persistent cold, cough and fever indicated a weak immune system. This, in turn, could mean that the person is infected. She said mostly people go in for an examination after it is too late and the patient has only two-three years. ,Life then becomes hell, she said. Simple precautions for a healthy life after being tested HIV positive a" avoid eating outside and have boiled water instead of the usual tap water. ,And, simple precautions to be safe a" ensure that the syringe is sealed and if blood transfusion is must, get it done at a reputed hospital. ,Also, avoid drugs and too many sexual partners. Referring to the fact that workers are the most affected, CBWE zonal director KKL Srivastava said that healthier workers would bring more prosperity. ,CBWE regional director AG Maurya said they were concentrating in all areas including the organised, unorganised, rural and managerial workers.,Chairman, State Human Rights Commission, Rajasthan, Justice SS Ahmad was chief guest and CBWE chairman KJ Thakkar delivered the presidential address, member CBWE governing body SG Misra was the guest of honour.

Title: 6,000 HIV positive cases in Vadodara
article: VADODARA: At first they seem bright and happy, perhaps because their hopes are still intact. Even social discrimination and societal taboos have not restricted them to come out in the open and discuss their worries and hopes, their fears and dreams. ,These are the 20-odd HIV positive patients who regularly visit SSG''s Vatsayan centre-OPD 7 on the 16th of every month. The centre has now become synonymous to their tryst with life.,A recent nationwide survey estimates nearly 6,000 HIV positive cases in and around Vadodara. The figure further projects nearly one lakh people who are affected in Gujarat, with every third person amongst a thousand carrying the symptoms of the dreaded disease.,A major cause for the high prevalence of the disease, the survey estimates is lack of awareness amongst the high risk migrant population. It is with this purpose that the Vatsayan counselling centre was started a year ago under phase II of the National AIDS Control Programme (NACP). ,"Over the past few years it is being noticed that more women in Vadodara are contracting the disease. If the male to female ratio was 4:1 a few years back it is 1:1 now. It is because more men in the high risk group are transferring the disease on to women who in turn give birth to an HIV-infected child," said Y S Marfatia, counsellor at the Vatsayan centre.,The centre, besides providing free counselling services, also distributes free medicines to those who are affected. Patients can also avail free counselling sessions through a toll free number 1097. ,Apart from keeping track of the number of patients getting affected, the centre also analyses sexual behaviour in high risk groups. ,"Nearly 40 per cent of the total cases in Vadodara had become susceptible to the disease because they underwent a blood transfusion and women are in a majority. This is because most women are in need blood during pregnancy. A detailed investigation revealed that most of the HIV testing for blood done by blood banks was faulty, where three different samples of blood were mixed before the appropriate reagents were added for confirming the presence of the virus. It was basically a cost saving measure employed by the banks, since HIV tests are costly," adds Marfatia.,"A majority of the HIV cases are prevalent amongst the migrant industrial worker population in the outskirts of the city and nearly 20 per cent are cases where three to four people share a single room. Since there are no societal controls they are more prone to indulge in homosexual relationships," says member of Peoples Training and Research Centre, Suresh Parmar.,Another vulnerable population are the children who contract the disease at the time of birth which according to Marfatia can be prevented if proper medication is administered during delivery. ,"During deliveries a drug called Nevirapine is administered to the mother and later to the new born in the form of syrup. By this one can reduce the chances of the child contracting the disease by almost 90 per cent. This is because during birth maximum volume of pheotomaternal blood exchange takes place thereby putting the baby at risk."

Title: HIV patients avoid prohibitively-priced drugs
article: AHMEDABAD/VADODARA: Rani (26) was detected HIV+ve two years ago and has already spent some Rs 75,000 on drugs alone. ,A widow, with a six-year-old son, she had to stop taking the life-sustaining anti-retro viral (ARV) drugs, or die of hunger first.,Many HIV+ve patients, mainly from low-income groups, prefer to stop medication, as they cannot foot the bills. aÅ“The doctor kept taking so much money, and my inlaws are not supportive. Under the circumstances, stopping medication midway seemed like the only feasible option,aï¿½ Rani said.,Another HIV+ve patient, Asha (28), says, aÅ“My husband is HIV positive too. It was impossible to continue with medication and run the house. So I decided not to take the drugs.aï¿½,Sonal, who was detected HIV+ve six years ago and has not taken any ARV, agrees, aÅ“It is not worth it. But if it becomes affordable, I would certainly like to take the drugs,aï¿½ she remarked in a matter-of-fact manner.,aÅ“Used in the first line of medication are two drugs and proteas inhibitor regime consisting of aËœLemivudineaâ„¢ and aËœZidovudineaâ„¢ which are priced today between Rs 1,500 and Rs 2,000 per month, compared to Rs 18,000 or Rs 20,000 earlier.,However, it still remains unaffordable for the poor sections,aï¿½ said Dr Samir Shah, deputy director of ESIS and project director of National Aids Control Organisation (NACO) from Vadodara.,Gujarat State Aids Control Society (GSACS) additional director Dr D M Saxena says, aÅ“We are trying to tie up with insurance companies, to give some cover to HIVaffected persons.aï¿½,aÅ“If a patient discontinues treatment and then resumes after some time, the medication becomes costlier and less effective,aï¿½ explains infectious diseases consultant Dr Atul Patel. Of the 42 lakh HIV+ve patients in India, Gujarat accounts for about 3,400. Going by the GSACS data, an HIV patient has to spend as much as Rs 2,333 every month on treatment and tests.,But price apart, these drugs are not even easily available. This, despite the governmentaâ„¢s decision of exempting anti-Aids drugs from excise and Customs duty to bring down the cost of ARV therapy by nearly 25 to 30 per cent.,A majority of those who acquire the HIV virus are daily-wagers who can''t even afford Rs 1,000 per month on treatment. Moreover, government hospitals,which are preferred by this segment of society, invariably don''t have the drugs. Vadodara-based Aids counsellor Dr Sandeep Shah said, aÅ“The ARV therapy has to be continued for a lifetime. In this situation, the therapy continues to be expensive for poor people. Itaâ„¢s not possible for someone who earns Rs 5,000 to spend Rs 1,800 on a monthly basis for continuing the therapy.aï¿½

Title: HIV-positive? World's still negative
article: BANGALORE: He fell ill and got the ''treatment'' he didn''t deserve. Both from his doctors and the world around him.,Vikram (name changed), a 29-year-old local techie, was wheeled into a city nursing home with a burning fever last month. The doctors diagnosed him as showing symptoms of diseases across the medical spectrum: viral fever, malaria, monkey fever and dengue. ,When Vikram showed no signs of improvement after a month in the nursing home, the doctors decided to send his blood to be tested for HIV at a laboratory in Mumbai. The result: HIV-positive.,A fortnight later, the tests conducted on Vikram''s blood samples by another hospital declared that the HIV-positive diagnosis was wrong. ,Vikram was totally HIV-free, they announced cheerfully.,However, the experience of being a HIV-positive patient for 10 days has had a devastating impact on Vikram. Old friends refused to shake his hand or acknowledge his presence. ,His lover of 10 years left him. "The trauma will stay with me till the end of my days," he says. "My prospective father-in-law shut the door on me, I got separated from everything, not just human beings but even the day-to-day activities that I so enjoyed. I got a separate plate, tumbler, towel, blanket and was not an invited guest at the dining table." ,Ironically, even "The doctors at the hospital would ask me funny questions about whether I had come across any sex-workers, and whether I was a drug-addict. I contemplated committing suicide. But I knew somewhere deep inside that something was wrong...",Thousands of AIDS patients experience Vikram''s ''10 days'' as they waste away. Will we continue to make ''educated'' guesses about their condition? For the sake of everyone who has tested HIV-positive, Vikram hopes the world''s answer will be in the negative.

Title: Lala disputes HIV report
article: BANGALORE: Stamp paper racket kingpin Kareem Lala has filed a petition before the Karnataka High Court disputing a Pune hospital''s report on him being HIV-infected. Justice H.G. Ramesh has issued notices on Wednesday to the state and other respondents.,The medical report said the tests conducted on Lala on October 10, 2001, shows he was an HIV carrier.,The debate on whether he was injected with the virus, as alleged, after his arrest, has sparked off a debate. While medical experts suggested that the report was submitted on October 10, 2001, Lala was arrested on November 7, 2001.,The petition said the report was not reliable and that Lala had contracted the virus in jail. It sought directions to the government to return a wristwatch, gold rings and Rs 5 lakh which were seized from Lala by the police.,aËœLie-detector is another lie'': Lala''s counsel M.T. Nanaiah said there is no need for his client to undergo a lie detector test since it is not conducive to his health condition.,Lala being HIV positive and diabetic, his health is deteriorating by the day with blood and sugar counts reaching alarming levels, Nanaiah maintained.,"Lie-detector test is another lie," Nanaiah ridiculed, stating that it was just another exercise to hoodwink the people.,Govt seeks cases transfer: The government has told a fast track court (FTC) that it has written to the Karnataka High Court to transfer all stamp paper racket cases to the special court set up at Central Jail in Parappana Agrahara.,Special public prosecutor and senior counsel B.R. Nanjundaiah said the HC had been approached to transfer all cases relating to the scam. The FTC was hearing an application filed by Lala seeking permission to visit his ailing mother and wife at Khanakpur. FTC judge Nagayya Shetty adjourned hearing to December 30 since a similar matter is pending before the HC.,Meanwhile, the Hyderabad police has filed an application seeking custody of Abdul Wahid, one of Lala''s accomplices. The judge posted the matter to December 30.

Title: Down with HIV, yet fighting
article: NEW DELHI: For the past six days, Tas Nawaz (32) has been living on a platform at New Delhi railway station. Tas is a qualified gemologist who came to Delhi seeking medical help from a voluntary group after being turned out of his Chennai home. He had already lost his job. Nawaz is HIV positive.,Now his only hope is a care home in Tiruchirapalli, but only if he gets the Rs 300 required for the journey. "I lost my job after they found out that I am HIV positive. My brothers supported me as long as my father was alive. Soon after his death, I was thrown out," says Nawaz.,In September 2002, he arrived in Delhi. "I was in a very bad shape. My weight had dipped to 45 kg and I could barely walk. Thankfully, an NGO took me in. Once I regained strength, I started looking for a job," said Nawaz, who was the head gemologist with a reputed Chennai jeweller.,But soon Nawaz learnt that it was an exercise in futility. Employer after employer turned him down because of his condition. He had started with sales jobs, but the situation was so desperate that he even sought a pizza delivery man''s job.,"I chose to be open about my condition. Fingers were pointed at me once and I lost my job for no apparent fault. I did not want to experience the ignominy again. I requested them to give me a chance to prove my mettle. But no one was listening," Nawaz remembered.,Medical professionals, too, were no better. "I was treated like a dog. Medicines were tossed at me from a distance and doctors and nurses refused to attend to me even when I was vomiting blood," Nawaz said of his stay at a south Delhi-based government hospital.,When all attempts at making an honest living failed, Nawaz decided to head for the Tiruchirapalli care centre. "I heard I would be able to work there. But I have only enough money for the journey up to Chennai. I am at my wit''s end," said Nawaz. ,But the air of dejetion is deceptive. He is anything but daunted, and his confidence in life is unshaken. "I am told I will live for another year at the most. But I don''t believe that. I will live and I want to live respectably, without depending on anybody for my living and medication," he says. ,Amen to that.

Title: Pregnant women under HIV cloud
article: HYDERABAD: A survey conducted in 23 districts of the state between August and October 2003, aimed at collecting epidemiological information, indicates that more than 1 per cent of pregnant women in 18 districts were HIV positive.,During the survey, blood samples were drawn from pregnant women attending ante-natal clinics and were used as proxy to measure the prevalence of HIV in the general adult population. In Chittoor district, six per cent of the pregnant women were found to be HIV positive. In Guntur, the percentage was 3.75, Ongole 3 per cent, Kakinada 2.5 per cent, Anantapur and Vizianagaram 1.25 per cent each.,The difference in HIV prevalence among the urban and rural population is not wide and this indicates that people in both places are equally at risk. About 95 per cent of pregnant women, who tested HIV positive in the ante-natal clinics are below 29 years. Though the state government claims that it had been successful in grappling with the epidemic and has been able to create greater awareness among people, agencies like UNAIDS and NGOs are worried over the increasing number of cases being reported among young adults in the age group of 15-44 years. The multiple partner syndrome which was once considered to be prevalent among the economically weaker sections of the society like truck drivers, has now cut across economic barriers.,Those who belong to affluent sections of the society are also having multiple partners and are in the high-risk zone.,According to YES regional forum, numerous factors facilitate the rapid spread of HIV among youth, including age and biological and emotional issues. A number of socio-economic issues further complicate the situation. The YES summit document feels that there is inter-relationship of HIV AIDS with economic development. The "broad minded attitudeaï¿½ is pushing men and women in the ages 15-24 into the centre of the epidemic and this is a global phenomena. What is disturbing is 62 percent of infected young people are women.

Title: HIV-positive husband becomes a proud parent
article: MUMBAI: Nirmala Patil (name changed) cannot stop smiling each time she looks at the crib in which her baby sleeps. Her joy is doubled, not just because she has a healthy baby, but because the decision to be a mother was an unusual one.,Ms Patilaâ„¢s husband is HIV-positive and the Patils chose to have a baby through a donor sperm. This meant that the child is biologically that of the mother, but that the sperm medically implanted was that of a donor.,Ms Patilaâ„¢s husband, Pritam (name changed), was educated and an eligible match. But when the 22-year-old tested positive for HIV in 1994 his world seemed to cave in.,However, three years later, he married Nirmala after admitting to her that he was HIV-positive. As they longed to be parents they were faced with an agonising dilemma. Could they take the risk of having a baby and perhaps passing on the virus? An HIV-positive couple may or may not pass on the virus to their child.,Though Ms Patil had tested negative for the virus, the Patils did not want to take any risks for their child. Intensive discussions with family members and counselling sessions with Dr I. S. Gilada, followed. Finally, the Patils opted for artificial insemination.,Mr Patil was offered the choice of storing his own semen for about six months at a low temperature which might kill the virus. But as he said, aÅ“I didnaâ„¢t think it was a completely safe or viable alternative.aâ„¢aâ„¢ Besides each round of cryopreservation would set the Patils back by at least Rs 20,000, Dr Gilada warned.,Mr Patil was also worried in case cryopreservation failed to kill the virus. That left the option of using donor semen. Taking the decision, he confesses, was not an easy one.,aÅ“My wife was initially hesitant. For obvious reasons,we wanted our own child. But over time, she grew to accept that this was the second-best option. We felt it is better to have a child who, is at least, biologically ours to some extent.aâ„¢aâ„¢,The Patils case is a rare one.aï¿½Such incidents of artificial insemination through donor sperm are rare because people want their own child and secondly, awareness is very low,aâ„¢aâ„¢ said Hrishikesh Pai, infertility specialist.,He said for HIV couples who want their own child there is another alternative a" bringing down the HIV viral load in the husbandaâ„¢s semen and then inseminating the woman. ,aÅ“In such cases, the triple drug regimen for HIV patients is administered to the person to bring down his viral load. If the load is undetectable after treatment, we test the semen because it may still carry the virus in high quantities. If the semen sample too tests negative for the HIV virus, we wash the semen sample and induce an artificial pregnancy,aâ„¢aâ„¢ explained Dr Pai.,Experts say that though studies have shown the risk of HIV transmission in persons with a low viral load is very low, there is always some degree of risk. This makes the option of donor sperm insemination a safer choice, though, as infertility expert Aniruddha Malpani says, aÅ“Psychologically, such choices are difficult to make.aâ„¢aâ„¢

Title: Bishop plans facility for needy HIV patients
article: PUNE: To commemorate his 25 years in office, Rt Rev. Valerian Daâ„¢Souza, the Bishop of Pune, is constructing a Rs 1-crore, 44-bed speciality hospital for needy HIV patients in Akurdi. ,According to Fr Nelson Machado, spokesman for the Pune Diocese, the hospital is the brainchild of the bishop and is funded by the donations received by the him during his silver jubilee anniversary celebrations held last year. aÅ“AIDS is a big modern-day problem. The bishop wants to bring relief to the poor and the needy, who have been afflicted by the disease,aï¿½ Machado said. The hospital will have a built-up area of 14,000 sq. feet to begin with.,There are also expansion possibilities. According to architect Romeiro Silveira, the hospital will be a ground-floor structure, with a special dormitory for women and selfcontained single and double rooms. There will be consulting rooms for doctors and an exclusive administrative wing.,The central courtyard will house a multi-purpose prayer facility for people from all faiths. Said Silveira, aÅ“The construction work has been in progress for the last eight months and the hospital should be ready in six monthsaâ„¢ time.aï¿½ The sisters from the St Anneaâ„¢s Order of Bijapur, who specialise in medical services, will be in charge of the hospital, he said.

Title: Free medicines for HIV-affected
article: THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The Kerala government has decided to distribute medicines free of cost to HIV-affected patients besides providing them with treatment facilities, an official press release here said. ,In a statement, Chief Minister A K Antony said that the state was the first to announce such a scheme for HIV-affected patients. Kerala had around 10,000 to 15,000 reported cases. ,Each patient would require Rs 1,500 per month for the anti-viral drugs and government would have to spend Rs 1.65 crore per year for providing medicines to patients.,The project was being implemented as a ''welfare scheme''. In the first stage, HIV-affected patients would be given anti-viral drugs from all the medical colleges in the state. ,Arrangements for distributing medicines from other government hospitals would me made later.

Title: Insurance for HIV-infected
article: BANGALORE: The Centre plans to bring in a legislation to protect people infected with HIV/ AIDS during the trials of HIV vaccine which will begin this year, an official said on Tuesday. ,With the country emerging as a hub of clinical trials by pharmaceutical companies, the Centre is thinking of providing insurance cover for people who undergo drug trials.,aÅ“We have worked on a format with a lawyers group...aï¿½ Indian Council of Medical Research director general N K Ganguly said.

Title: Over 450 Mumbai cops HIV infected: Police
article: MUMBAI: Nearly 450 men among the 40,000 strong force of Mumbai police were infected by HIV, a top police official said on Thursday. ,"The figure is based on data collected since 1991 and the number of such cases could be more," joint commissioner of police (administration), P K Jain, said. ,He said that since HIV testing was a voluntary effort, it was difficult to assess how many more people in the force carried the deadly virus. ,"These figures have come from various sources and since 1991. Some of the HIV carriers may have turned full-blown cases and died," Jain added. ,Sources within police force claimed that the rising figure of HIV cases in police was more to do with the lavish living and susceptibility to prostitution than contraction of the virus through transfusion, surgeries, etc. ,Alarmed by the increase in HIV cases within the force in particular and the growing threat of AIDS in the world in general, the city police has launched a massive education programme in association with the Mumbai District AIDS Prevention Society. ,"We have established an AIDS testing centre at Nagpada, which will be opened in a week''s time," Jain said. ,He added that the society and Mumbai police had trained 800 officers and men so far in AIDS education, who in turn would spread the message of AIDS prevention in the respective units. ,"These trained officers will target the families of policemen who face the risk of contracting the disease," he added.

Title: HIV test for thrice-married burglar
article: AHMEDABAD: In an interesting case on Wednesday, Deputy Inspector General of Police (Ahmedabad range) AK Sharma directed that an accused caught for multiple cases of burglary, dacoity and murder, be tested for the HIV virus, since he was married three times!,The accused is 35-year old Punam Kachrabhai from the Vaghri community who was caught from Nadiad in connection with some 25 offences in the various districts of central and south Gujarat where he was declared an absconder. ,Punam married three times and has two children from his first wife, Mina who stays in Napa village of Anand district. The other two wives, Nanda and Saaba stay with him in Asodar village of Borsad taluka.,He is also said to be co-habiting with a fourth woman. Addressing newspersons on Wednesday, Sharma said that Punam used to earlier operate with one Mominkhan Pathan who is now in jail, in similar offences, after which he independently led the operations.,The accused has already been arrested earlier in some 40-odd break-in cases in Vadodara, Surat, Navsari and other districts. Last he was caught in 2001, after which he came out on bail and turned fugitive.,In dacoity-attempts in Siswa and Sojitra villages of Anand, Punam_s gang ended up killing three persons from Siswa and one from Sojitra, when the villagers confronted them. Punam was caught with an accomplice identified as Shakrabhai Vaghri from near Vaishali ,cinema hall in Nadiad by a team of the rapid response cell of the DIG. ,He used to live under the assumed name of Dhiru Vaghela in Asodar with his two new wives. When questioned, Punam denied having married any of the women and claimed they were his sisters.

Title: Mandatory HIV test for cops every six months
article: MUMBAI: Alarmed at the increasing number of HIV-positive cases in the force, the Mumbai police have decided to make it mandatory for each of the 38,000 constables and officers up to the rank of inspector, to undergo an HIV test every six months.,As many as 450 policemen have tested HIV-positive since 1991, of which 18 have succumbed to the disease. Dr D.R. Waje, police surgeon and head of the Nagpada police hospital, said the hospital has had 301 HIV-positive cases in the past five years.,"We want to tackle the problem on a war footing," said joint police commissioner (administration) P.K. Jain. "In the first phase, we have asked all the new recruits to carry a health card. They will have to get themselves tested for HIV every six months and this will help us in the early detection of the disease.",The police department plans to build a computer database of the HIV-status of its staff. Insiders say that several policemen indulge in high-risk behaviour. A deputy commissioner confirmed that many policemen contract the virus from prostitutes.,Jain recently took a review of such cases and has now decided to create an AIDS-awareness programme at 83 police stations and 12 crime-branch units in Mumbai.,More than 800 policemen have been trained to create the awareness through posters, street plays and personal interaction with officers and men. Dr Alka Gogate, project director, Mumbai District AIDS Control Society (MDACS), said her organisation plans to carry out a scientific sample survey to study the real prevalence of AIDS among policemen.,"The figures are alarming enough. But this data talks about what the police hospital has come across.We want to assess the actual incidence," she asserted. The MDACS also plans to set up a voluntary testing and counselling centre at the Nagpada police hospital.,HIV specialist I.S. Gilada claims to have treated 100 cases over 10 years, "Policemen who come to me have typical symptoms of HIV, like tuberculosis or pneumocystis carinii pneumonia, and over 90 per cent of them also have a sexually-transmitted disease as well," he says.

Title: HIV test made mandatory for city cops
article: MUMBAI: Alarmed at the increasing number of HIV positive cases in the force, the Mumbai police has decided to make it mandatory for each of the 38,000 constables and officers up to the rank of inspector to undergo a HIV test every six months.,As many as 450 police personnel have been tested HIV positive since 1991, of which 18 have succumbed to the disease. Dr D.R. Waje, police surgeon and head of the Nagpada police hospital, said 301 HIV-positive cases had been admitted in the hospital in the past five years.,Said joint police commissioner (administration) P.K. Jain, "We want to tackle the problem on a war-footing. In the first phase, we have asked all the new recruits to carry a health card. They will have to get themselves tested for HIV every six months and this will help us in early detection of the disease.",The police department plans to build a computer database of the HIV status of its staff.,Insiders say that several policemen indulge in high-risk behaviour. A deputy commissioner confirmed that many policemen contracted the virus from prostitutes.,Mr Jain recently took a review of such cases and has now decided to create an AIDS awareness programme at 83 police stations and 12 crime branch units in Mumbai. More than 800 policemen have been trained to create the awareness through posters, street plays and personal interaction.,Dr Alka Gogate, project director, Mumbai District AIDS Control Society (MDACS), said her organisation planned to carry out a scientific sample survey to study the real prevalence of AIDS among police personnel. "The figures are alarming enough. But this data talks about what the police hospital has come across. We want to assess the actual incidence," she asserted. ,The MDACS also plans to set up a voluntary testing and counselling centre right at the Nagpada police hospital.,H I V specialist I.S. Gilada claims to have treated 100 cases over the past 10 years, "Policemen who come to me have had typical symptoms of HIV like tuberculosis, and over 90 per cent of them also have some sexually transmitted disease as well," he said.,However, some HIV specialists contest the theory of high prevalence among policemen.,Retroviral physician Shashank Joshi says the incidence of infection among policemen is low. "I have treated thousands of HIV-positive persons in my five years of practice at J.J. Hospital and Lilavati Hospital, but I have not come across a single HIV-positive policeman," he stressed.,Going by the figures put out by the Nagpada hospital, he said, every profession was at high risk. Dr Joshi said policemen needed targeted intervention, not for HIV at the moment, but for other ailments.,"They are increasingly suffering from hypertension, diabetes, and heart disease," he said.

Title: HIV+ persons cannot be denied jobs, rules HC
article: MUMBAI: In a major judgment welcomed by AIDS activists, the Bombay high court directed the New India Assurance company to bestow permanent employee status on an HIV-positive woman on compassionate grounds.,A bench comprising Justice A P Shah and Justice S C Dharmadhikari ruled last Friday that denying employment to a person solely on grounds of his or her HIV-positive status was discriminatory and violated the person''s constitutional rights.,The woman, who has three minor children, had applied to New India Assurance for a job in 1999 after her husband''s death. Her husband, who was employed with the company when he died, had tested HIV positive in 1997. The company refused to employ her after she too tested positive. Aggrieved, she moved the court in 1999.,The court had at that time directed the company to appoint her on a temporary basis, which it did. The judges, who disposed of the petition, observed that merely having the constitutional right to earn a living was of little use if it was violated.,The judgment, say activists, strikes a blow for thousands of HIVpositive persons. Mumbai alone has between 3.5 to four lakh HIV-infected people, approximately ten per cent of India''s HIV cases.

Title: HIV+ people cannot be denied jobs: HC
article: MUMBAI: In a major judgment welcomed by AIDS activists, the Bombay High Court directed the New India Assurance company to bestow permanent employee status on an HIV-positive woman on compassionate grounds.,A Bench comprising Justices A P Shah and S C Dharmadhikari ruled last Friday that denying employment to a person on grounds of his or her HIV-positive status was discriminatory and violated the person''s constitutional rights.,The woman, who has three minor children, had applied to New India Assurance for a job in 1999, after her husband''s death.
