Title: HIV mapping exercise to be over by March
article: CHANDIGARH: A regional review meeting on mapping of high risk groups was organised by the Punjab state AIDS control society on Thursday.,The meeting was organised to review and assess the progress of the mapping exercise in Punjab, Haryana, HP and Rajasthan under the guidance of the National Aids Control Organisation (NACO).,The prevalence of HIV is considered to be on the lower side in Punjab and as per the HIV sentinel surveillance round 2002, the prevalence in low risk population was 0.37 per cent and high risk population was 1.6 per cent.,The director of the Punjab AIDS control society, Anjali Bhawra, said the mapping exercise is being done in 12 district of the state. ,These include, Gurdaspur, Patiala, Faridkot, Bathinda, Ludhiana, Jalandhar, Kapurthala, Amritsar, Sangrur, Ropar, Ferozepur and Fatehgarh Sahib. ,This is meant to identify the population group at high risk for contracting HIV/AIDS and also to identify the locations where they are concentrated. The first report on mapping for Punjab will be ready by March end this year.

Title: Free HIV drugs for city
article: NEW DELHI: The Delhi government will provide anti-retroviral drugs to HIV/AIDS patients free of cost. The treatment will be available at 29 hospitals.,Other new measures to control HIV/AIDS will include the establishment of 17 voluntary counselling and testing centres, as well as seven regional and 10 zonal blood testing centres.,The government will also offer immunisations at 10 hospitals for diseases that are transmitted from mother to child.,Delhi health and social welfare minister Yoganand Shastri announced the new health measures at a press conference on Wednesday. ,The government is also planning to add 600 more beds to government hospitals by March 31, including a 140-bed trauma centre at the DDU Hospital and a 57-bed special ward/nursing home block at the Lok Nayak Hospital.,There are plans to develop three new hospitals at Najafgarh, Nangloi and Kanjhawla.

Title: 'Promiscuous' street children given HIV scare
article: VADODARA: Thirteen-year-old Rinky, an orphan living on the streets, is suffering from a sexually transmitted disease. Not that she is unaware of HIV, but despite best efforts of NGOs, Rinky refuses to give up her street life as she feels the vocational skills imparted at the non-formal education centre do not fetch her enough money.,Sixteen-year-old Ganpat, a street child, has ''married'' twice and admits to have frequented commercial sex workers too. Occasionally, he uses condoms which are easily available at various counters set up by NGOs across the city.,Despite growing awareness about HIV, most street children indulge in unsafe sex. To tackle this problem, NGO Vikas Jyot Trust on Wednesday organised an interaction between street children and adults suffering from HIV. During the interaction, it was revealed that street children threw caution to the winds as they had a false sense of security as also indifference to adverse situations.,"Adults with HIV shared their bitter experiences with children to create fear of stigma and social discrimination. They warned them of lack of medical facilities and frequent bouts of infections, ultimately leading to death," says Kamlesh Bhatt, project co-ordinator of the Aids project.,Members of Vadodara District Network of People with HIV (VDNP) a" an informal group of HIV patients a" addressed various issues concerning HIV.,"We fell prey to the disease as we had no one to educate us. Now, our aim is to share our experience and motivate these children to lead a healthy and risk-free life," says Parag Panchal, a HIV patient. "Awareness alone will not do the trick. Fear of dreadful diseases is an effective tool to advocate safe sex. These children are often victims of abuse, exploitation and neglect, and need to be educated," says Jyoti Dinesh, project co-ordinator of Street children Project.,The meeting focused on breaking myths about the disease and elaborate on the evils of unprotected sex. "I have a serious health problem, and it appears to be HIV. Medicines have not helped me. But this ''tavees'' around my wrist has given me relief. I will never indulge in any ''affair''," swears Gangaram (15),who sells water bottles at the station.,Says sixteen-year-old Gopi, "Elder boys on the pavement bully me. I cannot fight them. I am scared I might contract HIV as none of us use condoms. ''Didi'' (NGO volunteer) has tried to stop them, but they have ''relations'' with older women at the station.",In an effort to pull out these children from public places to prevent exploitation, the NGO has set up eight non-formal education centres in the city. Women and children are taught vocational skills like motorwinding, computer hardware, beauty parlour, embroidery and skill development like broom-making and tailoring. ,"We impart vocational training to these women and children to facilitate income generation. However, it is difficult to convince them to give up their street life. We never compel them to do anything. Instead, try to reform their ways gradually," explains Vijaymala Thite, a vocational trainer.,(Names of HIV patients and street children have been changed to protect their identities)

Title: Quickie HIV tests give wrong results
article: HYDERABAD: Many private pathology laboratories in the city only perform a preliminary test for HIV detection and the result may not be sufficient to rule out the presence of the scourge.,"Apart from a preliminary test, two confirmatory tests have to be done. Only then can one conclude the status of a person," said AP State Aids Control Society (APSACS) joint director (surveillance) Swaroop Kumar Reddy said.,The confirmatory tests have to be carried out a few weeks after the preliminary test as a personaâ„¢s blood can test HIV reactive only three months a" called the window period a" after the person contracts the virus. A test during the period can give a negative result and the suspect believes he is safe.,The doctors at APSACS testing centres ask suspects to come back after three months for confirmatory tests, if they test positive at the first time. But some private pathological laboratories perform only the Elisa or the Tridot test, which cost up to Rs 250.,However, a third test Neva is conducted at the 102 APSACS testing centres all over the state.,"If two out of the three tests show a positive result, it is concluded that the person has acquired the virus," an official said.,The polymerised chain reaction test gives a correct result within 72 hours of contracting the virus but APSACS does not offer it. "We do not have the provision to perform it," Reddy said.

Title: NDMC goes on the HIV offensive
article: NEW DELHI: This civic body has decided to step out of the closet, into the market. Next time you step into Chanakyapuri Market or Khan Market, not only are you likely to be bombarded by public service messages on AIDS but you can even get a condom from a vending machine.,The New Delhi Municipal Council (NDMC) is working in association with the Delhi State AIDS Control Society (DSACS) to spread AIDS awareness. Plans will be finalised by month-end to place public service messages for awareness and prevention of the disease.,aËœaËœCondom vending machines can be placed near provision stores or grocery stores so that people do not hesitate in using them. We will, of course, be targeting all our hospitals and dispensaries,aâ„¢aâ„¢ said Lt Col S K Garg, NDMCaâ„¢s medical officer of health.,The NDMC is considering Connaught Place, Malcha Marg, Sarojini Nagar and Khan Market as possible launch pads for this awareness scheme. According to the state health department, Delhi has low prevalence of disease but high vulnerability due to various factors like a large migratory population and a high percentage of risk. According to a recent survey, Delhi has 25,000 HIV positive cases and over 800 confirmed cases of AIDS.,aËœaËœAIDS is a growing problem and we feel responsible as a corporation to work towards controlling it,aâ„¢aâ„¢ Garg said. Advertisements regarding information on the disease will also be placed in public toilets, garbage stations and bus stands.,The NDMCaâ„¢s 20 service centres will also have messages about safe sex and sexually transmitted diseases displayed prominently. ,aËœaËœResidents come to get birth and death certificates or pay their property tax through these centres. This will help in the promotion of the message,aâ„¢aâ„¢ an NDMC official said.

Title: India should lead in HIV/AIDS management'
article: MUMBAI: With the affordable treatment mode available for HIV/AIDS in India, doctors here have to take a lead in monitoring and management of the disease, said Dr Paul Volberding, one of the co-discoverers of the first HIV cases in the world.,"The challenge before the Indian doctors is to set up a large number of testing centres. It would be easier than before as there is an assured treatment mode which is available at an affordable cost here," Volberding from University of California, San Francisco who is on a four-day visit, said.,Volberding, who was a cancer specialist, discovered the first case of HIV/AIDS in 1981 in his famous 5 A ward of General Hospital in San Francisco. ,Even after 22 years of discovering the first HIV/AIDS case, "the understanding of human immune system is still incomplete and we are carrying out a number of experiments in vitro and in vivo to come to terms with the disease," he said.,Volberding who had been to the pharma major Cipla on Monday said, "we (non-governmental agencies) are trying to work out methodologies how to work together with pharma companies to give people of the world affordable medicine.",Attending a closed door two-day conference on AIDS here, he said India should also be using the information dissemination as an important tool in the management of the dreaded disease.

Title: Seven HIV cases in Madhubani
article: MADHUBANI: Detection of seven HIV positive patients, including three at Madhubani and two at Jhanjharpur, in the two kendriya pariwar kalyan melas, jointly organised by the Union government and the IMA, at Madhubani and Jhanjharpur recently, has caused concern among the people about the possible spread of the disease in the district.,The three-day melas at both the venues attracted huge crowd, bringing into focus the dire need of adequate health care facilities in rural areas.,A total of about 43,000 patients were examined by a team of qualified doctors.

Title: A hospice for HIV patients
article: LUCKNOW: They''re just like us. Except that they''re facing a no-win battle with one of the world''s most dangerous diseases today. ,Life for 30-year-old Suresh (name changed) and 24-year-old Veena (name changed) changed dramatically overnight in July 2003, when they tested HIV positive. Suresh, by then, was a full blown AIDS patient. ,"Social boycott and mental trauma had to follow, and so it did, but the most unbearable part was the contempt that people showed towards my one-year-old daughter who thankfully has tested HIV negative," said a tearful Veena. ,Hailing from Chamoli, Suresh was forced to go to work at a textile mill in Surat in 2002, in order to support his family. ,"A malaria attack, followed by a few vaccinations, probably introduced the virus into my body," Suresh told TNN. "But I had no idea about AIDS until the doctors told that it leads to death." ,However, the confirmation came only when the couple went to an HIV testing centre at Meerut. Veena has not exhibited any symptoms of AIDS yet, but has been declared HIV positive, revealed Sister Alice of Shantiniketan. ,Suresh''s health began declining a few months back, with bouts of high fever as frequent as once in five days with regular shivering sensations and severe loss of appetite.,Inaugurating Lisieux Shantiniketan, the only charitable hospice for HIV and AIDS victims in UP, project director, UPSACS, Aradhana Johri informed that NGO''s working for AIDS patients across the state would be networked for the proper utilisation of resources. ,She stressed on the need to set up more of such centres to provide treatment for the opportunistic infections occurring in the case of such patients. ,Chief guest, DG, health services, DR HP Kumar also insisted on establishing such carehouses for HIV/AIDS patients.

Title: Centre told to lay rules for HIV+ sailors
article: MUMBAI: The Bombay High Court has directed the Union government to enumerate in an affidavit on March 3, the existing rules for considering extension of job tenure for sailors in Indian Navy who are HIV positive. ,The direction was given by Justice Ajit Shah and Justice S C Dharmadhikari on a petition filed by a sailor this week who was refused extension merely on the grounds that he was HIV positive. ,The petitioner''s 15-year contract came to an end on January 31, 2003 and as per the practice he asked for a three-year extension. However, his application was rejected on the ground that he was HIV positive. He then moved the HC challenging the decision of the authorities. ,The petitioner was diagnosed as HIV positive during his 15-year contract period. However, he was allowed to complete the term. Thereafter his request for extension was not considered. ,He urged the court to withhold his name from the media. The court said the government cannot come out with a blanket rule of not giving extension to any sailor who was HIV positive.

Title: Explain stand on HIV-positive sailors: HC
article: MUMBAI: The Bombay high court has directed the central government to explain its policy on job extensions given to HIV-positive sailors in the Indian Navy.,The direction was given by Justice Ajit Shah and Justice S C Dharmadhikari on a petition filed by a sailor last week, who was refused extension merely on the grounds that he was HIV positive.,Anand Grover, the sailoraâ„¢s lawyer, argued that there could not be a blanket ban on HIV-positive sailors. Such sailors should be medically examined to check whether they are fit enough to perform their duties, he said.,The sailor, an engineer in a submarine, was willing to work on shore, but the Navy was not willing to post him elsewhere. His 15-year contract came to an end on January 31, 2003 and as per the practice he urged for a three-year extension. ,His application was rejected on the grounds that he was HIV positive. He moved the HC challenging the decision. Central government counsel said there was a government policy for employees who were HIV positive.,He said the Navy had allowed the sailor to complete his 15 yearsaâ„¢ contract despite his HIVpositive status.

Title: HIV fear has them SMSing for â€˜knownâ€™ blood
article: MUMBAI: Itaâ„¢s almost like a chain mail, only more sobering. E-mails and SMSes are increasingly functioning as SOS flashes for families desperately looking for blood donors.,While blood banks are still the first port of call in emergency cases, families prefer known donors for planned surgeries that require blood transfusion. aÅ“Half my patients prefer to go in for a known personaâ„¢s blood rather than from a blood bank,aâ„¢aâ„¢ says cardiologist B K Goyal.,Needless to say, the biggest fear propelling people towards aËœknownaâ„¢ blood is the HIV virus. Though all blood used for transfusion has to be tested for HIV, Hepatitis B and C, VDRL and malaria, none of the tests are conclusive thanks to the incubation period. ,aÅ“The incubation period for most of these diseases ranges from a few hours for malaria to six months for HIV,aâ„¢aâ„¢ points out HIV specialist Shashank Joshi. aÅ“Most people thus think itaâ„¢s safer to use the blood of someone they know.aâ„¢aâ„¢,And what better way to spread the message than to use neo-tech? Not surprisingly, aËœBlood Wantedaâ„¢ e-mails and SMSes have become increasingly common. Narendra Desai, a businessman, followed the SMS route when he needed to stock AB negative blood, a rare group, for his three-month old sonaâ„¢s surgery. aÅ“My friendaâ„¢s father got Hepatitis aËœCaâ„¢ after a transfusion,aâ„¢aâ„¢ he says.,Mr Desai did not even bother to find out whether his sonaâ„¢s blood group was available at blood banks. aÅ“I did not want to take any chances, particularly as my son is too young. I eventually found my neighbour had the same group; he was healthy and had no bad habits,aâ„¢aâ„¢ he says.,Jimmy Mogal, a communications professional, who had heard stories of infections creeping in through borrowed blood, also went scouting for an O-negative blood donor among friends when a relative was due for a lung cancer surgery. aÅ“We insisted on getting blood from people we knew,aâ„¢aâ„¢ he says.,However, blood banks scoff at this cautious approach, and point out that they take all safeguards to ensure that their stock of bloodbags is as safe as it can possibly be. ,In fact, they insist that blood from a relative is more risky. An official at a blood bank cites the instance of a mother getting HIV after she was given her sonaâ„¢s blood. aÅ“He didnaâ„¢t know how to refuse to give blood for his mother. The mother is now paying for it,aâ„¢aâ„¢ he says.,Dr N.K. Naidu, medical director of the Indian Red Cross Society blood bank, corroborates the point. aÅ“We totally discourage intra-family donations,aâ„¢aâ„¢ he says. ,aÅ“First, most relatives will not confess to high-risk behaviour, if any. Secondly, there is a huge risk of a patientaâ„¢s body reacting to a close relativeaâ„¢s blooda"this is known as the graft vs host disease (GVHD).aâ„¢aâ„¢,Moreover, aÅ“knownaâ„¢aâ„¢ blood is as much of an infection risk as blood from banks, Dr Joshi says. aÅ“No blood is foolproof,aâ„¢aâ„¢ he declares. aÅ“It is a myth perpetuated by TV serials and cinema that known blood is safe.aâ„¢aâ„¢ ,There are 22 possible bloodborne infections like pneumonia and malaria that can be passed on through a transfusion, irrespective of whether the blood is from a bank or family. Thankfully, experts say, the risk is marginal.,One more issue: all the trouble of finding a safe donor may not really be worth it as there is no guarantee that the patient gets the blood donated for him. aÅ“Most hospitals follow the FIFO (first-in-first-out) principle,aâ„¢aâ„¢ says secretary of the Federation of Bombay Blood Banks, Dr Neelam Nijhara.,aÅ“They may not respect a patientaâ„¢s demand that only blood donated by his relative or friend be used for blood transfusion.aâ„¢aâ„¢

Title: Civic body wakes up to HIV
article: KOLKATA: An HIV-positive person''s body lying unattended for two days has set a municipality on an awareness mission. Bhutnath Adhikary was found dead on Friday morning in a locked room at his village Bhallogram in Burdwan. ,When police went to the village, the neighbours told them that no one wanted to touch him. Apparently, he had died on Wednesday but his body lay unattended because of the villagers'' apathy.,The police took out the body and sent it for cremation. Before dying, Adhikary had been left on his own and no one even gave him food every day.,Stung by the incident, the Daihat municipality launched a programme from Saturday to identify HIV-positive persons and arrange for their treatment. Municipality chairman Kalidas Ray accompanied a team of police and municipality officials. They rescued Paritosh Roy, who would have met a similar fate.,Roy got the disease during his stay in Mumbai, where he worked as a tailor. Soon after being tested HIV positive, he returned to his village Dewangunj in Daihat. Roy''s wife deserted him and took their two-yearold daughter with her. That was the last he heard of the two. Even if he wanted, he could not have searched for them. His family members had kept him locked fearing that the villagers would beat him to death.,On Saturday, the municipality chairman and his team broke open the door and took him out. "He has been sent to the School of Tropical Medicine where the doctors can take better care of him. Here he will die of hunger as well. We are trying to do whatever we can to heal these people. The treatment meted out to them is inhuman," said Roy.,He said there was little awareness in the area on AIDS and HIV. He narrated the case of one Tutul Ghosh of Tikargunj village, who was rescued by the police a few months ago. He was brought to the School of Tropical Medicine. After undergoing further tests and medication, he was released. An electrician by profession, Ghosh decided not to return to his village but left for Delhi, where he used to stay earlier.,Another villager struck by the disease who has gone missing is Harihar Roy of Makaltore village, who fled from home after testing HIV positive. He left a note saying he did not want to die of hunger.

Title: US approves first saliva test for HIV virus
article: NYT News Service

Title: New HIV test gives results in 20 mins
article: WASHINGTON: The US Food and Drug Administration has approved a new oral test to detect the AIDS virus that is highly accurate and gives the results in 20 minutes without using a needle.,The new test is the second rapid HIV-screening tool to come on the market since November 2002. ,Using the new oral test, health care workers simply wipe a treated test strip along a patient''s upper and lower gums, place the swab in a special testing liquid and wait 20 minutes for the results. ,If one line appears on the strip after the short wait, it means, with 99.8 per cent accuracy, the person is not infected with the human immuno deficiency virus that causes AIDS. ,If two lines appear, the likelihood of HIV infection is 99.3 per cent, federal health officials said at a news conference in Washington on Friday.,"This oral test marks a giant step forward in the war against AIDS in America and around the world," Tommy G Thompson, Secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services, said.,He said that needle-free testing "will improve care" for "people who might be afraid of a blood test and improve the public health as well.",The test can quickly and reliably detect antibodies to HIV-1 and can be stored at room temperature and requires no specialised equipment, according to the FDA. ,The Federal Centre for Disease Control and Prevention estimates there are between 850,000 and 950,000 Americans infected with HIV and that a quarter of them don''t know it. ,"That means 225,000 Americans don''t know they have the life-threatening" viral condition, said Thompson.,Moreover, the Secretary said, "each year 30 per cent of people" who get tested for HIV "don''t return for their test results." ,Consequently, they do not know whether they are infected and might continue risky behaviour that puts sex partners and others at risk for HIV infection.,Jesse Goodman, Director of the FDA''s Centre for Biologics, Evaluation and Research, said that the new test was safer for health workers who had been known to become infected by needles tainted with HIV. ,"This test is a historical milestone, because it can be used anywhere, anytime by virtually anyone," Mike Gausling, president and CEO of OraSure, which produced the new test, said at the news conference.,He said that there was a possibility that eventually it could be used as a home test.,Gausling and federal officials both said that the new test had significant potential for use in AIDS-plagued Africa because of its low cost, ease of use and fast results. ,An OraSure official said that the price of the test would range between $12 and $15, which was comparable to the amount charged for the rapid blood test.,Gausling said that his company''s rapid and accurate gum-swabbing HIV test already had been used to confirm results of other HIV tests in Africa. In this country, however, anyone who tests positive for the AIDS virus via the new method will be given an additional test to confirm HIV infection.

Title: Congressional hearing sought on HIV/AIDS in India
article: WASHINGTON: Several members of the US House of Representatives on Friday called for a joint Congressional hearing on HIV/AIDS situation in India citing a recent report that warned of 25 million cases by the end of the decade in the absence of an the urgent response to the disease.,A formal request in this regard was made in a bipartisan letter, organised by Frank Pallone Jr, founder of the Congressional Caucus on India and Indian Americans, to International Relations Committee Chairman Henry Hyde, where 22 lawmakers stressed the urgent need to address the issue of tackling AIDS in India and the widespread support among the members of the Congress for a hearing. ,With a national HIV/AIDS infection rate of just under one per cent, as high as five per cent among high risk groups, and an estimated 4.58 million people infected, India ranks just behind South Africa as the country with the largest number of HIV/AIDS cases. ,Despite these findings, the members wrote that they are encouraged by the Indian government''s response over the past year. ,"Political leadership from the Prime Minister, and in particular, a group of dedicated Parliamentarians who created a Parliamentary Forum on HIV/AIDS, have helped to motivate plans to expand prevention programs, provide anti-retroviral treatment, and draft legislation to criminalize discrimination against individuals living with HIV/AIDS," the lawmakers wrote.

Title: India Inc needs to awaken to HIV/Aids reality
article: MUMBAI: aÅ“One of our employees has Aids. How do we deal with him?aâ„¢aâ„¢ The corporate official who made this call to an Aids expert working with Avert, a state government-backed project focusing on Aids prevention and policies, could well be speaking for the whole of corporate India.,For, Indian corporate houses have largely ignored this important public health issue. A shocking 97 per cent of Indian companies do not have a policy on how to deal with employees with Aids or HIV, according to a study conducted by consultancy firm, PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC), on behalf of Avert and the Bombay Chamber of Commerce.,In fact, the Bombay high court had to show employers the way when in January 2004 it directed New India Assurance to give permanent-employee status to an HIV-positive woman on compassionate grounds.,aÅ“We get many calls from companies asking for information and guidance on Aids-related issues at workplace,aâ„¢aâ„¢ said Nidhi Dubey of Avert, which has been holding awareness workshops for Bombay Chamberaâ„¢s member companies every month.,Not only are business houses ill-prepared to deal with Aids at workplace, knowledge about the disease itself is poor. A manager for an engineering firm interviewed for the PwC study admitted, aÅ“Forget my employees, even I donaâ„¢t know the difference between HIV andAids.aâ„¢aâ„¢,On a positive note, Dubey believes that corporate houses are making an effort to change. The PwC study too found that about 65 per cent of the respondents were keen to spread awareness about Aids\HIV virus among their employees.,Companies such as Larsen and Toubro, Siemens, Tata Steel and Novartis are among the handful of companies in India to have drafted a policy on HIV\Aids. aÅ“Studies have shown that most people who get HIV or Aids are in the 18 to 45 age group.,Most of the workforce is also in this age group,aâ„¢aâ„¢ said an L&T official, explaining why companies should take the AIDS threat more seriously.,On a brighter note, Corporate India maintains that it would not ask any employee who has been detected with HIV to leave. ,aÅ“If the employee can perform his duties impeccably, then there will be no problem,aâ„¢aâ„¢ said a manager of an agrochemical company. Because of the stigma attached to the diseases, the HIV-positive employee is allowed to keep his status under wraps. ,aÅ“The employee can tell the welfare and medical officials about his status in order to seek medical and financial advice and aid, but even his immediate bosses and colleagues need not know about it,aâ„¢aâ„¢ said the L&T official. Siemens India policy on HIV/Aids states that employees, if necessary, will be given an opportunity to be redeployed.

Title: Counsel cushion at HIV test labs
article: Avishek Mitra (name changed), a student of a city college had everything going for him when a single blood test shattered his life. A local clinic found him HIV positive. He committed suicide.,Avishek would have found the courage to live if someone had told him that HIV doesnaâ„¢t necessarily means AIDS. Or that he could have lived a fulfilling life even with HIV.,But now there is hope. Spurred by dozens of such tragic reports, the health department is planning to make it mandatory for all HIV-test clinics to have a qualified counsellor, who will help the patients a" and their families a" cope with the shock. Those that violate the law will have their licence scrapped.,The health departmentaâ„¢s studies show that though not all take a drastic step like Avishek, disclosing HIV status without counselling almost invariably leads to extreme depression and nervous breakdown.,The international protocol specified by World Health Organisation demands every HIV testing centre to have experienced counsellors who will encourage the patient to continue with life.,"All the government HIV testing centres have qualified counsellors. In case a patient is found HIVpositive, he is counselled by experts who are at least postgraduates in applied psychology.,Otherwise, an HIV positive patient cannot bear the stress and stigma attached to it and becomes mentally unstable," said deputy director of West Bengal AIDS Prevention and Control Society, S. Ojha. But there is virtually no control over the private clinics and testing centres which test blood for HIV which have mushroomed all over the state.,"We are seriously contemplating a law that will allow us to act against such clinics," Ojha said.,There are 22 government centres in Bengal to test HIV. "By the end of this year, we will have 30 centres in the state which will cover some of the districts where we did not have the facilities," he said.,All the more reason why these new centres should have the safety net of counselling for HIV patients. According to protocol, HIV status is revealed only when the patient gives his consent for a test. If blood donated for transfusion tests positive for HIV, it is not disclosed to the patient. The blood is quietly discarded.,Prior to a voluntary test, the patient needs to be explained every aspect of the infection. Even if any venereal disease is detected and the patient belongs to the high risk group, he/she has to be counselled about possibility of contracting HIV infection. If the person is found HIV positive, all health hazards as well as misconception need to be cleared by the psychologists, say experts.

Title: Best to keep HIV status secret
article: AHMEDABAD/VADODARA: The mood was sombre at the National Sample Survey Organisation (NSSO) as the 50-odd colleagues of 34-year-old Sunita Patel held a condolence meeting to mourn her death on Monday morning. Shy of facing the family, they thought it fit to send a written message instead.,Patel committed suicide on Saturday and has named two of her colleagues, Yamuna and Alpa, who had driven her to despair by their snide remarks. They had alleged that she had contracted Aids and was of bad character.,Predictably, Yamuna and Alpa did not come to office on Monday. "Usually, col-leagues would go to the house of the staff member in such an event, but this situa-tion is very complex," said NSSO director Chandan Bandopadhyaya. The direc-tor said he did not know about the HIV status of Sunita and that she was being targetted by colleagues. His immediate concern was to obtain a copy of the FIR.,Sunitaaâ„¢s case is yet another extreme manifestation of the discrimination and harassment that HIV victims face in their community as also their workplace.,Take Manikbhai Rathwa (35), a con-tract worker at a small-scale industry in Makarapura GIDC, who was made to drink in a separate glass and eat alone during lunch hour. It was an unsaid so-cial boycott. Manikbhai was sidelined from his job responsibilities, and with-in two months he was thrown out of the company. He died soon thereafter.,In the case of Babubhai Chauhan, not a single person attended his funeral as he was found to have contracted HIV. People of Maneja chose to stay away from his funeral out of fear of infection. His wife and a close relative had to per-form the last rites.,Most people never disclose their HIV status at home or at the workplace for fear of discrimination and stigma. In most cas-es, the employers fire the HIV patient.,A survey conducted recently by Pro-ject Support Unit, in which 799 HIV posi-tive people were interviewed, revealed that 47 per cent of them had experienced discrimination. "Of these, discrimina-tion was highest at hospitals (50 per cent), society level (44.8 per cent), family (39 per cent) and workplace (22.9 per cent)," said PSU project manager Arvind Patel.,"Despite a law, employers continue to fire HIV positive employees at will. Peo-ple take the opportunity to ill-treat HIV patients, be it at hospitals, offices or at home," says Suresh Parmar, Aids proj-ect officer with the People''s Training and Research Centre.,Gopal Bhavsar, a rickshaw driver, was harassed by his colleagues after they came to know of his HIV positive status. They would not let him park his rick-shaw at the auto stand and would tell people not to take his auto as he would spread the disease.,"There are at least two cases of em-ployees being chucked out of jobs in Bhavnagar and Valsad after colleagues came to know of their HIV status," says Prof Gaurang Jani working on Aids is-sues at Jyoti Sangh. "Sunitaaâ„¢s case should serve as an eye-opener for the government and more awareness projects should be granted for sensitising employees in the government and pri-vate sector," says Prof Jani.,Best to keep HIV status secret at workplace Rogues gallery to be more aËœfriendly aâ„¢ Three Srinagar-based pickpockets held: The Railway police nabbed three Srinagar-based pickpockets from Vadodara railway sta-tion on Monday. Valuables worth nearly Rs 10,000 were recovered from them. Acting on a tip-off, the police nabbed the three while one of them was trying to pick the wallet of a person at the

Title: 'Flawed' HIV diagnosis nearly kills youth
article: FARIDKOT: It''s a scandal that''s going to make anyone''s blood boil. Call it a fall from grace or a disgraceful misdiagnosis by a doctor here, Jasvir Singh''s life, as he knew it, was changed utterly when he was wrongly diagnosed a HIV positive patient at Chandigarh Clinical Laboratory here a little over a month ago.,On April 23, Jasvir had gone to Guru Gobind Singh Medical College and Hospital here as he was having some skin problem. The doctor at the hospital advised blood tests.,Jasvir got his tests done from Chandigarh Clinical Laboratory here. One of the blood reports found him to be HIV positive. Soon after the scandalous revelation, he became a social pariah, his engagement collpased (he was to get married two months later) and his mother Gurdial Kaur had a heart attack and was hospitalised. ,The trauma overwhelmed Jasvir so much that he even tried to commit suicide. After more than two weeks of relentless mental torture, Jasvir decided to seek a second opinion. On May 15, he went to Guru Gobind Singh Medical College and Hospital for re-examination of his blood.,Much to his relief, the blood tests at the medical college found him HIV negative.,To be 100 per cent sure, Jasvir sought a third opinion and got himself examined from Arashdeep Laboratory at Amritsar. This test also declared him HIV negative.,Another sharp U-turn in Jasvir''s fortunes, this time for better. But for Jasvir, the news of his innocence has come much too late in the day. He has sought legal action against Dr Adarsh Kumar of Chandigarh Clinical Laboratory for damaging his social and family life.,Dr Adarsh is, however, unfazed. He sees a conspiracy of his business rivals in the allegations of Jasvir Singh.,The doctor said that Jasvir Singh and his brother (who works in the police department) wanted to blackmail him and when he declined to succumb to their tactics, Jasvir threatened legal action.,In his defence, Dr Adarsh said that only preliminary test for HIV are conducted at his laboratory and these are never conclusive as two more test are required for a final diagnosis.

Title: 25 HIV positive cases detected in Yamunanagar
article: YAMUNANAGR: Yamunanagar is on high-risk zone as far as AIDS is concerned. In the district 25 HIV positive cases have been deducted out of which 11 are full-blown cases.,Yamunanagar, which is geographically situated on the borders of Uttar Pradesh and Himachal Pradesh is known as largest industrial town of Haryana where the labour community mostly migrated from Uttar Pradesh and Bihar live practically.,Truck fleet in Yamunanagar-Jagadhri is also the second largest in the state. Truck drivers keep on going through out the country, which is the main cause for increase of AIDS cases.,According to the survey conducted by the newsman it has been revealed that number of trucks has increased in recent past here because most of the raw material from Mine Zone situated here goes to Delhi for the construction of fly overs. ,Supreme Court has banned mining in Faridabad area. It has been learnt that out of 25 HIV positive cases 9 truck drivers are carrying in this deadly disease. According to highly place sources out of 25 HIV positive patients there are 21 males and 4 females. It has been revealed that the ten patients are from the rural area and 15 from the urban. It is further learnt that one female died in the recent past who was from Jagadhri. ,District Red Cross Community Care Centre has undertaken the survey job in Yamunanagar district. By now the 17567 persons have been counselled in 15 different colonies of Yamunanagar who have been educated about the repercussion of the disease.,Mr DR Sharma Secretary District Red Cross when contacted here informed that in Red Cross Community Care Centre Hospital two patients are under treatment, out of which there is one male and one female. He said that medicine, food fruits and others things are provided by the centre and they prefer to keep the name of the patients secret. ,He said that number of camps including two at Truck Adda, 3 at Industrial area have been organized in the district to educate the people about this disease. Mr Sharma said that help from Panches/Sarpanches has also been taken in organizing the camps at rural area of the district.,He said that in addition to the camps condom and readable material has also been distributed. Even the stickers have been pasted on the trucks and hoardings have been placed at important junction of the city that informing how to avoid the killing disease.,In Yamunanagar district there are 700 Plywood/Veneer/Saw Mills units where regular exercise has been undertaken to educate the labour community. Even now the special care has been taken at 100 Bricks Kiln in the district. ,The first ADIS case was reported in homosexuals in U.S.A. in 1981 and in India the first case was identified in Maumbai and Tamilnadu in 1986. Mr Sharma informed that the main symptoms of HIV/AIDS was recurrent fever weight loss, persistent Diarrhoea, Spots on the skin in different parts of the body, fatigue or tiredness and loss of appetite. He said that it is establish fact that 24 percent of total population in young between 15-24 years and everyday about 7000 people are affected. ,He said that people at risk for H.I.V. are not allowed to donate blood. He said that an infected needle, blades are a razor can also transmit HIV. ,There are three blood banks in Yamunanagar. The first blood bank was established at E.S.I. hospital with the efforts of Red Cross, Lions Club Yamunanagar-Jagadhri in the years 1993. The capacity of storage is 500 units whereas the other blood bank at Gaba Hospital and Shri Maa Blood Bank are also functioning well. Mr Sharma claimed that it is standing instruction to these blood banks to check HIV test.,Mr Sharma informed that Director General Health Service Dr BS Dahiya has appreciated the efforts of Mr Vijayendra Kumar Deputy Commissioner Yamunanagar for taking lot of interest to control the deadly disease. Dr Dahiya in a letter to Deputy Commissioner said that the Yamunanagar Community Care Centre will become a model centre in whole of India.

Title: Being positive about HIV+
article: Finance minister P Chidambaramaâ„¢s Rs 259 crores for checking the spread of HIV/ AIDS is intended to "shift the focus from raising awareness to changing behaviour through interventions, particularly for groups at high riskaâ„¢aâ„¢. ,Rs 237 crore of the total amount will come from international donor agencies. The programme also seeks to promote public awareness and community support to HIV patients and aims at inducing sex workers, their clients and others at high risk to change their behaviour and lifestyle. ,Part of the funds will go to support NGOs as well. Chidambaram re-designed the Universal Health Insurance Scheme, currently skewed in favour of the non poor.,Only a very small number of families below the poverty line are covered because they cannot pay the premium. He proposed to make it poor-specific. The annual premiumfor an individual is Rs 165, the rest being paid by the government.

Title: Kerala CM intervenes for school admission for HIV kids
article: THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Kerala Chief Minister A K Antony on Tuesday asked the Director of Public Instruction to direct the authorities of a primary school in Kottiyur in Kannur district to admit two siblings who were denied entry to the school on the ground that they were suffering from AIDS.,The Chief Minister issued the instructions to the official after the matter was brought to his notice by North Wayanad MLA Radha Ragavan, sources in Chief Minister''s office said.,The two siblings were not allowed to study in the school after some parents objected to their admission.,The children''s father was suspected to have died after he tested HIV positive.,The Chief Minister also sanctioned Rs 25,000 to the children''s mother for their treatment and educational expenses.

Title: Best Bakery accused suffering from HIV
article: VADODARA: One of the 21 accused in the Best Bakery case Jagdish Rajput has been confirmed to be HIV positive and has been sent to Mumbai jail along with medical papers. ,This was confirmed by city police commissioner Sudhir Sinha. ,After the acquittal by fast track court of Vadodara in June 2003, Rajput went for ayurvedic treatment at the Raja Narayanlal Pittie Ayurvedic Hospital (RNPSH) here as he was suffering from diarrohea and facing severe problems in digestion, his family sources told PTI here today. ,This hospital had suggested him to go to Mumbai for an HIV test and after undergoing tests at SRL Ranbaxy Clinical Reference Laboratories located in Andheri east Mumbai, it was diagnosed he had contracted HIV, the sources added. ,His family alleged that he contracted the HIV virus in the central jail here where he was imprisoned from March 2002 to June 2003 for his alleged involvement in the Best Bakery case in which 12 people were burnt alive in the wake of post-Godhra violence.,They claimed Rajput has never had blood transfusion in his life and in jail, he was administered fluids intravenously on couple of occasions. ,His family suspects that Rajput may have contracted it after he was shaved by barbers in the jail, who used `same'' blade for several inmates. ,Jail authorities have, however, stoutly denied the charges there are no AIDS patients in the jail.

Title: Free HIV drugs still elude needy
article: PUNE: The theme chosen for the 15th international conference on AIDS that began in Bangkok on Sunday a" aËœReaching new combinations of antiretroviral drugs to those in developing countries who need them the most'' a" is not without good reason. The city is a good example of this.,Three months after former Union minister for health Sushma Swaraj promised that anti-retro viral drugs will be available free-of-cost at government hospitals, the drug continues to cost Rs 1,500. "We are still awaiting supplies. We were told by the Maharashtra AIDS Control Society in March that we would receive the drugs in three months.,That period is coming to an end now," said A.L. Kakarani, head of the department of medicine at the Sassoon hospital.,Kakarani added that the anti-retroviral therapy (ART) had been introduced in Mumbai as a pilot project, and that the Maharashtra AIDS Control Society was waiting for feedback before introducing ART in Pune and Sangli.,ART training for the staff at Sassoon on administering the drugs and monitoring the treatment was completed in March. Besides, the hospital is also fully equipped with laboratory requirements.,Organisations like Saheli HIV/AIDS Karyakarta Sangha, a voluntary organisation working for the empowerment of commercial sex workers in Budhwar Peth, are also apprehensive about whether the programme will indeed reach those who need the drugs the most.,"Who is going to decide who the beneficiaries of the programme are? Given the culture that we live in, CSWs will be given the last priority in a government hospital, even though they may be in need of the drugs the most," said Tejaswi Sevekari, project co-ordinator of Saheli.,She added that though the health ministry had committed that it would give women preference over men in treatment, the chances of that happening were slim, given the patriarchal system that we live in.,"The big question is how the programme is going to be implemented. The implementation will have to be so structured that it overcomes the cultural hurdles that stand between the therapy and the ones who need it the most," said Sevekari.,The cheapest schedule of anti-retroviral drug costs Rs 1,400-1,500 per month. The drugs have to be taken lifelong. The criteria set by the government for preference of treatment is for patients whose CD4 count is less than 200.

Title: Segregation of HIV patients in the name of advanced care
article: MUMBAI: Though J J Hospital authorities refuse the presence of an AIDS ward in the hospital, a senior doctor, who did not want to be named, said that aÅ“the HIV ward has indeed made a comeback with a new namea"advanced care unitaâ„¢aâ„¢.,Not only are all the patients in this ward seropositive (HIV+ status), they are in an advanced stage of aËœopportunisticaâ„¢ ailments such as tuberculosis, strains of which are infectious. Hence, the doctor in charge of the ward, Dr Alka Deshpande, who was awarded a Padma Shri two years ago for her work in the field of HIV\AIDS, calls this ward an advanced care unit. ,aÅ“During our HIV\AIDS OPD on Mondays and Fridays, we come across many patients who need urgent admission. We have set up the advanced ward for such patients. We also have AIDS patients in every other ward,aâ„¢aâ„¢ she told TNN. It is only to evolve a uniform protocol of treatment that we have put these patients together, she added.,An official from the department of medicine said that the wards attached to other specialities were at times reluctant to admit AIDS patients with infectious diseases. In most hospitals, each speciality is given emergencyaâ„¢aâ„¢ duty on a rotation basis. So, patients needing emergency attention on a particular day are admitted to the assigned department.,Endocrinologist and retroviral physician Dr Shashank Joshi, an honorary assistant professor in medicine at J J Hospital, said, aÅ“Ideally, there should not be an AIDS ward. One such ward was set up in 1989-aâ„¢90 and had to be closed down in 1992-aâ„¢93. ,"Subsequently now, such a ward may only be there for isolation but besides HIV, it should house patients with other infectious diseases. I ammost surprised that it has restarted.aâ„¢aâ„¢ ,Incidentally, Dr Joshi and Dr Deshpande had together moved the Bombay high court to ensure the closure of the aÅ“discriminatoryaâ„¢aâ„¢ AIDS ward in 1992-aâ„¢93. The new J J dean, Dr Pravin Shringare, said, aÅ“We will take care to tell our ward boys and phone operators that this is not an AIDS ward. It is just that the medicine department has the maximum number of people trained in AIDS/HIV care, so most seropositive men are admitted here.aâ„¢aâ„¢,The question of an HIV/AIDS warda"albeit under the title of advanced care unita"got a range of responses from public health experts. Dr V N Kulkarni, joint director of the State Aids Control Society, an affiliate of NACO, said that there could not be a ward dedicated to HIV/AIDS.,Dr Nagesh Shirgopikkar, who is an AIDS consultant with non-governmental organisation Salvation Army, said that aÅ“it is absolutely wrong if any hospital is segregating HIV/AIDS personsaâ„¢aâ„¢.

Title: JJ's separate HIV/AIDS ward flouts global norms
article: MUMBAI: "Can you connect me to the AIDS ward?'''' The telephone operator at J J Hospital, the 1,500-bed state-run institution in Byculla, promptly connects the caller to the ward located on the first floor.,During a visit to the 14-bed ward, the nurse in charge answers in the affirmative when asked if this is indeed an HIV ward. The only problem here is that global norms don''t permit a wholly dedicated AIDS/HIV ward. Public health officials here say AIDS/HIV patients cannot be segregated or isolated.,Officially, J J Hospital authorities refuse to call the ward an HIV/AIDS one. But a senior doctor at the hospital who did not want to be named said that "the HIV ward has indeed made a comeback. Only it has been rechristened the advanced care unit''''.,In 1989, the National Aids Control Organisation had selected J J Hospital for a pilot project to set up a model AIDS/HIV ward. However, a group of doctors had then moved the Bombay high court to protest against such "discriminatory'''' practices and the ward was shut down soon thereafter. The same enclosure now houses the new so-called AIDS/HIV ward,which was started three years ago.

Title: HIV students fight for education
article: THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Despite Kerala Chief Minister A K Antony''s personal intervention to get two HIV-positive kids admitted to SNLP School in Kottiyur, Kannur, the kids are still kept at the gate and education authorities are meeting with local bigwigs and AIDS awareness agency to find a way out of the impasse.,Akshara and her brother Ananthu, both below 10, were ordered to be admitted to the school. But when their mother, an AIDS-afflicted, brought her kids to school on Wednesday, they found a big gathering of parents and locals who refused entry to the kids for the fear that their kids will also be affected.,The kids were ordered admission after they staged a dharna before the Secretariat here on Tuesday.,The parent-teacher body of the school, the local political leaders, and panchayat officials were holding meeting on Thursday to find a way out.,The police who were called to get entry into the school shied out after they found stiff opposition from the parents and local residents. Meanwhile, the headmistress, C K Girija, has been placed under suspension for "dereliction of duty". Her omission was her failure to get the kids admitted. However, she has pleaded helplessness as the entire parents'' body opposed and threatened to withdraw their kids off the school if the HIV students are given admission.,One of the agitating parents when contacted over the phone countered if this correspondent would send his kids to the school knowing they would be mingling with potential AIDS. When pointed out that there were hundreds of unknown HIV-hit people in the society, he said ignorance was bliss.,The Director of Public Instruction told ,The Times of India ,that he was hopeful of a solution. However, considering the delicate nature of the issue, he would not rush with a remedy that would do more harm than good.

Title: No plan to make HIV test must for foreign tourists
article: THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The state government has no plans to make HIV test compulsory for all foreign tourists coming to Kerala, state Tourism Minister P Sankaran told the state assembly on Tuesday.,The Minister disclosed this replying to a supplementary by A K Balan (CPI-M), who wanted to know whether the government had any such plan in view of rise in AIDS cases in the state.

Title: HIV kids admitted to school at last
article: THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: A fortnight long conciliatory efforts of the district administration, Education Department, and various voluntary organisations have enabled two HIV-infected children to get admitted into school in Kannur district of North Kerala.,Akshara and her brother Ananthu have begun attending classes at the Swamy Narayana Lower primary School near Kottiyoor, albeit in a separate classroom. While Akshara was admitted to the second class, Ananthu secured admission in the first standard. In a pathbreaking incident parents of two children have allowed their kids to share the classroom with Akshara and Ananthu. A partime teacher , K Vinod Kumar, has undertaken the task of educating the kids.,The deadlock over their admission ended following a series of meetings of the administration nd Kottiyoor panchayat President K J Joseph with the parents and teachers association of the school and with the locals. The trouble started 15 days back when parents of the school students and locals refused to allow the two children to join the school. The children''s mother, Rema, who was also infected with HIV, protested against this at the Secretariat at Thiruvananthapuram last month. The children''s father died a few years ago due to AIDS. Moved by the plight of the children, Chief Minister A K Antony directed the Directorate of Public Instruction (DPI) to take measures to ensure the admission of the kids into the school. However the resistance from the parents and school staff delayed it for many days. Awareness campaign, conciliatory gesture negotiations all went in to make the move a success.

Title: Over 5 mn HIV/AIDS cases in India
article: KOLKATA: There are 5.1 million cases of HIV/AIDS in India at present with the highest incidence in Maharashtra, Union Minister for Statistics and Programme Implementation Oscar Fernandes said on Wednesday.,"From Maharashtra and Mumbai, the scourge of AIDS is spreading all over the country. Mumbai is the gateway for AIDS ... Incidence of the disease has rised from 3.8 million to 5.1 million," he said at the inauguration of the West Bengal Legislators Forum on HIV/AIDS in the Assembly premises here.,Fernandes, who is also the convenor of the Forum of Parliamentarians on HIV/AIDS, said till recently he had been unaware that the highest incidence of the disease in Karnataka was in his own constituency from where a sizeable number of people went to work in Mumbai.,He said the general perception that incidence of the disease was less in Bihar and UP may be proved wrong in future as there was no adequate detection facilities in those states.,Pointing out that the Forum of Parliamentarians on HIV/AIDS had been formed during the 13th Lok Sabha, Fernandes said it was the first step in sensitising legislators about the dreaded disease and now such fora were being formed at the assembly level. ,"The idea is that unless the political leadership becomes serious in fighting the disease, the common people will not take it seriously. It is heartening to note that the issue of HIV/AIDS has been included in the Common Minimum Programme of the UPA government," he said. PTI SBR KK SDG 08041913 D West Bengal Chief Minister Buddhadev Bhattacharjee said there were 5,489 HIV-positive cases in the state at present and of these 2,637 were cases of full-blown AIDS.,The number of women afflicted with the disease was more than men, he said, adding that 88 per cent of such cases had occurred owing to sexual transmission, while two per cent was due to transfusion of infected blood. ,Stating that the rising number of HIV/AIDS cases in the port township of Haldia in East Midnapore district was causing concern, he added that massive awarenes campaign must be launched among truckers and migrant workers. ,"We must shed the puritan attitude and take the campaign to the schools. We have been able to reach to a lakh children till now, but we need to do more," he said.,There were 34 Centrally-sponsored and 23 state-funded HIV/AIDS detection centres in West Bengal, the chief minister said adding the number of such clinics needed to be increased.,Altogether 60 lakh pieces of condoms have so far been distributed among people of the vulnerable groups, he said.,Others who spoke on the occasion included Speaker Hasim Abdul Halim, State Health Minister Surya Kanta Mishra, Parliamentary Affairs Minister Prabodh Sinha and Union Health Secretary J V Prasad Rao.

Title: Know HIV better, it's closer than you think
article: LUCKNOW: That running nose, that apparently harmless looking fever accompanied by body ache and throat pain could portend the fatal HIV positive infection, say experts.,Talking to TOI, classified medical specialist and clinical immunologist Command Hospital (Central Command) Lucknow, Lt Col DS Bhakuni, outlined the basics for people who could be in the grip of the deadly virus.,While unprotected sexual contact and shared needles/syringes were the commonest cause for the spread of the virus, Bhakuni said that the symptoms appeared in about 2-6 weeks. "In 50 per cent of the cases there are no symptoms at all," said Bhakuni, adding that one must go in for a test to be sure that one had not contracted the virus.,Since the test was based on antibodies forming after the virus entered the body, the results could be varying, he said. While a three-month period was considered sufficient for the test to give the result, ideally the person must be tested after six months too, he stressed. This was essential for people who had a slow immune system, Bhakuni explained.,Speaking at the concluding session of the two-day CME programme on ''Emergencies in medical practice'' at the Command Hospital on Sunday, Bhakuni said that health care workers (HCW) were at a major risk of contracting the disease. "India has approximately 5.1 million HIV positive cases and our armed forces population has not been spared. In our service hospitals we come across HIV patients for review, treatment and also the newly diagnosed ones," said Bhakuni, adding that they were being attended in all the disciplines of medicine and surgery resulting in exposure of HCWs.,"The operation theatre staff, nurses, nursing attendants and safaiwallas are particularly exposed to the accidental HIV infection by needles, blood and body fluids, he said, stressing that there is a need for awareness among the HCWs regarding the post exposure prophylaxis (PEP) against HIV infection.,Bhakuni mentioned that although the first case of HIV infection was reported in 1981, the guidelines for PEP were formulated in 1998 in USA based on clinical studies on anti retro viral (ARV) drugs as Zidovudine and Nevirapine. The last revision was done in March 2003 as newer drugs kept surfacing. Zidovudine reduced the risk of developing HIV infection by 81 per cent when given as PEP. There are no clinical trials on PEP hence it is based on evidence based medicine and opinion of the experts. ,The ultimate goal of PEP, he said, is maximal suppression of any limited viral replication and to shift the biologic advantage to host cellular immune system to prevent early infection. Hence ''highly active anti retroviral treatment'' (HAART) regimen has been recommended. After exposure the local replication of virus occurs in the host macrophages or dendritic cells. The host cytotoxic T-cells will kill infected target cells. If the infection is not contained at this stage, it is followed within 2-3 days by replication of HIV in regional lymph nodes. Viremia then follows within 3-5 days of virus inoculation.,Given the rapid appearance of productively infected cells, regimens with the most rapid onset of activity, multiple sites of antiviral action and greatest strength such as HAART are most effective, he added.,Earlier, in the scientific session, Dr Rajeev Agarwal of King George''s Medical University (KGMU) outlined the steps in management of burns, while Lt Col SP Prasad of CH (CC) talked about ocular injuries. Col BK Chopra discussed long bone injuries while Wg Cdr MS Sridhar gave a talk on spinal injuries. Lt Col MD Venkatesh CH (CC) discussed foreign bodies in aerodigestive tract. Col Prakash Singh from New Delhi gave a talk on ''missile injuries of the brain'' which was based on experiences during Kargil.

Title: Focus HIV awareness on colleges, not schools: Experts
article: VADODARA: "Schools are not the right place for HIV awareness programmes," said experts on HIV screening at Polytechnic College of the MS University here on Friday. aËœAwareness about the disease should be addressed at the age of puberty and college level," they said.,Around 150 first year students took part in the programme organised by the Indu Health Research Foundation Trust (IHRFT) and the MS University. Vice-chancellor KC Upadhyay and deans of all the faculties attended the function.,The programme will be conducted in all the faculties where health kit will be distributed among 10,000 students. Blood samples collected during the screening will be examined at Indu Blood Bank and results intimated to students.,"The programme had two-fold reasons. We not only want to create awareness among sexually active age group but also prepare private data for research," said Kiran Patel, a Florida-based NRI cardiologist, who conceptualised the programme.,"The MSU has a captive audience of 10,000 individuals from this age group,who come from different socio-economic background. Most statistics available in the country is based on hospital reports which form less than 10 per cent of such cases. We always have a notion that ideally in our kind of society such cases are not noticed. Our study may support or discourage the notion. But it will create awareness at the age of puberty.We want to have a debate within this population to break many myths," he said.,"Many, who are not aware about the treatment, have a conservative or a flamboyant attitude towards patients who need proper counselling and treatment with latest technology which is now available at several places," added Patel, who is also president of the American Association of Physicians of the Indian origin.,Vijay Shah, member of the IHRFT, said, "The age group around 18 is considered to be that of consent and the knowledge acquired during this period prevails throughout their lives which is not the same with school students. Also,myths that its treatment and social taboos can be broken at this age.",Upadhyay said, "More measures are needed to increase people''s participation in such initiatives. The disease is feared to take over a large population in our country by 2010."

Title: Indians quit IT jobs, aid HIV victims
article: NEW DELHI: This is one outsourcing beneficial to all. Volunteers from India will work in developing countries in Asia, Africa and East European countries for two years, quitting regular jobs here to get international exposure and adding new facets to their lives.,So be it Mozambique, S Africa, Kenya, Nigeria, Guinea Bissau or Bangladesh, Indians will help in HIV/AIDS, community and social work management, micro-finance, IT training or fund-raising. The world has truly become a global village.,This iVolunteer Overseas Programme is the result of collaboration between MITRA, an Indian charity started by alumni of the Institute of Rural Management (Anand) and Voluntary Services Overseas, an international charity.,"Some 1,500 people applied to be sent as volunteers. The first batch of eight leaves in September, 20 more will leave in February 2005," says Rooman Arif, a programme officer here.,Harjeet Singh Bagga, a 25-year-old who works with Capart, a fund-raising agency of the ministry of rural development, is going to Nigeria as micro-enterprise development adviser.,"I look forward to working in a marginalised society and learning a new language and culture," he says. ,And the job he''ll lose? "Life is risky. With my qualifications, I can always get another job. I have no liabilities now; later on, it might not be possible." ,Is he daunted about going to an unfamiliar place? "No. I have worked in Jharkhand, Kargil, Kutch, Uttaranchal and West Bengal. Travelling in diverse India is like travelling within continents."

Title: HIV infection among women likely to go up
article: NEW DELHI: India was likely to see increasing levels of HIV infection among women as they virtually had no control over their husbands'' sexual behaviour, a report has said.,The infection was also spreading among married women with a single partner, the ''India Country Report on Population and Development'', brought out by the ministry of health and family welfare, said.,"The future will see increasing levels of HIV infection among Indian women, who, largely monogamous themselves, have virtually no control over their husbands'' sexual behaviour," the report said.,As a large number of women became infected, the number of children infected through vertical transmission was also likely to increase, it said.,It had been suggested that that if effective prevention efforts were not implemented immediately and sustained over long time, infected people in India could reach an alarming number in a short time, the report warned.,Though Mumbai and Chennai had been the main focus of HIV/AIDS, the disease was no longer restricted to the major metropolitan areas, it said, adding it was spreading to rural areas, carried for example by migrant labourers and workers such as lorry drivers.

Title: McKinsey may help in HIV count
article: CHENNAI: The Centre will seek the help of private consultants to determine how many of India''s billion-plus population are HIV-positive after allegations that the official estimate of 5.1 million is too low.,Health minister Anbumani Ramadoss said his ministry could hire international consulting firm McKinsey, IIM, Bangalore or Tata Consultancy Services. "We are considering private agencies like Tata Consultancy, IIM-Bangalore and McKinsey to carry out this survey. This will be finalised in about two weeks," he said.,"We are very much concerned. We want to check this (HIV/AIDS) before this becomes an economic burden," he said. "We feel ashamed when visitors to India express apprehension over the AIDS situation here."

Title: Very few Ganesh mandals take up HIV/Aids campaign
article: PUNE: Ganesh mandals, who otherwise would have jumped at the idea of using any innovative theme to decorate their pandals, still seem to be non-receptive on the issue of spreading awareness for HIV/Aids.,So much so that only 32 out of the 3500-odd mandals in Pune and Pimpri-Chinchwad are using the anti-HIV campaign as a theme in the decorations of the pandals.,The state health department, in an attempt to exploit the popularity of the 10-day Ganesh festivities in the city, had announced cash incentives for those Ganesh mandals using the anti-HIV campaign as a theme.,While there has been a marginal increase in the number of mandals compared to last year, deputy health director, Pune, Dr Y V Doiphode told TNN that the department as expecting a much more favourable participation. "The numbers of participating mandals will hopefully increase in the coming years.",Last year, only 22 mandals in the city had participated in the government-aided awareness drive.,The reason, as majority of the mandals in the city explained, HIV/Aids is still considered a taboo, and would not help in attracting the crowd.,Doiphode, however, said the cash incentive is part of a state-wide campaign, which started last year, where the best mandal will get a cash award of Rs 30,000, followed by Rs 20,000 and Rs 10,000 as the second and third prizes respectively.,"It is an attempt to create awareness amongst the public and sensitise them on prevention of the deadly disease," he said, explaining the idea of involving the Ganesh mandals was conceived keeping in view the latter''s role in promoting a spirit of social harmony.,There are, however, a few exceptions who strongly feel that using such a theme will only help educate the society on a serious issue. According to the organisers of Datta Tarun Mandal at Somwar Peth and Jayhind Mitra Mandal at Shaniwar Peth, such festivities, which draw a huge crowd, should be effectively utilised to spread across an important message.,"It is not money alone, but the social responsibilities of a Ganesh mandal," said Ravindra Chavan of Datta Tarun Mandal, who has used posters to sensitive the people on the myths and facts about the deadly disease.

Title: Donors to be informed if tested HIV
article: HYDERABAD: Blood banks are now getting in touch with donors whose blood is found to be infected with HIV.,Until recently, blood banks used to discard HIV-infected blood and never bothered to inform donors about their HIV positive status. But, now blood banks are contacting donors whose bloods tests positive for HIV and asking them to go for a confirmatory test and for voluntary counselling and testing centres of the Andhra Pradesh State Aids Control Society (APSACS).,The Central government through a notification last year had allowed blood banks to disclose a donor''s HIV status. In June this year, National Aids Control Organisation too issued strict guidelines similar to the central directive. Officials of APSACS say that the practise is being followed for almost three years now.,But, despite the rules and legislations, doctors say that blood banks took a while to come to terms with the gravity of the situation and the need for communicating the information to the donors.,"Earlier, blood bank authorities used to absolve themselves of all responsibility by discarding bottles of infected blood. Now, they realise that the same donors may infect more people if they are not informed of their HIV status," said a doctor, adding that now most of the banks are following the guidelines policy and some are even keeping continuous surveillance of such donors.,During blood donation camps, voluntary donors are asked to fill up a form with their complete address and contact numbers. The donors are also informed that their blood will be tested for various ailments, including HIV.,However, blood banks are restricted from breaking the news of a donor''s HIV positive status. They ask donors to visit them, where they are told to go for another confirmatory and counselling. "We inform them to discuss the matter with a counsellor.,We do not declare in the report that the person is HIV positive," said Dr K Rajyalakshmi, state secretary of the Indian Red Cross Society. APSACS officials said that the blood banks are also monitored by them and even by the Drug Control Authority that issues licences to them. APSACS officials said that the blood banks are also monitored by them and even by the Drug Control Authority that issues licences to them.

Title: 12 HIV positive cases detected in Kishanganj
article: KISHANGANJ: A dozen HIV positive cases have been identified so far in this border district of Kishanganj. Tis was informed by the steering committee chairman of Charca (Coordinated HIV & AIDS and STD Response Through Capacity-building and Awareness), a much-hyped joint programme of Union government and UN agencies like Unesco, Unicef, ILO and UNDP, here on Monday. Charca targets to combat the dreaded AIDS through heightened awareness campaign. ,Kishanganj district magistrate DM-cum-chairman of steering committee Krishnamoorthy Senthil Kumar disclosed at a meeting that Kishanganj is one of the six districts across the country which was selected for launch of the programme because of its acute vulnerability on account of its typical topography. Other districts are Bellary (Karnataka), Guntur (AP), Kanpur (UP), Udaipur (Rajasthan) and Aizwal (Mizoram).,District project coordinator and AIDS Control Society member Haroon Rasheed said Kishanganj was selected mainly because "it was one of the most under-developed districts in India" with low literacy rates, female (18.49 per cent) and male (42.8 per cent), and also, on grounds of poverty and poor reach of social development efforts. Besides, there was low media access which was figured out as radio (1.6 per cent), TV (1.2 per cent) and newspapers (3.1 per cent).,He said because of the district being located on Bihar-Nepal border and close to Indo-Bangladesh and heavy migratory population, this was quite vulnerable to spread of sexually-transmitted diseases.,Additional district magistrate (ADM) Dilmohan Paswan said NGOs could provide invaluable services to Charca''s highly ambitions preventive campaign. Civil surgeon P Manjhi and chief administrative officer of MGM Medical College Dilip Jaisawal said the train passengers should be examined at the station at the time of boarding and before going to their respective villages.

Title: HIV+ prevalence rate declines: Report
article: PATNA: The sixth round of sentinel surveillance conducted by the Bihar State Aids Control Society (BSACS) from July 1 to September 30 this year indicates that the HIV+ prevalence rate is declining even as it remains unchanged in the "men-sex-men" (MSM) category.,The HIV+ prevalence rate in the MSM group remained 1.6 per cent of the total population both in 2003 and 2004. High-level BSACS sources said out of the 5,510 persons tested during the check period at eight sexually transmitted diseases (STD), one MSM, two female sex workers and seven antenatal centres, only 37 tested HIV+. Out of the 2,775 pregnant women who underwent the HIV test at seven antenatal centres (ANCs), only six tested positive three at the Patna Medical College Hospital (PMCH), two at the Begusarai Sadar Hospital and one at the Jawaharlal Nehru Medical College Hospital (JNMCH), Bhagalpur.,The HIV+ prevalence rate was, however, slightly higher among those who underwent the test at eight STD centres.,Of the 1,985 persons undergoing the test at these centres during the check period, 26 tested HIV+. This included five HIV+ cases at the Duncan Hospital, Raxaul, one at the PMCH, seven at the Anugrah Narayan Magadh Medical College Hospital, Gaya, five at the Darbhanga Medical College Hospital, six at the Katihar Sadar Hospital and one at the JNMCH. Not a single HIV+ case was detected at the Ara Sadar Hospital where 250 persons underwent the test.,The most significant decline was noticed among the female sex workers of Chaturbhujsthan (Muzaffarpur) and Shravan Bazaar (Munger). Out of the 500 female sex workers who underwent the test, only one from Shravan Bazaar tested HIV+.,BSACS project director C K Anil said though 250 female sex workers of Chaturbhujsthan underwent the test, not a single of them tested HIV+.,Out of the 250 persons in the MSM category who underwent the test at the Patna MSM centre, four tested HIV+, he maintained.,Anil said emphasis on the HIV/Aids awareness programme and an increase in the number of voluntary counselling and testing centres (VCTCs) have resulted in the decline of HIV+ cases in the state.,The number of VCTCs has increased to 45 in the state with five of them located in Patna. At present, there are 5,500 HIV+ cases in Bihar.

Title: Draft legislation on HIV/AIDS anti-discrimination soon
article: PUNE: Healthcare establishments (HCEs) or doctors denying treatment to HIV/AIDS patients, beware, for the proposed anti-discrimination law that is being readied, if passed, will hold the guilty liable for prosecution. Moreover, employers victimising an employee because of his/her positive status is also liable to be prosecuted under the proposed legislation. ,Prepared by a group of lawyers fighting large-scale instances of stigma, discrimination that has haunted HIV/AIDS patients, the draft legislation is almost 90 per cent complete. ,According to project co-ordinator of the Lawyers Collective HIV/AIDS unit, advocate Vivek Divan, the project was taken up in August 2002 at the behest of Congress MP, Kapil Sibal who spearheads a parliamentary committee with the aim to build a consensus amongst politicians against AIDS in the country. Sibal is currently the union minister for science and technology. ,While the draft will be discussed with Sibal and an advisory working group consisting members of the Indian council of medical research (ICMR) and national AIDS control organisation (Naco) on December 4, Divan told TNN the basic idea is to protect and promote the rights of people living with HIV/AIDS (PWA), besides those affected by the epidemic and those most vulnerable to it.,"Considering the present environment where HIV/AIDS patients are subjected to stigma, violence and inequity, it is important to have a legislation, which will help in reducing such instances, if not eradicate them all, and create a non-discriminatory environment based on principles of human rights," he said. ,Joint director of the national AIDS control organisation, Sadhana Rout, only said that the draft is being readied. "It will be finalised only after consultation with senior officials from the health ministry and other concerned organisations." ,Although Sibal could be contacted, he had earlier told this newspaper that the proposed law is one of the most challenging tasks for policy makers, as it has to deal with human rights abuse of vulnerable individuals and groups against the society. ,While the penalty is yet to be finalised, Divan said the proposed legislation will prohibit denial/dismissal/unfair treatment to HIV/AIDS patients in both public and private, as well as organised and unorganised work sectors.,Not only these, it also promises to create safe working environment and adherence of universal precaution norms to all health care workers.,While the media has also been prohibited from publishing articles/news stories without consent of the patients, the proposed law also makes it mandatory for all research and healthcare institutions to seek prior consent from the patients before any testing, treatment or research on them. ,Divan said the unit has already completed consultations, at both the central and regional levels, with various NGOs, network of positive people and others concerned to get feedback. "Important suggestions and recommendations are being carefully study so that that same can be integrated into the draft before being submitted," he said.,Although India has a national AIDS prevention and control policy, it does not have the status of a law, as a result of which it is not binding and enforceable in court. Organisations working in this field strongly advocate that in the backdrop of increasing cases of denial of treatment and discrimination, it is imperative that issues like consent and confidentiality, which till now are being governed by the common laws, should be dealt with separately.,Other salient features: ,* HIV/AIDS victims can access the highest attainable standard of treatment,* Naco and state AIDS control societies to be made statutory bodies,* HCEs and doctors to suppress identity of patients ,* Prohibit quackery and other forms of treatment which claim success to transmission of the virus

Title: When it comes to HIV, it's women first
article: MUMBAI STATISTICS,PHYSIOLOGICAL DISADVANTAGE,HIV+ WOMEN''S WOES,GENDER BIAS,(Some names have been changed)

Title: Health alarm: Steep rise in Bengal HIV curve
