article: KOLKATA: On World Aids Day, West Bengal finds itself in the company of Bihar and Orissa as one of the three major states to have defaulted on posting monthly surveillance reports on AIDS with the National AIDS Control Organisation.,What''s more worrying, Bengal is one of the states to have registered a rise of more than 20 per cent in the number of HIV-positive cases in a year. In 2003, the figure stood at 5,084 cases; the 2004 figure, to be released on Wednesday, stands at 6,941.,Officials said on Tuesday that they were "worried" at the second development. A 20-per cent rise was cause for anxiety, they said, but those dealing with HIV-AIDS here said the government should also start worrying about its failure to post the monthly AIDS-surveillance reports to NACO on time.,"The monthly reports are some of the best indicators of the spread of AIDS cases and tell planners the direction it is taking," a health department official admitted. ,"Failure to pass these data on to NACO on time betrays a lackadaisical attitude," he said. Officially, however, the state maintained that it had sent the reports "on time". "But we will have to check why NACO has not taken into account the figures we sent from the state," said Prabhakar Chatterjee, director of health services.,Officials dealing with the HIV-AIDS problem here say a look at the NACO files will be enough to tell which states passed data to NACO and when. ,There are a few states that have sent data only for the first few months of the year, they say, but add that none has been as lackadaisical as the three eastern states. ,Most states have posted data till July and the only others in the Bengal-Bihar-Orissa league are some of the Union territories and insurgency-ridden states like Manipur and Jammu and Kashmir.,However, there is one figure from which the state could draw some comfort a" the incidence of HIV-infected in ante-natal clinics has been found to be .5 per cent, half of the mark that experts say indicates a "highly alarming growth".

Title: Surat zips dangerously on HIV highway
article: SURAT/AHMEDABAD: On World AIDS Day, there is both good news and bad news for Gujarat. The good news first: As per the annual Sentinel Surveillance Survey carried out by the National AIDS Control Organisation between July 1 and October 20, the HIV prevalence rate in the highrisk group a" patients with sexually transmitted diseases (STD) a" has gone down from 4.48 per cent registered in 2003 to 3.67 per cent in 2004.,The bad news is that Surat has taken the sparkle out of all the good work done in the area of AIDS control by posting an alarming rise in the prevalence rate among STD patients a" from 5.2 per cent to 8 per cent during the period. The increase is being attributed to the city''s proximity to Mumbai''s booming sex industry and the high migrant population.,Surat has upstaged Ahmedabad, which topped the charts last year with a prevalence rate of 5.8 per cent. This year, the prevalence rate among all the high-risk groups has dipped to 5.2 per cent from 5.8 per cent.,"Surat has come as a huge disappointment," conceded Gujarat State AIDS Control Society deputy director DM Saxena. Saxena is not blaming the migrants alone. He says the rise is a fallout of strict police action against sex workers which has led to prostitution going underground. "Our efforts at AIDS prevention have failed completely in Surat. In Ahmedabad, sex workers tie rakhis to policemen while in Surat they have dispersed under pressure. In such a situation, interface with sexworkers is a difficult task for anti-AIDS workers," Saxena explained.,"The number of HIV cases in the city is bound to increase with hundreds of migrants coming to the city every day," says Geeta Shroff of Apmrityu Nivaran Sangh. Vikas Desai, who works for Partnership for Sexual Health (PSH), says, "Apart from local sex workers, about 100 call girls from Mumbai come to Surat every day. Besides, Mumbai is so close that a number of people frequent sex dens there".,The HIV prevalence rate amongst STD patients is a significant indicator of HIV status. The prevalence rate of HIV in the state''s population has come down from 0.38 per cent to 0.13 per cent in one year. As per the figures given by GSACS authorities, there are around 4,000 patients with AIDS and 19,000 HIV positive cases reported in Gujarat.

Title: HIV-infected kids further exposed to risks
article: PUNE: Treatment and availability of drugs for HIV/ Aids may have emerged as a key sector amongst pharmaceutical companies, but when it comes to children infected with this deadly virus, they sill continue to be the neglected lot.,Doctors in the city said lack of paediatric formulations in the market is creating newer problems in the fight against the disease.,"Most pharma companies are still reluctant to prepare and market paediatric formulations for the HIV/Aids infected children, as there is no lucrative potential market," explained Dr said Subhashree Raghavan, founder and executive trustee of Saathi (solidarity and action against the HIV infection in India), who is working closely with the city-based Prayas foundation for treatment of HIV-infected people.,"Not only companies are interested in developing paediatric formulations, but the lack of interest even by the government and international agencies is further adding to the problem," she said.,Senior clinical scientist at the National Aids Research Institute (Nari), Dr Raman Gangakherkar, said the commercial drug companies, in the backdrop of success in efforts to prevent transmission of the virus from mother to child in developed countries, are do not find it an attractive market to prepare and market paediatric formulations.,"It is not only India specific but the problem is a global phenomenon," he said.,City-based expert Dr Sanjay Pujari, when contacted, admitted that there are fewer options to treat children infected with HIV/Aids.,"The drugs presently available in the market are mostly capsules and difficult to measure syrups for adults, making it difficult to administer it to children," he said, explaining that absence of standardised dosing schedules for children is further adding to the problem.,Another clinician Suresh Sathe said doctors and other health professionals doesn''t have simple guidelines for treatment of HIV in children. "In most cases, bad-tasting, difficult-to-measure syrups or capsules are used for children," he said, explaining the use of oral solutions are not suitable for use in older children because of the large volumes needed.,Another challenge that most doctors face is the lack of paediatric formulations of anti-retrovirals, thereby making administering doses complex. "What else can we do, doses are determined according to weight or body surface and needs constant adjustments," Raghavan said.,Pujari, while pointing out that cases of mother to child transmissions have dropped due to medical interventions, children already affected with the virus are also exposed to the hazards of side-affects, particularly in the absence of specific formulations for them. "Even if the drug regimen fails, we don''t have a second line of treatment," he pointed out.,According to Raghavan, the rate of paediatric HIV infection in India and some African nations still continues to be as high as 15-20 per cent compared to two per cent in the developed countries. "This is primarily due to the much higher HIV prevalence among women in the child bearing age group in these countries," she said.

Title: HIV makes docs plead incompetence
article: HYDERABAD: HIV positive patients who need surgery for unrelated problems are being discriminated against by some doctors. The patients themselves are unaware that the doctors are abandoning them to their fate.,If a patient''s HIV status is discovered when he goes to a hospital in need of a surgery, the doctor may cry off the case, giving excuses that they are not technically equipped to handle it.,One such case took place at a corporate hospital recently. A doctor who initially refused to perform an operation on the patient after he discovered his HIV-positive status. He ultimately gave in to peer pressure and performed the operation, but only after demanding a huge sum from the patient.,Some doctors resort to other forms of mischief to dodge the virus. They have an understanding with pathological laboratories, which call up the doctor to inform him when the patient turns out to be HIV-positive in pre-surgical tests. The diagnostic report, however, does not disclose the HIV status so that the patient does not suspect he is being turned away by the doctor because of the fear of Aids.,"HIV-positive patients are indeed being discriminated against. Doctors must perform operations after taking the necessary precautions, but a number of them are excusing themselves," A P State Aids Control Society director K Damayanti said.

Title: HIV-positive sex workers form self-help group
article: PUNE: Saheli, an HIV/AIDS group working with commercial sex workers (CSWs), has formed Durga, a collective of 48 HIV-positive CSWs, to fight against social discrimination and strive for their rehabilitation.,The collective was formed on the occasion of World Aids Day on December 1.,"The women shared their experiences and expressed their willingness to be rehabilitated given the opportunity to find alternate means to earn their living. It is an extremely brave decision to speak out openly and form a collective, especially because their survival depends on it," said Tejaswi Severkari, project co-ordinator of Saheli.,Negotiating for proper medical care for the HIV positive CSWs, at the government hospitals, will be the big challenge for collective.,"Anti-retroviral drugs still are not available free of cost at the government hospitals, in spite of the government''s promise about the same earlier this year. We need to create more awareness among women about the treatments available and the places where these can be availed," said Tejaswi.,The collective will also act as a support system that women can depend on in times of need, be it monetarily or to take care of a fellow member in her final stage.,In order to draw attention to the predicament of HIV-positive CSWs, the women put up a street play at Mandai and Budhwar Peth on Friday and Saturday.,The play narrated the story of an HIV-positive CSW, who was not admitted to the hospital in spite of her medical condition and was homeless after being thrown out by her gharwali.,Last year, up to 20 CSWs lost their lives to AIDS. A candle-light vigil in their memory was held by Saheli members on December 2.

Title: Did the doctor inject his wife with HIV virus?
article: AHMEDABAD: A Maharashtra-based medical practitioner, accused of injecting his wife with HIV virus may soon ''speak the truth'' in front of forensic scientists of the Directorate of Forensic Science (DFS) in Gandhingar.,Dr Ajay Sharma, a resident of Nandurbar, will soon be brought to Gandhinagar by Maharashtra police for narcoanalysis, during which truth serum will be administered on him.,The Maharashtra police have pinned its hopes on DFS for gathering evidence against the accused and bring the sensational case to its logical conclusion. Using forensic investigative and interrogative techniques the cops are hoping that Dr Sharma will tell all.,The doctor was arrested about six months back on charges of deliberately injecting his pregnant wife, Bharati, with an HIV-infected syringe.,Both Bharati and her 11-month-old child, Vaishnavi, have tested HIV positive. However, Dr Sharma is steadfast on his claim that he had nothing to do with the deadly infection.,Officials of DFS told TNN that apart from the polygraph (lie-detector) test and narco-analysis, Dr Sharma is likely to be put through brain fingerprinting.,"The only possible way the accused could have injected his wife with HIV virus is by deliberately using an infected syringe. We will use forensic science to probe into Dr Sharma''s mind," said DFS officials.,Dr Sharma was married to Bharati on December 13, 2001, said police. However, Bharati soon got to know of Sharma''s previous love affair and there erupted differences between the couple and her in-laws.,The family feud worsened when Bharati gave birth to a baby girl, while her in-laws were expecting a boy. Unable to bear the pressure, Bharati went to live with her parents.,On January 9, 2004, after a short, yet sustained spell of illness, Bharati''s blood test results indicated that she was HIV positive.,On March 30, she lodged a complaint with the Nandurbar police accusing her husband and in-laws of torturing her and alleged that they had connived to inject her with the virus.,Bharati, in her police complaint, alleged that on October 10, 2002, Sharma allegedly gave an injection to her on the pretext that it was for treatment of jaundice.,When the police reached to her in-laws'' house, all the family members were absconding.,Later, on May 13, police nabbed them at a bus stop when they were trying to flee to Indore.

Title: A home and tender touch for HIV kids
article: KOLKATA: Joy is a lively toddler of 15 months. Swapan is a precocious six-year-old with an analytical mind that leaves kids twice his age bewildered. Archan, a few months older than Swapan, is years ahead in maturity. Nine-year-old Tapan is extremely sensitive. And Musharaf, 11, is full of mischief... And they were all born HIV reactive (HIV+). ,Their parents, though, didn''t know it when they abandoned the kids in roadside vats, railway platforms and berths at the dock. That diagnosis happened later. And then, it turned from bad to worse. "Even state-run hospitals shut their doors. Despite crores being pumped into sensitisation programmes and awareness campaigns, social acceptance is yet to take roots," remarked Organisation For Friends Energies & Resources (OFFER) secretary Kallol Ghosh.,Though the NGO has been working with nearly 5,000 destitute children for 15 years, it''s only a year-and-a-half ago, during mandatory tests, that the kids were diagnosed HIV reactive. ,Being HIV reactive, the children require special medical attention as their low resistance makes them susceptible to infection. With hospitals reluctant to admit them, the NGO realised the need for a hospice and decided to set up one. "Proper healthcare is critical for children as they can fall violently ill at times. Our hospital-cum-home, Anandaghar, aims to rehabilitate the children and bring lost smiles back to their lips," said Ghosh.,"A 2.5 bigha plot has been identified at Gobindapur near Narendrapur to set up the centre. Apart from clinical and psychological support, the children will also be offered education and possible enrollment in mainstream schools," Ghosh said.,Dr Kinshuk Misra from Oxford University has already educated the NGO''s staff on issues of sex and sexuality and provided comprehensive information on HIV and AIDS. Another organisation, PCI Delhi, is currently training the staff on ways to provide psychological support to the children. "Over the last year, we have carried out a widespread sensitisation programme at Gobindapur to ensure that there is no social resistance," he said. ,While Apanghar (for destitutes) is funded by Railway Children and Comic Relief Fund of UK and Apanjan (for mentally challenged) by Italian film-maker Sergio Scapagnini and Banyan Trust of UK, OFFER is keen to fund Anandaghar indigenously. A fund-raising concert is slated for January 17.

Title: HIV cases in MSU send alarm bells ringing
article: VADODARA: Three cases of HIV were detected during a screening programme conducted at the MS University recently. Out of 3,800 blood samples collected in the past four months, three tested positive. ,The situation is alarming and calls for immediate action from the university authorities to step up the HIV awareness and advocacy, say experts. "This implies a prevalence rate of 1:1200. We need to have effective HIV intervention programmes on the campus," says Dr Kiran Patel, US-based cardiologist, who is funding the project. ,The HIV screening project funded by Dr Patel and the Pallavi Patel Foundation for Global Understanding is the first of its kind in the university which has student population of nearly 33,000. "The new findings have made the case for the HIV advocacy at college level stronger. ,Our three year project with a funding of Rs 25 lakh per annum is screening only the first year students of various faculties and three colleges in the city. We hope to expand the project to rural colleges," says Dr Vijay Shah of the Indu Health Research Foundation Trust (IHRFT). ,"Screening the sexually active age group gives a different perspective on the HIV problem. Normally, most government policies and intervention programmes are based on government hospital reports which necessarily do not represent the entire population," adds Shah. ,Meanwhile, the HIV cases have caused concern among students who say that the university is lacking the initiative to set up a fullfledged HIV monitoring cell. "Despite the faculty of social work acting as a nodal agency of the Gujarat State Aids Control Society (GSACS), not many students, including student leaders, are aware of any HIV counselling centre or awareness activities on the campus," says Vikas Dubey, university general secretary. ,"We conduct several blood donation camps and samples are screened for HIV but detection alone will not suffice as we need awareness and counselling services," adds Dubey. ,Says Deepali Hande, co-ordinator of the Marg Counselling Centre in the MSU, "We are not carrying out HIV counselling as no student has approached us. A majority of problems that we come across are personal, academic or psychological." ,"We have a team of three or four teachers who have been trained in AIDS awareness and counselling. However, we do not have a direct intervention and screening as it would lead to discrimination. Moreover, students can always approach SSG''s Vatsyayana clinic for HIV/STD services," says Anil Navale, former dean of the faculty of social work. ,Ironically, even the state government seems to have ignored the fact that HIV prevalence worldover is highest among persons in 15-49 age group. Most of its targeted intervention programmes are focussed on high-risk groups like truck drivers, homosexuals, commercial sex workers and industrial workers. ,Says Dr DM Saxena, additional director of the GSCAS, "Targeted intervention is not feasible for the entire population. The HIV intervention is a multi-sectoral approach and believes in active involvement of all sections of the society. The university has to take initiative in making HIV services accessible to students." ,"We hope to catch them young and hence we have launched the school AIDS programme which has covered 50 per cent of schools across the state. The university or college students will be covered in our IEC mass awareness," adds Saxena.

Title: Nigerian inmate loses HIV+ son in jail
article: NEW DELHI: Seven months after Delhi High Court Chief Justice B C Patel ordered a special narcotics court to speedily complete the trial of Joy, a Nigerian HIV positive woman in Tihar Jail, the case has dragged on even as one her children died in detention on Thursday.,After her arrest under the NDPS Act, Joy had given birth to twins, one of whom was detected with HIV. ,The case had been brought to the notice of the Chief Justice by other inmates when he visited Tihar in May, 2004. Chief Justice Patel had then suo motu taken note of the woman''s case and ordered that trial be expedited.,The direction, however, remained on paper. The special NDPS court did not move quickly enough and now one of the twins a" Paul who was HIV positive a" has died. Peter is the other twin. Paul died in Tihar jail, while his mother continues to be incarcerated.,For 22-year-old Joy, it continues to be a long wait. Her advocate, Shilpi Jain, intends to move the high court for bail. "This is clear violation of human rights. ,The Chief Justice''s order was second such direction. In January this year, Justice O P Dwivedi had passed a similar order asking the special court to dispose Joy''s case within three months," Jain said.,Joy has been in Tihar Jail since April 2002. She was arrested from the railway station while in possession of two kilograms of heroin. At the time of her arrest, Joy was pregnant. On December 7, 2002, she gave birth to the twins.,A jail official on condition of anonymity said: "During the delivery her condition worsened. She was put on anti-retroviral therapy and was so weak that she could not even hold her babies." ,Unlike his twin, Paul could not be kept in the creche and was always bundled up next to his mother.,Moved by her suffering, the Tihar Jail authorities moved the Delhi High Court requesting a speedy trial for her. Despite Dwivedi''s order, the special NDPS court did not start the cross-examination of the witness. Finally in May, when Chief Justice Patel went to Tihar jail, he was informed about Joy''s health by the other women inmates.,On a suo motu cognisance, Chief Justice Patel passed the order for completion of trial in a month''s time. Even one month after this order, the trial did not begin. ,Although the court has finished the examination of 14 witnesses, it is yet to begin the final arguments in the case before pronouncing the judgment.,Until then Joy continues to lead a painful existence.

Title: HIV victim rescued by health officials
article: HOWRAH: Shunned by family, thrown out by the landlord and ostracised by the society, a suspected HIV positive man was loitering helplessly on roads in Howrah till the district health officials came to his aid.,Fifty-year-old Krishna Kumar Mondal (name changed on the request of the CMOH Howrah) was admitted to a state-run hospital in Howrah on Monday night.,Mondal had been living in rented house with his wife and daughter for some time now, said his neighbours in Samabay Pally.,A group D employee of the public health engineering department, Mondal started falling ill repeatedly about four years ago.,Over the last few months, he had swellings on different parts of his body. Suspecting that Mondal was suffering from AIDS, the landlord reportedly drove out the family.,In October 2004, the family went to live with Mondal''s wife''s parents in Beliaghata. But just as he thought the family would get a home, Mondal was thrown out of his in-law''s house due to his failing health. He returned to Samabay Pally a fortnight back.,Though they offered him food and water, fear and ignorance kept the neighbours away from him.,"Nobody wants to come near me. Even my wife and daughter have turned their backs on me.,But I am not suffering from AIDS," he insisted. According to Mondal, he was treated at Calcutta Medical College and Hospital where the doctors told him that he was not HIV positive.,The panchayat where he lived informed block medical officer Suparna Pal and he was taken to hospital by the Bally police in an ambulance.,"We cannot comment on his health and are trying to contact his family for documents of his previous treatment. We will conduct all necessary tests," said CMOH, Howrah, Dr Shankar Shah.,"Right now, we want him to get over the trauma. Our doctors are providing him all support," he added.

Title: Preventive measures: Doctors take HIV/AIDS medicines
article: HYDERABAD: Far from breaking the silence to talk about the dreaded AIDS, medical practitioners today are shying away from disclosing that they are taking treatment for prevention of HIV/AIDS during surgeries.,The treatment, called post prophylaxis, is taken after an injury during an emergency surgery. Though some doctors are unaware of the post prophylaxis treatment for prevention of HIV/AIDS, many are into it as a precautionary measure.,In it, a combination of anti-retro viral drugs Lamivudine and Zudovudine is taken twice a day. "That would be 60 tablets for a month as part of the post prophylaxis treatment for prevention of HIV," said Dr M V Ramana Rao, joint director, Blood Safety, at the AP State AIDS Control Society.,"The drugs are distributed to the superintendent of government hospitals for the staff through the district leprosy officer," he said. Medical staff, students and doctors at government hospitals take the treatment after a cut or a needle injury during surgery. "But not all members of the medical staff give their names on record, though they consume the drugs," Rao said, adding "so the exact number of doctors or medical staff consuming the drugs cannot be tracked.","A needle prick or a cut during surgery can lead to the mixing of fresh blood from the patient to the doctor and that can lead to AIDS or hepatitis. Such surgeons have taken prophylaxis treatment," said Indian Dental Association president, Dr Nageswara Rao. ,"In any surgery for accident cases, be it heart, spinal or ortho, all efforts will be made to save the life of the patient and the risks involved for the doctor may be sidelined," said Dr Mahesh Joshi, head of the emergency department at Apollo Hospital. "Majority of the corporate hospitals have theequipment to treat the patient, but for the doctors at government hospitalsthe risks would be more in terms of contracting a disease."

Title: 'Focus on curative aspects of HIV/Aids'
article: PUNE: Internationally-acclaimed Aids expert Dr Jeffery Nadler on Monday said the Indian government should equally emphasise on the curative aspects of HIV / Aids rather than solely positioning its campaign on prevention.,Director of clinical research at the division of infectious diseases in University of South Florida College of Medicine, Nadler has been frequenting India, particularly Pune, as part of the collaborative programme with Ruby Hall Clinic to train medical practitioners on various issues related to the deadly infection.,Having had the distinction of treating one of the first Aids patients in the US, Nadler said with effective treatment, an HIV infected person can live a normal life from 15 to as long as 35 years.,"But unfortunately in India, people are given to understand that HIV/Aids is totally incurable," he said, pointing out to government campaigns focusing totally on prevention.,"With so many infected people here in the country, it is high time that focus is modified," Nadler said, also calling upon the private sector the private sector to rise to the occasion, and reciprocate to what the government is doing.,"All that the private sector today needs is guidance and effective training," he said, while referring to the fourth annual course in HIV medicine, which is offered through a collaborative partnership between the university and the India centre for health, HIV/Aids research and training (Chart-India).,According to Dr Sanjay Pujari, director of the HIV unit at Ruby Hall Clinic, and one of the course directors, said the training curriculum combines cutting-edge medical, scientific and psycho-social information with an instructional methodology that is sensitive and relevant to the needs of Indian physicians.,It has been designed specifically to prepare the participants to meet the difficult tasks of diagnosing, managing and treating the infected patients, he said, adding that the participants, at the end of the course, are made to understand the transmission, epidemiology, screening for and diagnosis of HIV / Aids in resource-constrained settings.

Title: HIV/AIDS cases on the rise, but not on NACO website
article: NEW DELHI: The AIDS epidemic could well be on the rampage in a large number of Indian villages as well as among the urban affluent, but the National AIDS Control Organisation (NACO) is yet to make that official. The official NA-CO website explains in a most complacent manner, "While the spread of HIV continues, there is no significant upsurge in the number of new infections and in fact the rate of growth of HIV has registered a slowing down." NACO explains the conclusion by counting the estimated increase in numbers between 2001 and 2003. In 2002, it says there was an increase of 6.1 lakh HIV infections, but the number of new infections dropped to 5.3 lakh in 2003. Epidemiologist Dr L M Nath describes this conclusion as "premature". "There is no evidence that the epidemic is under control. The number of infections in high risk population may have peaked and sto-pped growing any further, but HIV in the general population continues to increase," he says. Close to 5.2 million people are estimated to be living with the virus in India. Most of these numbers come from six states identified as high prevalence: Andhra Pradesh, Karnataka, Maharashtra, TN, Manipur and Nagaland. Poverty, illiteracy, women's lack of empowerment and unemployment which leads to migration are known to be among the main factors that drive the epidemic. For several of these reasons, the Indian epidemic has been showing a shift towards rural areas. In 1998, the urban-rural differential in HIV prevalence amongst pregnant women was estimated at 8:1. This has now narrowed down to 2.4:1. Of the 5.1 million infections, 3.1 are in rural areas. "This alone is a cause for concern," admits an official. With the virus moving beyond the traditional high-risk groups such as truck drivers and sex workers, hospitals and private practitioners in cities too are getting an increasing number of patients from the middle and upper echelons of society.

Title: Global support for India's generic HIV drugs
article: Bleak Future

Title: In City of Joy, HIV man kills self at charity home
article: KOLKATA: Ashim Bala did not wait for AIDS to kill him. He hanged himself to death in the bathroom of Santi Daan, a Missionaries of Charity home in Tangra, early on Monday.,The 35-year-old was admitted in the home located at 37 Pulin Phatick Road in Tangra, on October 6, 2004 in a critical condition. The suicide was discovered by inmates at 6 am. "I was informed by Sambhu Deb, a patient. I went to the bathroom and saw Bala hanging. I got in touch with Brother Nicholas Patra, the home in-charge. He had the body removed and called in the police," said inmate Sudhakar Rao who is also suffering from AIDS. Enquiry officer B.K. Kundu took the body to NRS Hospital for post mortem. Brother Patra, who was at the hospital, wasn''t available for comment.,Vivian George, also an HIV positive patient like Bala said, "Bala was very sick. He would vomit continuously. He dreaded taking food. I generally took his food to him and told him that a healthy diet and treatment would improve his condition." George sighs and adds that his words fell on deaf ears since Bala had "lost the urge to live". Bala was a labour contractor from Bongaon. He is survived by his wife and a minor son.,Since Saturday, Bala had been more dejected than usual. He had received a telephone call from his wife in Bongaon on that day. "He told me his wife would not be coming to visit him on Sunday. She would come 10 days later," said George. His wife visited him frequently.,Santi Daan has three rooms and the one in which Bala was staying was for critical patients. Even as Bala''s body was being removed for post mortem, three people were bedridden and battling for life in that room. "They might die anytime," said George.,The home can accommodate 27 patients. There are 19 HIV patients in the home at present. Whatever Bala''s reasons for putting his life to a hasty end, neglect is unlikely to be one. Rao, who was a fruit juice seller in Bhubaneshwar, said, "Back in Bhubaneshwar, even the doctors refused to treat me. Here the brothers never made us feel unwanted. They ate with us and took care of us. We don''t interact with outsiders. We spend our time working and looking after other patients, who are more ill than us."

Title: HIV-infected still discriminated against in state hospitals
article: VADODARA: An 11-year-old boy suffering from fever and severe pain in his legs was refused treatment at a private hospital in Surat. The orthopaedic doctor attending on him put a label on the boyaâ„¢s X-ray report and file mentioning his HIV status.,Another patient, a pregnant woman in labour, was refused treatment by a private hospital on discovering her HIV status.,Recently, a patient in Gandhidham admitted in a private hospital for severe diarrhoea had to face the wrath of the doctor, who not only threw the patient out but also demanded that he deposit Rs 4,000 towards the cost of his bed, which would be destroyed.,Gujarat may have one of the highest number of trained doctors to treat HIV patients, but that has not reduced the number of medical discrimination cases, in the state. The Gujarat Network of People Living with HIV/AIDS claims that they get at least three cases of doctors refusing treatment to HIV patients every month.,Ironically, Gujarat has 5,000 trained doctors for the 75,000 known HIV cases in the state, according to the Gujarat State Aids Control Society (GSACS). In stark contrast, the rest of the country has only one trained doctor for every 9,010 HIV patients, according to the American Foundation for AIDS Research.,However, despite their training, many doctors refuse treatment to the HIV infected.,"Lack of sensitisation among healthcare workers can be as much of a problem as shortage of doctors. Despite our best efforts to build a better rapport between doctors and HIV patients, we get at least three to four cases of medical discrimination every month," says Umesh Patel, president of Gujarat Network of People Living with HIV/AIDS (GNP).,Says Daksha Patel, general secretary of GNP, "We suspect, there are many medical discrimination cases. But very few cases are reported for fear of stigma. Most private doctors refer the cases to the government doctors.",Meanwhile, GSACS is planning to train government doctors for the second time and hopes to rope in private practitioners for its orientation programme. "We hope to sensitise doctors in both government and private set-up. The training module will help fill up gaps between knowledge and practice," says Dr DM Saxena, additional director of GSACS.,He called upon the Indian Medical Association to take up initiatives in training healthcare professionals. "We need to train resident doctors who are constantly in touch with the patients. But so far, we have trained only the senior doctors and paramedic staff to handle HIV cases," says Dr S B Saxena, medical superintendent of SSG Hospital.,The medical discrimination could be a result of misplaced fear and ignorance among the healthcare professionals, say experts mooting for better awareness. "Most private doctors refuse treatment to HIV patients for fear of exposure to the infection. But so far, only 390 cases of HIV infection through occupational exposure have been reported worldwide, which is negligible. Moreover, we have a universal safety protocol a" Post Exposure Prophyllaxis (PEP), a triple drug shield against possible infection of HIV," adds Saxena., ,Self-help groups facilitate better HIV advocacy and formation of network of people living with HIV/AIDS is a good move in this direction.,"We have formed network of SHGs for better advocacy and to tackle stigma and discrimination. We have also set up a city-level panel of doctors, who have volunteered for the cause," adds Patel, who is monitoring the network in Surat and Vadodara.

Title: Killer HIV can kill cancer
article: Nature Medicine

Title: Husbands hauled up for high HIV rate
article: HYDERABAD: Must couples undergo HIV test before tying the knot? Yes, say Aids activists and the Andhra Pradesh Womenaâ„¢s Commission in the face of growing number of young girls acquiring the disease from their husbands.,"Almost 90 per cent of HIV-infected girls contract the virus from their husbands," said Mekhala, a consultant at Andhra Pradesh State Aids Control Society (APSACS).,As a small first step towards submitting themselves to HIV tests, experts say couples should go for pre-marital counselling. Counselling, they say, is essential for both the uneducated and so-called informed sections of society. "The problem is, many people do not even know what HIV is even if they are educated. They think they know everything but they really donaâ„¢t," Mekhala added.,While there have been enough awareness campaigns on how one should disclose his/her HIV status to the spouse, it is not really happening. Once they go for counselling, they can be asked to volunteer to undergo HIV tests.,What is alarming is the increase in infections in rural parts of the state. "There are dance bars and clubs even in towns and villages now. High risk behaviour is no longer limited to cities alone," said another APSACS official.,HIV test should be made mandatory and people should be made to keep this certificate alongside their marriage certificate, says Mary Ravindranath, chairperson of AP Womenaâ„¢s Commission.,She feels the prospect of a legislation on the issue were brighter than at any point of time in the past as "almost everyone is in agreement on the issue."

Title: STD clinics boost HIV numbers
article: HYDERABAD: Cold facts about the dreaded HIV/Aids scourge might be numbing, but one positive outcome of the spine-chilling statistics put out by health workers, is sexually-transmitted diseases (STDs) are out of the closet. In fact, Andhra Pradesh's high HIV/Aids prevalence rate, second only to Maharashtra, could also denote greater awareness among people. More people willing to subject themselves under the scrutiny of the electron microscope. In 1999, the state's prevalence rate of HIV/Aids was pegged at an alarming 2.63% (of every 100 individuals tested). This triggered a series of awareness campaigns and setting up of clinics for STDs. While the prevalence rate did show a gradual decline by 2003, health activists were alarmed when it jumped back to 2 per cent in 2004. A prevalence rate of over 1% is categorised as an 'epidemic'. Health officials said the figure has been computed from preliminary data, but admitted it's a cause for concern. While data received from two districts, Srikakulam and Warangal, are being re-checked and the National Aids Coordination Committee has been asked for a fresh survey in these two districts, the overall prevalence rate of 2 per cent is unlikely to change. Some districts such as Prakasam have shocked authorities as well with a high prevalence rate, a whopping 4 per cent. This is the first time such a high prevalence rate has been reported from this district. Guntur and Karimnagar too are among districts reporting high prevalence rates, 3.5 per cent. In Hyderabad, the prevalence rate has shown a decline over the last three years â€” from 1.5 per cent in 2002, it came down to 1.1 per cent in 2003 and 0.75 per cent in 2004. "This (Hyderabad's figure) is a marginal decline," Andhra Pradesh State Aids Control Society (Apsacs) project director K Damayanthi said, adding that it is a fact that the epidemic is "growing". "We still need to do a lot more in terms of awareness. We need to make young people perceive the risk and facilitate behavioural changes," Damayanthi said, explaining they still largely feel that they are not at risk. Despite the awareness campaigns, the young are still adopting a risky lifestyle, she said. Over 85 STD clinics and 105 voluntary counselling and testing centres have been set up across the state after the 1999 shocker, an APSACS official said. She said that the number of cases may have shot simply because there is greater awareness among people, who now visit these centres to get tested. The STD clinics, in particular, are visited by people with a high-risk behaviour who suspect or have symptoms of STDs. Interestingly, HIV prevalence among people with high risk behaviour is showing a gradual decline (See Box). It drives home one point clearly, behaviour is changing, say health activists.

Title: Ray of hope for HIV affected children
article: PUNE: Children fighting the deadly HIV/AIDS infection can finally find some succour. ,The Pune-based Emcure Pharmaecuticals on Saturday announced that a new 3-in-1 anti-retroviral cocktail, and that too in syrup form, will be available for kids infected with the deadly virus.,While this development will put India in the global map in drug manufacturing, experts associated with treatment of the infection said lack of paediatric formulations had created newer problems in the fight against the disease. ,"Although treatment and availability of drugs for HIV/AIDS may have emerged as a key sector amongst pharmaceutical companies, but when it comes to children infected with this deadly virus, they sill continue to be the neglected lot," said a senior researcher from the national AIDS research institute. ,While welcoming Emcure''s initiative, the researcher said most pharma companies were reluctant to prepare and market paediatric formulations for the HIV/AIDS infected children, as there is no lucrative potential market.,Named as Emtri Suspension, the new paediatric formulation will be manufactured at Emcure''s Pune plant, this new paediatric formulation.,Emcure''s director (operations) AK Khanna told TNN that the three drugs in the cocktail are Lamivudine, Stavudine and Nevirapine. The drug will be made available in Pune from Sunday after a brief ceremony in the presence of city MP Suresh Kalmadi and visiting first president of Zambia Kenneth Kaunda, he said, adding that is the first-of-its kind formulation to be available in the world.,Khanna said the combination drug is priced at less than Rs 500 per month for the therapy in the domestic market, while the pricing is yet to be fixed for the Africa.,With the rate of paediatric HIV infection in India and some African nations still continuing to as high as 15-20 per cent compared to two per cent in the developed countries, this combination will largely help both the infected ones and medical practitioners. ,While 5.1 lakh children below 15 years died of HIV/AIDS in 2004, according to a report published in UNAIDS in the year 2004, an estimated 22 lakh children below 15 years are living with HIV, the multilateral agency report said. In India there are about 55,000 children living with the illness till December 2004.,Asked if clinical studies have been done prior to releasing this combination in the market, Khanna said that is not required. "The three drugs are already available in the adult dosage form in the market, which was crushed and administered to children,aï¿½ he said, however, adding that a strong post-marketing surveillance will be maintained.

Title: Plague 'blessed' Europe with HIV immunity
article: NEW YORK: Devastating epidemics that swept Europe during the Middle Ages seem to have had an unexpected benefit a" leaving 10 per cent of today''s Europeans resistant to HIV infection, researchers say. ,However, they are divided on which one was responsible for it. Researchers, the Nature magazine reported, claimed this week that plague helped boost our immunity to HIV, but rival teams are arguing that the credit should go to smallpox. ,But what is clear is that something has boosted the prevalence of a mutation that helps protect against the virus. The mutation, which affects a protein called CCR5 on the surface of white blood cells, prevents HIV from entering these cells and damaging the immune system, the magazine reported.,Around 10 per cent of today''s Europeans carry the mutation, a significantly higher proportion than in other populations, researchers found. ,Geneticists know that the mutation, called CCR5-32, appeared some 2,500 years ago a" long before HIV reared its head. "You need something that has been around for generation upon generation," explains Christopher Duncan of the University of Liverpool, UK, who led the latest analysis. Plague fits the bill, he and his colleagues conclude from a modelling study. ,Ferguson says "smallpox seems the most parsimonious explanation as it largely affected children."

Title: High incidence of HIV+ cases in 15-19 age group
article: PATNA: The National Aids Control Organisation (Naco) director general S Y Qureshi, while expressing his serious concern over the high incidence of HIV positive cases in the age group of 15-19 years in the country, stressed the need for increasing awareness about HIV and Aids.,Stating that about 16,000 people are getting infected by HIV every day across the world, Qureshi said on Wednesday that a majority of those affected are in the age group of 15-19 years, which is a very disturbing trend.,Stressing on Aids education in schools, he directed the Bihar State Aids Control Society (BSACS) officials to train at least two teachers of each of the 3,500 government high schools in Bihar.,"By November this year, 95 per cent of the government hi-gh schools in Bihar should be covered under the School Aids Education Programme," he to-ld the BSACS officials. He ask-ed them to target adolescents in the age group of 15-19 years so far as creating HIV/Aids awareness is concerned.,BSACS officials told ToI that the Society has prepared an action plan to have five master trainers in each of the 38 districts of the state, who in turn will impart training to at least two teachers, including a female, of each of the schools in their respective districts. Henceforth, the School Aids Education Programme will be implemented by the education department with the technical and financial assistance from the BSACS, they added.,Speaking at a workshop on Aids education in schools organised by the Union HRD ministry in collaboration with Naco and the BSACS, Qureshi said awareness will act as a kind of social medicine to check HIV/Aids from spreading in the absence of a permanent cure of the disease.

Title: Cricketers break boundaries for HIV victims
article: BANGALORE: Cricketers and publicity go hand in hand. If one could discount the mad rush for photographs by a horde of cameramen, then Tuesday''s event at a leading hotel in the city would have showcased another side to cricket and cricketers.,In a short function organised by UNICEF, a handful of Indian cricketers led by the indomitable Rahul Dravid and Sachin Tendulkar showed about half-a-dozen HIV infected women that they were not alone in their fight against AIDS.,Perhaps in a gesture more telling than any other, Dravid, Tendulkar, Anil Kumble, Virender Sehwag, Mohammed Kaif and Harbhajan Singh tied the red ribbon (which symbolises the fight against HIV) on the wrists of the afflicted women. They may have felt ostracised at many other times, but on Tuesday, these women were on top of the world.,Much like with his batting, Dravid has approached the fight against AIDS with a vengeance. The world''s leading batsman urging safe sex is a familiar scene on television. Off screen, his message to those afflicted by AIDS was that cricket and cricketers were solidly behind them in their fight against the disease. "We as cricketers have a responsibility to society and are willing to lend a helping hand," he said.,It was a theme echoed by Tendulkar. "We need to make serious efforts to eradicate ill-conceived ideas on AIDS," he said.,The Board of Control for Cricket in India, in the person of communications committee director Amrit Mathur, also pledged their support to the cause.,Looking on fondly as the cricketers tied the ribbon were chairman of the Pakistan Cricket Board Sharyar Khan, who is also UNICEF co-chairman for AIDS control in Pakistan, Indian cricket coach John Wright and ICC panel umpire Billy Bowden.

Title: Transfusion leaves doctor HIV+ at 74
article: AHMEDABAD: Dr Hansa Desai, 74, can hardly see. This frail dental surgeon has fractured both her hip bones and is being fed through tubes. As if her suffering was not enough, she now has an HIV infection, got allegedly through a blood transfusion done recently. ,"She is suffering acute HIV encephalopathy which takes away major part of the brain and causes a host of other related problems. The HIV infection is progressing very rapidly as her immunity down because of old age," said infectious diseases specialist at the Apollo Hospital Dr Moti Talpada.,"My mother does not deserve this. Our family was shocked when her reports showed HIV positive. I know the blood banks can easily say that the donor may have been in the window period and the infection could not be detected. But I want people to know that this horror can visit them too,"says her son Ajay. Dr Hansa, who belongs to an illustrious family of industrialists, underwent a surgery to fix her hip bone at a Vadodara hospital two years back. Eight months ago, she broke her second hip bone for which she underwent another surgery.,Blood was sourced from a leading blood bank in Vadodara. "Her blood tests carried out before both the surgeries showed HIV negative. But after the second surgery, her condition worsened as she contracted infections. This prompted another blood test over a month ago which showed HIV positive,"says orthopaedic surgeon Dr Harshavardan Hegde,who operated on her in the Vadodara hospital.,Whataâ„¢s equally shocking is that the victim was virtually eased out of the Vadodara hospital after the report showed she was HIV positive. "We were not told to leave in as many words but we were repeatedly told that it would be better if we take our mother to the government hospital or to an Aids specialist,"said Ajay, who then shifted her to Apollo here.,"It is a fact that no blood can be guaranteed to be 100 per cent HIV-free as one has to consider the window period where the donor may not show HIV infection for six weeks to six months after contracting the same. In Gujarat, at least 2-3 per cent of HIV infections spread through blood transfusion, which was 10-12 per cent earlier,"said Dr DM Saxena of the Gujarat State AIDS Control Society.

Title: HC slams Centre for wrong HIV diagnosis
article: NEW DELHI: An Armyman, who missed a chance to be a part of the UN peace keeping force in Lebanon in 1999 as he was wrongly diagnosed as HIV-positive, got relief from the high court on Monday. The court asked the Union of India to compensate the petitioner, P S Vinod of the 2nd Madras regiment, for causing him mental agony.,Justice B A Khan and Justice Anil Kumar, however, denied P S Vinod the full payment of over Rs four lakh which the petitioner said he could not earn during that period.,After four years of legal battle, Vinod got the bench''s favour after the judges asked Centre''s advocate Siddharth Mridul to seek instructions on what amount would they give to the Armyman. Mridul has to get back to the court by May 6, the next date of hearing. The bench made it clear that in view of "no work no pay" principle, Vinod could not be paid over Rs four lakh, as he was never on job for that tenure.,Vinod''s counsel Major (retired) Ramesh submitted that the petitioner not only missed Rs four lakh but also had to spend lots of money on HIV tests at Safdarjung hospital and All India Institute of Medical Sciences and Post-Graduate Institute of Medical Education and Research, Chandigarh besides suffering mental agony and social stigma. Mridul admitted there was a possibility of wrong result in 200 HIV tests but rejected petitioner''s case for the compensation.

Title: HIV+, and still positive about life
article: MUMBAI: "HIV has given me a chance to complete my story." You wonder if you've heard Shabana right, but she is too deep in the rewind mode for you to interrupt. "Thanks to HIV, I did things I never thought I would do when I got married in 1995." Shabana's high points in life include getting a graduation degree in sociology, and frequent travelling. "Before I got to know of my HIV+ status, I had no aim in life. Now I want to work towards demolishing the myths surrounding HIV/AIDS." The wife of a rickshaw driver, Shabana now heads Mumbai's Network of Positive People. Most HIV+ people TOI interviewed maintained that infected persons can lead healthy, fulfilling lives provided they take care of their nutrition and receive family support. Says Mohammed (name changed), a purse maker from Mumbai, who has been living with the virus for 15 years, "Ab to main koi galat kaam nahin karta aur galat cheez nahin khaata. (I don't do wrong things or eat the wrong kind of food). Why should people be forced to keep quiet about their HIV+ status? After all, it would be educative for others if they can learn from our mistakes." His family in Bihar knows about his condition, "but I am wary about telling others here," he says. It is perhaps the fear of ostracisation that is forcing people like Mohammed to keep quiet, says Dr Nagesh Shirgopikar, who keeps tabs on Mohammed's health as part of the Salvation Army's HIV\AIDS programme. Take the case of Rohini (name changed), widow of a civic employee, who hasn't told her sister-in-law about her condition. "What if she throws out my children after I die?" But a few HIV+ individuals manage to stand up as shining examples, like Asha who pinned the red ribbon of support on Sachin Tendulkar and other cricketers on March 22. "My in-laws threw me out when my husband died because they held me responsible," recalls Asha, whose mission is to teach people that women are not solely responsible for the AIDS scourge. "I hail from a lower middle-class family where people don't know about HIV; even my parents behaved in a peculiar fashion," she says. But joining a support group changed that. Her parents have been counselled and are more supportive now. "I remarried five years ago and have a three-year-old daughter," says Asha who works with an NGO. Her daughter is not HIV+, an endorsement for the government's Prevention of Parents-to-Child Transmission of HIV programme.

Title: NGOs moot legal reforms to fight HIV stigma
article: VADODARA: On April 6, residents of Mamani Pol in the old city resisted a newly formed self-help group of HIV positive people----Association of People Living with HIV/AIDS (APLWHA)---from setting up their office in the locality fearing HIV infection. In 2000, Lakshya Trust, a community-based organisation working on HIV/AIDS awareness issues with MSM (men having sex with men) community, had faced similar reaction from residents. The situation has not changed even after five years. Ironically, the HIV positive group in question this time was to start a project to fight stigma and social discrimination against the HIV-infected. "With this incident, we had a taste of what was awaiting us. We were forced to move out of Mamani Pol after residents opposed to having an NGO working on HIV in their locality. For some days, we had to work from the SSG Hospital. However, we managed to set up office and drop-in centre at Amdavadi Pol. But we are still afraid of putting up a board," says Atul Raorani, president of the HIV positive group. Says Pritesh Shah, project officer of the state government-funded HIV/AIDS Care and Support Project, "Our project aims at sensitising people at large to reduce the stigma, peer counselling and clinical management of HIV-related illnesses. Our effort is to create employment for the HIV- infected and support education of children orphaned by HIV and women living with HIV. This apart, we hope to reduce the cost of anti-retrovirals (ARV) through corporate sponsorship." Social stigma is perceived to be a major challenge to HIV prevention, say NGOs working on HIV/AIDS. "Instances of discrimination reflect on severe lack of awareness about AIDS among the masses and the urgent need for attitudinal change. Unless the masses are sensitised, fear of stigma will discourage HIV patients from seeking medical care and counselling which, in turn, proves detrimental to HIV prevention," say Vaishali Ajmera, project officer of HIV/AIDS project, Vikas Jyot Trust. The Gujarat government has mooted a draft Act to extend legal support to the HIV- infected. The proposed Act will address various issues like social and medical discrimination, quality of life and enabling environment for the HIV-infected. Says additional director of the Gujarat State Aids Control Society (GSACS) DM Saxena, "A major social transformation is possible with legal modifications. HIV is no more restricted to high-risk groups but has filtered down to the general population. This has made amendments to the existing laws inevitable." Despite having laws like right to life, we have no legal authority to take action when a HIV patient is denied medical care. "Moreover, as we hardly receive any official complaints from NGOs or the victims, advocacy for their rights has become difficult. Most victims of discrimination refuse to file a police complaint," adds Saxena. Meanwhile, the NGOs argue that legal provision alone will not suffice. As HIV is no longer confined to high-risk behaviour groups, the government must involve the mainstream society in eradicating social stigma, they add. Says Sylvester Merchant, project officer of Lakshya Trust, "Social awareness and legal provisions must go hand-in-hand. Perhaps, a mass awareness campaign and public dialogue on the issue will help eliminate stigma. Unfortunately, most of our HIV interventions are target-oriented, aimed at high-risk groups, contact groups or stake holders like doctors, lawyers and police, who directly interact with the HIV-infected."

Title: 'Make employment policy for HIV+'
article: NEW DELHI: A man who was refused job by the Hindustan Aeronauticals Limited (HAL) on the ground that he was HIV positive has approached the court, giving rise to a larger issue on whether an AIDS patient can be denied job. Although the man has challenged the decision claiming his form has been mixed with another candidate and that he is not HIV positive, the Delhi High Court on Wednesday took a serious view of the issue. Justice Vikramjit Sen has issued notice to the Union government and asked them to place a policy regarding employment to a person suffering from HIV. "The matter is of great importance as well as of urgency," said Justice Sen. Manoj Ohri who appeared on behalf of the Union of India accepted the notice. According to Ohri, the petitioner was probably medically examined in Nasik in January 2005, a month after he sat for the interview. "I have called for the petitioner's files from the ministry," said Ohri. The petitioner, Jogendar Singh, filed his petition in the court challenging Hindustan Aeronauticals Limited's decision to deny him employment. Singh claimed somebody else's photograph was affixed on his form. In fact, even in Singh's appointment letter, the photo belonged to the other man. Although he had informed HAL about the mistake, the latter promised to rectify it. But the error was apparently ignored. Singh claims that the man whose photograph was pasted on his form could be HIV positive. To substantiate his argument, Singh also produced two medical certificates, one from S N Medical College, Agra, and the other from AIIMS declaring him HIV negative. Although Justice Sen empathised with Singh, he found the rejection ridiculous more on the ground that the man was HIV positive. "In the present case, a person who is otherwise qualified is being denied employment on what appears to be an incorrect stand," observed Justice Sen.

Title: Vows exchanged, HIV-free certificates too
article: PUNE: He''s a parking-lot manager and she doesn''t work. He has passed his ninth standard and she, her twelfth. Together, they have taken a more daring step towards AIDS awareness than most highly educated, wealthy youngsters would have done.,Instead of horoscopes, Fakruddin and Nazneen Tamboli, who married recently, exchanged HIV-negative certificates before finalising their match.,Despite years of propaganda by rationalists and health activists, thousands of families rely on horoscopes for match-making and take it as a personal insult if a physical fitness certificate or HIV-negative certificate is demanded, especially in arranged marriages. In fact, the mere mention of the ''H'' word threatens to derail matrimonial talks in most ''enlightened'' circles.,"I''ve been a member of the voluntary agency, Dilasa (Reassurance), for the last four years. We have been conducting AIDS-awareness streetplays and rallies. I realised that unless I set a personal example, our work will not go forward," says 26-yearold Fakruddin, a resident of Gopi chawl, Bopodi.,Interestingly, the match was made by the parents, not the couple. "I set three conditions a" my parents should like the girl; I will not accept any dowry; I will get my HIV test done and the bride should follow suit.",Fakruddin is largely inspired by his father, a state transport (ST) employee, who has been a social worker for the last 40 years.,"Since we were willing to offer my son''s HIV-negative certificate first, there was no reason for the bride''s family to get angry. Nevertheless, her father was upset at first. However, my son convinced her brother, a young engineer, and he and the bride, in turn, convinced his father," relates Rehman Tamboli, Fakruddin''s father, who is also active with Dilasa, a group of part-time volunteers working for AIDS awareness, orphans and leprosy patients.

Title: HIV-hit cops in city to get free treatment
article: MUMBAI: Given the growing incidence of HIV among policemen, the Mumbai police has decided to provide free antiretroviral (ARV) treatment to its affected employees. According to the latest statistics, the police force has 340 HIV/AIDS-af flicted personnel. In 2002, a police constable attached to the Local Arms Unit of the Mumbai police, suspected to have contracted the HIV virus, committed suicide. In 2003, another constable jumped from the third floor of the Nagpada police hospital after he learnt that he was suffering from AIDS. It is to help affected policemen lead normal lives that the ARV treatmentâ€”a cocktail of two or three drugsâ€”will be distributed free of cost. The drugs which have to be taken for the rest of the patient's life are expensive and many patients are not in a financial position to continue with it. ARVs are known to control the viral load and thus increase the life expectancy of the affected person. The Nagpada police hospitalâ€”the only hospital for the city's 39,000-strong police forceâ€”had so far never stocked the ARV drugs. However, the top brass felt that the unavailability of the drug meant that affected policemen kept away from the hospital.

Title: Five lakh HIV-positive cases in AP
article: HYDERABAD: High prevalence of sex by married people with non-regular partners and low use of condoms are among the main reasons for giving Andhra Pradesh the dubious distinction of having the country''s second highest number of HIV-positive cases after Maharashtra. ,Andhra Pradesh has five lakh HIV-positive cases and 50,000 AIDS patients, Andhra Pradesh Aids Control Society (APACS) Project Director K Damayanthi said. ,The number is worriesome when considered that the first HIV/AIDS case in the state was detected in Hyderabad in 1986. A survey has found that one person in every five married is having sex with a non-partner and only 25 per cent people are using condoms with non-partner sex, she said. ,The age profile of people found positive clearly shows that majority of them were young (45 per cent in the age group of 15-29 yrs) followed by the people in mid-thirtes (35 per cent in the age group of 30-39) and 3.66 per cent in less than 14 years, Damyanthi said., Major causes and determinates of HIV/AIDS identified in the state include the high prevalence of sex with non-regular partners and lower rates of consistent condom use with non-regular partners, the project director said.,The project director quoting a survey said Sexually Transmitted Diseases (STDs) were found to be highest among sex workers with 25 percentage followed by migrant workers 17 per cent, MSM and transgender 15 per cent and composite groups 12 per cent. ,The presence of high number of migrant population and a vast...,... network of national highways passing through the state are some of the reasons for the increase in the number of cases, she said.,She said it was feared that if the government does not wake up to the threat of increasing HIV positive cases, particulary in Guntur, Prakasam, Cuddupah, Nellore, Karimnagar, Chittoor and West Godavari districts, the state may overtake Maharashtra.,According to a survey, the HIV prevalence rate exceeded one per cent among Ante Natal Care (ANC) attendees in the entire coastal belt of the state as well as a few districts in Rayalseema and Telangana regions.,Eighteen out of 23 districts at divisional level and 12 sites at sub-divisional level recorded more than one per cent prevalence among ANC attendees, she said. A high prevelance of 2.5 per cent was observed among the women registered for ANC and those who walked in for deliveries in hospitals set up with Prevention of Parent to Child Transmission (PPTCT) programme, Damayanthi said.,The Prevalence of HIV among antenatal mothers and also mother to child transmission in case of positive women, are very high in the state and warrant special attention, she said,There are 37 PPTCT centre working in the state and in these centres testing...,... is done free of cost for all the pregnant women. In addition Anti Retro Viral (ARV) drugs are being supplied free of cost to all the pregnant women who test positive to prevent vertical transmission, she said. ,The government has increased the number of STD clinics from 28 to 85 covering most sub-district hospitals. The STD clinics provide treatment facilities to cure infections.,Realising the gravity of the situation in terms of the increasing number of AIDS patients, high priority is being given by APACS to provide optimal care and support to infected persons, she said.

Title: Wife seeks divorce from HIV husband
article: TARN TARAN: At last the village elders gathered and handed down their verdict in relation to the divorce of Paramjit Singh and Balbir Kaur (name changed) after the wife requested a divorce when she came to know that her husband was HIV positive. She feared for the health of herself and the couples young daughter. The elders also advised to not involve police and settle the issue amicably. ,Resident of village Sangha in Tarn Taran police district, Balbir Kaur had married an agriculturist Paramjit Singh of Rajewal village about six years ago. Paramjit wanted to go abroad for some lucrative job and had got his medical examination done before leaving for Dubai. The medical tests revealed that he was HIV positive. His wife Balbir decided to leave her husband and live with her parents and young daughter. Upon reaching her fathers house Balbir Kaur got HIV tests done on herself and her daughter and sighed a relief with the HIV negative reports. It was not know yet how Paramjit Singh acquired HIV. ,Paramdeep Singh Teja, SP (Headquarter) Tarn Taran told TNN that Balbir Kaur had filed an application with police alleging that her husband was HIV positive and his family used to harass her after she had desired to divorce him. He said he had called both parties on June 17 to discuss the matter and find an amicable way. ,However, he informed that village elders and ,panchayat, members gathered at village Pandhori Gola along with both families and mutually agreed that both Balbir and Paramjit should part away and lead their own lives. ,Meanwhile it is learnt that Balbir had also filed a complaint with Tarn Taran police that her husband and relatives from in laws side allegedly tried to abduct her.,Harbir Singh (name changed) father of Balbir Kaur told TNN that he was pleased that at least her daughter and granddaughter didn't have any disease. He said the family wanted Balbir to divorce Paramjit and the village have decided the same.

Title: HIV positive cases rocketing
article: KANPUR: The number of HIV positive patients in the city is rising. According to Ganesh Shankar Vidyarthi Medical (GSVM) College authorities over 120 HIV positive cases have been reported from in and around Kanpur. Alarmed by this trend, a five-member delegation of National Aids Control Organisation (NACO) will visit the city on Thursday . The HIV positive cases at Voluntary Confidential Counselling Testing (VCCT) centres indicate that individuals from lower strata of society still opt for multi-partner sex while a miniscule section contracts this disease through intravenous use of drugs and blood transfusion during pregnancies.,The six-month data of this year at the three VCCTs revealed that 10 out of more than 15 persons who tested HIV positive got infection through multi-partner sex, while three had used same needle for intravenous drug and two were infected by blood transfusion during pregnancies.,The number of HIV positive patients using same needle for drugs is on the rise among youths aged between 18 to 25 years. Most of them are from Beaconganj and Chamanganj localities.,The high risk patients, coming to VCCTs through non-government organisations (NGOs) are truck drivers, cleaners, para- millitary personnel and individuals living away from home. Such patients mostly come from Naubasta, Transport Nagar and Koyla Nagar localities. HIV positive patients from outside the city mostly come from Ballia, Bahraich, Gonda and Gorakhpur. Call girls are also a major factor in the increase in HIV positive patients. A major part of the Pony Road locality in Shuklaganj is turning into a red light area and increase in cases from this area is a cause of concern.

Title: HIV cases on the rise
article: KANPUR: The number of HIV positive patients in the city is rising. According to Ganesh Shankar Vidyarthi Medical (GSVM) College authorities over 120 HIV positive cases have been reported from in and around Kanpur. Alarmed by this trend a five member delegation of National Aids Control Organisation (NACO) will visit the city on June 23.,The HIV positive cases at Voluntary Confidential Counselling Testing (VCCT) centres indicate that individuals from lower strata of society still opt for multi-partner sex while a minuscule section contracts this disease through intravenous use of drugs and blood transfusion during pregnancies.,Six month data of 2005 at the three VCCTs revealed that ten out of more than fifteen persons who tested HIV positive had got infected through multi-partner sex, while three had used same needle for intravenous drug and two were infected by blood transfusion during pregnancies.,However, the VCCTs here are neither willing to give any details nor are they denying the figures. The cases of HIV positive patients using same needle for drugs is on the rise among youths aged between 18 to 25 years. Most of them are from Beaconganj and Chamanganj localities.,The high risk patients, coming to VCCTs through non government organisations (NGOs) are truck drivers, cleaners, para millitary personnel and individuals living away from home. Such patients mostly come from Naubasta, Transport Nagar and Koyla Nagar locality. HIV positive patients from outside the city hail mostly from Ballia, Bahraich, Gonda, Gorakhpur. ,Call girls, working in city outskirts, are also being cited as a major factor in the increase in HIV positive patients. A major part of the Pony road locality in Shuklaganj is turning into a red light area and cases reported from here have become a cause of concern for VCCT centre in-charge. A call girl racket was busted by the police in 2005 and out of the four women and one man arrested the latter tested HIV positive. Likewise in 2003 three call girls tested HIV positive. After that no fresh cases have been reported though prostitution is rife on the city outskirts claim VCCT in-charge.,In 2003 from January till December out of over hundred who reported for counselling six men and two women patients tested HIV positive. In 2004 14 women and 8 men tested positive. Also more than 450 patients were counselled at VCCTs. The only ray of hope is that people, on suspicion of HIV infection, are coming voluntarily to VCCTs for counselling.

Title: HIV cases in AP project scary picture
article: HYDERABAD: The latest Aids figures for Andhra Pradesh are out. There are a total of 14,211 cases going by the reportage from the districts as on May 31, 2005.,This means, the jump in figures is as much as 2,382 cases compared to the previous two months, according to sources in the Andhra Pradesh State Aids Control Society.,There has been a rise in Aids cases throughout the country though the figures of some states for the last two months have not been updated by the National Aids Control Organisation (Naco).,According to the latest figures, the total number of Aids cases in India is 1,09,349 compared to 1,04,824 in the end of April, 2005.,On the eve of a massive Aids awareness campaign across the country from July 1, a latest World Bank report submitted to the Government of India on June 23 brings out the point that the Aids situation in the country is more serious than ever before.,It is estimated that there could be 50 to 55 lakh people infected by HIV in the country. The report said six states, containing 30 per cent of India's population already have high prevalence.,Andhra Pradesh is among the three states which have high prevalence rate. The other two are Tamil Nadu and Maharashtra, according to officials of the A P State Aids Control Society.,HIV is spreading rapidly amongst women and is already higher in some rural areas than urban ones, the WB report said.

Title: BJYM, NGO join hands for HIV people
article: PUNE: HIV-positive people joining warkaris and spreading the message about the dreaded disease by distributing pamphlets. Sounds more like another filmi plot on the issue? ,In a bid to create awareness about HIV and Aids, the youth wing of the BJP, Bharatiya Janata Yuva Morcha, on Tuesday announced that it has joined hands with a NGO from Neral near Matheran.,"And what better time than the four day palkhi procession," said the city president of BJYM Sandeep Khardekar, adding that the idea is to provide an opportunity to a group of 50 odd positive people, including women, "to spread the message and create a positive attitude in the minds of the people.,According to Anees Deshpande from Apulki, the NGO which has been primarily working for all-round development of adivasis in the state, HIV positive people have always been looked down upon by the society, and are faced with stigma and humiliation. "We thought of giving them an opportunity to come out in the open and share their views," he said.,The palkhis of Sant Tukaram Maharaj and Sant Dnyaneshwar Maharaj will enter the city on Wednesday and warkaris would stay in the city till Saturday, July 2, during which lakhs of pilgrims from across the state, some even from outside, will assemble in the city before proceeding to their destination. ,Twenty-five year old Meera (name changed), who is also part of the 50-member group, who has been living an isolated life, after her HIV infected husband passed a year after marriage, wondered as to why people like her, has been targeted by the society for no fault of theirs. ,According to Khardekar, the group will also appeal to the people to lend a helping hand to let live the infected people a decent life. "If not jobs, people can come forward and provide opportunities to these people to start something on the small scale," he said.

Title: Troops to get HIV-awareness cards
article: PUNE: The Indian Army is in the process of printing pocket-sized 'awareness cards'for its 1.3 million troops, providing information about HIV/AIDS in Indian languages.,Similar to the ones given to UN peacekeeping forces, senior military sources in the Directorate general of armed forces medical services (DGAFMS) said the cards are an attempt to educate the defence personnel to take universal precautions and stay protected from HIV during the course of their duty.,The awareness cards are a result of a tripartite agreement signed in April this year by the Ministry of defence (MoD) and the National AIDS control organisation (Naco) with UNAIDS. As per the agreement, the UN agency will assist the MoD and Naco to design and implement a comprehensive AIDS prevention programme among army ranks, NCC cadets and para-military personnel.,The programme will include awareness-raising initiatives; peer education; and training and integration of HIV/AIDS and STD-related issues into the curricula of military schools across the country.,"The idea is to bolster the existing efforts in preventing the spread of the disease within the defence forces," said a source from the DGAFMS, adding that similar agreements have also been signed by the UN agency with other countries, like Costa Rica, Dominican Republic, Peru and Kazakhstan, to name a few. As a military official, earlier involved in the Armed forces AIDS control organisation (ACO), said, although the number of newly-infected ones in the defence forces has reached a "plateau" in recent times, troops still are a vulnerable lot because of their separation from families for unnaturally long periods. Although the actual number of HIV-infected in the defence forces has always been kept under wraps, it is estimated that there are over 4,000 HIV/AIDS patients within the forces. A report prepared by the ACO a couple of years back, had revealed that out of the total cases reported, 81% belonged to the army, 10% to the navy, 2% to the air force, and the remaining shared by others within the defence establishment.

Title: Cops cope with HIV
article: In Punjab, policemen are being put through a comprehensive medical examination after seven cops in Ferozepur tested positive for HIV recently. The objective: to provide mental succour and financial support for the afflicted personnel., In Mumbai, HIV-positive cops may soon get expensive drugs free from the force. This follows another pro-active step taken less than 12 months ago when the force accepted an International Labour Organisation charter to become a HIV/AIDS-friendly workforce with zero discrimination., In Pune, afflicted policemen no longer able to undertake strenuous beat work are assigned to the desk work supervising pollution under control-testing units.,The tough-as-nails khakhi force does seem to acquiring a 'sensitive' dimension, courtesy the HIV/AIDS epidemic. The red-ribbon philosophy of reaching out to afflicted persons seems to be gaining acceptance as awareness meetings and counselling sessions begin featuring in a cop's diary.,But the dark side of all this exemplary response is what brought it about in the first place. Is it proof of the suspicion that the police now qualifies as a highrisk-behaviour group? Has the epidemic seriously penetrated the force?,The answer depends on who is being questioned. An activist from Hyderabad nods an emphatic yes. "Policemen should be considered as part of a high-risk group along with commercial sex-workers, migrant workers and truckers,"he says.,But policemen disagree. "The force is not a high-risk group,"says joint commissioner (administration) Subhash Awate. The incidence of AIDS/HIV wouldn't be more than it was in the normal population, he asserted. He has a supporter in Mumbai District AIDS Control Society chief Nirupa Borges, who categorically states that policemen do not fall into this "hazardous"category.,But her counterpart in Bihar, Uday Kumar Ujjwala of BACS, has reason to believe that policemen are more at risk. "Incidence of sexually-transmitted diseases is high among them,"he says, explaining that persons with STD have a 10% higher risk of HIV-AIDS because of the lesions that facilitate the virus' entry.,A survey done by BSACS, among enunchs living in Patna, recently revealed that they numbered policemen among their regular clients.
