"We definitely consider the police force to be a high-risk group in the light of these findings,"says Ujjwala.,Non-governmental organisation Sakhi that has worked with commercial sex-workers in Patna, too, has found that cops are regular visitors. "The sex-workers' clients from the police include men from the top to the bottom,"claims a Sakhi activist.,The Andhra Pradesh AIDS Control Society consultants who interact with the police say the prevalence is greater among personnel of the AP Special Police and those who are on night-patrolling. According to Indian Labour Organisation official S M Afsar, young recruits posted away from home and with easy access to paid sex are more vulnerable to the disease.,In conservative Pune, a fresh case of AIDS or HIV-positive is registered every four months at the Police Hospital situated in the headquarters.,Of course, no comprehensive study has been carried out across the country to study the incidence or prevalence of AIDS\HIV among policemen. Joint commissioner Awate of the Mumbai Police pooh-poohs claims that 185 policemen in his 39,000-strong force are HIV-positive. And officials in Bangalore point out that the exact numbers are not available as the identity of the person affected by HIV is kept confidential unless the victim volunteers or the matter needs to be taken up legally.,At a time when there is a raging debate over the number of AIDS/HIV persons in the country, it is not surprising that there isn't a number one can put to the policemen with AIDS. This is all the more reason, feels social worker Preeti Patkar in Mumbai, that the "high-risk"tag should be avoided for policemen. "I wonder if this is true numerically. Moreover, adding such tags only worsens matters like in the case with commerical sex-workers."She adds that there is a need to sensitise various groups - "be they policemen or high-paid executives"- about HIV and AIDS.,Says N Borges of the Mumbai District AIDS Control Society: "There is definitely a need to sensitise people about the disease but not because of their so-called sexual behaviour. They often come in contact with blood in cases of accident or assault and they need to be aware about the pitfalls.",(Inputs by Abhay Mohan Jha/Patna, Mridula Chundur/Hyderabad, Gitesh Shelke/Pune and Paawana Poonacha/Bangalore)

Title: Woman, 20, convicted of infecting lover with HIV
article: A 20-year-old, Welsh woman has become the first in Britain to be convicted of deliberately infecting her lover with HIV during sex, according to a BBC report.,Cardiff Crown Court heard the woman, who cannot be named to protect the man's identity, had sex with him for 10 months knowing she was HIV positive. ,She admitted a charge of unlawfully inflicting grievous bodily harm. ,Judge Christopher Llewellyn Jones, who was sent a letter by the man who said his life had been ruined, sentenced the woman to two years' youth detention. ,The court heard that she had lied to her partner when he asked her if she carried the infection. ,The woman--who was 18 at the time of the offence and had had HIV since the age of 15--said she did not tell him because she feared that if she told him, he would leave her, reports the BBC.,The court heard the couple had protected sex after they met in a nightclub in September 2002, but stopped using condoms when they moved in together shortly afterwards. ,They split up early in 2004 because he suspected she was sleeping with other men, and he then began hearing rumours about her HIV status, the court was told. ,He confronted his ex-girlfriend but, said Andrew Jones, prosecuting, "she blatantly lied to him and told him not to be so stupid." The court heard she showed him a report which said that she was not HIV positive, but the man now believes it was doctored to show a negative result. ,She had, in fact, known she was HIV positive since June 2003, the court was told. The man discovered he was HIV positive 10 days before Christmas 2004 after undergoing tests. ,In a letter read to the court, the man said: "I now have to live with being infected with HIV for the rest of my life. ,"I will never forget the day I went to the clinic with my father and my brother and they told me I was HIV positive. I can never forgive her for the terrible pain my family is going through."

Title: HIV therapy in 100 hospitals
article: HYDERABAD: Anti-retrovial therapy (ART) for treatment of HIV cases will be provided in all government medical colleges and hospitals of the state in two years, Union minister for health Ambumani Ramadoss said here on Saturday.,The minister was participating in a function to mark the month-long Aids awareness and sustained holistic campaign (Aasha) and the launch of the Andhra Pradesh Partnersï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Forum to prevent the spread of the disease.,Ramadoss said since the state had the highest prevalence of sexually transmitted diseases (STDs), the therapy would be extended to all government medical colleges and hospitals.,Ramadoss said 25 hospitals in the country have anti-retroviral therapy (ART) centres and this would be extended to 100 hospitals by the end of the year.,Chief minister Y S Rajasekhara Reddy said Aids awareness cells would be set up at all the primary health centres (PHCs) in the state. As of now, 56 PHCs conduct the aids awareness programme, he said.,"The possibilities of introducing a chapter on Aids prevention from Class VI will be explored, considering the fact that more and more youngsters are falling prey to the disease," the chief minister said.

Title: HIV victims fight stigma with rakhi
article: AHMEDABAD: Thirty-year-old Seema (name changed) was confined to one room in her house in Vadodara, served food in separate utensils and also prevented from playing with her children. Her fault ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ she lost her husband to HIV and has contracted the infection.,On Friday, Seema, along with two other HIV positive women, will come out in the open after many months and tie a rakhi to MLA Bhupendra Lakhawala,marking the beginning of their fight against the discrimination and social isolation. "We hope to inspire other HIV-infected women to come out of their closets," says Seema.,"Rakshabandhan fosters bonding between brothers and sisters. The occasion will draw the attention of the masses to the stigma and discrimination meted out to HIV patients.Many misconceptions about the disease, like contracting it through handshakes, kissing, sharing utensils and clothes, have led to social isolation of HIV patients, especially women, even today.By roping in well-known people, we can reach out to a larger audience,"says Pritesh Shah, project officer of HIV/Aids Care and Support Project.,In Ahmedabad, sex workers tied rakhis to city police commissioner K R Kaushik, mayor Aneesa Mirza and municipal commissioner Anil Mukim.,Numerous teams of sex-workers, united under the banner of Sakhi Jyot Foundation, moved across 30 police stations, media houses and the city municipal corporation to tie red-ribbon rakhis and create awareness about HIV/Aids. "The idea was also to bring sex workers face to face with the prominent faces of the city and initiate a process of removing the stigma so that these women are accepted in the society,"says project director of the Ahmedabad Aids Control Society, Dr Laxman Malodiya.

Title: Wake up to HIV/AIDS, hair dressers told
article: CHANDIGARH: The Citizens Awareness Group in collaboration with the State AIDS Control Society, UT Chandigarh organised a seminar on HIV/AIDS for hair dressers, roadside barbers and beauty parlours at Female Literacy House, Sector 42 to create awareness on HIV/AIDS.,Speaking at the seminar, Dr Inderjit Kaur Walia, Director Health Services, UT Chandigarh highlighted the precautionary measures to be adopted to curtail the HIV/AIDS. She also said, already 1,500 cases of HIV positive had been identified in Chandigarh itself. She lauded the efforts of the society in collaborating with various NGOs to generate awareness about HIV/AIDS and provide the best possible testing and counselling facilities to the patients from the entire region.,Surinder Verma, Chairman, Citizens Awareness Group explained, how hair dressers and beauty parlours are high risk professions due to the nature of their trade. He stressed the need for the use of hygienic methods in the trade. Verma said: "To avoid the spread of infection, barbers should make use of sterilised or disposable razor. The best policy is to use fresh blade after every shave.,The IEC project for awareness generation among hair dressers and beauty parlours was started on February 19 from Female Literacy House and within this period about 2,200 individual counselling sessions have been held. Also 42 awareness generation camps were organised and 530 aluminium plates were fixed carrying instructions for the hair dressers/beauty parlours.

Title: 'Testing HIV positive is not end of the road'
article: LUCKNOW: A group of drunkards were sitting outside a bar. The urge to drink was strong, but none had a penny. A man comes by and asks the bar owner to serve drinks to all those with no money. ,The man pays the bill. The curious bar owner asks the man the reason of his generosity. The man sheepishly says, "It's a business secret." ,As everyone leaves. The bar owner repeats the question. The man replies, "I sell wood for cremation. You and I will never run out of business, till the time these men keep drinking and dying." ,Naresh Yadav narrates this story to summarise the status of work being done by the non-government organisations (NGOs) and government officers in the state for persons testing HIV positive. ,"Till the time, the number of HIV-positive persons keep on rising, NGOs and government organisations would keep on doing good business and they would never be short of grants," said Yadav, who himself is an HIV-infected man, but has plenty of spunk unlike others like him who are driven into depression due to the social stigma. ,"Crores of rupees have been pumped into HIV-AIDS prevention, control and awareness programmes in the last ten years. Hundreds of NGOs and government bodies are working for its eradication. ,But still, the number of HIV-positive persons has doubled over the years," he said and hastened to add -- "I don't mean that NGOs or the government are not doing enough for HIV-AIDS, but there is an apparent lack of devotion and commitment required to tackle the problem." ,Yadav has no reservation in accepting that he has tested HIV-positive. He enjoys life to the fullest and spreads the same message among others like him that testing HIV-positive is not the end of the road. ,Yadav has formed a network of HIV positive persons ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ "UPNP +" ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ UP Welfare Network for People Living with HIV-AIDS Society. ,Since the last eight months, he, along with 35 dedicated HIV positive persons have been working in eastern UP districts, Lucknow and Allahabad, spreading awareness about HIV-AIDS and encouraging infected persons to live life boldly and normally. ,The group is meeting in the state capital in a couple of days to draw the future course of action for reaching the masses to break the mindset against HIV-positive persons. ,The group will soon organise a rally ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ a first of its kind effort ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ in Lucknow for HIV infected persons. "Tuberculosis spreads faster than HIV. ,Hundreds die every year because of blood pressure and diabetes, who can otherwise be saved by proper disease management," he explained and added "Similarly, proper management can make an HIV positive person live a normal life". ,However, he said, the propaganda carried out by NGOs and the government makes people believe that the life is doomed after testing HIV positive. ,"What if one has an infection...one then take multivitamins, anti-oxidants, lives in a clean and hygienic place and take some precautions...and life goes as usual," he said. ,Yadav said very few HIV infected persons know that free treatment and medicines are available at Anti Retrovirus Therapy (ART) centres, including BHU and KGMU. ,An HIV-infected person needs counselling and capacity building. It has been seen that infected persons from lower classed are more forthcoming, in comparison to middle and upper middle class, who are reluctant to come in open. ,"The real issue today is how to help an HIV infected person live a normal life," he said. NGOs, government organisations and people need to work under an umbrella, he said adding we, the infected persons are ready to show the way.

Title: Want to join the Army? Get HIV test done first
article: PUNE: Starting October 1, aspirants for the defence forces will have to undergo a mandatory HIV test. In a landmark decision, the defence headquarters has proposed to make the HIV test mandatory for officers, junior commissioned officers (JCOs) and other ranks (ORs) in the Army, Navy and the Air Force to "check the spread of the epidemic". ,The directorgeneral of the Armed Forces Medical Services, surgeon vice-admiral V.K. Singh, said a detailed proposal has been sent to the ministry of defence (MoD), and is currently awaiting a final go-ahead. ,That, he said, was a mere formality. High mobility due to the nature of jobs, physically-challenging work environment and single-sex arrangements add to the vulnerability of the soldier or defence personnel. ,"Moreover, they don't have any choice of a posting, be it an HIV risk-prone area," he said. Worried about the incidence of infections in the Northeast, the Army has already made it mandatory for soldiers posted in the insurgency-hit area to carry condoms. ,"Currently, an HIV test is mandatory only for those sent abroad or posted in high-risk areas like the North-east," Singh said, adding that even pregnant Army wives are compulsorily tested for HIV. ,"We have the HIV-testing facility in 96 centres, and plan to add another 30 soon," he said. A similar move initiated a couple of years back was put on the backburner following criticism from several quarters, including the National Aids Control Organisation (NACO). ,"Even armies in the US, Thailand and some other countries strictly follow the practice of mandatory HIV tests," Singh said. ,The proposal was sent to the MoD after a memorandum of understanding was signed between UNAIDS and the Army in April this year. ,The UN agency has undertaken the task of assisting the MoD and NACO to design and implement a comprehensive AIDS prevention programme among military ranks, NCC cadets and other para-military personnel in the country. ,"Considering the severity of the HIV/AIDS threat in the country, certain tough measures have to be taken," he said.

Title: Stop counselling HIV patients at J J
article: MUMBAI: The state health ministry has asked a religious group to call off a programme for counselling AIDS patients at J J Hospital citing lack of space. ,The Brahma Kumaris had been invited by the dean some months ago following a spate of suicides by HIV-afflicted patients. ,The room where the Brahma Kumaris counselled the patients and advised them to adopt meditational techniques to counter stress is now shut. ,Confirming that the Brahma Kumaris had been told to leave, dean of J J Hospital Dr Pravin Shingare said the state government had denied permission for the Brahma Kumaris to stay on. ,"In any case it was an experimental programme which had to be approved by the government. Yet, I feel they really contributed to the well being of the patients, which is what my professors of medicine told me. I am trying to get them back," said Shingare. ,Shingare's enthusiasm for the Brahma Kumaris is not shared by the Department of Medicine which handles the crucial Anti-Retroviral Therapy (ART) for HIV positive persons. ,Under the ART programme, J J Hospital treats 2,371 severely AIDS-infected persons in addition to nearly 4,000 patients with the HIV virus who have not developed AIDS. ,Free anti-retroviral drugs are given to the 2,371 persons (1,612 males, 758 females, 1 eunuch) every month for six months and later refills are given for two months after six months are over. ,On any given day there are five to nine new patients and on a crowded day, there are nearly 200-250 patients sprawled across every available inch of space in the ART department on the second floor. ,From the same place, anti-TB, anti-pneumonia and anti-fungal treatment are also given to HIV positive persons. Additionally, free condoms are distributed as a measure of HIV prevention. ,From one end of the small room extending to another adjacent small room, HIV afflicted persons wait their turn patiently for treatment. If they are lucky, they get a wee bit of space on a wooden bench outside. ,Since many of then suffer from opportunistic ailments like tuberculosis, the likelihood of infection spreading from one person to another is always a risk. Individual counselling is tough as the resources are minimal and therefore often there is mass counselling. ,Since there is lack of space and of resources, anti-retroviral drugs that are sent in bulk packages from New Delhi are stored on the fifth floor in one corner. Often the counsellors or ward boys along with the patients run up and down to fetch the medicines. ,At J J Hospital, where space and resources are at a premium, a spacious room exclusively for Brahma Kumaris was indeed a luxury. ,"What was needed was medical counselling. You cannot invite Brahma Kumaris to come and counsel HIV positive persons. The hospital is not a religious place where non-medical persons are needed and that too in a crucial department like HIV/AIDS. When we in the department are gasping for more trained personnel and more space, I wonder how we can justify such peace meditation," asked a senior person in the ART department. ,Earlier this week, the ART department recently became the first centre in India to give free treatment to small children who have been afflicted with HIV virus. ,Now with special oral medicines suitable enough for small babies, the ART department has started treating babies though storage and refrigeration for oral syrup is still a problem for poor patients. ,In addition to the existing 35 children, another 100-200 children are expected to be given treatment under the ART scheme. The ART department at J J Hospital is also fast becoming the most preferred centre for HIV treatment and patients often come from far off places in Bihar and UP instead of going to New Delhi. ,And almost all of them belong to the lower strata of the society. The patients, however, do not get any sort of railway concessions. ,This despite the fact that the chief of the JJ Medicine department, Dr Alka Deshpande, who is also in the charge of ART treatment, has written to the railway minister, Lalu Prasad Yadav urging him to give railway concession that is routinely given to other medically ill patients who use the railways to travel to any hospital for treatment.

Title: Govt gives relief to HIV+ students
article: BANGALORE: Coming to the rescue of over five lakh HIV-infected patients and their children, the state education department has ruled that no school in the state shall discriminate against children affected by Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV). ,In case of violation, schools could lose affiliation or face punitive action. The order, issued by primary and secondary education principal secretary T M Vijay Bhaskar, will come into effect from the current academic year and will be applicable to all schools . government, aided or unaided. ,"There is no need for schools to know about the HIV status of the child at the time of admission. There should be no discrimination against children affected by HIV or those whose parents are HIV-infected," the order says. ,In order to ensure effective implementation of the order, the department has instructed all deputy directors of public instruction and block education officers to see HIVinfected students are treated on par with others. ,DDPIs and BEOs, will in turn, give necessary directions to all school headmasters, about the new order. The government'fs action follows the story of an eight-year-old girl who was denied admission by Dakshina Kannada school in August, which was widely reported the media. ,This, officials say, is also to prevent any cases of bias against children affected by HIV as the state is one of the hotbeds of AIDS. Karnataka has the fourth highest number of AIDS cases in India. ,The department has also taken up HIV/AIDS education at government schools with assistance from the health department. "Based on the information given by Karnataka State AIDS Prevention Society, we have printed information about AIDS and HIV in the inside cover pages of some textbooks for Class and 10," DSERT director Jagannath Rao said.

Title: HIV-infected couple to open meet on medicine
article: PATNA: An HIV-infected couple from Siwan will inaugurate the three-day 13th annual conference of the Indian Association of Clinical Medicine here at Hotel Maurya on Saturday. The scientific session would start on Friday evening. ,The couple, Arun Singh and Seema Singh of village Satwar in Siwan district, hails from a middle class family, are established cases of Aids. "With their sheer grit and determination they are carrying on with their work and have also given birth to an HIV negative baby," said the organising secretary of the meet, Dr Ajay Kumar. ,This bold initiative would help increase awareness among doctors and masses regarding this modern curse. This would be a giant step towards acceptance of HIV-infected individuals in the social mainstream and remove the stigma attached therein, Kumar added. ,Around 300 clinicians of the country, including R Handa, S C Dash, Uma Kumar (all from AIIMS New Delhi) B K Sahay and G Narsimullu (Hyderabad), Sukumar Mukherjee, Dhiman Ganguly (Kolkata) are expected to participate in the scientific deliberations. ,Various workshops, medi-quiz for PG students and presentation of real life cases would be organised during the conference. Diseases like diabetes, hypertension, heart disease, cancers along with newer afflictions like HIV/Aids have posed new challenges for practising clinicians.

Title: Empower sex workers: Antidote to HIV
article: NEW DELHI: The legal prohibition on prostitution and homosexuality is at odds with the strategy to fight AIDS which seeks to identify and target these two groups. ,Experts say it creates a predicament for the anti-AIDS programme. While the National AIDS Control Organisation supports targeted intervention in brothels, sex workers and facilitators are prosecuted as these activities attract punitive action. Experts and civil society underlined this discrepancy during the preliminary deliberations with the Plan panel.,Empowerment of sex workers is being pushed as the best antidote to HIV. Syeda Hameed, Planning Commission member, said: "Sonagachi in Kolkata has proved that the best way to check the spread of the HIV virus among sex workers is to bring them overground."

Title: Ostracism of HIV affected fading
article: SURAT: For 10-year-old Chinmay Kumar, an HIV+ve boy, social ostracism no longer exists. With over 2,000 people clapping while he was pinning the 'red ribbon'on guests during a function at the venue of 'Jai Ambe Ras Garba' near Puna Jakat Naka here on Thursday night, a new beginning was made. ,Standing ovation by the public indicated the likelihood of the gap between the likes of Chinmays and the rest being bridged. On the occasion, city police commissioner Sudhir Sinha lauded the efforts of the garba organisers. With both parents being HIV+ve, Chinmay, residing at Varachha here, too contracted it through them at an early age. ,Proper counselling has made the family lead a normal life.Chinmay is a student of class V. In a city, with an estimated 20,000 HIV +ive people, and around three of them dying on an average every month, there has been social segregation, mainly due to lack of awareness and the social stigma attached to it, says head of Gujarat State Network of Positive (GSNP) People, Surat chapter, Umesh Patel. ,Till recently, many among HIV+ve people in the city were scared to let others know, fearing social stigma, says Sonal Shroff of Lok Vikas Sanstha which works for creating awareness about HIV and AIDS in industrial belts like Hazira here. ,But with the intervention by NGOs, an ever increasing sensitisation is taking place, and not only the HIV +ive people are admitting it openly, they are also gaining social acceptance, Shroff adds. ,Last year during Navratri, around 10 of them sported T-shirts with inscriptions like 'Main Kaun Hoon? Main HIV +ive Hun' (Who am I? I am HIV +ive), but many failed to endorse this bold step, says Daksha Patel of GSNP here. ,But this time, hundreds of them came out in the open to mingle with others at the garba ground without any fear of ostracism, says Patel adding, "At the garba venue itself, several stalls were set up for creating awareness." ,With proper intervention, the spread of HIV could be contained to a great extent, but then the society at large would have to accept its responsibilities for adopting a humane approach to the issue, says an HIV +ive person Dina Limbachiya (31), residing at Katargam. ,Organising workshops, seminars and other events would have an impact only if adequate steps are taken to sensitise the society, says organiser of Jai Ambe Ras Garba Jayesh Liliyawala.

Title: '86 pc of HIV transmission is through sex'
article: CHANDIGARH: By 2025 as many as 50 million people in the country will be infected with AIDS. Out of this, 40 million can be saved only if there is 100 per cent use of condoms among commercial sex workers as 86 per cent of HIV transmission in the country is through the sexual mode. ,These startling facts and figures were revealed by the director general of National AIDS Control Organisation (NACO), Dr SY Quraishi, who was in town on Monday. NACO is initiating a special programme, PACT India ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Partnership for AIDS Control and Treatment. ,As a vehicle to promote awareness about the disease and human rights for its victims, NACO has tied up with Art of Living besides entering into a partnership with CII. "Active involvement of various sections of media, judiciary, education besides religious leaders is being sought to make the programme a success," said Dr Quraishi. ,Listing out various steps taken by the government to check the menace of AIDS Dr Quraishi said, "Central Council of AIDS has been formed under the leadership of the Prime Minister and a conference of all chief ministers is scheduled to be held shortly. NACO is networking with 31 ministries. ,The aim is to identify states which are underperforming in the AIDS programme." The number of centres providing anti-retroviral drugs is scheduled to swell from the existing 25 to 50 in the country. ,Speaking about the ARD centre at PGI Dr Quraishi said, "Since the number of AIDS patients in the city per se is not dramatically high, the centre will be upgraded and given a boost in another two to four years." Punjab is fast becoming a higher risk state due to its large number of carriers, which include truck drivers and migrant labourers. ,The state has already 2,034 HIV positive patients, 334 full-blown AIDS cases and 92 deaths reported due to the disease, till April 2005. Dr Sonia Trikha of state AIDS control society said the first phase of the national programme was from 1987 to 1999 and the second phase in now on. ,The first case from the region was reported in 1987 whereas the first case of Chandigarh was detected in 1992 and till now 4,797 HIV positive cases have been detected in the region with 248 in Chandigarh, said Dr Trikha.

Title: HIV prevalence rising among newly-weds
article: HYDERABAD: Even as the government is contemplating the proposal of pre-marital HIV testing, the number of newly-weds turning out to be HIV positive is increasing in the state. At several HIV counselling centres in the city and around the state, 90 per cent of the support seekers are recently married young couples. ,"I have noticed this trend in the past one year, where women aged between 18 years and 25 years, who were recently married and contracted the disease from their husbands are approaching us in large numbers," said P V Ramesh, president of the NGO, Telugu Network for HIV Positive People (TNHPP) where all the members giving help are also HIV-positive. ,These young women are tested either at the time of their first pregnancy which in most cases is within one year of marriage or when their husbands fall sick or die. Statistics available with the AP State Aids Control Society (APSACS) show that 80 per cent of the women are monogamous or have relations with just one man, who is their husband in case of married women. ,For men, the means of contracting the virus are many. Experience of many NGOs providing counselling for the infected shows that a lot of young men are contracting the virus from having sexual relations with an older lady in the neighbourhood. "They have physical relationships with these 'aunties' whose husbands are away. ,The 'uncle' would have contracted the disease during one of his tours and gives to his wife who in turn passes it on to the younger man. This young man gets married and infects his wife. The cycle is the same in the cases of almost every newly-wed couple who comes to us for counselling," said K Badri, a counsellor with the city-based NGO, Cheyutha. ,This means of contracting the virus is not restricted to a particular economic class. In many districts, there are cases of young boys who have indulged in MSM or male-sex-with-male. The TNHPP has been getting at least four to five cases of MSM in each district in the past year, where 16 to 18-year-old boys are involved. ,MSMs, truck drivers, sex workers all these come under the high-risk group. However, recent studies by APSACS show that even the general population is showing high-risk behaviour. The figures this year show that out of the total infected population in the state, 45 per cent are in the 15 to 24 year bracket and another 45 per cent in the 25-49-year bracket. ,According to the counsellors at the city-based Network for HIV Positive People where 'positives' counsel fellow 'positives', the high-risk group should now include college-going boys and girls as well. "Many young college boys and girls are finding it easy to indulge in pre-marital sex as there are many brokers around the city who can provide them with a room at a nominal rate. ,They form more than 90 per cent of the people approaching us for guidance on what to do after being diagnosed HIV positive," said M Swapna, president of the network. ,However, these 'positive' people working to aid other 'positive' people, feel while pre-marital testing could be useful to some extent, there is no guarantee that either the husband or the wife would not indulge in unsafe sex after marriage. "People should themselves start realising their moral responsibility to their partner and be safe," Swapna said.

Title: Rape victim undergoes HIV test
article: MUMBAI: Blood samples of the 13-year-old Sahar rape victim and the police constable accused of raping her have been sent for HIV testing at the Nagapda Police Hospital, even as social workers stressed that the girl should undergo post-trauma counselling.,The victim, who used to beg at the traffic signal near the international airport, was allegedly raped by constable Chandrakant Pawar on October 17. The matter was reported to the Sahar police station and Pawar was arrested.,Recently, the girl was brought to the police hospital by crime branch officials and made to undergo blood tests to determine her HIV status, sources said. If the victim tested positive, sources said, she would be given proper counselling.

Title: At the receiving end: HIV+ spouses
article: MUMBAI: For long, Indian housewives have silently suffered transmission of HIV from their erring husbands. They are now fighting back. Through sections of the Indian Penal Code that clearly defines the transmission of a disease as a method of causing hurt; they are seeking justice, jail sentences for their husbands and compensation. On the flip side, there are cases of innocent men who are taking their philandering wives to court. ,Thirty-four-year-old Savita Ambekar had been married for well over eight years. A teacher in a small municipal school of Mumbai, her husband Sunil Ambekar worked as an upper division clerk in a government concern. Savita thought she had a happy marriage with a daughter and an evidently doting husband. She did have her fights with Sunil when at times he would stay out at nights or say he had urgent work on holidays. But as always, he had an explanation. ,A persistent cough and skin rashes which refused to go away took her to a government hospital where she was diagnosed as HIV-positive, seven years after marriage. When Savita, who had never had any physical contact outside her marriage, gave the news to Sunil, instead of receiving sympathy she faced a barrage of allegations and insinuations. The hospital where she had gone for treatment and counselling guided her to an NGO. Determined to fight for her rights and dignity, she used all the help that came her way to go to court. She also charged her husband under Sections 269 and 270 of the IPC for hurting her (along with Sections 323 and 325 of the IPC).,Section 269 of the IPC states that whoever unlawfully or negligently commits an act which is, and which he knows or has reason to believe to be, likely to spread infection of any disease dangerous to life shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months or with fine or both. Section 270 stresses on malignant transmission. On the other hand, Section 323 defines punishment for voluntarily causing hurt, while Section 325 defines punishment for causing grievous hurt.,Another case concerns 28-year-old Nitin Kapoor, who appeared to love his wife Gauri Kapoor more with each passing day. The software engineer had met Gauri, a consultant interior designer, through a common friend. In the first half of this year, Nitinï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s health deteriorated. Tuberculosis made his life miserable for many months and then he was diagnosed with skin cancer. A blood test also revealed that he was HIV-positive. Aghast at the discovery, he confronted Gauri who initially denied anything but later confessed to a brief fling with one of her clients. Outraged, Nitin has now dragged his wife to court and slapped a suit under Sections 269 and 270 read along with Sections 319 and 320.,Although the West has prosecuted people who had transmitted diseases knowingly or through criminal indifference, in India, that is yet to happen. For a long time, diseases were considered acts of god and accepted fatalistically as oneï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s lot. But things are changing. Both Savita and Nitin are among the few in Mumbai who have dragged their spouses to court. Helping them fight for their rights is a non-governmental organisation called the Lawyers Collective. ,"We are helping three women and two men who have registered cases against their respective spouses at a magistrateï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s court in Mumbai," says Julie George, legal officer, of Lawyers Collective. In Delhi, there had been a case where a woman filed a criminal suit against her husband for transmitting the HIV virus but the suit made no headway as the husband died due to HIV virus complications. Alaka Deshpande, head of the medicine department and in charge of treating HIV patients at the government-run J J Hospital, says a majority of the HIV-positive women who come to the hospital have been infected by their husbands. ,(Certain names and professions have been changed to protect their identities)

Title: Children of HIV patients learn to save
article: MUMBAI: Three-year-old Jubaal Roy, an HIV+ child, clung to his earthenware piggy bank and refused to let his mother break it open at Cama Hospital on Friday afternoon during a function organised by Yuvak Pratishthan, a voluntary organisation that works with HIV affected people in slums across the city.,During the function, children of HIV-affected men and women were given brand new, golden piggy banks in which to collect the money they were given as presents. The endeavour aimed at teaching these children to save money. Yuvak Pratishthan has been involved in such programmes for the past five years.,Children who had been saving money since last year got to break their pots at the function as their parents gathered the ten, twenty and hundred rupee notes scattered on the ground along with a heap of coins.,The money collected by the children will be invested in Kisan Vikas Patra, a savings scheme in which the money deposited will double over a period of time. Yuvak Pratishthan invested Rs 1,000 for each child along with the money collected by the child in the piggy bank.,Social activist and fashion designer Shaina NC, associated with Yuvak Pratishthan, attended the function and handed out the Kisan Vikas Patra certificates to the children.,All parents present at the function were HIV+. However many of the children were not affected by the virus. "During childbirth, children of HIV-affected parents are given a compulsory shot of Nevarapin, a drug that prevents the transmission of the virus from mother to child," said Yuvak Pratishthan general secretary, Medha Somaiya, adding that the drug had an efficiency rate of 97 per cent.,Addressing the children, Yuvak Pratishthan president, Kirit Somaiya said the piggy banks had magic in them. "When you break the pots, you'll land up with double the amount of money you began with," he said.,"Earlier, if a man was told he had AIDS, he would attempt suicide at the very thought. Now, however, families are more aware and more accepting of HIV patients and do not throw them out of the house any more," said Somaiya.

Title: Designer plans movie on HIV/AIDS
article: BANGALORE: New York-based Indian-American fashion designer Sanjana Jon, who has brought Miss Universe 2005 Natalie Glebova ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ a Canadian national of Russian originï¿½ï¿½ï¿½to the city, plans to make a movie starring Glebova alongside Bollywood star Salman Khan, her fashion designer brother Anand Jon and actress Paris Hilton in 2006.,Says Sanjana, "My movie will be a super natural thriller aimed at creating HIV AIDS awareness. We hope the actors will sign up for the movie, most of which will be shot in India. ,One of the titles suggested for the film is Seven Descendants, though its storyline is still being worked out.",Salman has already done a Hollywood movie MariGold that will hit the theatre in 2006.,Giving the slogan 'Get an HIV AIDS test, it is in fashion', Sanjana said she is planing to bring in the Backstreet Boys and some Hollywood stars to India, besides organising a film festival for spreading awareness on HIV/AIDS here.,Related to singer K J Yesudas and Zack Zacharia, who is a close buddy of George Bush and is tipped to become Governor of a state in the US soon, Sanjana wants to carve a niche in the world of fashion and entertainment.,With over 50 per cent of India's population being under the age of 25 years, it is important to sensitise them on the disease, she said. She wants to rope in the more 'rich and famous' to campaign on AIDS awareness. ,"Our intention is not to talk about sex, but to send a message on getting tested for AIDS".,While in New York, people discuss these things openly, but in India the society is very conservative. So it is all the more important that there is greater awareness created here, she said.,Thanking Bollywood actor Salman Khan,who through his movie Phir Milenge succeeded in creating AIDS awareness, Sanjana said, "Women are the worst affected as they constitute 60 per cent of all the AIDS victims."

Title: HIV+ve man to contest Surat polls
article: SURAT: Umesh Patel (28), an HIV positive for the past seven years, will be contesting the ensuing civic polls from ward no 19, having jurisdiction over Karanj (south) near Varachha.,But, he will not ask for votes. Instead, he would creating awareness among the public at large about HIV and AIDS, for an enabling environment to check further spread of the epidemic.,"I am not interested in politics. Being an HIV positive myself, I think that I should create awareness about the disease while mingling with the public in my ward, as only adequate safeguards and behaviour are required to curb it," says Patel.,Patel has studied till class 12 and hails from a humble background. He knows that only by creating awareness about HIV and AIDS among the public, the epidemic could be curbed to a great extent. ,Patel was diagnosed as HIV positive in 1998. Since then, he has been actively associated with Gujarat State Network of Positive (GSNP) people. Presently, he is the president of this organisation.,There is lots of stigma and discrimination associated with people having been diagnosed with HIV and AIDS, which results in misconceptions, causing hurdles in creating an enabling environment for curbing the spread of the epidemic, says Patel.,By revealing his HIV status to the public and then asking them to be fully aware of the cause and effect of the epidemic, he would attempt to develop social awareness to check the rise in the number of cases of HIV and AIDS, he says.,Only five per cent of HIV positive people know about their status, as many do not opt for testing due to fear of social discrimination. ,This results in a major hurdle for prevention programme, he says. Keeping this in mind, he would be putting in all efforts for creating a social environment, in which people would develop a healthy attitude toward prevention of the epidemic, he told TNN.,Along with around 1,000 people, including those with HIV positive status, he would take out a rally in his ward on Friday. ,The aim of the rally would be to promote awareness about HIV and AIDS, he said. After the rally, he would file his nomination at the collectorate.

Title: 135,630 cases of HIV infection reported in China
article: BEIJING: HIV infection in China is swelling and the country had an accumulative 135,630 HIV cases reported by the end of September, including 7,773 fatalities, Vice Health Minister Wang Longde said on Monday.,The cases involve 31,143 AIDS patients and 7,773 fatalities. The three provinces of Yunnan, Henan and Guangdong and two autonomous regions of Xinjiang and Guangxi reported over 10,000 cases each, accounting for 77 per cent of the country's total, said Wang at a national tele-conference on HIV/AIDS prevention and control.,Drug abuse is still the main cause of HIV infection, blamed for 40.8 per cent of the total infections, while illegal blood selling and unprotected sex have respectively led to 23.0 per cent and 9.0 per cent of the infections, he said ahead of the world AIDS day on December 1...,...Infections through 'unknown channels' account for 23.4 per cent of the total, the minister said, adding that most of such infections occurred due to unprotected sex.,'Although the epidemic is still spreading at a comparatively low speed in the country, the number of infection cases is still rising, especially among certain groups of people and in several regions,' he was quoted as saying by Xinhua news agency.,The infection rate among sex workers increased from 0.02 per cent in 1996 to 0.93 per cent in 2004 and the rate in pregnancy in high-risk regions increased from zero in 1997 to 0.26 per cent in 2004.,'This indicates that the epidemic is spreading from high-risk groups to ordinary people, and that China is in a critical period for AIDS prevention,' Wang noted.

Title: 7,500 people HIV positive in Bihar
article: PATNA: The Bihar State AIDS Control Society sponsored a marathon run and rangoli competition in collaboration with OSERD on Thursday to mark the World AIDS Day 2005.,The marathon run started from the society's office in Sheikhpura and concluded at Gandhi Maidan. Hundreds of students from different educational institutions participated in the run for generating awareness about the disease. ,Joint director of the society, Vishal Singh said that in the state of Bihar where 7,500 people are living with HIV/AIDS, the duty of the society is to ensure the best services in terms of support and prevention.,In another programme organised by the International Health Organisation (IHO), the chief guest and urban development minister, Ashwini Kumar Chaubey, stressed on the need to make people aware that HIV and AIDS were not a stigma hence the patients suffering from it should not be treated as untouchables. ,Expressing concern over the high incidence of the disease among migrant labourers, he said that the mentality of people needs to be changed.,An eminent physician of Patna, Dr S N Arya, corroborated Chaubey and added that another high incidence group is that of long-distance truck drivers. ,He also emphasised the need to give proper treatment to pregnant women suffering from the disease. "If properly treated, the possibility of newly borns contracting the disease from their mothers is very little," he said.,A street play was organised by the cultural society of the organisation to generate awareness.,A rally of 1,000 students and Red Cross volunteers was flagged off by chief secretary G S Kang from the Red Cross Bhawan on Thursday morning. Students held placards and banners for the AIDS awareness campaign.,Zonal inspector general of police Amrik Singh Nimbran appealed to policemen to resist from activities which cause the disease. He even asked them to extend their support and care to HIV/AIDS infected patients.,The Bihar branch of Francois Xavier Bagnoud India took out a cycle rally with 50 NCC cadets cycling their way towards generating awareness from Moinul Haq Stadium to the North S K Puri office of the organisation.,An NGO, Sarthi Foundation organised a street play "Suraksha kavach" at Khagaul to communicate the importance of the use of condoms to ward-off the disease.,At another function at Adarsh Divya Vikas Sansthan, former minister Sita Sinha emphasised the importance of awareness about the disease. ,An NGO, Sarva Saksharta, organised a programme in the memory of AIDS victims to discourage the discrimination against HIV-infected persons.,Another NGO - Deepti - organised an AIDS camp and free blood test campaign for detecting the disease. Prayas organised a programme to educate children living at the Patna Junction about the disease.,A similar workshop was organised at the Siwan Railway Station by All India Drona Anglo Vedic Society where free distribution of condoms took place and people were sensitised about the disease.,Speaking at a conference organised at Manvadhikar Sangrakshan Pratisthan and its chairman and former CM, Jagannath Mishra said that proper care must be taken to avoid AIDS, which he described as 'a debilitating disease'.,A series of events was organised at Gyan Niketan School. Shweta Bhattacharya of International School won the first prize in the Inter school debate. ,In the Inter school group discussion Kshitij Sinha of Gyan Niketan won the first prize. The second and third prizes were bagged by Shubham and Shashank of Gyan Niketan and St Karen's School respectively. ,The programme was inaugurated by retd judge S Narayan and was conducted by Kiran Bala Sinha and Alka Sinha. Students also staged a play 'jankari hi bachav hai' to educate their friends. ,Gramin Evam Nagar Vikas Parishad, Islamia Teachers' Training College, Patna Medical College, Maya Tetar Lok Seva Sansthan, A N College, NGO Sneh and Samaj Kalyan Parishad also organised functions to mark the day.

Title: HIV spreading fast among youngsters
article: HYDERABAD: HIV is spreading among the youngsters at an alarming rate and 50 per cent of those affected are in the 18-25 age group. ,Sixty one per cent of the HIV patients are based in urban areas, according to Dr P Somasekhara Reddy, director, department of health. ,He was speaking at an AIDS awareness rally organised by the Confederation of Indian Industry (CII) on Saturday. The rally was taken out from People's Plaza on Necklace Road to Sanjeevaiah Park. ,In the year 2004, 4.9 million people were infected with HIV and three million people died due to the infection, he said. ,Addressing the gathering, Dr I V Subba Rao, principal secretary (medical and health) said that an estimated 75 million people worldwide would be infected by 2010 and the figure may touch 100 million by 2020. ,The rally was flagged off by AP State AIDS Control Society (APSACS) project director K Damayanthi. Over 300 participants from corporate houses, NGOs, schools and colleges took part in the rally.

Title: HIV couple wed on world AIDS day
article: PALAKKAD: Sending the message that AIDS need not come in the way of nuptial bliss, an HIV positive couple got married at Muthalamada near here on World AIDS Day on Thursday.,Asokan and Ajitha, who tested HIV positive some time back, got married at the venue arranged by 'Sneham Charitable Trust', about 20 km from here...,...The 'tantri' of famous Guruvayur Sree Krishna temple, Chennas Dinesan Namboodiri, was the master of ceremony for the wedding which was attended by social activists, writers and cultural leaders.,"The couple have been longing to get married for quite some time. Now their dream has come true. We are happy that we could help them to lead a happy life," Sneham Trust Chairman Sunildas told PTI.,They had got betrothed at Thrissur on November 21 at the residence of eminent writer Dr Sukumar Azhikode.

Title: Not enough being done for HIV-infected
article: NEW DELHI: Prime Minister Manmohan Singh on Thursday expressed his displeasure on India missing its target of providing anti-retroviral drugs to 100,000 people by mid-2004. Till November 2005, only 15,000 people had received the drugs.,He said "Not enough is being done to provide anti-retroviral treatment to HIV-positive people. Prices must come down further to make these drugs more affordable and accessible to all. ,Drugs can cost around 1,300 rupees a month ($28) ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ less than a meal for two at a medium-priced restaurant in New York or London ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ but still out of reach for many Indians." India has 5.13 million people living with HIV/AIDS, the second largest number after South Africa. ,The government's goal is to ensure that in the next two years, India's health delivery system will be restructured to provide a comprehensive package of services to the community and to HIV infected persons, the prime minister said. ,"Our AIDS programme needs to get out of the narrow confines of the health department. It must become an integral part of all government departments. NACO should be made an integral part of the National Rural Health Mission," he said. ,Health minister A Ramadoss said that in the third phase of the prevention and treatment programme beginning from April next year, the government plans to mobilise over $1 billion of assistance through international partners to ,expand the access to treatment and counselling.,The World Bank has said HIV/AIDS could become the single biggest cause of death in India unless prevention and treatment was improved and made cheaper. ,Singh said there was also a need to prod the Indian pharmaceutical industry and accelerate basic research and produce low-cost drugs and vaccines.

Title: Draft legislation on HIV/AIDS ready: Sibal
article: NEW DELHI: Draft legislation on protecting the rights of HIV-infected people has been finalized and submitted to the Health Ministry, Science and Technology Minister Kapil Sibal said on Thursday.,"The legislation has been drafted by lawyers collectively and deals with various issues such as discrimination, confidentiality, right to treatment, care and support," Sibal, who chaired the group involved in drafting the legislation said at the launch of 'Quiet Storm', a UNDP-Penguin publication.,"I hope the government will take action on it soon," he said.,The draft had been prepared in about one and a half years and had been presented to the Health Minister, he said.,Sibal said currently there was no law to deal with issues such as dignity of people infected with HIV, husband's duty towards his wife with reference to the infection, financial support to be provided by the government and blood banks' responsibility.,HIV-infected people should be having all the rights availed by other people, he said adding even doctors were hesitant in treating them.,It was time the world community recognized the challenge posed by HIV/AIDS, Sibal said adding pharma companies and multinational companies had not done much towards vaccine production. Of the total spending on vaccine production, only one per cent was going for HIV/AIDS vaccine.

Title: Quick HIV test gives the scare
article: Health officials in New York and San Francisco said on Friday that a widely used rapid test for the virus that causes AIDS had been producing too many false-positive results, frightening healthy people into thinking they might be infected.,The test, called the OraQuick Advance HIV test, is the same one the US Food and Drug Administration has said it will consider approving for sale to the public for home use without a prescription.,But officials in the two cities and at the drug agency also emphasised that the test, which requires a mouth swab instead of a blood sample, should not be abandoned, because its convenience made it a valuable tool in fighting AIDS.,Rather, they said, the problem needs to be investigated, and clinics and patients need to be aware that a positive result must be confirmed by another type of test. Difficulties with the test were first reported Friday in the San Francisco Chronicle.,In New York, Dr Susan Blank, an assistant health commissioner, said that city clinics performed 3,600 to 3,700 tests for the virus, HIV, each month, largely using OraQuick, and until recently they had about five positives a month, a rate well within the makerï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s prediction. ,But in November, Blank said, the number shot up to 30, which was cause for concern. "Weï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ve made several lot switches to make sure we have most recent specimen kits," Blank said.

Title: CRPF suggests HIV testing for its recruits
article: PUNE: Close on the heels of the Indian Army announcing mandatory HIV testing of all recruits, the Central reserve police force (CRPF) has now made a similar suggestion to the ministry of home affairs (MHA). ,JK Sinha, director-general, CRPF, said a final decision rested with the government. ,Declining to give the exact status of HIV/AIDS infected in the CRPF, saying it was difficult to find out the exact number, Sinha said, "We are in a dilemma, as compulsory HIV testing is still not allowed under the pretext that it will be an infringement of human rights.,"The CRPF has 185 battalions, mostly deployed in field areas, besides 119 static formations. ,While admitting that HIV/AIDS is a problem area, as its personnel were vulnerable due to their long separation from families and difficult working conditions, Sinha said he hoped the armyï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s initiative would pave the way for the other paramilitary forces. ,"Like the army, the CRPF can be declared a special group,"he said. He, however, said the number of cases had seen a decline in the past couple of years due to concerted awareness programmes initiated by senior officials and the CRPF Wivesï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Welfare Association. , ,The armyï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s plans to make HIV testing compulsory for all recruits is awaiting clearance from the ministry of defence. ,Initially scheduled to start from October 1 this year, director general of the armed forces medical services, Surgeon Vice Admiral VK Singh, recently told TOI that the implementation had been delayed due to procedural reasons, and that it would come through soon.

Title: UAE clams up to HIV+ people from AP
article: HYDERABAD: Job hunting in the United Arab Emirates (UAE) may not be easy any more for people from AP, with the emirate tightening norms for visa seekers in a bid to deny entry to HIV-positive individuals from AP.,The UAE media have been portraying AP as a state that does not run stringent health checks on people intending to travel abroad. ,The UAE government took up the issue with the Union minister of state for overseas Indian affairs Oscar Fernandez during his recent visit there. The minister promised to tighten up pre-departure health checks.,There have been instances of people from AP being detected HIV-positive after landing in UAE. One such traveller, G Vadla, 38, was detected so the very day he landed in the country a month ago and is now undergoing treatment in Kuwaiti Hospital, Sharjah. ,He is said to be in a bad state and the emirate is said to be planning to repatriate him as soon he has recovered a little.,Every year hundreds of people from AP visit UAE on visit visas, which is valid only for 45 days. But many use the visa to enter the UAE and search for jobs within the validity period. ,After obtaining an offer letter from a UAE company, the job-seekers return to India and apply for a work visa.,IT and business administration professionals from AP top the list of job-seekers in the UAE.

Title: Six prisoners in Bettiah test HIV positive
article: BETTIAH: The HIV-AIDS time bomb is ticking at a furious pace in the border district of West Champaran, where, in a closely-guarded ongoing survey by the Bihar State Aids Control society (BACS), almost two dozen HIV-positive cases have already been detected. ,Adding panic to an already alarming scenario is the detection of half a dozen AIDS cases in the Bettiah jail. If that was not enough, one case has been found to exist in the Bettiah police lines too. ,"Where did you get this information?" West Champaran civil surgeon Arundhati shot back to a query on Tuesday even as she was frantically trying to locate two BACS teams in the field. ,On being told that jail inmates are agog with the news that six fellow prisoners have been tested AIDS-positive, the civil surgeon played down the report as the finding of a preliminary investigation. ,"We need to take two more tests before arriving at any conclusive finding," she said. Sources said that three cases have been found in the bordering Sikta block and two in Chanpatia, apart from the solitary case in the constabulary at the police lines. ,While migrant labourers returning from Delhi, Haryana, Punjab, Gujarat and Mumbai are feared to be the most vulnerable group, the detection of six cases in the local jail has set alarm bells ringing. ,Several inmates told TOI that enforced sodomy by musclemen prisoners has been a stark norm here. Young boys coming to jail fall prey to criminals reigning within the jail, an inmate said. ,"I have asked the civil surgeon for a detailed report," DM Rahul Singh said, adding that adequate steps for treatment would be taken up immediately. The DM has directed the civil surgeon to conduct tests across the rank and file of the police force.

Title: HC reinstates HIV-positive SI
article: HYDERABAD: A division bench of the Andhra Pradesh High Court comprising Justice J Chalameswar and Justice Ramesh Ranganathan on Thursday directed the police department to reinstate an HIV-positive trainee cadet sub-inspector.,The court also quashed Rule 17(3) of the Andhra Pradesh Police Manual which debars HIV-positive persons from joining the police department. ,The court declared the rule as ultra vires and violative of fundamental rights guaranteed by the Constitution .,The court was dealing with a writ petition, questioning the decision of the State Level Police Recruitment Board (SLPRB) in disqualifying an HIV-positive person from joining government service. ,Terming the order as inhuman and without justification, the court directed that the petitioner be employed if he satisfies other critical criteria.,The petitioner, whose name is being withheld to protect his identity, had earlier moved the AP Administrative Tribunal contending that he was selected as a cadet sub-inspector on stipend from the Warangal zone, but was denied the post on the ground that he had tested HIV-positive.

Title: 21 pregnant women tested HIV+ve in 10 days
article: PATNA: Twenty-one pregnant women were tested HIV +ve in only 10 days duration during a mobile campaign organised by the Bihar State AIDS Control Society.,The society had organised a "Prevention of parent to child transmission" mobile van campaign to ensure the best of the services in terms of prevention and control of HIV/AIDS from the parent to child. ,The 13-day campaign, which concluded on Saturday, was undertaken in all the 38 districts of the state. Out of 13,673 pregnant women, who were covered during the campaign, 9,037 pregnant women opted for counselling. ,Out of these, 21 were tested HIV/AIDS positive. Tetanus toxide injections and tablets of iron folic acid were distributed among the pregnant women during the campaign. ,The society had detected a total of 25 HIV +ve cases among pregnant women in a span of six years in Bihar, whereas 21 such cases were detected in just ten days during the just-concluded mobile campaign organised by the society. ,"The basic aim is to address the needsof the people in terms of prevention and control of HIV/AIDS," said Vishal Singh, Joint Director, Bihar State Aids Control Society.

Title: Activist 'grooms' 25 youth to take HIV test
article: PUNE: Setting an example for youngsters, 25 youths from the Gopi chawl slum in Khadki underwent HIV tests last week. Six of them are getting married soon and two of them have convinced their brides to take the test too.,The rest have married recently. The credit for starting the trend in a low-income pocket like Gopi chawl goes to young activist Fakruddin Tamboli, who exchanged HIV certificates with his bride in April last.,Interestingly, Fakruddin is himself a semi-literate parking lot operator, but has inherited his zeal from his father, Rahman Tamboli, who is a union leader.,Although TOI and news channels highlighted his story last year, Fakruddin found it difficult to convince more than five youths to go in for the HIV test before matrimony. Last week, however, he was able to convince 20 more.,"Many of these boys are uneducated, non-matriculates, working as masons, hawkers and labourers. There are Hindus, Muslims, neo-Buddhists. It was difficult convincing the more literate ones because they are more educated than me. ,I told them it is important to undergo the test to save their spouse and children from AIDS," says Tamboli.,Local NCP leader Bhushan Salve, who is celebrating his birthday on January 1, agreed to do the test and others gained in confidence. They were supported by the Yashwantrao Chavan memorial hospital, where the tests were conducted for just Rs 10 per person.,The slum-dwellers felicitated all the 25 youngsters on the occasion of Salve's birthday on Sunday.,A middle-aged man also went in for the test. Mehboob Sayyed, a graduate, who went in for an inter-community marriage with his college sweetheart recently, also got her to do the test. "I cited Fakrubhai's example," he said.,Asked about the toughest part, Fakruddin says, "Many of them ask me, 'What if I find out I am HIV-positive? I tell them not to worry for 10 to 15 years as medicines are available. And, by that time, a remedy would come by," says.

Title: Cautious clients sponsor HIV tests
article: AHMEDABAD: Imagine Julia Roberts 'Pretty Woman' brandishing an HIV-free certificate after Richard Gere solicits her. Well Sonu, a sex worker from Ahmedabad, had to do just that at the behest of her young client who wanted to take no chances. ,HIV awareness campaigns seem to have acquired a new spin. The virus may not have deterred men from sexual adventures but many are going out of their way to ensure that these are safe. ,Sex workers associated with the Sakhi Jyot Foundation in Ahmedabad recount interesting episodes with their clients. "Of 15 regular clients, there are at least three men who would insist that I get an HIV test done before booking me for the night. ,I generally don't agree to go to the laboratory myself, in which case they send a laboratory assistant home to take a blood sample. Once the reports are clear, the rendezvous is set," says Sonu. ,"I have come across a couple of men who choose the girl and the following day they have her blood tested. Once the test is negative, they pay and book the girl," says Lata, a sex-worker supplier operating from Paldi in Ahmedabad. ,Sex workers say that though the number of such men, who can spend Rs 300-500 extra for their tests is minuscule, there is a definite awareness about HIV and clients go that extra mile to ensure their safety. ,"Since most clients ask about our HIV status, we generally keep our reports handy. In fact, clients who rarely used a condom, now wear two-three together to protect themselves," says Shanta, a peer educator of the sex workers. ,In fact, sex workers also admit that sometimes they also have to counsel clients, especially the young, about the emergency dose of drugs the ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ post-exposure prophylaxis ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ that has to be started within 4-8 hours of unprotected sex and continued till 28 days. ,"There is a great deal of awareness and safe-sex practices are on the rise. Against 45,000 people we counselled in 2004, over 70,000 people were counselled till October 2005.,Besides, the number of people who came to the voluntary HIV testing centre has grown from 35,000 in 2004 to 45,000 till October 2005," says Gujarat State AIDS Control Society deputy director DM Saxena.

Title: HIV-hit to run city pharmacy
article: PUNE: In a rare initiative in the country, a pharmacy for the HIV-positive in the city, to be run by the people who are HIV-positive, was launched here on Monday by a pharmaceutical company. ,Called Taal, the pharmacy, located on Laxmi road in the Nana Peth area, will initially provide anti-retroviral (ARV) drugs for adults as well as the infected paediatric population registered with the Network of Maharashtra by People Living with HIV/AIDS (NMP+). ,It was inaugurated by Bollywood actor Nana Patekar. Established by Emcure Pharmaceuticals as part of its corporate social responsibility, its director (operations), A.K. Khanna, said Taal has been established in co-ordination with NMP+, Network of Positive People living with HIV/AIDS (INP+) and technical support from the Human Development Resource Network (a non-profit making organisation supported by the UNDP regional HIV and development programme.

Title: A tale of two HIV positive women
article: AHMEDABAD: Being diagnosed HIV+ was bad enough, but 32-year-old Seema (name changed) had to face worse - she was sexually exploited by her father-in-law for 10 days after her husband's death.,"My father-in-law told me if I wanted to stay in his house with my illness, I would have to oblige," Seema told TOI. She later refused to put up with the mental and physical abuse and shifted to a rented house with her two children. ,Life has been tough as she is expected to earn a living as well as live with the virus that constantly bogs her down with fever and other illnesses. ,If Seema's in-laws made life hell for her, the situation was quite opposite for 26-year-old Pushpa of Behrampura, whose father-in-law took it upon himself to take care of her and her child.,The tale of these two women was revealed at a training workshop on ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Homebased care of the HIV-positive' organised by Adhaar, a network of over 450 HIV+ people in Ahmedabad.,Pushpa's father-in-law, Medhaji, attended the workshop held at Jyoti Sangh, sponsored by Resource Centre for Sexual Health and HIV-AIDS with technical help of Saral, a city-based organisation.,"I am lucky as my father-in-law even accompanies me to the doctor when I am ill. Even my sisters-in-law help me with household chores when I am down with some illness," says Pushpa.,Cases like Pushpa's, say HIV activists, are few and far between as most of the infected people are discriminated against within their families. "There are many families who simply throw out the HIV+ member, fearing stigma. ,Families who accept them tend to discriminate by not allowing the HIV+ member of the family to cook, use water from the pot, wash clothes or even play with the kids, fearing infection," says Varsha, president of Adhaar who is also HIV+.,Varsha said many HIV+ people are being helped by organisations like Dardi Seva Trust who sponsor children's fee and food. ,The aim of the home-based care training workshop is to sensitise family members about the HIV virus, issues related to safety and hygiene levels that need to be maintained in a house with a HIV patient.

Title: Man behind bars for hiding HIV-positive status from spouse
article: SURAT: In the first case of its kind in the state, a man got arrested on Monday for concealing his HIV-positive status from his wife, who filed a complaint at a police station here on Saturday night. ,Lata Kantharia, in her mid-twenties, walked into Rander police station to register a complaint against her husband. ,Lataï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s complaint was that her husband had not disclosed his HIV+ve status to her before marriage. ,The police arrested Lataï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s husband and his sister under IPC sections 269 and 270 which classifies the offence as 'Negligent act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life'. ,"The husband is in possession of reports that proves that he was HIV-positive before he married Lata. ,It is on this basis that we have arrested both of them," says Rander inspector RS Patel. ,Lata married her husband in May 2002 after he divorced his first wife. ,However, it was when Lata was eight months pregnant in October 2003 that the gynaecologist revealed that she was HIV-positive during a routine check-up. ,Her kid, who is two years old now, is feared to have contracted the virus. Lataï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s problem did not end here. ,According to her complaint, she was asked to leave the house. ,It was then that she approached an NGO, Garima, for help. ,Human rights and social justice department deputy inspector general Meera Varma says in cases where the wife alleges that she contracted the virus through her husband, the burden of proof lies on the husband.

Title: Alang migrant workers unleash HIV crisis
article: ALANG: Long separation from the family, pathetic working conditions in ship-breaking and recycling yards and comparatively good money are prompting the large population of migrant workers to go to sex workers and thereby increase the risk of contracting HIV infections.,This necklace-shaped shipbreaking yard on the western flank of Gulf of Cambay is a home to thousands of migrants from Madhya Pradesh, Orissa, Uttar Pradesh, Bihar and Jharkhand.,"The migrant workers who live in the ship-breaking yards of Alang and Sosiya, exhibit inclination to visit sex workers and thereby increase the risk of contracting HIV infections," said Dr Niloo Vaishnav, chairman of Bhavnagar blood bank.,"We conducted HIV sero survey of migrant workers of Alang ship breaking yards from July 2004 to September, by taking samples of 2155 people. The results indicated that 0.7 per cent of the people tested HIV positive," he said.,Vaishnav said, though the result is not alarming, what is a matter of concern is their highrisk behaviour. If the number of HIV infections is less, it is only because the sex workers whom they are visiting may not be having the infection. ,But, their behaviour is definitely a matter of concern and hence, we are creating awareness among the workers," he added.,The study was conducted under the auspices of Project AIDS, Bhavnagar blood bank, which has been engaged in AIDS education and prevention work in Alang for over 10 years, focusing on reducing high-risk behaviour among the workers, Vaishnav said. ,"As with other migrant work force, the HIV sero status of the Alang population was of special interest," he added.

Title: BEST model for HIV positive staff
article: MUMBAI: Organisations grappling with the problem of discrimination against employees suffering from AIDS could take a leaf out of the BEST book. ,With nearly 150 of its staffers testing positive for HIV, the mammoth public utility system is adopting new modes of treatment, counselling and humane work practices to cope with the problem.,Maharashtra is among the states hardest hit by AIDS: some 23 per cent of the country's estimated 4.5 million HIV-positive patients live here. A concerned BEST management is slowly coming to terms with its liability, in terms of loss of manpower and efficiency. ,Ever since BEST announced the ILO-approved HIV/AIDS workplace intervention policy two years ago for its 43,000-strong workforce, an increasing number of people have taken part in the voluntary counselling and testing programme.,Although BEST is tight-lipped about the number of HIV/AIDS-affected people on its staff, the estimates were obtained by studying the number of people who are availing of Anti-Retroviral Therapy (ART) medicine given free of cost by the organisation.,For HIV patients like Suresh, a 43-year-old senior BEST employee, the free treatment and counselling programme has provided a new lease of life. ,Suresh was shattered when he tested positive a few months ago, and had decided to put in his papers and go back to his native village at Malvan. ,But after attending the counselling and treatment programme initiated by a team of BEST doctors, Suresh has now decided to stay on. He is back at work and leads a normal healthy life.,BEST officials said the programme initially did not evoke a good response as employees feared being identified as HIV-positive, but soon they came around to realise that they could lead a healthier life if they knew what was in store for them. ,"We tell them that their HIV status will remain confidential and at no point of time will it be revealed to anyone. They are allowed to function and work like any normal person in the organisation," said Omprakash Ahuja, chief medical officer, BEST.,BEST has also given fully paid medical leave up to six months one-time for full-blown AIDS patients. This is done in order to help them recover from debilitating infections, which they become susceptible to on account of weaknesses in the immunity system. ,"In many cases, patients are referred to municipal hospitals to recover from tuberculosis or other immuno deficient diseases," said Ahuja.,The mode of treatment includes counselling family members of patients. Health workers often visit the employee's residential quarters and meet the kin to provide emotional support and guidance.,"In all cases, strict confidentiality is maintained," said Dr Anjana Palve, project co-ordinator at Mumbai Aids Control society (MDACS). ,The state-funded MDACS has targeted 25 BEST bus depots to conduct HIV counselling programmes for conductors, bus drivers and mechanics. ,"They have a peer leader who is usually a very caring person amongst the group. The victim finds it easy to confide in him about the disease," said Palve.,Patients like Suresh can also take comfort from the fact even if they succumb to the disease, the BEST now has a policy that ensures a job for their spouses. ,"Also during their tenure, there will be no discrimination for promotions or unequal treatment just because they are HIV positive," said Ahuja.

Title: Surat tops again, this time in HIV
article: SURAT: If there is one boom that is taking the sheen off the diamond city, it is the alarming spread of HIV. ,Surat has the highest prevalence of HIV in Gujarat among female sex workers (FSW) and gay men (MSM) according to a recent sentinel surveillance of HIV and sexually transmitted diseases (STD) carried out by six NGO partners and Gujarat State Aids Control Society (GSACS). ,It has pointed out that Surat is highly vulnerable as 13.20 per cent of female sex workers have been infected with HIV, while among gay men, it is 15.60 per cent. ,In fact, GSACS calls it a "concentrated epidemic" as even five per cent HIV prevalence is considered epidemic. The prevalence rate in the general population (low risk groups) has remained static at three per cent. ,But the high-risk groups show an alarming trend. Huge migrant population in Surat is suspected to be responsible for high vulnerability, states Gujarat State Aids Control Society, which is all set to sign a memorandum of understanding with the Orissa government. ,"Once the MoU is in place, migrants from Orissa heading to Surat or Alang might find themselves being escorted by HIV peer educators. "That's not all. ,On their arrival at Surat, they will post a card bearing their local address to the nearest NGO working on HIV. This will ensure better healthcare and HIV awareness to migrants," says Dr Rajesh Gopal, additional project director, Gujarat State Aids Control Society. ,"A mapping of sexual behaviour in Surat has identified at least 2.6 lakh migrants from Orissa alone," adds Gopal. Recently, GSACS expanded the targeted intervention groups from 21 to 25, which includes migrants.

Title: Vadodara sees drop in HIV cases
article: VADODARA: Banyan City Vadodara stole a march ahead of Surat, Rajkot and Ahmedabad by containing HIV among female sex workers (FSWs) and gay men. ,A recent survey to detect HIV and STD (sexually transmitted diseases) indicates that 6.8 per cent of FSWs in Vadodara were infected with HIV compared to last year's 9.2 per cent, while only four per cent of gay men (men having sex with men - MSM) were HIV positive against last year's 6.80 per cent. ,However, the number of STD cases have increased or remained stable. The screening was carried out by the Gujarat State Aids Control Society (GSACS) through its six NGO partners ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Vikas Jyot Trust, Paras PSM, Lifeline Health and Lakshya Trust (Vadodara, Surat and Rajkot centres). ,Says additional project director of GSACS Dr Rajesh Gopal, "Through STD clinics, we arrive at definite indicators of HIV prevalence in vulnerable groups like FSW and MSM. ,The general population reports low prevalence rates, which could build complacency. Hence, we conduct such surveys." ,The saving grace for Vadodara is its homogenous population as it does not attract migrants like in Surat, say NGOs. Moreover, the city started its HIV intervention early ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ about five years back. ,"Unlike Surat and Ahmedabad, which have a huge number of migrants and visitors, Vadodara has a stable population that has made intervention easier. ,We also have many NGOs reaching out to different target groups ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ commercial sex workers, gay men, taxi and auto drivers, industrial workers ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ which covers all those at risk," says Sylvester Merchant of Lakshya Trust, Vadodara. ,"MSMs need intervention at multiple levels ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ promooting use of condoms, giving access to STD care and providing an enabling environment as patients are often reluctant to approach any hospital or organisation for fear of harassment," Merchant adds. ,Kamlesh Bhatt of Vikas Jyot Trust seconds the fact. "Our sensitisation programmes, for all the contact groups like police and lawyers, have helped in creating an enabling environment to address the issues of HIV." ,"In the last five years, FSWs have become more organised. The use of condoms has increased. Earlier, FSWs used condoms five out of 10 encounters. But now, the adherence is up to seven. ,FSWs are not only educating their clients on safe sex and prevention of HIV and STD, but availing of healthcare services offered by our mobile clinics," Bhatt adds "STD prevalence is high compared to last year as there are many new members volunteering for the survey. ,Moreover, STD care and treatment needs more focus as we are dealing with people with high risk behaviour," Merchant says.
