Title: China starts human trials of new anti-HIV drug
article: BEIJING: Chinese military scientists have started testing a new combined anti-HIV and Hepatitis B drug on humans after successfully extracting a chemical compound from a local herb, the state media reported on Wednesday.,Extracted from Inula britannic, the compound, 1,5-di-O-caffeoylquinic acid (1,5-DCQA), has proved to be able to work on HIV or HBV (hepatitis B virus) in a way different from current medicines, a leading scientist with the Academy of Military Medical Sciences, Dong Junxing said.,"If clinical experiments back up initial findings, the compound will be an irreversible HIV and HBV integrase inhibitor, which provides a new alternative for AIDS and hepatitis B treatment," Dong was quoted as saying by 'China Daily'.,Dong and his team started research in 1993 with filtering effective anti-HBV constituents from more than 100 kinds of Chinese herbs. Two years later, they began to experiment on ducks and monkeys.,The research team has begun a six-month clinical research on about 200 healthy volunteers. "If it goes smoothly, a new medicine will be on the market in two years," he said.,"We will try a combined prescription of the new drug and current medicines to see whether it can have better efficacy," he said.,The price of the new drug may be much lower than any other one now available, Dong said, because they can synthesise the constituent chemically instead of extracting it from herbs.

Title: Positive news for HIV
article: Cancer and HIV treatment will now become less crippling for the common man. The budget proposes to slash customs duty on 10 anti-HIV and 14 anti-cancer drugs and kits from 15% to 5%. ,These life savers will now be exempt from excise duty and countervailing duty, greatly helping the afflicted middle and lower classes.,The budget also has good news for the poorest. PC announced a funding hike for the National Rural Health Mission to Rs 8,142 crore in the next fiscal from Rs 6,075 crore. This will help set up 1,000 block level community centres to provide medicare to the most backward villages.,The total allocation to health ministry has also been increased from Rs 9,676 crore to Rs 12,546 crore. Funding for the National Aids Control Programme has been raised from Rs 476 crore to Rs 636 crore. ,More money will also be spent on routine immunisation programme and reproductive and child health care programme. From Rs 155 crore allotted last year, the allocation for immunisation is up to Rs 326 crore.,Government wants to eradicate polio by 2007 and has allotted Rs 1,004 crore for the project against last year's Rs 806 crore.

Title: HIV positive woman heads NGO's community kitchen
article: PUNE: She is just another 30-year-old working woman. With her business-like approach, giving orders to subordinates to meet deadlines, no one would ever think she is HIV positive.,Today she heads the community kitchen of an NGO, that prepares about 150 'dibbas' (lunch-boxes) for the sex workers.,A former sex-worker, Ruby is "reliving life on her own terms and conditions". She is aware of her HIV status but this does not dampen her spirits.,"I have been living a healthy life so far. I just take multi-vitamins, eat healthy, nutritious food and try to remain happy," she says.,When she was 16, Ruby was sold to a brothel in Budhwar Peth, red light district of Pune, instead of being married off as promised by her cousin.,Left with little choice, she worked there when one day the hospital authorities diagnosed her and her daughter as HIV positive.,Thanks to a local NGO, she underwent training on 'How to Live with AIDS' in Geneva and Philippines and "picked up the pieces of her life" and is busy in her community kitchen.,"We charge the food less than the hotels. Apart from that we give free meals to about 18 women everyday, ten of whom are inflicted with HIV," says Ruby whose daughter is currently living in Mumbai.,Ruby's is not the only case of sex workers braving odds.,Yashodhra and Sulochana left the world's oldest profession once they adopted the role of 'peer-educators' with an NGO. ,"I was only 13 when my husband dumped me here 30 years ago. But I left it all when I decided to work for the AIDS campaign. I don't earn much but at least I have mental strength now," says 45-year-old Yashodhra.,They now try and do their own bit in spreading awareness about HIV/AIDS among fellow sex-workers.,"We tell them how grave this disease is. We inform them about methods of prevention from it. We ask them to use protection for not just their clients but also their regular partners, which they tend to avoid. We also give them lessons on personal hygiene," says Yashodhra, who feels "more empowered" than she ever was.,"They are true women of substance. Today they feel they have more control over their health, attitudes and lives. They are leading exemplary lives trying to work under adverse circumstances where everything and everyone is pitted against them," say Michele Andina, Project Director of NGO Pathfinder International, that is working to reduce the prevalence of AIDS among sex workers.

Title: UN envoy calls for womens' agency to fight HIV
article: UNITED NATIONS: The UN special envoy for HIV/AIDS in Africa has voiced the need to set up an international womens' agency to deal with gender discrimination that has resulted in rapid spread of the pandemic in the continent.,Briefing reporters on Friday on his trip last month to Lesotho and Swaziland, Stephen Lewis, UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan's Special Envoy for HIV/AIDS in Africa, said it was "impossible to traverse the continent of Africa without an enveloping sense of horror and despair at the carnage amongst women.","Lesotho and Swaziland are but symbols for the greater whole that we are losing millions of young women in Africa. In the process, we are creating a generation of orphans whose lives are lives of torment," he said.,..."If there was a powerful international force for women, we would not be in this galling predicament," Lewis said.,He called for an agency on the scale of the UN Children's Fund (UNICEF), arguing that while the current agencies dealing with women's affairs including the UN Development Fund for Women (UNIFEM) and the UN Population Fund (UNFPA) are performing well, a larger organisation is needed.,Lewis pointed out that the recent appointment of a 15-person high-level panel examining the issues of development, humanitarian assistance and the environment has only two female members.,Decrying this ratio, he urged efforts to expand the panel's membership, and to have "absolute transparency in its proceedings," adding that it must also be open for submissions from women's groups.

Title: Goa diktat: Take HIV test before tying nuptial knot
article: NEW DELHI: Goa's plans to make an HIV test mandatory for registration of marriages are likely to generate considerable controversy as they have already attracted the ire of health experts, legal luminaries and human rights groups.,Goa's health ministry is looking to amend the Goa Public Health Act so that HIV testing can be facilitates for couples seeking to marry. ,The state cabinet has already given a green signal and health minister Dayanand Narvekar will move the amendment when the assembly meets in July.,Till then, the government has thrown open this amendment for "public debate". There is an option - that if either of the spouse is willing - the test need not be carried out. ,But this is not cutting much ice with those protesting the move.The decision has in vited strong protests from activists and lawyers. ,Senior advocate Colin Gonzalves told TOI "any mandatory testing is wrong. Couples should rather be counselled and educated. If they want to get a testing done by choice after that, its their business. But a mandatory test can't be imposed on them.",According to advocate Aparna Bhat, "Mandatory testing is a violation of human rights. Its similar to forced testing and is discriminatory." Speaking to TOI from Mumbai, Narvekar said he would welcome suggestions from NGOs and individuals.,"Goa has a common civil code. So all marriages have to be registered irrespective of caste and religion. ,Now, we want all couples to marry with an HIV-negative certificate in hand. Cases have come up in Goa where women have found, after their marriage, that their husband is HIV positive or vice versa.",By that time, both partners have been infected, the minister claimed. "This rule is on the lines of a similar clause in the GPHA in the 1900s, whereby small pox vaccination was compulsory for couples before they married," he said.

Title: Should HIV testing be mandatory before marriage? No
article: Jhanavi Goswami, VP, Network of People Living with HIV,Any kind of mandatory testing is wrong. It is a violation of human rights. It's almost similar to forced testing, and is discriminatory in nature. How can the government even think of making HIV testing mandatory before marriage? ,Do we have the required infrastructure? In a country where its villages and small towns don't even have decent hospitals and laboratories, how does the government expect the people to get themselves tested for HIV? ,Even the expenditure involved, Rs 5,000, for testing, is very high. How can young couples, especially poor people, afford it?,Besides, there is no proper code of conduct for carrying out these tests. For a little money, negative reports can be purchased, and that will defeat the whole purpose of eliminating Aids. First, the government has to ensure that there isn't any tampering with the reports and only then think of going ahead with such a step. ,Unfortunately, we are years away from such a reality. It may seem ironical that being HIV-positive, I am so strongly advocating against making the test mandatory. ,But after having gone through it, I now know the real picture. And under no circumstance will I ever ask for it to be made mandatory. At the age of 16, when I was still in Class X, I was married to a businessman. ,Only after the marriage, did I get to know that he was HIV-positive. I was completely unaware of the consequences and the gravity of the situation. ,When he died in 1994, the year we got married, I was already infected and so was my unborn child. My daughter passed away soon after. My in-laws put pressure on me to leave and I went back to live with my parents. ,Today, I am a counsellor with the AIDS Control Society in Assam. And everyday, I meet women who have a similar story like mine. But that hasn't changed my opinion ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ I don't want the test to become mandatory.,Instead, I feel the government should consider making HIV counselling mandatory. To-be-married couples should be encouraged to go in for pre-marital counselling on Aids. ,The government can run awareness programmes whereby the entire community is involved. In fact, all religious leaders should involve themselves in counselling a couple. After all, more people are bound to listen to a religious leader. ,This will be the best way to make people aware and prevent Aids from spreading. Making testing mandatory will never solve the problem. Let's try to remove the problem from its roots.,(Jhanavi Goswami is HIV-positive) ,As told to Kounteya Sinha

Title: Should HIV testing be mandatory before marriage? Yes
article: Dayanand Narvekar, Health Minister, Goa,Mandatory testing of couples planning to tie the knot is the only way we can stall the menace of HIV from spreading in India. Every day, we get new cases of women who test HIV-positive just months after their wedding, thanks to an HIV-positive husband who passes on the disease to the hapless wife. ,Nearly 40% of HIV-positive people in India are women. What is their fault? Even today, arranged marriage is most common in the country. ,A woman is seldom asked about her opinion. It's only after marriage, when she is infected and the damage is done that she finds out about her husband's illness.,The predominance of arranged marriages means that most wives and husbands come together as virtual strangers. As such, there is no communication between them and hence, the woman can never know if her husband is infected. ,So, mandatory testing of couples for HIV will be the only way to stop such rising incidences. Therefore, we decided to make a HIV test mandatory for registration of marriages. ,We are amending the Goa Public Health Act for this reason. While the state cabinet has already shown its green signal, we will put the amendment before the state legislative assembly in July. Goa has a Common Civil Code. ,So, all marriages have to be registered irrespective of caste and religion. It will be easy to implement the mandatory testing plan. All couples will now be allowed to marry once they have the HIV-negative certificate in hand. ,The compulsory test rule is on the lines of a similar clause in the Goa Public Health Act in the 1900s, whereby small pox vaccination was compulsory for couples before they married. If the amendment comes through, Goa would be the first state in the country to have mandatory HIV test before marriage. ,In 1986, Goa had amended the Public Health Act, allowing health authorities to forcibly test anyone suspected of Aids. After this amendment, a certain Dominic D Souza was detained and quarantined for the first time in Goa. The Goa bench of Bombay High Court released him but upheld the legislation. ,The order clearly states that the couples cannot register their marriage unless they produce a certificate issued by the Goa Medical College or the directorate of health services or such other authority. ,The certificate has to clear that their blood samples have been investigated or tested at laboratories, centres, etc notified for the purpose. ,This way, we are certain, we can fight this deadly menace called Aids.,As told to Kounteya Sinha

Title: Breastfeeding: Precautions can save kids from HIV
article: CHANDIGARH: Breastfeeding is considered to be important for the health of a new-born, but some unfortunate mothers have to bear the trauma of denying this to their babies. The worst devastated are lactating mothers suffering from AIDS whose only hope for themselves lies in their kids.,For this it is important that they do not breastfeed their children and administer them anti retro-viral drugs regularly. ,Meeta is one such woman who has been lucky that her son, who is now one-and-a-half-year-old, has been spared by the deadly disease. Her only concern in life is to keep her son away from the disease. "That is why I named him Ayushman (the one who has a long life)," Meeta says. ,Dr Avinash Jolly, coordinator, AIDS hotline, Chandigarh, says, "Research shows that avoiding breastfeeding does bring down the risk of HIV in children considerably. But this fact was not well propagated among HIV infected women here." ,He revealed that around 20% children get infected by the disease during pregnancy, 50% during delivery and 33% through breast feeding. ,Meeta claims she got infected through her husband who was HIV positive. Asked whether she knew about her husband's ailment, she said, "I wasn't informed about this. ,It was an arranged marriage and I come to know about it only after I got pregnant.",Similarly, Vidya, also an HIV positive, says, "Two of my children are HIV positive and one has been confirmed negative." ,The third one was saved due to the precautions she took after realising that she was an AIDS patient.,Sonia Trikha, project director, State AIDS Control Committee, said that there are about 59 positive and lactating women registered with them under the 'prevention from parent to child transmission programme' (PCTCT) programme. ,"They are counselled here and made aware about how to ensure that the child is not affected through breastfeeding. ,Women are now increasingly becoming aware about the programme an we are already getting results," she said.

Title: Here, marriages are made after HIV test
article: SURAT: Looking at horoscopes of prospective brides or grooms, as the case may be, is passï¿½ï¿½ in Surat where those keen on matrimonial alliances are more bothered about verifying the HIV status of their would-be marriage partners. ,This trend is more discernible among youngsters. And the level of awareness about HIV and AIDS has gone up with Surat having the highest number of non-government organisations in the state working in this field. ,Seema Shah, 26, living in Athwalines and a freelance interior designer says, "Youngsters today are not very much concerned with matching horoscopes. ,Rather, the mental and physical wellbeing of their prospective partners is more important." Bhumi Desai, 24, a resident of Ghod Dod road, says, "I would prefer to get married to a person who gets his HIV test done before marriage." ,And nobody would like to get cheated by their partners when it comes to HIV test. If anybody is then he or she would not be averse to taking action. ,Recently, a complaint was filed at Rander police station concerning the hidden HIV status of a life partner. It is not just youngsters who are bothered. ,Parents of children of marriageable age are also keen to ascertain the HIV status of the bride and groom. Ami Patel, a resident of Parle Point and mother of a 23-year-old daughter, says, "There is a pressing need to get an HIV test done of prospective life partners." ,Janki Desai, a resident of Adajan and mother of a 25-yearold son, says, "Getting an HIV test done of prospective life partners, if made mandatory, could save everyone concerned from a lot of trouble and embarrassment." ,However, not all are in favour of making the test mandatory. Dr Vibha Marfatia, director at Sahas, an NGO working for HIV and AIDS awareness, says, "Undergoing an HIV test before marriage may not be able to present a true picture of the HIV status of a person, as he may be in the window period then. Voluntary counselling and testing would be a better option."

Title: When marriages are made after HIV test
article: SURAT: Looking at horoscopes of prospective brides or grooms, as the case may be, is passï¿½ï¿½ in Surat where those keen on matrimonial alliances are more bothered about verifying the HIV status of their would-be marriage partners. It is not just youngsters who are bothered. ,Parents of children of marriageable age are also keen to ascertain the HIV status of the bride and groom. Ami Patel, a resident of Parle Point and mother of a 23-year-old daughter, says, "There is a pressing need to get an HIV test done of prospective life partners." ,Janki Desai, a resident of Adajan and mother of a 25-yearold son, says, "Getting an HIV test done of prospective life partners, if made mandatory, could save everyone concerned from a lot of trouble and embarrassment." ,However, not all are in favour of making the test mandatory. Dr Vibha Marfatia, director at Sahas, an NGO working for HIV and AIDS awareness, says, "Undergoing an HIV test before marriage may not be able to present a true picture of the HIV status of a person, as he may be in the window period then. Voluntary counselling and testing would be a better option."

Title: Study rings HIV alarm for Kolkata
article: KOLKATA: The alarm bells are ringing loud. The HIV virus has hit Kolkata hard. A first-of-its-kind crosssectional statewide survey carried out among highrisk groups has come as a rude shock. ,Overturning the commonly held perception of West Bengal being a low HIV prevalence state, a survey by the National Institute of Cholera and Enteric Diseases (NICED) says Kolkata is all set to acquire the features of a high HIV prevalence area.,Worse, West Bengal is now in the the league of medium HIV prevalent states with Darjeeling having the highest HIV prevalence rate of 15.6%, says the study. Comparatively, Kolkata is better off at 9.6%. The report has been forwarded to National Aids Control Organisation (Naco), WHO and the state government as well.,Assistant director of NICED's epidemiology division, Dr Kamalesh Sarkar,-- who headed the survey-- said, "The findings are extremely disturbing. Bengal has long been considered a low HIV prevalent state.,However, figures show that we have already entered the medium prevalence zone with a prevalence of 5.6%. Kolkata stands at the threshold of high-prevalence zone. If proper targeted intervention projects are not implemented, HIV will assume enormous proportions.",The number of HIV positive persons per 100 in the high-risk group (read sex workers) in a particular year forms the base for calculation of HIV prevalence rate according to NACO guidelines. ,If the count is less than five, then a particular area is classified as a low prevalence zone, whereas, if it is more than five but less than 10, it is categorised as a medium prevalence zone. A prevalence rate of 10% or more puts an area in the high HIV prevalence group.,Nineteen districts were initially categorised into high, medium and low prevalent districts based on the estimated number of sex workers in each district.,While Kolkata and Darjeeling were chosen from among the high prevalent districts, East Midnapore and North 24-Parganas were chosen to represent medium prevalence zones. Murshidabad and Purulia were chosen as low prevalent districts.Over 11% sex workers tested positive for venereal diseases.

Title: HIV-positive men can father healthy kids
article: NEW DELHI: HIV-positive men in India could soon father children without infecting their wives or children. Indian scientists will soon visit the Centre for Disease Control in Atlanta to learn the latest sperm-washing treatment, in which individual sperms are removed from the semen of an HIV-positive man and then used on his wife through artificial insemination.,This way, the sperms are rid of HIV. This treatment ensures that an uninfected woman can have a healthy baby without having unprotected sex with her HIV-positive husband. Still not available in India, this treatment is becoming popular in Europe.,Speaking to TOI, AIDS scientist Suniti Solomon, who is also director of the Y R G Centre for Aids Research and Foundation, said: "Even if they are married to HIV positive husbands, women across the globe still want to be mothers. ,Sperm-Washing treatment is a great new technique that can fulfil this desire without risking the woman's life. In this procedure, the semen of an HIV-positive man is taken, centrifuged in different gradients, removing the virus and then introduced into the woman's body. The woman then conceives without picking up the virus.",She added: "Nobody in India is well versed with this technique. So we are sending a team of scientists to Atlanta to learn it. The faster we start this technique, the more lives we can save. ,At present, 20 lakh women are HIV-positive because their husbands were infected and didn't wear a condom. No instances have been found where HIV was present in the sperm sample following the washing treatment.",Saying that over 5,000 couples in Italy and kGermany have successfully tried this technique, renowned American AIDS specialist Kenneth Mayer had a word of caution. ,He told TOI: "There is always a risk that the semen can remain infected in minute form even after washing. That way, the woman can get infected too resulting in bitter legal battles. This is why the technique hasn't caught on in US as much.",He added: "Not all gynaecologists in India will be able to carry out the technique. It will therefore be a very expensive procedure. However, if this sperm-purification technique is mastered by Indian doctors, a huge number of women will benefit from it.

Title: HIV cases in India rise to 5.2 million
article: NEW DELHI: The number of people living with HIV/AIDS in India has increased. The latest figures compiled by National AIDS Control Organisation (NACO), using improved data collection strategy, has shown that an estimated 5.21 million adults in India are living with HIV.,The previous figures, compiled in 2004, had shown that India had 5.13 million people infected by the deadly virus. Of the estimated adults living with HIV in India, over 38% are females and 57% are of rural background. ,Besides, 90% of the infected people do not know that they are carrying the infection. "According to the latest figures available with us, 5.206 million people are HIV infected. ,The adult prevalence is still less than 1% ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ at 0.91% in the country," K Sujatha Rao, director-general of NACO, said on Sunday.,This has made NACO decide to increase the number of centres that assess the spread of HIV/AIDS virus in the country. The number of detection centres will be increased to 1,150 from 750 at present. ,The proposed additional centres will come up primarily in Bihar, UP, Chhattisgarh, Rajasthan, Orissa, MP and Jharkhand, considered to be highly vulnerable.,"We are planning the additional centres to create an accurate system to gauge the number of people affected by HIV/AIDS and also ensure 100% coverage. The next five years will be crucial for India's AIDS control programme. ,We are currently where South Africa was in 1990. But the country had then not bothered about preventive measures. That's why now, almost 30% of the population there is HIV positive," Rao said.,He added: "Tamil Nadu, Andhra Pradesh, Karnataka, Manipur, Nagaland and Maharashtra are among the most affected states in the country. However, there is some goods news from Tamil Nadu as the spread of virus has been curtailed to some extent. ,The trend in this state is going down but we would not like to believe that the problem is over." According to NACO, prevalence of HIV among ante-natal clinic attendees fell below 1% in Tamil Nadu. ,However, HIV prevalence among STD patients has increased substantially over the previous year in Delhi, Rajasthan and Orissa. ,HIV prevalence was greater than 1% among antenatal mothers in 95 districts including nine in the low prevalence states. HIV prevalence was greater than 10% in 34 STD sites across the country.

Title: HIV infected persons enter into wedlock
article: PALAKKAD: An HIV infected man and woman got married at a function organised by the Muthalamada Senham Charitable Trust on Thursday.,The wedding ceremony of Parameswaran (35) and Pushpalatha (30) was solemnized by the Guruvayour Temple Thanthri Chenos PC Dineshan.,This is the second marriage of HIV infected persons organised by the Trust, V Sunildas, secretary of the Trust said in a press release.

Title: No entry for HIV+ men in AP police force
article: HYDERABAD: Men tested HIV positive cannot join the police force in Andhra Pradesh. Nor are those with decayed teeth or stammer can make an entry.,This is as per a new GO. According to it, apart from the physically handicapped, those with knockknees, pigeon chest and flatfoot are also not eligible to join the police force.,Candidates with varicose veins, hammer toes, fractured limbs, those hard of hearing and abnormal psychological behaviour also do not stand a chance.,Sub-inspector aspirants will have to take revised pattern of test to get into the police department from the next ,recruitment.,Aspirants have to take a descriptive test both in English and Telugu each for 100 marks in the recruitment process. This is apart from objective type examinations in arithmetic, reasoning-mental ability (paper III) and general studies (paper IV) each for 200 marks.,Candidates, who do not secure minimum marks in descriptive examinations, will not be considered for further selection process irrespective of the performance in objective tests. ,The minimum qualifying marks is 40 per cent for OCs, 35 per cent for BCs and 30 per cent for SC, ST and ex-servicemen.,The home department has issued orders on the changes in the recruitment of sub-inspectors and constables recently. ,The police department wants to fill up 600 sub-inspectors and about 7,000 constable vacancies by the end of this year. A notification to fill up the vacancies is expected to be issued very soon.,The changes have been made after Andhra Pradesh Police Academy, which trains sub-inspectors and constables, expressed unhappiness over the writing skills of the candidates both in English and Telugu.,"The descriptive tests in English and Telugu have been introduced as SIs are supposed to write reports like case diary, chargesheets and statements, for which they need writing skills in both the languages,"P Gowatham Kumar, Chairman State Level Police Recruitment Board told TOI. ,For constables, the minimum education qualification has been made Intermediate for OC candidates while SC/ST candidates should appear for Intermediate examinations and should possess SSC. ,Aspirants for civil constables will have to take a written examination in objective for 200 marks and for armed reserve category the written examinations will be for 100 marks.,Fifty per cent of the sub-inspector vacancies in civil category will be filled by direct recruitment and 30 per cent through elevation of head constables and assistant sub-inspector and five per cent will be allowed from armed reserve and APSP on transfer. The new GO said aspirants for civil SIs should be between 21 and 25 years.

Title: New law to fight HIV discrimination
article: NEW DELHI: The Centre is set to bring in a comprehensive legislation to prevent discrimination against HIV-positive persons in all spheres of public life, including the private sector.,Drafted by the Union health ministry in consultation with experts and affected persons, the proposed HIV/AIDS Bill 2006 ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ to be introduced in the Monsoon session of Parliament ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ is the first specific legal measure to prohibit discrimination against HIV-positive persons, especially in jobs, education, healthcare, travel and insurance.,Though India has a national AIDS prevention and control policy, it does not have the status of law and is not enforceable in court. For instance, a person claiming to have lost her job because she is HIV-positive cannot necessarily seek redress in court on the basis of the policy.,"The Bill aims to address several gaps in the existing laws and policies," health secretary P K Hota said.,"The most important are the anti-discrimination provisions which will apply to the private sector also."

Title: India set to undertake study on HIV resistance
article: NEW DELHI: Fearing that the Indian strain of the deadly HIV virus is fast becoming resistant to anti-retroviral drugs â€” the only effective way to treat HIV â€” India is undertaking south Asia's largest multi-centre study to ascertain the type and extent of resistance.,To be financed by National AIDS Control Organisation, the pilot study on drug resistance, surveillance and monitoring, to be conducted in East Godavari region of AP, Tambram hospital in Chennai and J J Hospital in Mumbai will alone cost nearly Rs 1 crore.,The samples collected from various study sites will be tested in the National Aids Research Institute, Pune. Three other regional laboratories in AIIMS, Delhi, PRC, Chennai, and NICED, Kolkata, are also being accredited to carry out similar tests in the future.,Data coming out of the tests will be sent to the National Institute of Medical Statistics which will analyse it against the WHO guidelines of drug resistance.,The data will then be placed before a 12-member National Committee for HIV Drug Resistance, that will make the final analysis. Formed in March 2006, the committee includes four officials from NACO, two microbiologists, epidemiologists, two statisticians and two clinicians.,According to health minister A Ramadoss, the committee will have large scale data on the extent of drug resistance that the Indian Aids virus has developed by August 2007.,India at present uses three drug regimens under the anti-retroviral therapy (ART) programme. Two drugs among these three â€” Stavudine, Lamivudine and Nevirapine â€” are given in combination to decrease resistance among HIV positive patients. The drugs destroy the virus from different sides.,Resistance to these drugs would mean that the first line of drugs are failing to contain the infection and NACO has to immediately start second line alternatives, which are still not available under the government's Aids control programme and will have to be purchased, increasing cost of HIV treatment in India.,Speaking to TOI, officials in NACO said: "The study will be done on two types of patients. The first will be on those who are HIV positive. ,They will be given ART and 12 to 15 months from administering of the drug, they will be accessed. We will see whether the patient put on therapy is responding or not and what is the outcome.,"The second category will be in prevention of mother to child transmission sites. We will target women who come with first time pregnancy below the age of 25. If they test positive for HIV, we will enrol them for the study. ,They should not have been on ART before and should be sensitive to drug therapy. We will need 70 HIV positive women to get at least 47 samples. Not all samples are fit for testing. ,They die due to improper handling while being transferred from site office to the lab. From good samples can we get multiple copies needed for its genotyping. This will help us to ascertain the type of virus we are combating," officials added.

Title: India has the highest HIV+ population
article: NEW DELHI: India now has the highest number of people living with HIV. According to the 2006 Report on Global AIDS Epidemic â€” released on Tuesday in Geneva, India had 5.7 million cases of HIV by the end of 2005, against 5.5 million in South Africa. ,Most infections have been caused by unprotected heterosexual intercourse. Accounting for two-thirds of HIV cases in Asia, estimates of total deaths in India â€” since AIDS was first identified in 1981 â€” range from 270,000 to 680,000. ,The UN agency also estimated that only 7% of Indians who needed antiretroviral drug therapy actually received it last year while only 1.6% of pregnant women who needed treatment to prevent mother-to-child HIV transmission were receiving it. ,UNAIDS India chief Dr Dennis Broun told TOI from New York: "India's National Aids Control Organisation says the country has 5.2 million cases of HIV aged between 15 and 49 years". ,However for the first time, UNAIDS has tried to reach estimates on the basis of cradle to grave. That shows India has more people living with HIV than South Africa. India's ART treatment rate is also dismal.

Title: 50% prostitutes in Tamil Nadu HIV+: UNAIDS
article: NEW DELHI: "States like Tamil Nadu, Maharashtra, Andhra Pradesh and Karnataka have the highest prevalence of HIV in India," says UNAIDS India chief Dr Dennis Broun. A study of prostitutes in Tamil Nadu found 50% of them had been infected with HIV. ,For the first time, NACO also admits that the figures could be correct. A senior NACO official said, "India does have 5.7 million cases if all age groups are considered. But we also have to take into account India's population. The South African model isn't even comparable.",The report says 18.8% of South African adults were living with HIV. The corresponding figure in India was 0.9%. ,Released a day before the UN General Assembly on AIDS kicks off in New York where NACO DG Sujatha Rao is representing India, the report revealed some interesting figures. To date, around 65 million people have been infected with HIV. ,AIDS has killed more than 25 million since it was first recognised in 1981. The vast majority of 38.6 million people living with HIV in 2005 were unaware of their status.

Title: HIV positive to support newly infected
article: LUCKNOW: For the first time in UP, HIV positive people, who have successfully overcome the mental agony which comes with the virus, will now be working as peer counsellors for those who are latest to have joined the group and consider themselves doomed.,The initiative has been taken by the Anti Retroviral Therapy (ART) centre of the King George's Medical University (KGMU) on the recommendation of the National AIDS Control Organisation (NACO). ,As per the proposal, the KGMU will engage HIV positive people to work as peer educators and counsellors at its ART centre. Non government organisations (NGOs) will be asked to provide peer counsellors for the job.,Besides KGMU, there are ART centres at Meerut and Varanasi in UP, which provide free treatment to AIDS patient and HIV positive people. ,However, the KGMU ART centre will be first in the state to engage HIV positive people to help out their peers. Such experiments have been successful in southern India.,The ART centre incharge, Prof AK Tripathi, when contacted, said that while the project, on one hand would help in rehabilitation of HIV positive people. On the other hand it will provide free counselling to those who are finding it difficult to tackle life after discovering that they are carrying the virus. ,"Usually a person is taken over by acute depression on discovering that he/she has fallen prey to HIV. Situation becomes worse because of the social stigma attached to it. Such people require support and love,"he said.,Naresh Yadav, president, UP HIV Positive People Network, an organisation of HIV positive people, has readily accepted the offer and has started working on the project. ,He told TOI that he has called the board meeting of the Network to seek funding from government and NGOs for payment of some honoraria to persons who will devote time at the Centre.,Yadav believes that peer counselling will make a lot of difference. Counselling can be done by any ordinary person, but they only give the message. But when a HIV positive person will sit at the Centre, it will be a living example for other HIV positive people for leading a normal life. ,"What we want to communicate is that HIV positive people can lead a normal life, provided they take some precautions,"he said.,The counselling session will advice on adherence of treatment process, regular monitoring and check up, nutritious diet and disease management, besides other things. ,The salary support to the counsellor will give them a source of livelihood. Significantly, a government order already exists which states that HIV positive people should be given preference while making appointment as counsellors. However, it could not materialise earlier because of various reasons.

Title: NBA to distribute HIV/AIDS materials in China
article: NEW YORK: The National Basketball Association of the US has teamed up with the UN's Children's Fund to distribute education materials and sports kits on HIV/AIDS to schools in seven provinces of China.,Dubbed as 'Skills for Life in a Box,' the kits contain interactive HIV/AIDS learning materials for teachers and peer educators to use in the classroom.,Each kit also contains a basketball and other sports equipment to help young people learn about inclusion, empathy, teamwork and fair play.,Chief of UNICEF's HIV/AIDS Programme in China, Ken Legins explained that the project was an exciting way to mobilize young people to be more sympathetic towards those living with AIDS.,In China, there are over 840,000 people living with HIV/AIDS, but awareness remains particularly low among children and young people, UNICEF said.,A recent study found that 50 per cent of a sample of 2,500 young people between the age group of 15 and 20 could not explain how to protect themselves from HIV.,In addition, around half the young people in the same study believed that HIV could be transmitted by sharing chopsticks, the Joint UN Programme on HIV/AIDS (UNAIDS) said.

Title: She has learnt to live with HIV
article: HUBLI: For 29-year-old sociology post-graduate Yamuna (name changed), hailing from a middleclass family in Dharwad, nothing is more satisfying than sharing her own experience.,Life for her tore apart when her late husband, a hardware businessman from Belgaum, was tested HIV-positive in 2001 within a few months of marriage. She, too, acquired the infection when she was five months pregnant and had her premature baby aborted, and that nearly cost her life.,Nevertheless, Yamuna picked up the threads of her life post-HIV and learnt to live life fully, thanks to some NGOs. Today, she is full time counsellor at the Anti Retro-viral Treatment centre at KIMS Hospital in Hubli, busy teaching the public that the lives of HIV-positive persons are no different from others', and 'stigma' should be the last word on one's mind while dealing with infected persons.,"Initially, it was traumatic to learn about the infection. But I received a lot of support from my in-laws and NGOs. I now openly tell the world about my status and I frankly share my experience with others," she discloses.,Interestingly, like others, Yamuna does not reprimand her husband for ravaging her life. "He was a nice man and loved me a lot. He took care of me till his last breath on August 15, 2004. It's nothing but fate," she avers.

Title: HIV+ve pair ties knot in Rajkot
article: RAJKOT: They hope to live happily ever after. Hope, because both Manoj Gohel, 24, of Rajkot and Rama Kargatia, 23, a widow from Junagadh, who tied the knot here on Thursday, are HIVpositive. ,The couple first met six months ago in a support group meeting organised by the Rajkot District Network of People Living with HIV/AIDS (RDNP+). ,However, it was not smooth sailing for them even after they decided to take the plunge. RDNP+ president Jagdish Patel, who is also HIV-positive, said, "We faced lots of problems in convincing Rama's relatives for the marriage. ,The fact that both hail from different castes also proved to be a hurdle. But constant persuasion by our members and the couple's willingness ultimately made it possible." ,Manoj, who is also vice-president of RDNP+, said that he has been HIV-positive for last six years, but did not know how he got the virus. Rama got the virus from her husband, who died of AIDS four years ago. ,Patel said that the purpose behind such marriages is to give a social status to HIVpositive people and also because they can understand each other's problems better than anybody else. ,The members of RDNP+ visualise creating an enabling environment for people living with HIV/AIDS where they have easy access to treatment, care and support and can exercise their rights without facing any discrimination, he added. ,Around 250 members meet and try to help each other at the support group meetings.

Title: 29% of HIV+ve people refused loans
article: NEW DELHI: Discrimination is rampant in Indian work places against employees living with HIV or AIDS with a large number being forced to resign or take voluntary retirement.,This has led to almost 74% employees not disclosing their status at office due to fear of being ostracised. And of the 26% who did disclose their status, over 10% have reported discrimination. ,These are the findings of a first of its kind study on the socio-economic impact of HIV and AIDS in India, carried out by the National Council for Applied Economic Research (NCAER) and supported by the National AIDS Control Organisation (NACO) and United Nations Development Programme (UNDP).,The study, based on the survey that spread over six states â€” Andhra Pradesh, Karnataka, Maharashtra, Tamil Nadu, Manipur and Nagaland â€” also revealed the different nature of discrimination.,After covering 2,068 HIV households and 6,224 non-HIV households and interviewing 2,386 people living with HIV and AIDS (PLWHA), the study has shown that while 29% have been refused loan facilities and nearly 30% have been denied promotion, benefits have not been given to 20% of PLWHA.,Over 16% were forced to resign and 10% forced to take voluntary retirement. The attitude of co-workers has also been discriminatory. While 42% felt they were neglected and isolated, nearly 29% reported being called names by their colleagues. ,The study also notes that around 14% of men and 12% of women PLWHA reported facing discrimination at health facilities, with the discrimination being slightly higher in urban areas.,The nature of discrimination is different with 25% being refused medical treatment or referred to another health facility, 40% feeling neglected and isolated and 30% abused and teased.,Women bear the brunt of the stigma. More women faced discrimination like neglect, isolation and verbal teasing in the family. The study has highlighted that women are supportive of their HIV positive husbands (12.4%) than men of their HIV positive wives (8.4%). ,An overwhelming majority (84%) of women in the sample informed their spouses immediately of their HIV positive status, while the percentage of men who did the same is much lower (69%). ,Nearly 5.5% of female PLWHA have been asked to leave home after testing positive in comparison to only 1.9% of the male PLWHA.,The study estimates that lost earnings due to morbidity or death caused by HIV and AIDS could pull down total household incomes of HIV households by 9.24% and this could, in the long term, have a deleterious impact on the economy as a whole in terms of reduced savings and investments.,According to the report, children from HIV and AIDS households also have lower enrolment and higher dropout rates, affecting the access, demand, supply and quality of education. The girl child was found to be more affected, being more likely to be withdrawn from school.,Since most of the HIV infected persons are not only in their prime working age but are also often parents of young schoolgoing children, the epidemic would have an adverse effect on many aspects of child well-being, the study notes.,More children from HIV households dropped out of school to take care of the sick or their younger siblings, assist in household chores or to take up a job as compared to non-HIV children. ,Reasons like 'not interested in studies' and 'education considered unnecessary' were higher for non-HIV households, a sign that education is valued in HIV households and that they are forced by circumstances to withdraw their children from school.,Among the reasons for low school attendance, 'parent unwell', 'not paid fees' and 'had to look after younger siblings' or 'attend to household chores' was higher for children from HIV households than those from non-HIV households.

Date: Pervez Iqbal Siddiqui & Lalit Kumar,Jul 28, 2006, 04:07 IST
Title: HIV+ boy tied to his Meerut hospital bed
article: LUCKNOW/MEERUT: Fifteen-year-old Vijay doesn't stand much of a chance against the dreaded HIV, but the shocking conditions at Meerut Medical College hospital have added torture to his agony. ,This inmate of Meerut's juvenile jail has been tied to his bed with patients of infectious ailments all around him. The boy can no longer speak because a lesion in his brain has paralysed the right side of his body. ,In a semi-conscious condition, he lies at the Intensive Therapy Unit tied to his bed "to keep him from falling off, or pulling out his intra-venous injection lines". ,No one has thought of giving him a bed with side guards to prevent a fall. Among Vijay's neighbours at the ITU are fever and tuberculosis patients Daya Ram, Hoshiar and Kailashi Devi, each of whom could pass on a fatal infection to this HIV positive boy. ,Vijay, whose name has been changed as per a legal requirement on identifying HIV victims, has been losing weight because he can barely eat. Yet, he does not have a Ryall's tube inserted in his abdomen to feed him. ,He also has painful bed sores from lack of nursing. Doctors admit it may just be a matter of time before Vijay, a daily wager's son, breathes his last. ,No juvenile remand home inmate in UP has yet been reported to have died of AIDS. Vijay's sole attendant Ram Khilawan, an employee of the juvenile jail, said, "I manage to feed him two biscuits on some days. That is the only thing he gets, apart from injections. He is fast losing weight." ,The instructions on Vijay's bed chart on Wednesday, of which TOI has a copy, do not mention a diet plan except for intra-venous glucose. ,Asked who was monitoring his nutrition intake and why the boy was not being fed through a tube, the doctor on duty â€” not willing to be named â€” said he was "not aware" of these details. ,Why was a boy, whose natural defences are so low, put beside tuberculosis patients? The doctor said, "It is true he can easily catch infections. But we have our limitations. ,I am not sure where else we can put him, really." The boy was sent to the juvenile jail from Bulandshahr on April 2, on charges of "theft".

Title: HIV cases converting into TB at alarming rate
article: LUCKNOW: The Human Immuno Virus (HIV) cases in Uttar Pradesh are now getting precipitated in the form of tuberculosis (TB). And their conversion rate is extremely high, according to experts of World Health Organisation (WHO) working in different cities of the state.,Officials with the state TB cell estimate that at present one TB patient has the potential to infect 15 others, all because of the decline in immunity levels. ,According to state TB officer (STO) BK Agarwal, country's northern zone, comprising UP, has been marked as a high alert zone.,The annual rate of infection (ARI) in this zone, according to the state TB cell, stands at 95 cases per one lakh people as compared to the country's average of 75 cases. The rate is significantly higher in case of urban areas because of high population density. ,It is because of this, officials admit, there are chances of epidemic-like-situation if the prevalence rate is not brought under control.,Data available with the WHO consultants clearly mentions that there are nearly 2.3 lakh cases of TB in the state. This, despite all 70 districts of the state being covered under the directly observed treatmentâ€” short course (DOTS), the programme which was launched way back in 1995. ,Officials, however, claimed that at present more than 5 lakh patients have been put on DOTS therapy through 14,059 centres operating in various parts of the state. ,The national tuberculosis programme (NTP), it is learnt, had been declared as a failure by the government itself. It was found that the programme met only 30 per cent of the expected results. ,It has now been replaced by the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme (RNTCP). But the revised programme, officials admit, is yet to reach every nook and corner of the state.,"The diagnostic part of the disease is one of the most critical area which has to be taken into account. For there are instances wherein the doctors of various provincial health centres (PHCs) have not been able to diagnose the disease properly. ,As a result they were not able to avail the DOTS therapy in time," said a senior officer with the UP TB cell on condition of anonymity. ,Another constraint is low density of DOTS centres. Sources said that the department is now seeking help of NGOs and anganwadi workers by equipping them with proper training so that they can help in propagating the therapy in villages.,Moreover, the cell is now coming out with TB drugs especially meant for children.

Title: Pre-marital HIV test mandatory in Goa?
article: PANAJI: The Goa government will discuss at the next meeting of the state Cabinet the issue of legislation on mandatory HIV tests before marriage, officials said on Friday.,"There are diverse opinions on the issue. A few find that the test should be mandatory while others say it should be voluntary. It is for the Cabinet now to take the final decision," said state Health Secretary UK Wohra.,Public hearings on this issue were held in both districts -- north and south. "We will assess the public opinion before deciding on the issue. We have got the trend about general opinion on the issue," Wohra said.,He said while some people feel the tests should be mandatory to save women from suffering, others opined that the matter should be left to the couple.,Once the state government makes up its mind on the issue, it will have to amend the state Health Act and Marriage Registration Act, he said.,About HIV/AIDS cases in Goa, Wohra said, "Goa figures in the middle risk zone. Being a tourist state, the situation may be alarming if precautions are not taken.",Quoting official figures, he said there are around 12,000 HIV-positive cases in Goa. "All need not be Goans and the figure may be much more. We are involving private hospitals to get the exact data," he said.

Title: TB biggest killer of HIV+
article: NEW DELHI: Tuberculosis has become the single largest killer of AIDS patients in India. Figures compiled by India's National AIDS Control Organisation has revealed a catastrophic trend â€” over 60% of AIDS patients contract and ultimately die of TB. ,What's worse, AIDS is fuelling a resurgence of TB in the country. Faced with this double plague, India has now decided to scale up and integrate the National AIDS and TB control programmes from 2006. ,Under phase three of the National AIDS Control Programme during the next five years, in which India plans to spend $2.5 billion, $500 million is being kept aside solely for treatment and care. ,By 2012, India plans to set up 2500 Integrated Counselling and Testing Centres in universities, hospitals and medical centers across the country. At present, there are 2815 ICTC that check AIDS patients for TB. ,According to Dr Kurien Thomas from Christian Medical College, Vellore, who has designed the NACP III programme, the additional ICTCs will test 21 million people, of whom 30 lakh are expected to have symptoms of TB. ,These people will then be referred to India's Revised National TB Control Programme. Also, the present Voluntary Counselling and Testing Centres, that check patients for AIDS, will be integrated into ICTCs. ,NACP phase II was completed in March and the next phase would be implemented during the 11th five-year plan. The implementation is likely to start from November in 2006. ,"Of the 5.2 million HIV infected Indians, over 10% are expected to have full blown AIDS. Every AIDS patient has 15% chance every year of developing TB, which shows that every AIDS patient will develop TB some time in their life. ,Under NACP III, we will confront both TB and AIDS together. When people become infected with TB and AIDS, it is almost always an irreversible formula," Thomas said. ,The issue of TB and HIV complimenting each other has become so serious that for the first time, experts have been brought together at the World AIDS Conference in Toronto, starting on Sunday to conduct separate sessions on the menace and specially discuss TB.,TB specialist Dr Bobby John, who will attend some of the TB-AIDS sessions, told TOI that TB kills over 1,000 people every day in India. And its interaction with AIDS patients is making it more lethal. ,India reports 1.8 million new cases of TB, which is 1/5th of the global TB burden. Nearly 370,000 people die of TB in India annually. ,"Studies have shown that the co-infection rate in India is as high as 60%. That's why we are beginning a TB-HIV module under our TB Control Programme. The need for early identification and treatment of TB is desperately urgent. ,TB and HIV/AIDS is particularly deadly in Indian states due to widespread stigma, low levels of awareness, poorly coordinated services and a lack of mobilisation at the local and national levels."

Title: '60% of S Asia's HIV+ in India'
article: TORONTO: India is home to 60% of South Asia's HIV patients, a World Bank report released at the 16th International AIDS Conference on Monday said.,The report warns that South Asia is facing an HIV pandemic, with an estimated six million people infected, and said the epidemic was driven mainly by the region's flourishing sex industry and injecting drug users. ,Pointing to gaps in India's AIDS control programme, the report criticised the country for running most of its prevention programmes on urban populations though the epidemic has been found to be more rampant in rural populations. ,"Little is known about these rural epidemics, but in many locations like Rajasthan and Karnataka, local sex work plays an important part in HIV transmission," the report said.,It said that South Asia's AIDS epidemic would grow rapidly unless the region's eight countries, especially India, tackled high-risk groups such as sex workers and their clients, injecting drug users and men having sex with men, with better HIV prevention measures.,Regional risk factors have been identified as widespread stigma and discrimination, poverty and inequality, illiteracy, low social status of women, trafficking of women for commercial sex, porous borders, widespread migration, high levels of mobility, cultural restrictions on discussing sex, high rates of sexually-transmitted infections and limited condom use. ,"The future size of India's HIV epidemic will depend on the effectiveness of prevention programmes for sex workers and clients, MSM (men having sex with men) together with injecting drug users (IDUs). ,Throughout the country, tackling stigma and discrimination towards vulnerable and often marginalised people engaging in high risk behaviours, and those living with HIV, remains vital. HIV prevention makes treatment more affordable, and treatment creates opportunities for enhanced HIV prevention," the report said.,Focusing on five countries in the region for which there is adequate data Bangladesh, India, Nepal, Pakistan and Sri Lanka the report concluded that countries must tailor their HIV prevention programmes to suit their local conditions rather than rely on global or regional approaches.

Title: Patient in UP branded HIV-positive
article: KANPUR: 'HIV+' - the words are written on the wall over a hospital bed on which lies a young ailing woman. The lines on her face are not those of age, but of neglect. ,Her doctor is away, her relatives don't have the money to get specialised tests conducted and, to top it all, she has been branded 'HIV+' in blatant violation of medical ethics.,This is the plight of 30-year-old Maya (not her real name), whose clinical tests in the government hospital Kanpur showed her to be an AIDS patient. However, her relatives do not have the money to get her CD 4 test done, which will ascertain how far the disease has advanced and predict the risk of infections. ,Besides, the senior doctor who was attending to her for paralysis in her legs and arms, has proceeded on leave and the junior doctors and para-medical staff seem to be distancing themselves from her. ,Maya's medical history says she is an old patient of tuberculosis and has been found HIV positive in the ELISA tests conducted three times here at voluntary testing and counselling centre at the GSVM Medical College.,For treating such patients, junior doctors claim that there is no tertiary centre, no universal precautions and no facility of HAART (Highly Active Anti Retroviral) therapy available in the hospital. ,Besides, there is no government testing facility in the entire city that could conduct CD 4 count of the patient. Junior doctors have repeatedly requested the husband and sister of the victim to take the blood sample to Lucknow for CD 4 testing but all their efforts are going in vain, as they don't have money.,Against the norms of National AIDS Control Organisation (NACO) that states that doctors and nurses attending to HIV positive patients should wear latex impermeable gloves, their eyes should be protected, shoes should be covered and if the patient has tuberculosis then his/ her face should be covered with mask. ,In this hospital there is no such arrangement and admission of such patients is a routine there. Doctors believe that there is 0.3% chance of their getting exposed to the dreaded virus. ,Relatives of other patients in the same ward are also living in scare of catching infection but there is no one who could counsel them that HIV could be transmitted only through sexual intercourse, through intravenous substances and from mother to child.

Title: 1,717 rly employees test HIV positive
article: MUMBAI: The Railways has woken up to the rude reality that over four per cent of its field staff will not be in a position to do strenuous work in the near future. ,According to the July 2006 railway medical records, as many as 1,717 employees of the Mumbai division have tested HIV/AIDS positive. ,The data collected by both Central and Western Railways also revealed that 254 patients with full blown AIDS were currently taking anti-retro viral (ART) treatment at different railway hospitals across Mumbai and Kalyan divisions.,There are nearly 40,000 employees working in both Western and Central Railway's Mumbai division. Senior railway officials have admitted that it was a cause for worry as over four per cent of the employees were now affected by the disease. ,More so because bulks of the victims were staff who were constantly on the move and were involved in physical and technical work. ,"Nearly 80% of the HIV victims comprise drivers, gang men, ticket checkers, mechanics, guards, technicians and railway policemen," said a senior railway official...,...,Counsellors based at the railway hospital, Byculla, said the cadres have low awareness levels about HIV/AIDS and were the most vulnerable lot.,"They are away from their families for extended periods," said a railway health official. Employees like 42-year-old Bala Chavan (name changed), a Kalyan resident who used to work as a driver, was forced to take voluntary retirement as he was no longer able to work. ,Chavan tested positive five years ago, and since the last three years he has been on ART treatment. "The unfortunate part is that his entire familyâ€”his wife and two kidsâ€”have tested positive as they were not aware of the disease," said a senior railway official.,The railways started voluntary, counselling and testing centres (VCTC) a decade ago at various railway hospitals across Mumbai. ,"The disease was not widespread at that time and we used to get one or two cases every two months. But it was after 1995 that the number picked up," said a senior doctor.,According to her, the numbers shot up following increased awareness. "But even now people come forward only after they have developed serious symptoms of the disease," she said.,For employees like Pradeep Kale, a ticket checker who came to know about his positive status last year, it was a huge shock.,Pradeep visited the VCTC at Jagajivanram Hospital because he was suffering from TB. "I was asked by the doctor to take the Elisa test as the disease showed no signs of abating," he said. ,Doctors attending to Pradeep said he was deeply depressed and needed counselling every week. Till date, nearly 500 railway employees have succumbed to the disease.,The railways have now begun a massive advocacy and awareness programme across all sections of its employees. Recently, office-bearers of various trade unions affiliated to the railways were trained for the HIV/AIDS awareness programmes., "The office-bearers will now act as peer educaters and will in turn create awareness at the grass root levels," said Anjana Pavle, health co-ordinater with Mumbai District AIDS Control Society (MDACS).,The MDACS is running a ILO-sponsored work place intervention programme with BEST employees. "BEST has framed an HIV policy approved by the ILO," Pavle said.,The policy states that no employee will be segregated or will be terminated from their jobs on the basis of their HIV status. ,Also, the identity of the victims will be kept secret and no mandatory testing will be deployed on employees.,"The need of the hour is awareness about the disease so that it does not spread like wildfire," said Pavle.

Title: Orissa boycotts HIV+, govt cell has no idea
article: BHUBANESWAR: Nobody knew when a young HIV+ couple in Belaguntha block of Orissa's Ganjam district committed suicide after being ostracised by their locality. ,Surprisingly, even the State AIDS Cell (SAC) claims ignorance about the matter. "We were unaware of the incident," said SAC project director R K Choudhury.,Though senior SAC officials claim that there has been a decline in instances of social boycott of HIV+ persons in the state, volunteers working at the grass root level have a different story to tell.,"The decline is evident from the fact that only three such cases were reported at the anti-discrimination unit," said SAC deputy-director Dr Annapurna Mishra. "We have seen how the people do not discriminate against the HIV+ people in many parts of the state," she added.,One complaint was received from Kendrapara district where villagers debarred an HIV+ family from attending any social functions. ,Similarly, according to the anti-discrimination unit, the villagers did not allow cremation of an HIV+ man's body due to the fear that the smoke emitting from the pyre would spread the disease. The man was finally buried. Similarly, an HIV+ girl in Jagatsinghpur district was expelled from her school. ,"We intervened in this incident," said Choudhury. But the anti-discrimination unit that has been in operation for a year now, only addresses complaints made by the victims themselves. ,"SAC anti-discrimination unit only reacts to the complaints made by HIV+ persons. We don't take up cases on our own," said Nandita Nayak, an officer in charge of the unit.,SAC is unaware of several cases across the state where HIV+ persons have been shunned by their neighbours and communities, including the alleged killing of one Loknath Mishra in Puri. He was stoned to death on Friday as he was HIV+.

Title: Law to safeguard HIV-affected people
article: KOCHI: The Centre was planning to bring in a law to prevent discrimination against HIV-affected people, Union Health Minister Anbumani Ramadoss said here on Monday.,The objective of the law was to make the social life of the HIV-affected people comfortable, he said after distributing financial aid of Rs 15,000 each to 51 HIV positive children from various parts of Kerala.,The programme was organised by 'Keraleeyam', a Thiruvananthapuram-based social service organisation.,Pointing out that HIV-AIDS was found more among those in the age group of 15 to 25 years, the minister emphasised the need for awareness programme against the condition in schools and colleges.,Among those spoke included V K Ibrahim Kunju, MLA, and Ernakulam District collector Mohammed Haneesh.

Title: Private boost for cheap HIV drugs
article: Last month, a global summit was told that a quarter of the AIDS-affected didn't have access to life-saving medicines. With India having about 57 lakh HIV-positive people, the largest in any country, the gap between demand and supply of drugs assumes alarming proportions. ,Despite the government providing free AIDS drugs since 2004, only 35,000 have benefited so far. The rest can't access them regularly. Hence, a move by pharmaceutical companies to provide AIDS drugs at discounted rates is welcome. ,This year, Emcure Pharmaceuticals Limited, in association with the Network of Positive People (NMP+) and the Indian Network of Positive People (INP+), launched two "Taal" pharmacies in Pune and Nagpur, where those with HIV/AIDS get medicines at subsidised cost. ,Says Arun Khanna, executive director, Emcure, "The centres take care of those who don't have access to treatment and doctors, and also their psychological and immunological issues." Emcure provides the drugs on a no-profit basis and the revenue generated by the centres goes to the networks. ,The average monthly cost of anti-retroviral drugs (ARVs) in the first line of treatment per person is Rs 500. Drugs for the second line of treatment are more expensive and cost between Rs 7,000-8,000 per month. In the Pune and Nagpur centres, 500 and 100 people, respectively, are receiving treatment. ,The company plans to open more centres, with two being set up soon in Namakkal in Tamil Nadu and in Aurangabad. Such a public-private partnership is running parallel to the governments. ,Says Umesh Patel, president of Gujarat Network of People Living with HIV/AIDS (GNP), "Even though medicines are free from the government services, there's a high dropout rate because of poor quality of services. People have to wait in long queues for meeting the doctors and for ARVs. ,Also, testing takes two-three days. So they prefer to switch to private pharmacies." According to Patel, the largest initiative for providing discounted ARVs is being done by Reliance HIV and TB Centre in Surat. ,It's a partnership of Cipla, Reliance, CII and of people living with HIV/AIDS. Here, drugs are provided free of charge for 15 days in a month. That means patients need to spend just Rs 250 per month. ,There's also the AIDSCare Network in Surat, says Patel, which gives Cipla drugs at Rs 90 per month. "The company gives concessions but the Network too absorbs part of the subsidy," says Patel. Medicines for the second line of treatment are available here for Rs 1,200 per month. ,There are about one lakh HIV positive people in Gujarat. Of these, about 10,000 should get ARVs, says Patel. But government efforts cover just 1,500. There is, however, skepticism about some of the private efforts too. ,K K Abraham, president of INP+, says, "Emcure has a vested interest in wanting to sell its AIDS medicines." Patel adds, "Emcure medicines are given out in government outlets because they give low quotations. But there have been complaints of side-effects and of the CD4 count (T-cell) going down after use of Emcure drugs." ,CD4 count lowering generally indicates progress of the HIV infection. The irony: India is one of the world's largest suppliers of generic ARV drugs to the developing world.

Title: Genes responsible for HIV
article: HYDERABAD: It is not just promiscuity, infected syringe or blood that makes a person vulnerable to HIV/ Aids. The genetic make up of an individual could very well decide his vulnerability to contract the infectious disease.,Scientists at the Hyderabad-based Centre for Cellular and Molecular Biology (CCMB) say that there could be a gene that makes Indians more susceptible to the virus â€” more so people from the South. India has over 6 million people infected with the virus.,After extensive research, CCMB has identified five such genes out of which two are widely prevalent among people from the South. ,Close to 75 per cent of HIV/Aids cases are from the states of Andhra Pradesh, Karnataka, Tamil Nadu and Maharashtra. In the South, Andhra Pradesh is most vulnerable, with Guntur topping the list of HIV/Aids cases.,"The genetic make up of Caucasians make them more resistant to the virus as against Indians,"says Shailendra Saxena, CCMB scientist leading the research on infectious diseases.,"There is a high probability that the genetic structure of people from the South makes them more prone to HIV/Aids. These genes have been identified and we will be adopting a molecular approach to see the effect of HIV on these genes,"Saxena says.,This experiment will be performed in the centre's newly-acquired Bio-Safety Lab, Level III (BSL III). ,"As per World Health Organisation norms research on infectious diseases can be done only in BSLs. BSL III, which though functional, is undergoing the validation process which would declare it ready for work,"CCMB director Lalji Singh points out.,HIV/ Aids is considered the most serious public health challenge in India. Till now places which send the maximum number of workers abroad and areas that fall on the main truck routes have been touted as the main centres in India that see incidence of HIV/ Aids. ,"The fact that we are more vulnerable means that as a community we must be more energetic in promoting values of morality and safe sex. Also we have to eradicate drug abuse,"an analyst says.,As per international estimates, India could have 20 -25 million HIV cases by 2010. UN studies predict that over 12 million people in India could die in the country between 2000-15 from Aids.

Title: Swayamvar for HIV-infected
article: AHMEDABAD: Suresh Parsana (25) is looking forward to meet his match on October 1 â€” someone he can relate to as a soul-mate. ,He will head for the 'swayamvar' organised for HIV-infected persons in Surat. There will be many like him seeking life-partners who would stand by them in this difficult journey called life. ,"There is a lot of pressure from my community to get married. I am inundated with proposals from suitable girls. But I don't want to marry and ruin a girl's life. I would rather choose an HIV-infected girl,"says Suresh. ,Once he finds his match, he plans to tell his relatives later that theirs' was a love marriage! Over 80 HIV-infected people are expected to participate in this meet and look for companions who would understand their fears and offer support in face of the deadly infection. ,"The idea is to provide a platform to the HIV-infected to find partners, making them feel that life doesn't end once you're infected with the virus. We now want to promote the concept of positive living amongst the HIV-infected who tend to suffer extreme loneliness and depression battling the disease on their own,"says DM Saxena of Gujarat State AIDS Control Society. ,Networks of HIV-positive people have been established in 14 districts of Gujarat under the aegis of Gujarat State Network of Positive People (GSNP+) which has a data bank of around 3,500 such persons. ,What makes this interesting though is that the organisers are anticipating that fewer women than men will turn up. ,"We run a marriage bureau where we already have applications of 45 men and eight women from Surat who are seeking life-partners. There would be other people from Ahmedabad, Vadodara, Rajkot, Amreli, Bhavnagar and other places. Women would surely have more choice as compared to men here,"said Rani Patel of GSNP+ in Surat. ,Patel said that while most male HIV applicants seeking marriage proposals are married, women are mainly widows or divorcees.

Title: In Surat, a 'swayamvar' for HIV patients
article: AHMEDABAD: Suresh Parsana (25) is looking forward to meeting his soulmate on October 1. On the given day, Suresh will head for the 'swayamvar' organised exclusively for HIV-infected people in Surat. ,It is an occasion where these people may find someone to spend the rest of their lives with. ,"There is lot of pressure from my community to get married. I am inundated with proposals from suitable girls. But I don't want to marry and spoil a girl's life. I would rather choose an HIV-infected girl," said Suresh. ,Finding his match, he plans to tell his relatives later that theirs was a love marriage. Over 80 HIV-infected people are expected to participate in this meet and look for companions who will understand their fears and offer hope beyond the deadly infection. ,"The idea is to create a platform for HIV-infected people to find partners who will make them believe that life does not end once infected. We now want to promote the concept of positive living among the HIV-infected, who tend to suffer extreme loneliness and depression battling the disease on their own," said DM Saxena of Gujarat State AIDS Control Society (GSACS). ,Networks of HIV-positive people have been established in 14 districts of Gujarat under the aegis of Gujarat State Network of Positive People (GSNP+), which has a data bank of around 3,500 such persons. ,Interestingly, organisers are anticipating that fewer women will turn up.

Title: Child gets HIV
article: KOLKATA: At nine months, she was detected with thalassaemia. At two years, she tested positive for HIV. And her parents believe it was the 'drop of life' that gave her the virus. ,The thalassaemic girl needs weekly blood transfusions to stay alive. Her parents suspect it was one such blood unit, taken from the Central Blood Bank that infected her with HIV. ,"We got blood only from the Central Blood Bank. We couldn't afford anything else," said her father Shankha Nath Sardar, who makes just Rs 1,800 a month. ,"I struggle to even get the Rs 50 for a bottle of blood. My daughter needs at least three bottles a week," he said. For Shankha, if there was anything worse than learning his daughter had HIV, it was being accused of giving her the killer virus. ,"When we told the blood bank, they told me that since I am a taxi driver, I infected my daughter. They refused to give me blood till I and my wife underwent tests. We did so in July, 2005, and both of us are HIV-negative," he said. ,Their ordeal started in early-2002, when the child was barely nine months old. She had high fever which wouldn't go down. The local doctor gave up. ,Her parents, Shankha and Kanak, rushed her to BC Roy Children's Hospital. She was diagnosed to be suffering from thalassaemia and doctors asked Shankha to get a unit of blood immediately. ,The weekly transfusions continued. But the child started developing other symptoms and her health started failing. When she recovered somewhat, she was referred to NRS Hospital where she was treated under Moloy Ghosh. ,The child, her father said, was the youngest of all patients in the hospital's day-care section. Early 2003, the doctor treating her suspected something worse and asked the parents to get her tested for AIDS. ,The test, in May 2005, confirmed she was HIV-positive. A second test carried out at the School of Tropical Medicine corroborated the report. On May 26, 2005 Shankha and Kanak were told that their only daughter had HIV. ,When the shocked couple tried to trace the route of the infection, it led back to the blood bank.
