Title: HIV awareness classes for teachers
article: BANGALORE: A scheme to periodically review the syllabus and an awareness programme for teachers in aid of HIV+ children â€” primary and secondary education minister Basavaraj Horatti's goodie bag came loaded at the valedictory session of the seminar on 'Karnataka's Elementary Education System' at national Institute of Advanced Sciences on Saturday.,The minister announced a scheme that would cover the various aspects of syllabus revision ranging from the methodology of revision to the periodicity of revision to be launched soon. "This is to ensure that our children do not have to study an outdated curriculum," he said.,When a member in the audience raised the issue of discrimination shown towards children diagnosed as HIV+, Horatti said, "We are planning to start a programme for teachers so that they do not discriminate against such students. They too have an equal right to education and childhood.",He hoped that the programme would help alleviate the current problem of students dropping out when an HIV+ student enrolls at a school.,Horatti also discussed the setting up of a committee to formulate a state education policy, which would be headed by former Department of State Education Research and Training (DSERT) director Jagannath Rao. "The policy would be aligned to president Abdul Kalam's vision 2020 for Karnataka. It would cover everything from the larger goals of the policy to more minute details like the ratio of teacher and students in a class.",The minister also touched upon the introduction of English from class one in the language policy that would be effective from June 1, 2007. He also assured that there would be no political interference in the functioning of government schools.,He also advocated frequent interactions between parents, teachers and the panchayat to achieve education goals of each child in every village.,Horatti spoke about the effectiveness of the committee of physical education in Punjab and Haryana and said that the findings of the Karnataka committee headed by Justice Vaidyanathan would be implemented in the curriculum.

Title: Cipla launches new anti-HIV drug
article: NEW DELHI: Pharma major Cipla on Thursday launched its fixed dose single pill anti-HIV drug Viraday priced at Rs 5,200 a month.,Viraday is a combination of three anti-HIV drugs -- Efavirenz 600 mg, Tenofovir 300 mg and Emtricitabine 200 mg, a company official said here.,"We are offering the drug at Rs 5,200 a month which is a fraction of the international price of approximately USD 1,100 (about Rs 52,800 a month)," he said.,While the company is introducing this drug in India for the first time, it is also looking at export opportunity, especially in Africa, the official said.

Title: Nearly 10,000 HIV positive cases in state
article: PATNA: With the number of HIV positive cases on the rise, the disease is threatening to assume alarming proportion in Bihar.,According to the latest statistics provided by the Bihar State Aids Control Society (BSACS), the number of HIV positive cases in the state is close to 10,000. The first case of AIDS in Bihar was detected in Nawada in 1992. ,In the last two years, the number of such patients have shot up by over 3,500 and more than 100 have died due to AIDS. Around 64 per cent of the HIV victims are males.,On an average around 2,000 HIV patients are being detected every year in Bihar. Unofficially, even members of the society concede that the actual figure of HIV patients would be much higher.,Despite the claims of creating awareness on AIDS and HIV, patients hit by the dreaded disease still face social boycott. There are reports from Saharsa about one Shambhu Singh of Pama village who was left to die by his family members and co-villagers. ,Singh was working in Delhi and has been an HIV patient for the last three years. Earlier, there were reports from Darbhanga about the wife of an AIDS patient having to drag the body of her deceased husband to the cremation pyre because relatives and villagers refused to touch the body.,Earlier, an HIV patient was reportedly isolated and locked in a room at Darbhanga Medical College and Hospital. Apparently, the media publicity and awareness campaign launched by voluntary organisations is still to evoke the desired public response.,Sources said a major chunk of HIV patients in Bihar are migrant workers returning to the state after being affected by the disease in Mumbai, Kolkata, Delhi and other places. ,Not surprisingly, the growth of HIV patients has been alarming in eight districts of North Bihar due to largescale migration of labourers. These are East Champaran, West Champaran, Khagaria, Madhubani, Purnia, Kishanganj, Muzaffarpur and Sitamarhi.,But it is not just the large number of migrant labourers the state has to worry about. The state has been identified for trafficking of women especially in areas located near the Indo-Nepal border.,There are 22 identified red light areas having about 3,000 sex workers in Kosi area alone, according to an NGO Bhoomika Vihar. ,The number rapidly increased during the past five years. â€œIts anybodyâ€™s guess what the actual figure of HIV patients in Bihar will be if sex workers and their clients are tested for HIV,â€ said Arun Kumar the convener of Bhoomika Vihar.

Title: HIV+ve persons find soulmates
article: AHMEDABAD: The air was thick with apprehension when young HIV positive persons gathered in Surat last week for Gujarat's first ever 'swayamvar' for them. ,The future seemed bleak, and they had no idea who would come for the swayamvar. But as luck would have it, at least four couples found life partners for the difficult journey ahead. ,"I saw her sitting there and instantly fell for her. Throughout the day, she kept turning down my proposal. Finally, she agreed and we will marry soon," says Pradyuman, 27, who runs a stationery shop in Ahmedabad, of his wife-to-be Renuka. ,The Gujarat State Network for Positive People (GSNP+) that organised this event said they were encouraged with the results. ,Interestingly, Surat-based Saurashtra Patel Sewa Samaj has offered to get the couples married by footing the bill. ,"We would be happy if the couples marry along with others in the mass marriage ceremony being organised by us on February 11 so that HIV positive people can be integrated into the mainstream," says Kanji Bhalana, who said the Samaj is ready to spend between Rs 10,000 and Rs 50,000. ,Pradyuman has not told his parents about his illness though he has taken his brother into confidence. ,"There was a lot of pressure from my parents to get married but I did not want to spoil a girl's life. Meanwhile, there was a need to get married to satiate my needs," he says. Renuka, 24, is a widow who lost her husband to HIV. ,"After his death, I felt lonely with no one to support me. Moreover, battling the disease was taking a toll on me. I needed a companion and I am glad I have found a partner who will understand me in sickness and health," says Renuka. ,"The couples are from different parts of Gujarat including Saurashtra, north Gujarat and south Gujarat. ,The four women who are getting married are widows while the boys are unmarried, which is also a positive development as far helping the cause of widow remarriage is concerned," said Daksha Patel of GSNP+ who said that the network is planning to make the swayamvar an annual affair.

Title: After drugs, HIV has Punjab village in its grip
article: BHAINI FATTA (PUNJAB): It started out as drug abuse, but this sleepy hamlet in Sangrur district is now faced with the fact that it may be a step short of an AIDS epidemic.,It all began when sarpanch Hari Singh sought help from Punjab's health officials to rid the village of its drug menace. Little did he know that this would open a whole new can of worms. ,Health department officials, who visited the village of 3,000 people a fortnight ago and tried to get its residents to sign up for rehabilitation, have found that of the 10 blood samples they collected during an impromptu check up, seven have tested HIV positive.,While the alarmed health department officials are back to haunt the village again â€” this time with an official from the Chandigarh-based AIDS Control Society, the scared villagers have either fled the scene or retreated into a shell. ,This time the officials have managed to collect 24 blood samples. ,Most villagers are in denial that they could be on the threshold of an AIDS epidemic. Sarpanch Hari Singh, who had sought help to rid the village of drug addicts, says the problem began about two decades ago, when people developed chronic pain after years of drinking contaminated water. ,"What began as complaints of joint pain soon led to most of the village getting addicted to some pain killer or the other,"he said, adding that the village got fully hooked to drugs sometime around by 1998 by which time "morphine injections were easily available in the village, though at a higher price".

Title: Six Bihar cops test positive for HIV
article: PATNA: HIV/AIDS has suddenly become a talking point in the Bihar police. After a recent mass testing of 400 to 500 police employees, rumours are flying thick and fast on who all are HIV-positive. ,Officially, about six constables have so far tested positive for HIV in the Patna police lines. But the grapevine has been agog with reports of some senior police officers too, testing positive. ,The police and the state government have denied the rumours. But home commissioner Afzal Amanullah told TOI, "HIV is a matter of concern for us. We want to carry out tests on our police employees but will keep the identities of the positive persons confidential." ,Amanullah, however, denied that he had confirmed the positive status of two senior officers, even though a news agency quoted him. ,"Our testing will not be in isolation. We have made provision for providing anti-retroviral drugs to those who test positive so that the onset of full blown AIDS is delayed," he said. ,He added that the force would ensure that those employees who have tested positive were not discriminated against. ,"Wives of the HIV+ constables have also tested positive and arrangements have been made to provide them with ARV drugs as well," the home commissioner said. ,Police lines hospital head Dr P Ojha on Wednesday said recent sample surveys in various districts had shown alarmingly high incidence of HIV in general population. ,"This triggered an alarm in the police force and we started conducting voluntary tests," he said, adding, "Since an earlier health check up had found a high incidence of venereal diseases (VD) among police personnel, we were eager to carry out HIV tests as a person suffering from VD becomes more prone to contract HIV." ,Ojha said a large number of police constables stay away from their families for months and are often posted in remote areas, thereby becoming prone to high risk behaviour changes. ,"We intend to create awareness about HIV in the forces so that people come forward for tests and those who test positive can be provided timely treatment," he said. ,Admitting that the awareness level on HIV is extremely low, especially among the junior police personnel, Dr Ojha said, "Our state is endemic to kala-azar which is known to suppress immunity of the infected persons. Such persons can easily fall prey to HIV, which further compromises the immune system."

Title: Pregnancy kits for HIV tests
article: KOLKATA: This was too good to be true: the number of HIV cases actually showed a drop in the state this year till August. The state was relieved. What it did not know was that patients who had turned up for HIV tests were actually being tested for pregnancy, thanks to dud kits.,At the heart of the problem is Monozyme (India) Ltd,which is being probed for supplying these dud kits. The director of this Secunderabadbased drug firm, jute baron Govind Sarda, was arrested last month. What Monozyme did was fairly simple: it fooled around with nitrocellulose strips, which are used for testing HIV, Hepatitis B and C, and pregnancy. But the composition in the strips vary for the different tests.,For HIV tests, the strips are fitted in Cromatography Immuno Array (CIA), a rapid test kit. Several hospitals and blood banks in Bengal use this. CIA, however, is only a screening kit, and a further confirmatory test is required after this, but this is seldom done.,Monozyme broke the first rule when it sold HIV test kits (both Elisa and CIA) which were not capable of performing the P-24 protein test. The P-24 test helps detect HIV at an early stage, making early medical intervention possible.,"Some district hospitals and blood banks objected to Monozyme's kits, but nothing came of it," a source said. Next, Monozyme reportedly slipped in the nitro-cellulose strips used for pregnancy tests in the HIV test kits (CIA). "Now, all these kits have a control band. If only this is highlighted, it means the test is negative," said a source. Most tests â€” obviously â€” were negative. "What else would one expect when victims, including males, were only being subjected to pregnancy tests?" he said.,As a result, the total number of HIV cases detected in the state dropped this year. In 2004, an average of 4.5 persons were detected with HIV. This went up to 6.4 in 2005. Then came Monozyme, and it looked like HIV was a thing of the past. While the fraud lasted, Monozyme minted money.,"By excluding the P-24 test, it managed to bring down the cost of each kit to Rs 27-28, way below the Rs 120 it sells for. It made even more money by using the pregnancy test strips, which costs Rs 3 apiece," the source added.

Title: Teacher gave me HIV, says US student
article: NEWARK: Prosecutors want a former Newark, New Jersey, teacher accused by a student of infecting him with the virus that causes AIDS to be tested for the disease.,Hassan Vann, 29, a former music teacher at West Side High School in Newark, was indicted on Thursday, accused of sexually abusing a student who now has AIDS, the Essex County prosecutor's office said. Vann faces up to 30 years in prison and 14 charges, including sexual assault and contact, official misconduct, child welfare endangerment, giving drugs and alcohol to a child and failing to notify a sexual partner that he had a sexually transmitted disease.,"Mr Vann's alleged conduct involving his former student was vile and has forever changed this young man's life," said Essex County prosecutor Paula T Dow. Paul Loriquet, spokesman for the prosecutor's office, said the victim told authorities he's only had unprotected sex with Vann and that prosecutors plan to ask a judge to order Vann to undergo an AIDS test.

Title: Games can help keep HIV at bay
article: MUMBAI: This is one ABC lesson with a difference. It is, for one, targeted at teenagers who could be at a risk of AIDS\HIV. For another, it will not be delivered through long lectures and boring sermons, but through the medium of games.,Gamesâ€”be they online, board or of the outdoor varietyâ€”will be used to drive home the message that ABC in an age of AIDS\HIV stands for abstinence, be faithful and condoms.,So, an online cricket game at a few NIIT centres will be interspersed with teenagers Amar and Tara talking about "main jawan hoon, nandaan nahin (I am young, but not immature". A board game, a la KBC-style quiz, will test one's knowledge on the dreaded disease as well as other general topics. The idea is clearly to deliver anti-AIDS\HIV messages as part of fun and games.,"Youngsters don't like to be lectured. They are likely to switch off the moment they realise they are being advised. So, we made an effort to devise a campaign that spoke their lingo and didn't preach," said Sonalini Mirchandani of Joh-ns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health, which has come up with the Amar and Tara theme for AVERT-India.,AVERT-India is funded by the USAID and works in seven districts of Maharashtra such as Mumbai, Thane, Nagpur, Solapur, Satara, Aurangabad and Sangli.,The need to target the youths cannot be overlooked considering that 33% of those hit by HIV belong to this age group. India has over 5.1 million AIDS\HIV-positive persons.,To sensitise the youth, the game kit will be distributed to the 75 non-governmental organisations that are funded by Avert-India in these seven districts. "Even some NIIT centres in these areas will load our games on their computers," added Mirchandani.,The games were inaugurated in Aurangabad by AVERT-India project director Dr S M Sapatnekar on Tuesday. "It is a conscious decision to underline not just condoms but even abstinence and fidelity as keys to AIDS\HIV prevention," he said.,Addressing a gathering of over a thousand students from Aurangabad district, he said that although the AIDS\HIV epidemic had assumed worrisome proportions, there is no denying that it could have been worse. "If India has not suffered like Africa, it is only because of the Indian culture. Here, family as a unit is still supreme," he said.,It is keeping the Indian sensibilities in mind that the ABC approachâ€”originally devised in African nations that had lost almost 25% of its populace to the AIDS\HIV pandemicâ€”is now being widely adopted in India, he said.,Experiences of local NGOs in Aurangabad lend credence to this belief. "When we started HIV\AIDS interventions around three years ago in Aurangabad's slums, we realised that people were squeamish when we talked about condoms. So, we adopted the ABC message instead of just talking about condoms. We even started integrating routine health programmes with AIDS\HIV messages. This works in grabbing the attention of people," said Dr Rajesh K of the Babasaheb Ambedkar Arogya Abhiyan, which is funded by AVERT.

Title: HIV treatment protocol for children
article: NEW DELHI: With a paediatric HIV treatment protocol finally in place, India has, for the first time, put 2,000 children below 15 years on life saving paediatric drug formulations to treat HIV.,Till now, drugs under the Anti Retroviral Therapy (ART)â€” the only treatment available for those infected with HIV/AIDS â€” were administered on children by dividing fractions of adult formulations according to the child's age, which often led to under or over-dosage through human error causing resistance to the drug.,The National Aids Control Programme hopes to identify 10,000 HIV positive children with a CD-4 count less than 15% by November 29 to coincide with former US president Bill Clinton's visit to India. These children will then be put under Anti Retroviral Therapy by 2007-end.,Clinton will be in India for three days to meet HIV infected children in Mumbai, Delhi and Tamil Nadu besides talking to Indian pharma industry about manufacturing secondline Anti Retroviral Therapy drugs at cheaper rates. ,Clinton's HIV/AIDS Initiative Foundation is supplying the paediatric HIV drug formulations to India.,National Aids Control Programme has identified 12,000 HIV infected children from the four worst affected states â€” Tamil Nadu, Andhra Pradesh, Maharashtra and Karnataka. However, only those children with a CD-4 count less than 15% are being put on Anti Retroviral Therapywhile the rest are being put under counselling and observation.,India is also making CD-4 count test free for children. Adults, however, have to pay Rs 250 for the test. The CD-4 count tells the doctor how strong the immune system is and the stage of the HIV infection.,Speaking to Times of India, National Aids Control Programme director general K Sujatha Rao said, "We are undertaking a survey to identify the load of paediatric HIV cases in India. We have started with the four high prevalence states. ,Once children are found to be HIV positive, CD-4 count is being undertaken to know the viral load. Since Clinton is providing us with the paediatric drug formulations for 10,000 children, we hope to identify the children in need of the drugs before he arrives.",India is also procuring 19 Qualitative Polymerase Chain Reaction machines (PCR), the only diagnostic tool in the world that accurately detects the presence of HIV in children aged below 13.,According to National Aids Control Programme, 33,000 new-borns get HIV every year from their infected mothers. Over 50% of these children die within two years of birth while 80% of them die within five years. According to UNAIDS, 120,000 children in the country were living with the virus in 2004. ,National Aids Control Programme estimates that around 60,000 new infections occurred last year and according to rough estimates, around 250,000 children were HIV positive. The treatment will cost National Aids Control ProgrammeRs 8,000 per child.

Title: 'HIV tests not a must before marriage'
article: ERR-RTF

Title: 38% of HIV-hit in India are women
article: NEW DELHI: More than 38% of those living with HIV in India are women, most having acquired the virus from regular partners who were infected during paid sex. According to the 2006 AIDS epidemic update compiled by UNAIDS and WHO, which was released on Tuesday, unprotected heterosexual intercourse is the cause for the bulk of HIV infections in India.,Over 5.7 million of the 8.6 million people living with HIV in Asia are from India, most of them adults aged between 15 and 49. According to the report, India is experiencing a highly varied HIV epidemic which appears to be stable or diminishing in some parts while growing at a modest rate in others. In some rural areas, the prevalence of HIV ranges between 1.1% and 6.4% among adults, underlying the varied character of the epidemic.,Six of the country's 28 states account for nearly two-thirds of the HIV cases, the highest prevalence rates being found in the Mumbai-Karnataka corridor, Nagpur, the Namakkal district of Tamil Nadu, coastal Andhra Pradesh and parts of Manipur and Nagaland. Risk-taking during paid sex is commonplace in India. This, despite surveys showing that 54% and 49% of sex workers in Mumbai and Pune respectively are HIV positive.,The report says despite the fact that very little research has been done on gays in India, the data collected has revealed HIV prevalence among gays in Chennai and Mumbai at 6.8% and 9.6% respectively in 2004. The number now stands at 12% for Mumbai and 18% for AP.

Title: Women make up 38% of HIV+ cases in India
article: NEW DELHI: Over 38% of those living with HIV in India are women, most of them having acquired the virus from regular partners who were infected during paid sex.,According to the 2006 AIDS epidemic update compiled by UNAIDS and WHO released on Tuesday, unprotected heterosexual intercourse was the cause behind bulk of the HIV infections in India.,Over 5.7 million of the 8.6 million people living with HIV in Asia are from India. Most of them are adults aged 15-49 years. According to the report, India is experiencing a highly varied HIV epidemic which appears to be stable or diminishing in some parts while growing at a modest rate in others. ,In some rural areas, prevalence of HIV ranged between 1.1% and 6.4% among adults underlying this highly varied character of the epidemic.,Nearly two-thirds of HIV infections have been found in six of the country's 28 states.,The highest prevalence rates were found in the Mumbai-Karnataka corridor, Nagpur, Namakkal of Tamil Nadu, coastal Andhra and parts of Manipur and Nagaland.,Risk-taking during paid sex is commonplace in India, even though surveys have shown that 54% and 49% of sex workers in Mumbai and Pune respectively are HIV positive. ,The report says that even though there has been very little research on the role of sex between men in India's HIV epidemic, data collected in Chennai and Mumbai found HIV prevalence of 6.8% and 9.6% respectively in 2004. The number now stands at 12% in Mumbai and 18% in Andhra Pradesh.,"The highest national HIV infection levels in Asia continue to be found in south-east Asia where combinations of unprotected sex and homosexuality, along with unsafe injecting drug use, are fuelling epidemic," the report adds. ,Speaking to TOI, UNAIDS India director Dr Dennis Broun said,"The most important development is that India has started to recognise the role homosexuality is playing in fuelling the AIDS epidemic.
