Title: Second line HIV treatment a reality?
article: NEW DELHI: Second line antiretroviral treatment (ART) in India, for those HIV patients who have become resistant to first line drugs, could soon become a reality.,The health ministry has asked the chemical and fertiliser ministry if public sector pharmaceutical companies under it can manufacture and supply the generic version of second line drugs at cheaper rates than private Indian pharma companies. ,Four companies â€” Rajasthan Drugs & Pharmaceuticals Ltd, Indian Drugs and Pharmaceuticals Ltd, Hindustan Antibiotic Limited and Karnataka Drugs & Pharmaceuticals Ltd â€” have been approached by the ministry. ,Health ministry officials feel the proposal will serve a dual purpose â€” the second line drugs will cost NACO 40% less than what private companies are offering while the deal will help revive these public sector pharma companies.,At present, India's National Aids Control Organisation only provides first line drugs that cost NACO Rs 8,000 per patient on ART per year. Second line drugs will cost NACO Rs 8,000 per patient per month.,NACO estimates that 2-3% of the 52,000 patients on ART treatment in India have become resistant to first line drugs. Speaking to TOI, Dr B B Tiwari, NACO's ART consultant said, "We are presently providing ART to 52,000 patients. ,Our first priority is to upscale first line therapy to 100,000 people by 2007, rather than start a very expensive second line for 1,800-2,000 people who have become resistant to first line drugs. ,With over 99% of the Indian population not infected with HIV, we plan to spend over 80% of our resources on prevention.",A health ministry official added, "NACO is giving serious thought to second line drugs. Public pharma companies have been approached to see whether they can supply second line drugs like Tenofovir, Abacavir and Retanovir cheaper. The pharma companies are yet to get back to us.",The health ministry is also undertaking South Asia's largest study to ascertain the type and extent of resistance to first line ART, the only effective way to treat HIV.,This pilot study on drug resistance will be conducted in east Godavari region of Kakinada in Andhra Pradesh, Tambaram hospital in Chennai and J J Hospital in Mumbai. It will cost nearly Rs 1 crore.,India uses three drug regimens under the ART programme. Two drugs among these three â€” Stavudine, Lamivudine and Nevirapine â€” are given in combination to decrease resistance among HIV positive patients.

Title: France to levy tax on air travel to fight HIV
article: NEW DELHI: France will soon request India to levy additional tax on airline tickets, with the money raised through it being used to purchase life-saving drugs against HIV, TB and malaria. ,France, along with 18 other countries, has already started to levy tax on airline tickets under a recently initiated funding programme called UNITAID.,The countries hope to raise $63 million through the programme by 2006-end, $300 million by 2007 and $500 million by 2009. This will be used to purchase drugs for developing countries, fighting the three life threatening diseases.,Speaking to TOI, France's foreign minister Philippe Douste Blazy said he is planning to meet his Indian counterpart Pranab Mukherjee soon to work out the details.,According to Blazy, French president Jacques Chirac, who was the first to suggest a global air ticket tax to fund drug purchases, has already spoken to Prime Minister Manmohan Singh about levying the tax. Blazy suggested that India could either make it mandatory or voluntary for passengers to pay the tax. "India should levy the airline tax for its own interest. If India joins us, we will be able to raise a lot more money. With the funds already raised, we will be able to provide 100,000 children in 40 developing countries paediatric antiretroviral drugs. India is studying the issue," he said.,Supporting UNITAID, former US president Bill Clinton said Cipla and Ranbaxy are pricing a new child-friendly product â€” a three-in-one dispersible ART tablet which will need no refrigeration â€” for less than $60 per year, or 16 cents per day, for an average child weighing 10kg.,The new prices have been made possible by UNITAID, which will provide the Clinton Foundation HIV/AIDS Initiative (CHAI) with $35 million in 2007 to buy medicines and diagnostics. CHAI will contribute $15 million.

Title: HIV+ kids to get gift of life from Clinton
article: NEW DELHI: Christmas will arrive a month earlier for 1,400 children suffering from AIDS in India. And Bill Clinton will play Santa, his sack of goodies containing the gift of life. ,The former US president will formally donate 10,000 paediatric doses of antiretroviral (ART) drugs, the only effective way to treat HIV â€” to UPA chairperson Sonia Gandhi on Thursday, the eve of World AIDS Day. ,The ART doses will increase the lifespan of these infected children by 10-15 years. Till now, the drugs were administered to children by dividing fractions of adult formulations according to the child's age, which often led to under- or over-dosage, causing resistance to the drug. ,Sonia will also release the recently developed treatment protocol for paediatric HIV cases under the National Paediatric HIV/AIDS Initiative. ,Seven paediatric HIV excellence centres are being set up in Bangalore, Chennai, Hyderabad, Delhi and Imphal. ,These will have qualitative polymerase chain reaction machines (PCR), the only diagnostic tool in the world that accurately detects the presence of HIV in children aged below 13. ,A Naco official said, "We have purchased 85,320 adult doses of ART and are getting 10,000 paediatric ART doses free from the Clinton Foundation. Till October, we had put 44,000 people on ART. The number now stands at 51,500." ,Health minister A Ramadoss said, "On the eve of World AIDS Day, we will launch a scheme to provide free treatment to HIV infected children. We estimate there are around 65,000 kids with HIV infection, out of an estimated 5.2 million HIV people in the country."

Title: Govt move on HIV law finds varied interpretations
article: HYDERABAD: The government move to bring in a legislation to make HIV test mandatory for 'to-be-married' couples has evoked mixed reactions. ,While health officials see it as a silver lining in the gloomy cloud, politicians and religious leaders have expressed their apprehensions relating to the stigma attached to the disease and issues pertaining to implementing such a law.,"While intention of the government is clear, one can foresee the implications of such a legislation. Considering the stigma attached to HIV/Aids, testing for 'to-be-married' couples could have a negative impact. Instead of enforcing such a legislation, the government should focus on prevention and treatment,"AP Council of Churches' secretary J A Oliver told TOI on Wednesday.,Jamiat-ul-Mominath president Moulana Mastal Ali also expressed similar views. "Islam does not prescribe any tests prior to marriage. ,Muslims follow the sharia where it is enough if the couple say 'kubool' at the time of the nikah. Any disease should be prevented instead of imposing laws pertaining to its testing,"he said.,As per the law, HIV testing cannot be undertaken without one's permission. It is done during donation of blood and such a legislation might be a hindrance to one's privacy, according to observers.,However, officials beg to differ on this line of thinking. "More than the legislation per se and abiding by it like any other law, the legislation will help ward off the stigma attached to the disease. Awareness among the public to know their status is of more importance which is the focus of the new 'Be Bold' campaign launched for HIV/Aids,"said APSACS project director G Ashok Kumar.,Last month, the 'Be Bold' campaign was ushered in by a testing camp conducted by APSACS and the health department for its own staff, leading the way for public to 'be bold' and follow suit.,A large percentage of women get to know of their HIV status only during pregnancy, mostly in the age group of 18-25 years, said Ashok Kumar.,While welcoming the move, he said, public awareness leading to pressure for such a test would be more effective than any law.,The National Aids Control Organisation (NACO) estimates 5.7 million people suffering from Aids in the country. ,While AP tops the list, other states having a high number of HIV-infected people are Maharashtra, Tamil Nadu, Karnataka, Manipur and Nagaland.,"There is no denying that our state has high number of HIV-infected people. But the legal and social implications need to be worked out before making the testing mandatory,"Hyderabad MP Asaduddin Owaisi, who is campaigning in Karimnagar, told TOI.,Prior to marriage, in case a person is found to be HIV positive, the world does not come to an end as he/she could marry another HIV-positive individual and still have children, who can be normal, with proper medication and care.

Title: Naco covers less than 10% of HIV-infected
article: NEW DELHI: Of the 52 lakh HIV infected persons in India, only 46,000 receive free antiretroviral therapy (ART) that's crucial to preventing them from developing AIDS. ,This was admitted by National AIDS Control Organisation (Naco) in an affidavit before Supreme Court in response to PILs by NGOs accusing the government of tardy action in preventing HIV infected persons from becoming victims of AIDS.,In the absence of ART, all infected persons will suffer progressive deterioration of immune functions and finally develop AIDS and die, they said, and charged the government with failing to achieve its target of giving free ART to one lakh HIV positive patients by 2005.,Studies conducted in developed countries show, without ART, an HIV positive person typically contracts full blown AIDS in 5-10 years. There's no similar study done in India, the NGOs said.,Naco, the AIDS fighting arm of the health ministry, in its affidavit denied the government ever fixed a target of giving free ART to one lakh HIV patients by 2005.,"India's commitment to cover one lakh people with ART by the end of 2005 was an aspiration,"Naco said. ,The target of providing free ART to three lakh HIV positive patients will be achieved by 2011, Naco declared in its affidavit. ,Differing with the approach of the petitioners, Naco said of the 52 lakh HIV positive, only 10% can be said to be suffering from AIDS and needed ART. ,This means that the remaining 90% can wait and watch their infection grow into a full blown case of AIDS.,However, Naco contradicts its statement by giving the example of the global trend. "Even globally, 80% coverage is considered optimal assuming that 20% of patients will avail private treatment,"it said. ,So when other countries are targeting 80% of their HIV infected population, India is struggling to bring 10% under the anti-HIV drive.

Title: Netas to roll up their sleeves for HIV test
article: HYDERABAD: Looks like it is time for politicians to practice what they preach. In tandem with the state government's 'Be Bold' campaign against HIV/Aids encouraging people to get tested and know their status, an HIV/Aids testing centre will be set up in the Assembly from December 18-20.,The testing centre will be open throughout the day as long as the assembly sessions last and will conduct HIV tests on MLAs who 'voluntarily' approach them for it.,"With AP clocking the highest number of HIV/Aids patients in the country, the 'Be Bold' campaign launched on World Aids Day on December 1, this year seeks to address the stigma related to the disease urging people to 'voluntarily' test themselves. This will at least prevent further spread of the disease and help victims change their lifestyle accordingly,"said G Ashok Kumar, project director, AP State Aids Control Society (APSACS).,The centre will conduct HIV Whole Blood tests which will spell the results in a span of 10 minutes. If an MLA is tested negative, he will be informed immediately. ,But in case the result is positive, it will be run through two more confirmatory tests, the results of which will be given the next day. ,Apart from a laboratory technician to conduct the test, there will also be a counsellor who will provide basic information on the virus, its various modes of transmission, precautions and other lifestyle modalities. ,"Prior to the test, one will be pre-counselled about HIV/ Aids. A consent form will also have to be filled up, declaring that he (patient) is voluntarily undergoing the test and the result will be kept confidential,"said Dr M V Ramana Rao, joint director, blood safety, APSACS. ,There are around 500 HIV testing centres across the state including voluntary and prevention of parent to child (PPTC) testing centres. ,Here there are three rapid tests that are conducted to confirm the virus â€” Combaids test, EIA Comb test and Tridot test. ,In case the first test proves positive, then the two other confirmatory tests are conducted and the final result declared on the following day along with some counselling for added measure.

Title: 'Eveteasers' beat HIV+man to death
article: ERR-RTF

Title: HIV/AIDS workshop for cops soon
article: PATNA: The police force in Bihar will now learn about HIV/AIDS in an intensive two-day orientation workshop which will begin in eight districts shortly. ,This (orientation) has come a couple of months after several policemen tested positive for HIV leading to speculation that there could be many more.,In fact, expressing its concern over HIV in the forces, the state government even decided to hold an HIV screening test for future recruits.,The workshop which will benefit about 3,000 policemen will be conducted by NIS-Sparta, a well-known agency, which recently sensitised 4,500 Uttar Pradesh policemen on the same lines. ,It is hoped that the orientation would enable the state policemen to not only protect themselves from HIV but also understand the magnitude of the disease.,The workshops have been organised by the Trafficking and HIV/AIDS (TAHA) project under the UNDP. The organisers are hopeful that it would enable the policeman to understand the nuances of trafficking and ways to prevent it.,An official involved with the project said, "We often found that when trafficking cases would emerge, the victims would be put behind bars and the trafficker would get away easily. Through the orientation we hope to sensitise the police force about this heinous human crime.",He said Bihar had become a major transit point for traffickers, many of whom operated through Nepal. ,Though there are no concrete estimates on Bihar, a report by NHRC in 2003 said about 35 lakh girls were missing and presumably trafficked. "If our police force is aware and alert about trafficking, we are sure this menace will decrease," he said.,UNDP-TAHA project focal point officer Neeraj Kumar told TOI, "The orientation has begun in several blocks. By the middle of January, 2007, we will wind it up. Then a second round of orientation will begin in May, 2007.",Kumar said the state police have been extremely responsive. "Although mostly the junior level employees are taking part, some of the senior officials including those posted as SP have also shown keen interest," he said. ,Since trafficking is also closely linked with HIV/AIDS, the orientation will sensitise policemen on how to support a victim who is HIV positive. ,"The policemen will be told about various NGOs that can extend a helping hand to victims. Currently, policemen rarely have any knowledge about NGOs working in the areas of HIV/AIDS," he said.,To break the taboos surrounding HIV, one session during the orientation would be addressed by an HIV positive woman. ,"We want the police to see that those carrying the virus look like normal people and there is no harm in interacting with them. They would also see how much they can learn from her," he said.

Title: A new condom to combat HIV
article: NEW YORK: US scientists claimed to have developed a molecular condom which may protect women and their unborn or nursing children from AIDS virus. The liquid formulated by Patrick Kiser and other researchers at University of Utah turns into a gel-like coating when inserted into the vagina. ,Then, when exposed to semen, it returns to liquid form and releases an anti-viral drug to attack HIV, according to the online edition of BBC News. ,The Utah project is part of a worldwide research effort to develop "microbicides" drug-delivery systems such as gels, rings, sponges or creams to prevent infection by HIV and other sexually transmitted diseases. ,First-generation microbicides now being tested are expected to be available within four years and to be 50-60%effective. And the researchers predict it will be around 10 years before it might be in widespread use. The idea has already been featured in the Journal of Pharmaceutical Sciences. ,However, Kiser said they lasted only for a short time, meaning they had to be used shortly before sex. The potential advantage of his technology is that it would be much longer lasting. ,He said: "The ultimate hope for this technology is to protect women and their unborn or nursing children from the AIDS virus." ,The Utah project is part of a worldwide research effort to develop "microbicides" drug-delivery systems such as gels, rings, sponges or creams to prevent infection by HIV and other sexually transmitted diseases. ,They are seen as a way for women protecting themselves from HIV, in nations where AIDS is widespread, where rape is rampant, or, where conventional condoms are not reliably available.

Title: HIV test 'by default'
article: HYDERABAD: HIV test on pregnant women in government hospitals may be made 'almost compulsory' soon. That is, the test will be done as a matter of routine on all patients. But if a woman specifies that she does not want the test done, it will not be carried out.,This was one of the recommendations made for the five-year Aids programme in the state by the AP State Aids Control Society (Apsacs) project director G Ashok Kumar at a meeting of National Aids Control Organisation (Naco) held in Jaipur earlier this week.,"This is a kind of 'virtual compulsory testing' since Naco guidelines specify that one cannot be forced to take an HIV test by making it compulsory nor can it be done without the person's consent. ,Such a system will directly ensure that all pregnant women are tested by default and at the same time gives them the option of 'not' getting it done," said Ashok Kumar."As of now we want to implement it in government hospitals and later extend it to the private medical institutions too.",Keeping in line with Apsacs' 0/7 campaign to make the state's children free of HIV/Aids, this new system of 'opt-out' HIV testing will prove beneficial.,"If women get to know during pregnancy that they are positive then it is still possible to prevent the child from turning positive using the right kind of medicines," said Dr J V D S Prasad, deputy director (anti-retrovial therapy centres), Apsacs. There are a total of 575 HIV testing centres in the state.

Title: Project studies cover for HIV
article: MUMBAI: A pilot project in Andhra Pradesh could change the health insurance industry's view on insuring HIV positive patients. ,The project will test a basic micro-health insurance cover with the options of critical illness and AIDS riders. So far, insurers across the world have been refraining from offering AIDS cover, given the high degree of spread, issues with pricing and expectation of losses due to claims. ,At present, insurance for HIV positive patients has only been developed through a Ugandan government initiative in conjunction with USAID for 25,000 mine workers. ,The Indian project, initiated by the Centre for Insurance and Risk Management (CIRM), an arm of the Chennai-based Institute for Financial Management and Research (IFMR), is being tested before it is taken to insurance companies.,The project is particularly important, considering India has over five million people affected by the HIV virus. ,A micro insurance product is typically designed with lower sum assured ranging from Rs 5,000-Rs 50,000 to keep premiums low and affordable. ,The AIDS rider will be available to all those who buy the basic cover and opt for this rider additionally. It is expected to cover people who have opted for the cover from any hospitalisation, drug or other medical expenditures arising due to an HIV infection. ,The team at CIRM is testing the pilot in conjunction with a local NGO in Andhra Pradesh.

Title: Dandruff a sign of HIV?
article: NEW DELHI: Sebo rrhoeic Dermatitis (SD), a severe form of dandruff, is now being looked at as an early signal of HIV. Trichologists and doctors have found that HIV infected patients are 10 times more prone to suffer from SD.,According to Dr Barry Stevens, president of the London Trichology Society and pioneer of single follicular hair transplant, incidence of SD among HIV patients is as high as 30% as compared to a mere 3% among the general population.,Doctors also say that SD on the ears is often a presenting feature of AIDS. Indian studies, on the other hand, put the rate of incidence at 56%.,A study conducted by scientists from SBMP medical College and Hospital and Research Centre, Bijapur's department of Dermatology, Venereology and Leprology found that the prevalence of SD in HIV-positive and AIDS patients is between 34% and 83%.,The study said that SD's incidence and severity are closely related to the stage of HIV infection. ,More severe, widespread disease in the HIV infected, with more lesions, has led to the suggestion that the clinical picture seen in HIV infection-AIDS should be termed as SD-like....,..... dermatitis of AIDS and should be regarded as a distinctive entity caused by immunological defects.,As the disease becomes more advanced, the lesions spread and exacerbate. Stevens told TOI: "SD is increasingly becoming common in HIV patients. We have, therefore, started to see SD as an early warning sign for HIV. ,SD causes redness of the skin and produces a yellow flake. Rashes occur mainly on the scalp and around the eyebrows, ears and moustache. ,Some HIV-infected individuals have had SD rashes on the chest, back, armpits and groin. The cause of SD is not known but a yeast Pityrosporum ovale does play a role in the disease.",Indian Trichologist Dr Akshay Batra added: "SD is one of the most common skin diseases experienced by HIV-infected individuals. However, every patient suffering from SD will not be HIV positive. ,A health care provider should, therefore, evaluate cases of SD that do not respond to typical over-the-counter treatments. HIV infection does lead to a profound alteration of the immune system, putting the infected person at risk for several different types of skin diseases."

Title: First-target cells of HIV identified
article: NEW DELHI: Researchers from the University of Washington in Seattle have, for the first time, found exactly how the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) enters the female body during sex and which are its very first-target cells in the vagina.,The discovery provides hope to a devastated scientific community working on developing an effective microbicide, to help women protect themselves against HIV, after clinical trials of the most promising anti-HIV vaginal gel were recently halted in India and Africa. The gel was found to heighten the risk of contracting HIV rather than providing protection.,Now, the knowledge of how the vagina allows the virus to enter the body will provide a crucial boost for these scientists to discover the most effective microbicide. Microbicides are creams or gels that aim to block HIV from invading a woman's body.,Using a unique model system they developed, the scientists found that HIV-1 simultaneously enters two different types of cells in the vaginal epithelium (outer lining of vaginal cells) associated with the immune system â€” Langerhans cells (LC) and CD4+ T-cells â€” but through different mechanisms. The scientists reported in the journal Immunity, that both LC and CD4+ cells move out of the vaginal epithelium after the infection.,Researcher Julie McElrath reported, "Understanding the initial events in the establishment of vaginal HIV type-1 entry and infection has been hampered by the lack of appropriate experimental models. We have now shown that upon contact, HIV-1 rapidly penetrated both LC and CD4+ T-cells. HIV-1 entered CD4+ T-cells almost exclusively by CD4 and CCR5 receptor without requiring passage from LC. By contrast, HIV-1 entered LC primarily by means of multiple receptors. Our findings shed light on the very earliest steps of HIV infection and may guide the design of effective strategies to block local transmission and prevent HIV-1 spread.",Scientists have for long known that HIV-1 enters CD4+ cells by interacting with a protein called CCR5. But the researchers wanted to know what happens when women are exposed to HIV through vaginal sex. The team then used a chemical treatment to separate the outermost layer of vaginal skin from the underlying tissue. They then exposed this layer to HIV viruses that had been tagged with a glowing dye. The team could then see which cells the viruses had infected. Within two hours, HIV had attacked the CD4+ T-cells, and infected almost half of them. "Now we know that any effective microbicide must prevent HIV infection from entering both T-cells and LC," a NACO official said.,Women are physically more susceptible to HIV infection than men. Married women in developing countries are among those at highest risk due to their multi-partner husbands. Most new infections, about 14,000 every day, are in women.,According to WHO, 17.5 million women are living with HIV/AIDS, the worst affected being those aged 15-24 years, who are three to four times more likely to be infected with HIV than young men of the same age. UNAIDS says over 38% of those living with HIV in India are women.

Title: 'Herpes drug can control HIV'
article: NEW DELHI: It's a troublesome duo where the effect of one worsens the symptoms of the other. Now, researchers have found that treating one can help keep the other under control.,A team of scientists, led by Dr Nicolas Nagot of the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, in the first major study of its kind, has found that treating genital herpes can help keep the AIDS virus under control in women with both infections, and might also reduce the spread of HIV.,In the study, conducted in Africa and published in Thursday's New England Journal of Medicine, women who took the herpes drug Valacyclovir had less HIV in their blood and in their genital secretions.,This finding is significant for India, where a recent study conducted among commercial sex workers in Chennai by YRG Care found 78% of them suffering from herpes. People who have genital herpes sores are more likely to be infected with HIV during intercourse. When they develop a sore, their immune system tries to heal it. ,If HIV in semen, vaginal fluid, or blood comes in contact with a herpes sore, the risk for infection is high. In the Africa study, 140 women from Burkina Faso, who were infected with both the herpes and AIDS viruses, received either Valacyclovir or dummy pills for three months. ,Those on the drug had less HIV in the bloodstream, with their count dropping from an average 20,000 virus copies per mm of blood to 8,000 copies. The placebo group saw their HIV levels shoot up from an average of 50,000 virus copies per mm of blood to 63,000.,The group on medication was also found to have less HIV in their genital tract 13% compared with 27% in the placebo group. The use of Valacyclovir also cut down the amount of time HIV was highly present and active in the genital tract by 59%. ,Reacting to the study, Dr Suniti Solomon from YRG Care told TOI from Chennai, "Because genital herpes is so common in India among sex workers and HIV infected women, we have been using a cheaper herpes antiviral called Acyclovir 400 mg three times a day for 10 days on initial patients and 800 mg two times a day for 15 days in advanced patients."

Title: HIV/Aids still a taboo in corporate world
article: HYDERABAD: Believe it or not, discrimination against HIV-positive persons is prevailing at the cosy corporate work places, a study, quoting top honchos and staff welfare officers, has revealed.,Shockingly, there are even cases where employees refused to share food or utensils and rooms with HIV-affected people due to stigma, the state-wide study added. ,These startling findings were revealed in a study on workplace interventions on HIV/Aids for Andhra Pradesh State Aids Control Society, conducted by Y G Consultants and Services (YGCS).,The study was conducted in 12 companies, including Satyam, Dr Reddy's Labs and ITC in the city. General managers, HR managers, medical officers, staff welfare officers and employee unions of these dozen companies were interviewed by the consultant who in turn took feedback from their employees. ,However, almost all the key personnel stated that HIV positive employees would continue to work and would not be replaced because of company's policy that it cannot terminate their services.,"Awareness about HIV/Aids is there but there is very little implementation of workplace intervention mechanisms. Some companies have engaged the services of NGOs for this, but the problem is that HIV/Aids should not be seen to be tackled with the help of external agencies. It should be treated as part of the business plan of a company,"YGCS executive director Y P Gupta told 'TOI' on the sidelines of a workshop on 'Workplace Interventions for HIV/Aids' on Tuesday.,Most medical officers reported that employees were aware of condoms and how to use it. However, access to condom at workplace is almost negligible. ,Majority of the employees were buying condoms from medical shops. Even though the majority of general managers were in favour of installation of condom vending machines in canteen, security gates and toilets, they said it should be decided by the top brass of the companies. ,"Most of the employers feigned ignorance of HIV-positive employees or they did not want to talk about that. At the same time employees reacted to awareness programmes saying they did not indulge in sex with multiple partners,"added Y P Gupta. He said the non-existence of workplace interventions could increase the attrition rates. ,According to Hindustan Latex Family Planning Promotion Trust team leader Anita Rego, HIV/Aids had started having its effect even on the national GDP.

Title: FM mulls insurance for HIV positive
article: NEW DELHI: Even as insurers suggested that it was not possible for them to devise an insurance cover for those infected with HIV, FM P Chidambaram went ahead and told the Group of Ministers (GoM) that government would examine the issue.,The move suggested by labour minister Oscar Fernandes may raise hopes for millions of HIV/AIDS patients but insurance company sources said they have informed government that it may not be possible with low premiums since claims will be higher. ,"Besides, there may be certain exclusions for which insurance companies will not pay any claims," an executive said. But then, as a senior PSU executive said, if there was a directive from government, the launch of a policy for HIV patients could be explored, with an element of subsidy from government.,In developed countries, insurance companies have started providing such risk coverage and the Indian players could also use insurance policies to devise one for the local market.,Apart from health insurance, even vehicle owners can draw some solace with Chidambaram promising the insertion of a clause in the Insurance Act to ensure companies do not refuse the mandatory third-party insurance. ,The move will be of particular interest to public sector companies, who are often saddled with loss-making business â€” particularly from transporters â€” as the private players refuse to cover the losses.,The third-party business is the biggest drain on their balance sheets with claims as high as 300% â€” that is, they have to pay Rs 300 for every Rs 100 they earn as premium.

Title: 'NGOs spent Rs 4.23 cr to check HIV/AIDS'
article: PATNA: Health minister Chandra Mohan Rai has said a sum of Rs 4.23 crore has been spent by national and international NGOs to check the spread of HIV/AIDS in the 2005-06.,Replying to a query raised by Dilip K Yadav during question hour in the state legislative council on Tuesday, Rai said HIV test centres have been set up at 85 primary health centres in nine most sensitive districts and 14 referral hospitals in Bihar. The people of the state have been imparted necessary training in 35 districts about HIV/AIDS. ,The DMs and civil surgeons concerned have been given necessary instructions in this regard, he added.,One-time settlement: Energy minister Bijendra Prasad Yadav on Tuesday has said the Bihar State Electricity Board (BSEB) has so far earned Rs 12.58 crore from the one-time settlement scheme.,Replying to a question of Bhim Singh (RJD), the minister said the BSEB had waived off a delayed payment surcharge (DPS) amount of Rs 7.47 crore of different category of consumers. ,He also claimed that the monthly revenue of the BSEB had increased manifold during the last couple of months.,No budget provision: There was no budgetary provision for holding cultural mahotsavs for minorities in 2006-07, said minorities welfare minister Manjar Alam.,Replying to a query raised by Baleshwar Singh Bharati (Bharatiya Janata Party), the minister said no amount has been sanctioned for holding cultural festivals of minorities in the next financial year also.,AIDS cases: The state government on Tuesday has claimed that there has been no sharp increase in the number of HIV/AIDS cases in Bihar.,Replying to a queries by Nawal K Yadav and Samir K Mahaseth in the council, the health minister said that in 2006 there was an increase of only 0.033 per cent in the HIV/AIDS cases in the state. ,Large scale migration of people from Bihar is one of the main reasons for the spread of AIDS, the minister said.,Cotton Mill: The state government has made a diagnostic survey of the closed cotton mill at Siwan. ,Replying to a calling attention motion of Kedar Pandey (CPI) in the council, industry minister Gautam Singh said the cotton mill at Siwan has been closed since 2000. ,Industry minister said a total of 310 employees were working in the mill.,The Siwan SP has been directed to provide security to the property of the mill as well as its sprawling campus, he said adding that the government is committed to revive the mill by inviting private parties to run it. ,The state government is also in the process of preparing the DPR of the mill, he added.

Title: HIV+, yet a beautiful life
article: PUNE: Danny West (46) is a positive man in more ways than one. Living with HIV for the past 22 years, Danny was invited by a Pune pharmaceutical company to interact and inspire positive people at their care and support centre, Taal, at Nana Peth. ,A qualified social worker living in the UK, Danny has been working in the field of HIV/AIDS by providing training and education to people living with the disease through his organisation Realising Your Life. ,According to Danny, positive people need to face the challenge posed by the virus by first empowering themselves. "It is important for us to be informed and educated about the virus. ,Thus empowered, we take on our relationships, families and work with a positive approach,"he said. "It is only when we are properly informed and begin to take decisions for ourselves that we can become leaders,"said Danny, who is set to begin a one-ofits-kind leadership programme for HIV positive people in the UK from April 2 this year. ,He said that unlike in the UK, the fight against HIV/AIDS here is still in its early days. ,"The major challenges here are the taboos that HIV raises â€” sex, sexuality, drugs and death. This is what makes tackling HIV incidence a difficult situation. But people here can use this as an opportunity to talk openly about these issues and understand them.",Pointing out the silver lining, he said, "In the UK, HIV/AIDS is considered a predominantly gay, drug abusers' and, now, African affliction. The public is considered almost impervious to the virus. Hence, there are no national campaigns against HIV there. In that way, India is better.",Danny, a gay himself, who has been on anti-retroviral therapy only for the last five years, stressed on adopting a positive attitude towards life in order to beat the virus. ,"You have to take care of yourself, eat a healthy diet, exercise, sleep well and laugh a lot,"he told his audience.

Title: Red Cross takes up fight against HIV/AIDS
article: NEW DELHI: The Indian Red Cross Society (IRCS), which has played a key role in providing relief to people affected by natural disasters, has now trained its guns on HIV/AIDS.,With a number of initiatives ranging from youth education to promotion of safe blood already in its agenda, the organisation has set a target to double its capacity in India in terms of clients and resources to counter the disease.,"Presently, India is in the preliminary stage of the disease. HIV/AIDS is not yet a general problem as it is confined to certain groups and geographical pockets," Mukesh Kapila, special representative of the Secretary General of the Geneva-based International Federation of Red Cross (IFRC), said.,Earlier, AIDS was perceived as part of an African problem. But now, it is a major cause of concern in Asia with India home to the second highest population of HIV-positive people, he said.,The IRCS, with guidance and cooperation from IFRC, has initiated upskilled HIV/AIDS programmes in the country.,"The young school and college-going population will come under the gambit of our programme. But we will have a targeted approach towards high-risk groups like truckers, sex workers and drug abusers," Kapila said.,The IRCS, under its Youth Peer Education scheme in six states -- Andhra Pradesh, Tamil Nadu, Maharashtra, Karnataka and Uttar Pradesh -- has been imparting training to youth to spread awareness about AIDS.,"We will double our capacity in terms of the number of clients and resources in the next couple of years," Kapila said on the sidelines of an international health meet in New Delhi.,Since the organisation's focus is on blood collection and donation, the IRCS has taken on the task of ensuring safe blood supply.,In India, nearly three to five per cent of HIV/AIDS is transmitted through blood transfers. "It is our task to ensure that the blood is HIV-free, for which tests are carried out," Kapila said.,He said India with its technical expertise, pharmaceutical advancement and economic clout could play a leading role in fighting AIDS in the South Asian region.,"Leadership by a country like India on social issues such as fighting AIDS will certainly place the country in high esteem not only in the region, but also across the world," Kapila said.

Title: AIIMS didn't detect HIV, she paid the price
article: NEW DELHI: How aware are doctors at the country's premier medical institute about basic AIDS symptoms the ones that appear in all HIV-AIDS advertisements issued by the government and targeted essentially at the common man?,Not much if the medical records of 17-year-old Jyoti Chauhan (of which Times City has copies) are any indication. Jyoti died at AIIMS on March 26, two days before which her family was told that she was HIV positive and that further tests were required to find out the extent of the infection. Jyoti never got the time to undergo the tests.,When Jyoti was first admitted to AIIMS on September 28, 2006, she had severe diarrhoea later diagnosed as Crohn's Disease and a history of tuberculosis. Besides, her menstruation had stopped. ,Nine days later, while still under treatment for Crohn's, she was subjected to a bone densitometry test and found to weigh a dismal 18 kg. Her discharge summary dated the same day records how she had lost 12 kg in the past three years.,HIV-AIDS never figured in the doctors' diagnoses at that point she had not been tested. Jyoti was readmitted on November 2 with dengue. Two days later, she was asked to get an HIV test done. Though AIIMS on Wednesday claimed they were aware of her HIV status at that point, the discharge summary dated November 18 has no mention of it. ,This despite AIIMS spokesman Dr Shakti Gupta's assertions that as per the recommendations of the Centre for Disease Control and Prevention, Atlanta, "all patients who come to the hospital are treated as HIV+ as a precaution.",Says her brother, Yogesh, "They never said a word about HIV during her dengue attack. When they told us four months later, we thought she had contracted the disease during that period through the 20-odd units of blood and platelets that she received.",Asked why the family was never informed about her HIV status in November, Dr Gupta said, "It was just a suspicion, we needed the test reports to confirm it. They never collected the reports. Thus neither did the discharge summary mention HIV, nor was the family informed or counselled.",Yogesh, an illiterate auto driver, admits he did not collect the report. But, he says, "At the time of discharge, nobody asked for the report either. I was never told how serious it was and we had assumed that if nobody has mentioned anything to us, the test must have been negative.",The whole course of Jyoti's treatment, meanwhile, has left AIDS experts shaking their head. Says Dr Pradeep Seth, formerly head of the department of microbiology at the institute who worked extensively on AIDS: "Loss of weight, diarrhoea, history of TB these are all classical symptoms of full-blown AIDS. ,In fact, the government's awareness ads talk extensively of the same symptoms. It is very surprising that no HIV test was done during her first hospitalisation. In any case, the virus does not manifest itself in the tests before at least two-three years, so there is no way she could have contracted the infection in November.",Refuting AIIMS's claims of having known Jyoti's HIV status since November, Dr Seth said, "Where then is the CD4 count report? They should have done it immediately. Why didn't they do the test to find out the viral load the girl had? Putting two and two together, AIDS should have been thought of in September itself which AIIMS obviously failed to recognise.",An under-pressure AIIMS on Wednesday issued a statement regarding Jyoti's case a statement with glaring loopholes that are exposed by Jyoti's medical records issued by AIIMS itself. ,The statement says Jyoti was first admitted to the hospital on November 2 with Crohn's Disease and later diagnosed with dengue, ignoring her first hospitalisation on September 28 and simply clubbing the two occasions. ,The statement claims she was diag-nosed as HIV positive on November 4 and the patient's attendant "were advised to send the patients for post test counselling", a claim Yogesh stoutly denies. The statement mentions an older TB infection in 2005-06 but makes no mention of her severe weight loss.,"We need to go through the records further to be able to see the complete picture," Dr Gupta said.,abantika.ghosh@timesgroup.com

Title: BSF reinstates HIV-positive constable
article: NEW DELHI: A BSF constable who was removed from service after testing HIV-positive has been reinstated in a rare gesture, indicating a growing sensitivity in the paramilitary force towards such personnel. ,The man, who was stationed along the western frontier in his home state of Gujarat, was compulsorily retired in 2005 after he was found "unfit" to perform his duties. ,BSF rules do not permit personnel with 40 per cent physical "inefficiency" to continue in service and he was removed on medical grounds, official sources said here. ,Sources in the force said the constable underwent sustained treatment that led to considerable recovery, after which he expressed his willingness to return to work. ,Deployed with the artillery wing of the force, the constable, who is in his mid-30s, had joined the BSF in 1990 and is married. He is likely to be posted again in Gujarat, the sources said. ,The decision to reinstate him was taken after a special medical board set up by Director General A K Mitra, in a rare gesture, found him fit to resume duty. ,BSF officials hope the decision will instil a sense of confidence and hope among HIV-infected personnel in the force and prompt them to take a serious look at treatment. ,The BSF is already concerned at the "substantial" number of HIV-infected personnel and has joined hands with the United Nations Development Programme to provide education and awareness to its men. ,The BSF has installed condom vending machines in all battalions and sought the assistance of counsellors to tackle the crisis. ,According to official figures, 94 cases of HIV have been reported in the force so far. Seventy per cent of BSF personnel are aged between 25 and 40 and stay away from their families for long periods. ,It is "natural that biological compulsions drive them to commercial sex workers", officials said. They said AIDS was still considered a social stigma and personnel were reluctant to undergo voluntary medical check-ups. ,Another risk was the possibility of enemies taking advantage of "vulnerable" young personnel by luring them into "honey traps".

Title: 'Breastfeeding helps reduce HIV transmission chances'
article: NEW DELHI: HIV-positive mothers can significantly reduce the chances of their child becoming infected with the virus by exclusively breastfeeding their baby till it reaches six months of age. ,A landmark study by scientists at the Africa Centre for Health and Population Studies, South Africa, has found that exclusive breastfeeding significantly reduces the risk of HIV transmission from mother to child in infants, compared to those also given solid foods or replacement feed like formula milk.,The research, published on Friday in 'The Lancet', has made some interesting findings. The researchers found that there is just 4% risk of post-natal transmission to infants solely fed on breast milk between the age of six weeks and six months of age.,Infants who received supplements like formula milk or animal milk in addition to breast milk were twice as likely to be infected as infants who received breast milk only.,However, children who were given solids in addition to breast milk, were almost 11 times more likely to acquire the infection.,Following these results, AIDS scientists are now calling for the United Nations guidelines to be changed to promote exclusive breast feeding by mothers in developing countries. At present, guidelines from Unicef and UNAIDS say the best option is to bottle-feed the babies with formula milk, where it is safe and hygienic to do so.,This study has serious implications for resource poor countries like India where 30% of the estimated 5.2 million strong HIV population are women. According to NACO, about 30% of the children born of HIV positive mothers end up having the infection. While 10% get it in the womb, an equal number get infected during delivery and breast feeding. Reacting to the study, NACO DG K Sujatha Rao told TOI, "The study endorses what we practice in India. We encourage exclusive breast feeding of children by HIV positive mothers. Babies who are breast fed are protected against diarrhoea and pneumonia. Some African countries did try exclusive bottle feeding and recorded an increased child mortality due to HIV.",According to India's top HIV scientist Dr Suniti Solomon, there is 14% chances of the child getting infected with HIV by the mother's milk. ''A child deprived of mothers milk will anyway die of diarrhoea rather than HIV,'' she said. She added, ''Breastfeeding does carry with it a risk of transmitting HIV infection from mother to child, but it still remains a key intervention to reduce mortality. In India where poverty is endemic, replacement feed, such as formula milk or animal milk, is expensive and cannot act as a complete substitute.'',The African scientists cite a biological reason that might explain their latest findings.,The study, that involved around 2,700 babies born between 2001 and 2005, found that the death rate by three months of age for babies who were exclusively breast-fed was less than half that of infants who received infant formula alone.,Over 15% of babies whose HIV-infected mothers did not breast-feed them died by three months, compared with 6% of the babies whose mothers fed them exclusively. ,The study indicated that for women in impoverished countries where AIDS is prevalent, the health benefits of ,breast milk appeared to outweigh the risk of passing on HIV through breast-feeding. UNAIDS estimates that over 300,000 children are infected with HIV through breastfeeding every year.,Reacting to the study, UNAIDS chief in India Dr Dennis Broun told TOI, "This research is a highly significant input but much more evidence is required for a formal recommendation to be made regarding exclusively breast feeding of children."

Title: Breastfeeding could cut HIV risk to babies
article: Breastfeeding cuts HIV risk to babies,London: Exclusively breastfeeding a baby till it is six months old could cut the risk of mother-to-child HIV transmission, scientists say. ,The Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) is a life-threatening condition in humans in which the immune system begins to fail.,Hoosen Coovadia and other researchers from the Africa Centre for Health and Population Studies at the University of KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa, compared solely breastfed babies with those who were also given formula or solid foods, reported the online edition of BBC News.,In the developed world, the risk of mother-to-child HIV transmission has been cut from 25 percent to under 2 percent because of the use of antiretroviral therapies, exclusive formula feeding and good healthcare support. ,But these benefits are often unavailable in the developing world and exclusive breastfeeding is the best option for most women, the researchers said.,Breastfeeding remains a key intervention to reduce mortality and is also associated with fewer breast health problems.,The researchers said that there was a four percent risk of post-natal transmission to infants who were just fed on breast milk between the age of six weeks and six months. ,Infants who received formula milk or animal milk in addition to breast milk were nearly twice as likely to be infected as infants who received breast milk only. ,And those given solids in addition to breast milk were almost 11 times more likely to acquire infection. ,It is thought that this higher risk is due to the larger, more complex proteins found in solid foods that may lead to greater damage to the lining of the stomach, allowing the virus to pass through the gut wall. ,Hoosen Coovadia of the Africa Centre said: "The question of whether or not to breastfeed is not a straightforward one. We know that breastfeeding carries with it a risk of transmitting HIV infection from mother to child, but breastfeeding remains a key intervention to reduce mortality." ,

Title: HIV infection in kids detected late
article: NEW DELHI: Children continue to be ignored and discriminated against in India's fight against HIV. A study, exploring the barriers to accessing care and treatment for HIV infected children in India, has found that most children are diagnosed for HIV when they are 30 months or older.,Carried out by Avina Sarna from the Population Council of India in collaboration with the Social Awareness Services Organisation (SASO), Asha Foundation and Freedom Foundation in three high prevalence states Manipur, Karnataka and Andhra Pradesh, the study found that less than a fifth of children had been diagnosed with HIV infection before 18 months of age.,The largest proportion had been tested between 30 and 60 months while a fifth had been tested between 19-30 months and the remainder after 60 months. Sarna told TOI that annually, 27 million children are born in India of which 80,000 are infected with HIV. ,"We, therefore, initiated a study between June and December 2006 that interviewed 91 caregivers of children under 12 years of age who were taking ART and 117 caregivers of children under 12 years of age not taking ART. ,Late testing also means delayed initiation of co-trimoxazole prophylaxis which prevents life threatening opportunistic infections in infancy. Testing in early childhood programmes such as immunisation services, MCH clinics and well baby clinics needs to be explored," she said.,According to the study, most HIV tests on children were carried out after the positive status of their parents came to the fore. Less than a fifth of the children had been told of their HIV status. The most common reasons cited for not disclosing the HIV status to children were societal stigma and a fear that the child would tell others in the community.,Conducted to also assess the current level of adherence to ART among children receiving treatment, the study found that overall adherence to treatment was high. Only 44% of caregivers reported never missing any doses of medications ever. Just over a third of the caregivers could correctly identify all four routes of HIV transmission. Some caregivers mentioned mosquito bites, medications and eating food outside as possible routes of transmission.,Nearly half the caregivers reported difficulties in administering medications to children in their care. The three most commonly cited problems were the child's refusal to take medications, breaking tablets to get the correct dose as paediatric formulations are not available and children spitting out medications due to bad taste.,Meanwhile, Naco is expanding India's paediatric HIV programme. It is procuring 19 Qualitative Polymerase Chain Reaction machines (PCR), the only diagnostic tool that accurately detects the presence of HIV in children aged below 13.,kounteya.sinha@timesgroup.com

Title: AP may make pre-marital HIV test must
article: HYDERABAD: Andhra Pradesh government wants couples to take an AIDS test before marriage. Chief minister Y S Rajasekhara Reddy said on Tuesday that the government would pass a law to make pre-marital HIV test mandatory in the state.,State health minister K Rosaiah had announced in the assembly in November last year that a legislation would be adopted. Reddy denied that the proposed law would violate human rights. ,"Human rights of innocent young women married off to HIV positive men who hide their status should be given higher priority,"he said.,"I do not understand what kind of rights'discourse allows innocent persons to get infected by the dreaded disease,"the CM said at a function to launch a public-private project for HIV/AIDS infected children.,The government will launch an awareness programme at the district level before passing the law, officials said.

Title: Andhra to mandate pre-marital HIV testing: CM
article: Balasahyoga

Title: Blood may hold clue to HIV drug
article: NEW DELHI: A molecule found abundantly in the human blood could soon spearhead the fight against the AIDS virus. ,In a significant breakthrough, German scientists have found a protein in human blood that blocks multiple strains of HIV, even those resistant to existing medications. ,The Virus-Inhibitory Peptide (VIRIP) inhibited 60 strains of HIV from infecting cells in laboratory tests, a discovery that could lead to the development of new HIV/AIDS drugs. ,Announced in the journal 'Cell' by researchers from the University of Ulm on Friday, VIRIP was found to target a sugar molecule which HIV uses to infect a host cell. ,VIRIP specifically targeted a region in the peptide, which is usually buried in the viral envelope that becomes exposed only when the virus enters the cell and makes the first direct contact between the viral particle and host cell. ,Thus, VIRIP plays an essential role in the ability of HIV to fuse with and infect its hosts immune cells. ,Scientists have believed for long that molecules in the blood carry inhibitory effect on HIV, but had failed till now to pinpoint which molecules provided such promise. ,So the team sifted through one million blood proteins and finally found fragments of VIRIP to have anti-HIV impact. ,Making a slight change in its amino acid components made it more effective, boosting its anti-HIV potency by 100-fold. What makes HIV special and dangerous is that it is quite good at adapting resistance to drugs. ,Many of the virus surface proteins â€” natural targets for inhibitory drugs â€” mutate at a very fast face. ,"The findings reveal a new target for inhibiting HIV that remains fully active against viral strains that are resistant to other drugs. VIRIP may stall and control HIV-1 replication in infected individuals. This promises to be highly suitable for development of a new class of HIV-1 inhibitors targeting the highly conserved fusion protein," the researchers concluded. ,There are now over 20 different HIV drugs in use. But the treatments fall into one of four categories based on their modes of action. What's worse, a growing number of HIV strains are becoming drug resistant. ,HIV resistance to one drug can lead to resistance to other drugs in the same class. ,"The world needs a variety of drug classes because multi-drug resistant viruses are starting to show up more and more. In at least some industrialised countries, it is already a severe problem," said Frank Kirchhoff of the University of Ulm. ,According to latest WHO estimates, nearly 40 million people worldwide are living with HIV/AIDS. ,Close to 4 million people became infected with HIV in 2006, and the virus was responsible for about 3 million deaths last year alone. ,kounteya.sinha@timesgroup.com

Title: HIV+ dentist, mother held for 'infecting' wife
article: NAGPUR: A Lucknow-based HIV-affected dental surgeon and his mother were arrested on a complaint lodged by his wife's parents alleging that their daughter got infected with the deadly virus after the marriage, police said on Saturday. ,Harshwardhan Chaturvedi, working with Babu Jagjivanram Dental College and Hospital in Lucknow, and his mother Asha were arrested from their residence early this week, they said. His wife's parents, who reside here, had lodged the complaint with Dhantoli police last month alleging that the dentist married their daughter in 2000 without disclosing that he is an HIV positive and they came to know about it after her health started deteriorating. ,Chaturvedi and his mother were arrested in Lucknow and produced before a local court here on Friday which remanded them to judicial custody till April 22. ,Police have booked the dentist's father Prakash Chaturvedi and sister Jaya, who are absconding, in connection with the case.

Title: WHO prescribes HIV testing for all
article: MUMBAI: The World Health Organisation (WHO) has rolled out a new recipe to fight the HIV\AIDS epidemic: doctors should urge all their patients to undergo the HIV test rather than recommending it only to a few. Of course, people who don't want to undergo the test can choose to opt out.,On Wednesday, the WHO unveiled its latest recommendation- a far cry from its older module of seeking voluntary testing for HIV\AIDS-ostensibly to identify the 'silent epidemic'. Persons who don't know they are infected (and WHO believes there are millions who don't) will thus know their status, take steps to not infect others and seek timely help, goes the new WHO logic.,In New Delhi, NACO (National AIDS Control Organisation) secretary K Sujatha Rao welcomed the new guidelines. "We are positive about it. What is wrong with doctors advising patients to test for HIV?" she asked. "We can't stretch the confidentiality clause to the point that it affects the patient's health." Indian patients reach hospitals too late for any help to be provided. "Such a recommendation would only help us treat patients," she added.,While NACO now brainstorms on how to roll out the new recommendations and tackle the ethical issues, many public health experts in India are not sure about the mandate. "We have to use such guidelines intelligently," says Dr R D Lele, who is credited with identifying and treating the first HIV-positive patient of India over 20 years ago. "We only have to target sexually-active persons in the age group of 16 to 45 years, drug users and patients who have undergone blood transfusions," he says. "What is the point of asking a 65-year-old patient with cough and cold to undergo the test?",Moreover, as Dr Lele points out, if the test is offered routinely to all patients, there is a danger of false positives. "The HIV test is known to give false positive in case of patients suffering from malaria or chronic liver disease.",In India, there also is the problem of stigma attached to the HIV diagnosis. In Africa, the attitude is different considering that the epidemic has wiped out tens of thousands in their productive age group. In the US, the government is trying to implement the Centers for Diseases Control recommendation for annual testing for people in the age group of 16-35 years.,But in Kolkata, the staff of the Calcutta Medical College Hospital refused to touch the body of a young AIDS patient who died there two days ago. The extent of stigma attached to the HIV\AIDS tag is still immense. "A couple of months back, a pregnant woman died outside a government hospital in Indore. In Lucknow, a renal failure patient who was HIV-positive had to wait for 16 hours before activists could get him a hospital bed," pointed out HIV rights activist-writer Bobby Ramakant from Lucknow.,Experts recommend that India should first put in place the many checks advised in the WHO guidelines: counselling before and after the HIV tests, introduce universal precautions such as double gloves for doctors and medical staff treating HIV\AIDS patients, etc. "We first have to work towards reducing the stigma towards HIV\AIDS in healthcare settings," says Ramakant.,Akila Shivdas from the Centre for Advocacy & Research (CFAR), which has been working in the field of HIV\AIDS advocacy, felt WHO's new recommendations are a sureshot prescription at normalising the epidemic. "The WHO idea is that by not according HIV\AIDS a special category, the epidemic can be normalised. But this normalisation process can't begin from the top, it has to start from within the community," she advised.,She points out to Thursday's news about the emergence of new HIV\AIDS hotspots in Uttar Pradesh and Bihar. "We now have small towns and villages with 1% incidence of HIV in pregnant women. This is considered high. If the testing is made mandatory in such areas without the proper buildup, it can have a disastrous effect.",The WHO team agrees that the shift from voluntary testing to provider-driven testing is drastic. "This is radical in the sense that things have to change," said WHO HIV/AIDS director Kevin De Cock. "Across the world, people with HIV are flowing through healthcare settings, not being diagnosed and not being offered the advantages of knowing their status.",But it remains to be seen if the formula will work in India, in the manner it is meant to.

Title: One out of 100 adults in India HIV-positive
article: NEW DELHI: India might be a low prevalence country for AIDS with only 0.9% of the adult population estimated to be infected with HIV. But in numbers, the situation looks grave with nearly 1 out of 100 adults in the country being HIV-positive.,In Bihar and Uttar Pradesh, the task of raising awareness about HIV is especially difficult due to the high proportion of rural population and relatively low levels of literacy. In Bihar, nearly 90% of the population lives in villages. In Uttar Pradesh, the figure is 79%. A particular problem is the literacy levels of females in both states. In Bihar, only one-third of females were literate at the time of the 2001 Census, as were 42% in Uttar Pradesh.,Despite such obstacles, awareness of HIV, how it spreads and ways to avoid it have risen in both states, according to bilingual HIV statistical chartbooks on the situation of HIV/AIDS in India, Bihar and Uttar Pradesh brought out by the Population Foundation of India, New Delhi, and Population Reference Bureau (PRB), Washington DC. The books were released at a seminar organised on Saturday. According to the charts, testing for HIV prevalence at sentinel sites in Bihar and UP has shown that HIV infection is spreading in the states, although the overall level of prevalence appears to be low at present.,Women are the most vulnerable to AIDS and yet their knowledge of the deadly disease is abysmally low. India's most scientific survey â€” the National Family Health Survey III, which for the first time came up with trend data on HIV/AIDS-related behaviour â€” has made some startling revelations.

Title: 'Incorrect figures of HIV cases in India'
article: NEW DELHI: The number of Indians infected with the HIV in the country is substantially lower than the current official estimate of 5.2 million, according to National AIDS Control Organisation (NACO) and UNAIDS.,NACO attributed the dip in the prevalence level among women sex workers and in antenatal clinics, especially in southern states, that have brought the figure down.,"The survey is still on, but early trends have shown that the figure is much lower," a senior NACO official said today.,Though, he refused to reveal the figures, he said they have come to conclusion because the prevalence level among women sex workers has gone down.,Analysis of existing sentinel data has shown that prevalence in antenatal clinics has shown a decline in some southern states -- Tamil Nadu, Karnataka and Andhra Pradesh -- which are the high-risk states.,The same trend was also seen in Maharashtra.,"This time, we are sure of our figures because the sentinel sites have increased from 728 to 1162," he said.,Denis Broun, country coordinator of UNAIDS, agreed that the previous figure of 5.7 million could be an "exaggeration".,UNAIDS had maintained that there was 5.7 million people living with HIV in India, while the government had insisted on the figure of 5.2 million.,"I could now say that the earlier numbers were exaggerated as compared to the current trends, which is showing a substantially low figure," Broun said.

Title: Treat HIV patients with dignity: Justice Yacoob
article: MUMBAI: Most persons suffering from HIV-AIDS have done nothing wrong to get infected with the disease and should be treated like humans, especially at their workplaces, Justice Z M Yacoob of the Constitutional Court of South Africa said on Tuesday.,"It is a serious epidemic and there is less awareness about it. Most of those infected with the disease have nothing to do with sex workers," Yacoob told a meeting organised by the India Centre for Human Rights and Law.,"Since persons suffering from the disease are getting better medical treatment during the past 10 years, there is a need to change the mindset and treat them like humans at workplaces," he said.,"There are several people suffering from the disease who have never seen sex workers and children who are suffering have not done anything wrong. Then why the discrimination?" he asked.,Recently, a South African airline was ordered by the court to take up the issues of employees being treated for the dreaded disease.

Title: New test for HIV resistance developed
article: PUNE: An indigenous, low-cost "HIV drug resistance test" to help physicians detect resistance to drugs among HIV patients and plan better medical intervention has been developed in Pune.,Developed by Pune-based GeneOmbio Technologies and HIV expert Dr Sanjay Pujari, the new test will be commercially available from next month.,"Similar tests currently available in the market are priced around Rs 25,000. Our test will cost less than Rs 10,000," said Pratap Mukhopadhyaya, chief executive and head of geneOmbio.,In order to validate the test internationally, samples from the National Reference Laboratory in Sydney will be regularly received for testing, Mukhopadhyaya said.,Plans are now afoot to file a patent for this product, he said.,GeneOmbio is a contract research organisation specialising in providing customised DNA-based service and has been promoted by the Science and Technology Park, Pune.,HIV drug resistance testing is gaining popularity due to the continuing spread of HIV and the emergence of drug-resistant strains of the virus. According to its promoters, the new test will enable physicians to design a tailor-made second line regimen for HIV patients after analysing which drugs have shown resistance and why in the first line of treatment. ,"We will be able to get exact information as to which anti-retroviral (anti-HIV) drugs are developing resistance after doing the test," Dr Pujari said. ,So far, the test has been carried out on 45 patients here.

Title: HIV+ children face boycott in Kerala school
article: PAMPADY: Five HIV positive children in Mar Dionysius Primary school in Kerala's Kottayam district face a boycott as parents of most of the students on Monday refused to send their children to the institution and even threatened to withdraw their wards.,Only three children attended classes in the school here as parents continued to protest the presence of the five afflicted children. The Parents-Teachers Association (PTA), which met on Monday, formed a five-member committee to take a decision within three days on their future course of action, said the school manager, Paulose Mar Pachomios Thirumeni.,The HIV+ students, studying in classes two and three, also did not turn up as the vehicle carrying them to school had developed some complaints, said authorities of 'Asha Kiran', the rehabilitation centre where the children are staying.,The five children were refused permission to continue with their studies in the school in December last year after parents of other students came to know about their HIV status. After the state government put pressure on the school authorities, the students were re-admitted on June 18 this year.

Title: 'Bihar among worst HIV-hit states'
article: PATNA: Regional Aids Training Centre and Network in India (RATNEI) medical director Dr Diwakar Tejaswi said here on Friday Bihar and eastern UP are among the worst HIV and Aids-hit states of the country.,Addressing the closing ceremony and certificate distribution function of RATNEI's five-day advance training on "Aids and Anti-Retroviral Therapy", Tejaswi said according to the combined records of doctors, sentinel sites and mobile awareness and testing (MAT), there are about one lakh HIV positive cases in Bihar and this number is continuously on the rise.,In MAT round-1, 80,000 HIV positive cases were detected in Sitamarhi alone. One of the main causes of concern is that about 87 per cent of the affected patients are not aware of their status, Tejaswi said and added that every person should get himself tested even if he/she are not susceptible to HIV. The number of ART centres should be increased for the benefit of the patients, as, at present, there are only two ART centres in Bihar, Tejaswi said.,HIV positive children are a cause of serious concern as most of them have inherited the disease from their parents. To reduce the number of such children, the programme, "Prevention of Parent to Child transmission", needs to be strengthened. The use of condoms should be popularised among people not only in cities, but also in rural areas, he added.,Quoting a survey report, Tejaswi said only 18 per cent of the rural women of the state have heard of the HIV/Aids. Areas like Muzaffarpur, Kishanganj and Purnia, which have high incidence of Aids, mostly among the migrant labourers, must be made aware of the preventive measures like use of condoms, he said.,Chief guest Dr Gopal Prasad Sinha appraised the work done by RATNEI for the cause of HIV positive and Aids patients. He urged doctors to participate in such training programmes.

Title: Docs suspended for refusing to deliver HIV+ woman's baby
article: MEERUT/NEW DELHI: The National Aids Control Organisation (Naco) team, headed by Dr Damodar Bachani, (Joint Director), which visited Meerut Medical College - where Rais Abbas claimed to have forced to perform the delivery of his son after doctors refused to help is HIV-positive wife - has said in its official report to Naco Director General K Sujatha Rao that the delivery was conducted by doctors on the night of June 27. ,Meanwhile, the Uttar Pradesh government on Friday suspended two doctors of the hospital for refusing to handle the delivery. ,Dr Urmila and Dr Abhilasha Gupta were suspended after they were found prima facie guilty of denying treatment to the HIV+ pregnant woman, official sources said in Lucknow. ,Abbas's wife, 35-year-old Sunita, told ,TOI,,'' My husband brought me to the hospital labour room at about 11 pm on Wednesday. They duly admitted me. But, then I told them that I am HIV+ and their attitude changed entirely. I was immediately segregated, and put in the septic labour room, where I have been the only patient since I arrived here.'' ,Abbas, a high school drop-out who spray-paints moulded sculptures for a living, dittoed this. He added that he was asked to buy several pairs of gloves from the market, besides a blade. Then, ''while the doctors stood by and issued instructions, I carried out my wife's delivery, petrified of doing anything wrong. I have three daughters, and now I have been blessed with a son.'' ,Abbas had fallen in love with the Hindu widow and mother of two daughters and married her 12 years ago. This is Sunita's fifth baby. While she is HIV+, Abbas claims to be ''perfectly healthy'' himself.,Asked why the doctors did not carry out the procedure themselves, he said, ''They said it requires a special suit in the case of an HIV+ person. That they had used up their only such suit in an earlier HIV+ delivery case. I do not really blame them now because they tell me HIV is very dangerous and spreads very easily.'' ,His wife had been diagnosed as HIV+ after a test was carried out on her when a throat infection refused to heal. That was five years ago. And, she was being treated at the medical college's oncology department. The college principal, Dr Deepti Bisht and the head of gynaecology, Dr Abhilasha Gupta, couldn't be contacted, despite repeated attempts. ,But, Meerut chief development officer, Ms Roshan Jacob, who was handed the preliminary probe, told TOI, ''There were apparently four PG medical students, and a nurse and an ayah, in attendance. The medical college claims the medical staff carried out the delivery. The woman disputes it. There's a question mark on what really transpired.'' ,But, Jacob admitted that things were quite out of place. ''For instance, patients' attendants should not have to buy gloves or blades or other items themselves. ,The doctor on duty in the ward did not come for the delivery. Proper facilities were not available in the septic labour room. And, worst of all, the entire staff showed a deplorable insensitivity in a case demanding care and compassion. ,Also, there was no coordination between different departments, or the labour war-d would earlier have known the mother's HIV status.'' ,On July 28 last year, TOI had carried a report of a terminal HIV+ patient having been tied to his bed in the medical college. He died days later. ,State Health Minister Lalji Verma assured prompt and just action. ''If the incident is true, the guilty will not be spared,'' he declared. However, the Naco probe team has a different take on the events. ,Team member Bachani said Sunita, who has been on ART treatment for HIV in the same hospital, was transferred from a general labour ward to a septic labour room meant for patients of infectious diseases like Hep B, C and HIV after her HIV status became public. ,This led Abbas to believe that they were being discriminated upon.,Bachani added," After he made the allegations, we interrogated Abbas who kept changing his name to Sonu, making us a little suspicious. After several hours of inquiry, he finally admitted that he did not deliver the child. Initially he had said he had assisted the doctors. But when probed further, he could not recall how a delivery was conducted. Abbas has now given us a written statement confirming this.'' ,According to Naco, Abbas has formally withdrawn his complaint against the doctors and the child has been put on Neviripine - a prophylactic treatment to stop mother-to-child transmission of HIV.

Title: 'Docs wouldn't touch my HIV+ wife'
article: MEERUT/NEW DELHI: A man has claimed he was forced to perform the delivery of his son himself at Meerut Medical College after doctors refused to touch his wife upon learning that she was HIV-positive.,However, a two-member team from National Aids Control Organisation sent to probe the incident has submitted a written statement of the alleged victims â€” Rais Abbas and his mother-in-law â€” in which Abbas said he hadn't conducted the delivery himself.,But contradicting his own statement, Abbas told TOI he had to carry out the delivery, with gloves and a blade he purchased from a chemist. Abbas claimed he even cut the umbilical chord, tied it up and cleaned and disinfected the area â€” while the doctors gave instructions from a distance.

Title: Will HIV+ Telgi survive full term?
article: PUNE: Will the kingpin of the stamp paper case, Abdul Karim Ladsab Telgi, survive 13 years in prison to serve the full term of his sentence?,According to Telgi's counsel Milind Pawar, his client who is HIV positive was found to have a CD4 count of 23 in April this year. A CD4/CD8 test is conducted to measure the strength of the immune system of a person already diagnosed with ,HIV infection. The count is sought when the person with HIV shows signs of a weakened immune system. He is also ,diabetic.,"The test was carried out at the Sassoon General Hospital," Pawar said, adding, "I've no clue about the latest CD4 status." Telgi, who was hospitalised early last year, underwent a similar test, both at Sassoon and the ,National AIDS Research Institute (Nari).,While Sassoon reported his CD4 count as 204, Nari said that Telgi's CD4 count was 180. According to HIV expert Dr Sanjay Pujari, the normal count in a healthy, HIV negative adult can vary, but is usually between 300 and 1,500 CD4 cells/per cubic millimetre.,"If Telgi's count is 23 cells per cubic millimetre, that means his health is sinking," Pujari said. Pawar, on the other hand said his client currently seems to be in good health, but deteriorates "intermittently".,Telgi's lawyers had earlier moved an application in the MCOCA court, praying that authorities at the Yerawada central prison, where he is currently lodged, should submit all the previous health records of Telgi to the court and a team of medical experts should be formed to examine him.

Title: Court notice over HIV+ students' plight
article: THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Taking note of the plight of five HIV-affected students facing boycott at Mar Dionysius School in Pampady, Kerala High Court on Thursday issued notice to the school management and its Parent Teachers Association.,A bench of chief justice H L Dattu and justice K A Sankaran issued the notice on a petition filed by an NGO, which sought the court's intervention to ensure that the children are able to continue their study. A special messenger will deliver the notice.
