The case will now come up for hearing next week.,The NGO also sought direction to the government to frame a policy or law regarding treatment of HIV-affected people.,The HC notice comes a day after the NHRC sought details of the matter from the state government.,The children, who are in Class II and Class III, have not been able to attend classes due to the alarm raised by parents of other students. In fact, they had to discontinue their studies in the school last December after fears expressed by the PTA. But following government intervention, they were taken back. However, the controversy rose once again as the school reopened this academic year. The school authorities have pleaded helplessness saying they cannot afford to displease the other parents and children. The parents are also adamant that if the HIV-affected children were allowed with their wards, they would rather withdraw their kids from the school.

Title: HIV-positive man ends life
article: MUMBAI: Fed up with complications arising from his HIV-positive condition, a 32-year-old man committed suicide by hanging himself from a pipe on the terrace of Holy Family Hospital in Bandra West on Monday. ,Police sources said the victim was a resident of Nallasopara and worked as a driver with a private company. He was diagnosed with this condition about two years ago, and was taking treatment from a medical practitioner.,On Sunday, his condition deteriorated and he got himself admitted to Holy Family Hospital. In the evening, his wife left for their home and the victim was alone in his room. Around midnight, he is reported to have become restless and even approached a doctor saying he was feeling uncomfortable. The doctor had advised him to relax and then the man returned to his room.,On Monday morning, when the staff went to the terrace to clean it, they found his body hanging from a pipe. The hospital administration immediately informed the Bandra police, and the body was sent for an autopsy.,AIDS consultant Dr I S Gilada said in most such cases, patients are in need of proper counselling by hospital staff, without which they may plunge into depression. "If the patient is suffering from any kind of problem, this must also be considered by counsellors," he said.,According to him, with medical treatment now HIV patients are able to live eight years or more, after being diagnosed with the condition.

Title: BPOs may screen recruits for HIV
article: NEW DELHI: It is possible that a job interview with a BPO firm could in the future entail a HIV/AIDS test. And once recruited, you could also be subjected to random alcohol testing. Players in the BPO industry, which has a large youth employee base, are considering HIV/AIDS tests as part of the recruitment process. ,No final decision has been taken. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½A few BPOs have approached me informally and asked if they could introduce HIV/AIDS testing for employees. They also discussed testing employees for alcohol which makes sense as liquor affects employee performance,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Nasscom president Kiran Karnik told ET.,Asked about the rationale for considering HIV/ AIDS testing, Mr Karnik said, ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s a changing world. The point of all medical tests is to find out if a person is, in any way, unfit for the job. It is individual company policy as to what tests are conducted. As far as Nasscom's policies go, we have a Nasscom Foundation that disseminates information on non-discriminatory HIV/AIDS policies at the workplace.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½,It is learnt that a leading Gurgaon-based BPO has told its senior executives that such tests are in the offing. When contacted, the company spokesperson refused to confirm it but said, ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½There are many Gurgaon-based BPOs that have had trouble with employees turning up drunk at work. These companies are looking at testing employees for alcohol.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Given the sensitivities attached to HIV/AIDS testing, it remains to be seen whether BPOs, or anyone else for that matter, can make such testing compulsory. ,Terming HIV/AIDS testing as ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½discriminatoryï¿½ï¿½ï¿½, Business Process Industry Association of India president Sam Chopra said, ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Iï¿½ï¿½ï¿½d support the alcohol-testing measure. There is currently an understanding that the security personnel would bar inebriated employees from entering the premises.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s not known whether BPOs are considering testing employees for alcohol on a random or regular basis. Companies that ET spoke to said they havenï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t faced any case of intoxicated employees or liquor consumption in the workplace but pointed towards ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½othersï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ in the fraternity hit by the bottle. ,Recently, a Faridabad-based BPO employee, killed two children and injured four others in south Delhi allegedly under the influence of alcohol. Another leading Hyderabad-based BPO said the idea was interesting but was not being considered by the firm.,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Most employers have best practices which include prohibition of alcohol consumption in the office premises. If the employee manual makes it clear that an employee canï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t be found intoxicated in office or consuming liquor, the employer is entitled to test the employee,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ says Nasscom vice-president Ameet Nivsarkar. According to Nasscom projections, IT-enabled services firms and BPOs together had about 5.5 lakh people on their payrolls in fiscal 2006-07.

Title: Going places a new way to battle HIV
article: NAGPUR: Flying abroad to attend international seminars, taking management courses in premier institutions and holding top posts. People in the city diagnosed with HIV are now going placesâ€”a new way of battling the deadly disease.,Last month, a patient from the city visited Stockholm to attend a global meet on HIV/AIDS. The 23-year old woman, Rama (name changed), also claims to be the only HIV positive person in the entire world to attend this seminar held on June 4 and 5. The delegates from participating countries had assured to bring an infected person along, but it was only from India that Rama attended the seminar as a patient herself. Unfortunately, she was not able to make the presentation in the meeting as her flight was delayed and by the time she could make it to the venue, the time slot allotted to her was over.,The meetâ€”ASEM workshop on HIV/AIDSâ€”was organised by Asia Europe Meeting (ASEM). This is an international forum with members from the European Union and ASEAN, and takes up various issues like AIDS.,Her trip was sponsored by MAMATA another organisation working for HIV patients. "What's worse, the mother of one was facing several other problems too. Her plight as well as the confidence she has got contributed to her selection for the seminar," said Aasha (name changed), who is also HIV positive. Both of them are members of Sanjeevani, a city-based organisation started by HIV positive persons. ,When contacted, Rama said though she could not make the presentation the seminar exposed her to a whole new world. A gesture by a woman photographer in the seminar deeply moved her. "It was shivering cold. Though she knew that I am an HIV positive person, the photographer took off her coat and made me wear it. This is one gesture which I would have, probably, not experienced back home," she said. ,Back in India, Rama plans to implement the Swedish approach to tackling the disease. According to this approach, if a person is found infected, then the doctors track down all his partners to find out if others have been infected too. This system helps in containing the disease to a great extent, she said.

Title: Meet on HIV/AIDS awareness opens
article: PATNA: A two-day workshop on HIV/Acquired Immuno Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS) awareness programme, jointly organised in collaboration with Jan Shikshan Sansthan (JSS), Asian Development Research Institute and UNESCO, New Delhi, started here on Tuesday.,In the inaugural session, JSS, ADRI director Vikas C Jaipuriar spoke about the seriousness of global, national and local status of HIV/AIDS infections with the help of data. ,He said it is high time people became aware of HIV/AIDS not only for themselves but also for others.,In the first session, Nishat Fatima as a resource person said though HIV infects an individual; it spreads as a social problem. Others who addressed the gathering included Dr Sujata Kumari, BN Patnaik, Anjani Kumar Verma and Sanjeev Kumar.

Title: Pre-marriage HIV test: Docs divided on issue
article: NAGPUR: "Punish them," cries Archana Chaturvedi while recuperating at a city hospital. Suffering from multiple complications due to her HIV positive status, Archana came to know about the infection only after five years of her marriage to a Lucknow-based dentist. ,Alarmed by the rising HIV cases in the city, local doctors feel that need for a pre-marriage test should be advocated among the citizens, especially for the marriageable youths. On the lines of Kerala where testing HIV has been made mandatory prior to the marriage, city doctors feel that the concept would augur well for the prospective brides and grooms. ,"No one has any right to destroy the life of others and in legal point of view, one can be held responsible for infecting the other," said deputy commissioner of police Suresh Mekala of Zone-I. Apart from being a medical graduate, DCP Mekala also handled the case of Archana Chaturvedi. Husband and mother-in-law of Archana were arrested by Dhantoli police station. Archana's family has approached high court for more stringent punishment for her husband and in-laws. ,"HIV should be made mandatory which should be supplemented by a regular medical check-ups and pre-marriage counseling for a better post marriage life," said Dr Satish Muley. ,"The city is witnessing a spate of divorce cases and it is high time that the precautions are duly taken," said Dr Muley, who opined that NGOs and marriage bureaus should take more interest in spreading the awareness among the masses about the pre-marriage medical tests and counselling. ,"Though these (HIV tests and counseling) are positive suggestions but masses would find it difficult to accept," said Sunil Gangwani, who runs a franchise of web-based marriage counseling centre. ,"Though I support pre-marriage tests but my vote will go for blood grouping before marriage to take guard against thalassaemia," said Gangwani. ,Dr Nalini Kurvey, president, Nagpur Obstetric and Gynaecological Society, also admitted that there is a spurt of HIV cases in the city in the recent time and the society needs to open up to the idea of accepting the responsibility of opting for pre-marriage medical check-ups including HIV tests. ,"It is absolutely the need of the hour," said Dr Kurvey. "The tendencies of hiding facts are often proved to be fatalistic but still people tend to do such things in the society risking lives," she said. ,Attached to NKP Salve Institute of Medical Science, Dr Sunita Ghike feels otherwise. Though she claimed to have witnessed a rising cases of HIV infection among the spouses, who has contracted the diseases from their husband, Dr Ghike opined that such pre-marriage tests would hardly help. ,"The HIV test would fail if the infected person is in window period, which is very dangerous. No tests can indicate anything when the patient is in window period," said Dr Ghike. ,"If both the prospective groom and bride mutually decides and consent to go for such tests and counseling, there is no problem. It would be not feasible to force anyone to undergo any tests," said Dr Ghike.,soumitra2.bose@timesgroup.com

Title: HIV infection ups lung cancer risk
article: Independent of cigarette smoking, infection with HIV, the virus that causes AIDS, is associated with an elevated risk for developing lung cancer, a study shows.,Dr Gregory D Kirk from the Bloomberg School of Public Health, Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, Maryland and colleagues evaluated lung cancer deaths among participants in injection drug users followed since 1998 as part of an AIDS study. ,There were 27 lung cancer deaths among the 2,086 participants; 14 of the deaths occurred in HIV-infected subjects.

Title: Insurance cover for HIV+ likely
article: NEW DELHI: India's 2.5-million-strong HIV population will finally have an insurance policy to fall back on, once they develop full blown AIDS.,A Chennai-based private insurance firm, Star Health and Allied Insurance Company, is set to launch India's first-ever health cover for HIV-positive people, early next week.,Under the scheme, an HIV-positive patient with a CD-4 count not less than 500 cells per cubic millimetre of blood, will have to pay an annual premium of Rs 3,000. ,Once he or she becomes a full blown AIDS patient, the company will pay a one time compensation of Rs 50,000 back to them. The company has also tied up with 1,800 hospitals and labs where it will conduct the CD-4 test of HIV patients seeking insurance cover. ,The CD-4 count test is used to gauge immunity levels of an HIV-infected patient and to assess whether damage caused by the virus requires life-saving anti-retroviral therapy (ART). ,The CD-4 count is used in combination with the viral load test which measures level of HIV in blood. The test is ordered when a person is first diagnosed with HIV as part of a baseline measurement. Tests are repeated every six months. The CD-4 count in healthy adults ranges from 500 to 1,500 cells per cubic millimetre of blood.,In HIV infected people, it goes down by 60 cells per cubic millimetre of blood per year as HIV progresses. ART is administered when an HIV-positive person registers a CD-4 count under 200. Speaking to TOI, chief of Star Health V Jagannathan said, "At present, we have fixed the premium at Rs 3,000. However, we plan to revise that and lower the price in the next renewal.",He added, "This health insurance cover is awaiting Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority approvals. We hope to get them by this weekend. All that a patient has to do is come to us for the insurance cover. The blood tests will be conducted by us." According to Naco, of the 2.5 million people with HIV in India, nearly 3 lakh at present suffer from full blown AIDS.,Reacting to this move, K K Abraham, chief of Indian Network of People Living with HIV, told TOI, "For someone with CD-4 count above 500 following proper treatment regimen and good nutrition, transmission from HIV to AIDS will take nearly 15-16 years. The company, therefore, has done good research. However, that such an insurance cover is being launched at all is a great sign for India's HIV population. At present, no such cover exists. Hopefully, many other companies will come up with similar schemes for HIV-positive people.",Currently, AIDS insurance is not offered in India and insurers have complained that lack of representative data has kept them from venturing into the segment. Globally, the government of Uganda was the first to offer AIDS insurance to 25,000 miners. Star Health had recently come out with a Diabetes safe insurance policy. It covered already known diabetics against risks arising out of specified complications. The policy cover ranged from Rs 50,000 to Rs 4 lakh.

Title: Patient tests +ve, then -ve for HIV
article: MUMBAI: A patient's HIV-test result has created a storm in the Maharashtra government-run J J Hospital at Byculla in Mumbai. ,The patient, who was put through the HIV test on June 29 at a private laboratory just outside the hospital as a routine probe before surgery, showed positive for the virus. But another test done subsequently at J J Hospital showed his status to be negative.,Questions are now being raised as to why the first test was done at the private laboratory.,The flip-flop was discussed at the hospital's Board of Visitors' Committee meeting on Thursday and an inquiry was instituted, officials said.,Flip-flops in HIV tests â€” medically known as "false positives or false negatives" â€” are known and associated with mental trauma. The World Health Organisation has even drawn out a regimen for HIV testing: a patient has to undergo three tests over a period of six months before he or she can be labelled as HIV-positive.,On June 29, the patient â€” whose identity was not disclosed â€” was rushed to J J Hospital at 10 pm with a ruptured tendon. As the hospital's laboratory was closed, the resident doctor on duty sent the patient's samples for HIV test to a nearby private laboratory. "This result was positive," a doctor said.,It was only when the patient, during recovery after the emergency operation, visited the skin outpatients' department, that he was advised to undergo another test within J J Hospital. ,This time, the result was negative. A senior doctor said: "On June 29, a rapid test done at the private laboratory showed the patient was HIV-positive. We, however, used the standard `test to determine his status and he tested negative." J J Hospital dean P Shingare confirmed the sequence of events.,"Such discrepancy can traumatise a patient," said Syed Ahmed, chairman of the hospital's Board of Visitors' Committee, which has prominent citizens as its members, before seeking an inquiry.,J J Hospital superintendent H Jadhav said the inquiry would establish why the sample was sent out for testing at all. "A team of expert doctors will scrutinise the patient's HIV status," he added.

Title: Inquiry into HIV flip-flop at JJ
article: MUMBAI: A patient's HIV-test result has created a storm in the state government-run J J Hospital at Byculla.,The patient, who was put through the HIV test on June 29 at a private establishment just outside the hospital as a routine examination before surgery, showed positive for the virus. But another test done subsequently at J J Hospital showed his status to be negative. Questions are now being raised as to why the first test was done at a private establishment.,The flip-flop was discussed at the hospital's board of visitors' committee meeting on Thursday and an inquiry was instituted, officials said.,Flip-flops in HIV testsâ€”medically known as "false positives or false negativesâ€”are known and are associated with mental trauma. The World Health Organisation (WHO) has even drawn out a regimen for HIV testingâ€”a patient has to undergo three tests over a period of six months before he or she can be labelled HIV-positive.,On June 29, the patient, whose identity was not disclosed, was rushed to J J Hospital at 10 pm with a ruptured tendon. As the hospital's laboratory was closed at the late hour, the resident doctor on duty sent the patient's samples for HIV testing to a nearby private laboratory. "This result was positive, a doctor said.,And it was only when the patient, during recovery after the emergency operation, visited the skin outpatients' department that he was advised to undergo another test within J J Hospital. This time, the result was negative. A senior doctor said, "On June 29, a rapid test done at the private laboratory showed the patient was HIV-positive. We, however, used the standard Eliza test to determine his status and he tested negative. J J dean P Shingare confirmed the sequence of events.,The flip-flop was highlighted at a meeting of the board of visitors' committee of J J Hospital on Thursday. The committee comprises MLAs and prominent citizens. "Such discrepancy can traumatise a patient, said Syed Ahmed, chairman of the committee, before requesting an inquiry.,J J Hospital superintendent H Jadhav said the inquiry would try to establish why the sample was sent out for testing at all. "A team of expert doctors will scrutinise the patient's HIV status, he added.

Title: HIV positive undertrial attempts suicide in Muzaffarnagar
article: MUZAFFARNAGAR: An HIV positive undertrial tried to commit suicide by hanging at the district jail here.,An accused in a murder case, the prisoner had been segregated by jail authorities since he tested positive for HIV three months ago while undergoing treatment.,The inmate tried to commit suicide by hanging himself with his 'dhoti' on Saturday night but other prisoners raised an alarm, police said. He was taken to a hospital and his condition was stated to be serious.,The inmate was lodged in the jail since last one year.

Title: Indian businesses can gain by preventing spread of HIV: WB
article: WASHINGTON: Noting that a large number of employees of Indian industry are vulnerable to HIV, the World Bank has said the country's private sector stands to gain by supporting interventions aimed at preventing the virus from spreading at the workplace and in local communities. ,"As India emerges as a global economic power, it is important that Indian businesses pursue business practices and policies that are in the best interest of the community at large," Mariam Claeson, the World Bank's HIV/AIDS Coordinator for the South Asia Region said in a release. ,"Businesses have much to offer and to gain from early decisive action to prevent HIV and reduce the cost and social impact of AIDS," she added. ,The report "Corporate Responses to HIV/AIDS" says a large share of India's population, who are employees of Indian industry are vulnerable to HIV, and the disease affects primarily young and middle-aged adults during their peak productive years. ,It said AIDS has a direct impact on companies' profitability in hard hit countries. In the worst case scenario, the economic effects are observed in greater absenteeism and staff turnover, higher recruitment and training costs, and higher costs in medical care or insurance coverage, and retirement funds. ,"Even in countries with overall low HIV prevalence, such as India, the mere cost of treating people living with HIV and AIDS will be a huge economic and social burden to society. Early decisive action by companies, that reach a large share of the population at risk, pays off," it said.

Title: Trafficked women more prone to HIV
article: Journal of the American Medical Association

Title: Abandoned infant tests HIV negative
article: NOIDA: Fifteen-day-old Chhoti is unaware of the miraculous turn in her fortunes. The infant, who was tested HIV+ by a Ghaziabad pathology laboratory on August 4, has now been confirmed to be HIV free by more advanced confirmatory testing. Abandoned by her parents, taken up by another family who found her, only to be given up again to the police, and then belived to be HIV+, Chhoti seems to have live a lifetime in fifteen days.,A report of the SRL Ranbaxy Laboratory, at Andheri, Mumbai, has found no trace of HIV-1 or HIV-2 in a sample of Chhoti's blood which was sent there for HIV-DNA testing. The tiny survivor is now a star, with numerous childless couples queuing up to adopt her. Noida industrialist and social worker Sonia Kohli, who runs an NGO called Sahyog and in whose custody the Noida city magistrate has placed Chhoti, was inundated with requests to adopt the little girl on Saturday. This followed the airing of the news that Chhoti had been declared completely HIV free. ,What is heart-warming, however, is that, many of the couples volunteered to adopt Chhoti even when she had not been declared HIV free, according to Sonia Kohli." They were willing to pay for her treatment and stand by her in every way," said Kohli. "This time though, we will ensure that she gets responsible parents. Moreover, she is going to be properly and legally adopted." ,Meanwhile, Mala Sarin, wife of Ghaziabad medical representative Neeraj Sarin, who had allegedly taken Chhoti away from rickshaw puller Mintu Gupta, is not happy. Neeraj Sarin told Times City, "My wife has become extremely emotionally unstable after we returned the little girl. She is getting treatment from a Noida psychiatrist and we sometimes have to restrain her from running away somewhere. She has been bedridden ever since Chhoti was taken away. ,One cannot help loving that child but we had no choice. We wanted her to get the best possible help and treatment so we had to return her. How we wish we had got the confirmatory tests done ourselves." ,Mintu Gupta, the rickshaw-puller who first found Chhoti, said: "My wife has also become ill after having to give up the girl. ,We are a childless couple but I suppose the girl was not for us." Mintu refused to comment when asked whether he had been forced by a policeman to give the girl to Neeraj. There have been allegations that the officer, related to Sarin, had arranged for Gupta to get the child. Responding to rumours, Sarin denied that the police officer was related to him.,"He happened to be posted in Muzaffarnagar when I lived there," Sarin said.

Title: HIV cases on the rise in district
article: NAGPUR: There has been an alarming 60 per cent rise in the number of HIV infected patients undergoing treatment at the government medical college (GMC) here. While there were around 5,000 HIV-positive patients until January, there has been a whopping 3,000 more cases in the past six months alone.,A UNAIDS report released over six months ago had also mentioned that while the trend of HIV is more or less stable or diminishing in the rest of the country, it has shown a reverse trend in the region. ,However, the figures at GMC are just the tip of the iceberg and cannot determine the number of new infections. GMC is the only medical set-up in the district to have a anti-retroviral therapy (ART) centre. ,There are similar centres in GMCs of Yavatmal and Akola. The ART clinic in Nagpur also caters to the patients from neighbouring Chhattisgarh, Madhya Pradesh as well as Andhra Pradesh.,According to data available at ART clinic here, there were 5,200 patients in January 2007, which has grown close to 8,000 in July. What is worrying is that since April, the number of HIV admissions has risen to more than 400 in a month. ,Over half the patients are from Nagpur city or nearby areas while the rest are from other parts of district. ,Head of the GMC's medicine department Dr Harsha Salkar, said better road connectivity to the city has contributed to the problem due to the influx of truckers, who are a high risk group.,Increasing awareness about the disease is also one of the reasons for more patients coming forward for treatment, said a doctor.

Title: No one will be forced to undergo HIV test: Government
article: NEW DELHI: No citizen will be forced to undergo an HIV test, the Centre has told the Supreme Court putting an end to the debate on making such tests mandatory.,"The government feels that there is no public health rationale for mandatory testing of a person for HIV/AIDS," the Centre said in response to a court notice in a case where the Andhra Pradesh government had denied promotion to an HIV-positive constable. ,The high court had quashed the state's decision. Aware of the effect of such a decision on lakhs of government officials, the apex court had sought response from the Centre to the question on "whether a person found HIV+ could be considered for appointment as sub-inspector of police in contravention of the recruitment rules".,The health ministry, in its affidavit, said it was aware of the active debate in the country on the issue of mandatory testing of people suspected of carrying HIV infection. Refusing to side with those canvassing for a mandatory test, the ministry said such an approach could be counter-productive as it may scare away a large number of suspected cases from getting detected and treated. HIV testing carried out on a voluntary basis with appropriate pre-test and post-test counselling is considered a better strategy and is in line with WHO guidelines, it said.,The ministry said it was wrong to deny employment or promotion to anyone just because he had tested positive for HIV. "HIV-positive persons should be guaranteed equal rights to education and employment as other members of the society," it said. ,"HIV status of a person should be kept confidential and should not in any way affect his right to employment, position at workplace, marital relationship and other fundamental rights," the ministry said.,dhananjay.mahapatra@timesgroup.com

Title: 211 HIV+ cases in Kishanganj
article: KISHANGANJ: Bihar's border district of Kishanganj has the dubious distinction of having an alarming number of HIV positive cases. According to the latest official count, there are as many as 211 HIV positive cases across the district.,Bihar State Aids Control Society (BSACS) has already declared Kishanganj district a "high risk" zone in view of high number of HIV positive cases.,Kishanganj district, which shares common borders with Nepal and Bangladesh, was one of the seven districts in the country to be earmarked for the launch of UNICEF-sponsored Co-ordinated HIV/AIDS Response Through Capacity Building and Awareness (CHARCA) programme in 2002 because of the high number of HIV positive cases and the area's vulnerability to the dreaded disease. ,Though much has been done to spread awareness by the sponsors of CHARCA over the years, AIDS has not been checked.,Several campaigns for spreading awareness about AIDS are now underway.,The CHARCA co-ordinator Haroon Rasheed said huge migrating of labour force, illiteracy, lack of awareness and largescale trafficking were the prime reasons behind the spread of the disease in the district.,"Women are more susceptible to HIV virus as they had no command in terms of sex, early marriage, forced sex and unhygienic conditions," the CHARCA co-ordinator said.,Meanwhile, dilly-dallying by NF railways in extending toll free space on Kishanganj railway platform No 2 for information-cum-resource centre of CHARCA for sensitising migrant people about Aids is obstructing Aids awareness proghramme. Kishanganj DM M Saravanan had already made the request for the renewal of the same as early as April, 2007.,The Katihar division commercial manager (DCM), NFR said he had already intimated seniors that renewal of toll free space was the prerogative of the Railway Board. Last year, the sanction was allowed for one year which expired on August 23, 2007.

Title: Throw out HIV kids: Parents
article: BARUIPUR: Parents have demanded that a Baruipur primary school throw out children suspected to be HIV-,positive. The West Bengal Board of Primary Education has, however, stood its ground and refused to give in to ,the demand.,The incident is a virtual repeat of an episode in a remote Kerala village, where HIV-positive children were ostracised by parents and their wards last year. ,The vicious whisper campaign against the children was started about a fortnight ago by a local goon at Gobindapur village, 25 km from Kolkata. He incited some villagers into demanding the ouster of the students. These 'HIV-positive' students are residents of a home run by an NGO.,Things came to a head about a week ago, when some parents submitted a signed memorandum to the school authorities, demanding that the HIV-positive children be removed. ,"We cannot allow our wards to study with HIV-positive kids. They are a threat and will infect our children. The school must throw them out, failing which we will withdraw our children," the letter to the headmaster stated.,One of the signatories to the memorandum, Sikha Ghosh, acknowledged she had no idea what HIV-positive or AIDS meant â€” except that it was a dreaded disease that everyone should guard against. "I was told that my child would contract the disease if she came in contact with the affected children," she said.,Another parent, Ila-ub-Mollah, insisted he would withdraw his son if HIV-positive children continued to study in the school. "I don't want to take any risks," he said.,The irrational demand, fuelled by ignorance and mischief, is similar to the ostracisation campaign that had rocked a primary school in Pampady district in Kerala. In December, parents put pressure on school authorities to oust five HIV-positive children. A subsequent outcry from NGOs had forced the school to re-admit the children.,The school authorities in Baruipur, too, were faced with a dilemma and approached the primary education board. The latter saved the day with a tough stance. ,"Making such a demand is dangerous. It is a result of ignorance. That HIV is not contagious is not known to those making the outcry. We will try to explain the facts to them. If they still remain adamant, the administration will step in. No student will be removed from the school at any cost. We have to rise to this challenge," said board chairman Ashok Bandyopadhyay.,Local CPM MLA said the issue had been stoked by a handful. Pallal Ghosh, secretary of the NGO to which the children in the line of fire belong, termed the entire episode unfortunate. "It can be solved if we get a chance to speak and explain the situation to villagers. I have spoken to the DM," he said.

Title: Orphaned HIV+: Children no one wants
article: NEW DELHI: It's a ray of hope in an area of gloom. Recently, a 15-day-old baby, Chhoti, was found abandoned. Though rumoured to be HIV positive, many couples on hearing about her through the media, volunteered to adopt her. ,However, not many are as lucky as her. Most people don't come forward to adopt HIV positive children. Recently, an HIV positive woman in Chhattisgarh, driven by poverty, offered her newborn daughter for sale. But no one wanted the baby as she too was infected. Later, the local administration, which got to know about the issue, stopped her from selling the baby and made arrangements for her treatment. ,Says Sonia Kohli, who runs Sahyog, an NGO, and in whose custody Chhoti was, "Since the news was out in the media, people initially came forward to adopt Chhoti. When the hype died, people backed off. Even some doctors advised me against keeping the child. I have now given the child to a family, but I am sure that if Chhoti was HIV positive, nobody would have legally adopted her." ,Arun Dave, president, AIDS prevention club, Rajkot, corroborates, "Ever since we started working for the cause of AIDS, 18 years back, not even one family has volunteered to adopt an HIV positive child." ,In many cases, even when the child turns out to be negative later, people are scared to adopt. HIV positive children turn negative only until they are one-and-a-half years old. After that, it's believed their status doesn't change. But medical miracles do happen. Anyhow, adoption agencies have a definite role to play here â€” in convincing the families and educating them about the issue. "If we have a child who is HIV positive-turned-negative, we tell the family about the child. After counselling and making them understand the medical aspects, if they are still willing, they accept the child. However, this happens only once in a blue moon," says Madhavi Hegde Karandikar, adoption practitioner, Bal Asha, Mumbai. ,Such children are mostly adopted, either by rich parents and those settled abroad or foreigners. "Adopting an HIV positive child requires a lot of willpower. Moreover, social acceptance of such children is less in our country. Outside India, people are more educated about HIV," says Nilima Mehta, chairperson, Child Welfare Committee, Mumbai. ,"There is a social stigma attached to it. Even today, there is not much awareness about HIV. Not many even know the difference between HIV positive and AIDS. They are ignorant about how HIV is passed and so don't want their families and friends to know that the child was born with the virus," says Dave. ,Outside India, there are many organisations which have been successful in placing HIV positive children in permanent and foster homes. One such project is Children With AIDS Project of America, which seeks out adoptive parents for HIV infants and children. Its database has over 1,000 waiting families. ,Experts say there are no legal restrictions for adoption of HIV positive children. "We can give such children in adoption, provided there are families willing to take them and all documents are in place," says Wendy Andrews, adoption officer, Hope Foundation, New Delhi. Despite various measures taken by the government, people suffering from the disease still face stigma and isolation. A UNAIDS report claimed in 2006 that India had the largest number of people living with HIV/AIDS, an estimated 5.7 million. ,"Adopting a child involves knowledge within oneself that all children are equal, be they healthy or with special needs and therefore equally deserve security within a family. One should be better informed about the subject and make a choice knowing and understanding all these aspects," says Aloma Lobo, chairperson, IYC Community Centre, Bangalore. ,shanthi.selvarajan@timesgroup.com

Title: Woman fights for HIV+ students
article: KOLKATA: Had it not been for this plucky housewife from a little known village in South 24-Parganas, seven HIV-positive students studying in a local school might have been thrown out a long time ago. ,A large number of villagers were opposed to the boys being allowed in Kamini Debi Primary School in Gobindopur, some 25 km from Kolkata. They had even started a signature campaign demanding that the seven HIV-positive kids, who are supported by an NGO, be thrown out. The West Bengal Primary Education Board has so far refused to accept the demand. But much of the credit for this goes to Mitali Biswas.,Mitali, the mother of an eight-year-old-girl who studies in Class III of the same school, was the first to bring the matter to the notice of the school authorities. Her daughter had befriended one of the seven HIV-positive students and she found nothing wrong with it. She even welcomed them home.,"They used to spend most of the time together. One day she drank water from the same glass that her HIV-positive friend had used. Some senior students who saw this went to her and asked her why she drank from the same glass. They scared her that she would also contract the dreaded HIV. That day she came home crying and told me the entire incident,"said Mitali. ,The next day Mitali went to the school and told one of the teachers how students were being discriminated. ,"The students cannot be blamed. They had probably heard all this from their parents and were repeating it,"says Mitali. ,She herself never felt anything wrong with her daughter befriending an HIV-positive girl. "I have heard about the AIDS awareness campaign and even participated in some of the sessions organised by Unicef. It is surprising that many who people attended these sessions are still not convinced and are blind with superstition,"she said. ,What she says is true. There are villagers who refuse to budge their ground and insist that their children could get affected by studying in the same school with HIV positive students. The likes of Khairul Bibi, Bhutnath Mondol and Ajira Bibi do not want their children to continue in the same school. ,The primary education board with officials from the state health department want to meet the school authorities and the guardians to find out a solution. The meeting is likely to take place next week. The local CPM MLA Rahul Ghosh said that efforts are on to make the villagers see reason. ,"We have started talking to the villagers. Some of them have already backtracked and claim that they were forced to sign or misled. We have talked with the district administration as well. The villagers will be explained,"said Ghosh. ,The director health services Sanchita Bakshi refused to admit that the state's expenditure on Aids awareness campaigns had turned futile with villagers just 25 kms from Kolkata still living with wrong notions on the dreaded virus. ,"I have heard about the incident. Some people are deliberately misleading the people,"said the director of health services.

Title: School for kids, HIV-affected
article: BANGALORE: Here is some hope for abandoned HIV-positive kids. Women entrepreneurs and corporates from leading business houses have come together to start a school-cum-training centre for abandoned kids and HIV-positive persons. ,Needz, a trust working towards this, was inaugurated by health minister R Ashok on Sunday at the Infant Jesus Home for Children at Dodda Gubbi., ,Ashok said, initiatives to address the issues faced by HIV positive persons is great. But he advised the trust members against naming or running the institution exclusively for such people as it would separate them from the mainstream. ,The institution aims to adopt around 50 children, currently housed at the Infant Jesus Home for Children, and impart education to them. A vocational training institute will be part of the initiative. ,Mother Vinnigaurd, a German who runs the Infant Jesus Home for Children, said it is time Indians contributed to social causes and fight against the stigma. "I have been in India for more than three decades. Now, I am an Indian and I feel everyone should chip in for such a noble cause. We don't have to go to Germany or any other country. We have the capacity to address our concerns ourselves," she said.

Title: Hospital shock for HIV+ woman
article: BOLPUR: Her husband left her nine years ago. But that wasn't the biggest blow. Shefali Mondal's (name changed) world came crashing down when she was detected HIV+ two months ago. Her in-laws, who had been supportive since her husband left her, ostracised her and tried to force her to leave home.,A distraught Shefali tried to end her life on Friday by jumping in front of a train at Bolpur station. She was rushed to Bolpur subdivisional hospital, where her left arm had to be amputated. Shefali was saved, but that is not where her ordeal ended. When the hospital authorities came to know of her HIV+ status, they shifted her to Burdwan Medical College and Hospital on Sunday - even before she could recover from the surgery. ,Shefali told TOI on Sunday that she had nothing to look forward to in life. "Everyone except for my mother-in-law turned against me, insisting that I go back to my father's home in Panrui. The pressure on me increased when my mother-in-law was sent to Kolkata for treatment. I finally went away and spent two nights at Bolpur station. On Friday, I decided to end my life," she said.,One of her brothers-in-law, a businessman, maintained that she had not been forced out of their home in Santiniketan's Shyambati. "We did not compel her to leave. We live with small children and didn't want to take any risks. So we suggested that she stay with her parents at Panrui. You cannot blame us. We even promised to provide for her." ,Shefali's son works in a Kolkata-based private firm and is not in touch with his mother regularly.,S K Bhowmik, Birbhum chief medical officer of health, said, "There is no infrastructure at the Bolpur hospital to house such a patient. She had disclosed her HIV+ status as soon as she was brought in. A blood test confirmed this. In spite of that, doctors went ahead with the operation and treated her. So it shouldn't be said that she was shifted elsewhere as soon as doctors found that she was HIV+. In fact, all local HIV+ patients should be registered at Burdwan Medical College and Hospital." ,However, he admitted that the precautionary measures necessary to operate on an HIV+ patient were not taken at Bolpur.,At Bolpur hospital, patients who spent two days with Shefali in the ward, sounded quite worried. A doctor said, "We have asked higher authorities for better equipment to re-arrange the operation theatre. Then, we will be better prepared to tackle such cases in the future."

Title: HIV+ mother gets child's custody
article: JAIPUR: A woman who was infected by her HIV positive husband and punished by a lower court which wrenched away her 9-year-old daughter from her saying she was unfit to be a mother, on Friday got custody of the girl thanks to a sessions court in Jaipur.,The woman was married in 1995 and contracted the deadly disease from her husband, a soldier in the army. When he died in 2003, her in-laws threw her out of the house because she was HIV positive and refused to let her daughter go with her.,Hoping that the legal system would be sympathetic and less blinkered than her community and peers, the woman filed an application in the court of an additional civil judge seeking custody of her daughter. That, however, was not to be.,On September 17, civil judge and judicial magistrate Madhusudan Roy observed that she should not be given custody since she was HIV positive. "As the woman herself is HIV positive, she will be unable to look after her daughter and it is also not in the latter's interest and welfare. The young girl also does not have any problems living with her grandparents, where she is studying," the lower court said. And in the face of all convention, he also disclosed the identity of the woman.,Helped by women activists and lawyers, the ostracised woman approached the sessions court and argued that the lower court's order violated the Supreme Court's 1999 judgment which barred disclosure of an HIV positive person's identity.,On Friday, additional sessions judge Prithvi Raj stayed the lower court's order. "After hearing the plea, the sessions court stayed the order and fixed the next hearing for October 11," said the woman's lawyer, Ajay Kumar Jain.,An NGO had also taken up her cause. "We are happy as she has won half the battle," said Kavita Srivastava of an NGO which had helped her in the battle to reclaim her daughter. Civil rights lawyers said that after the woman was widowed, the family had waited for the husband's death benefits to come in before throwing her out.

Title: Court order on HIV+ mother angers experts
article: MUMBAI: The custody battle of an HIV-positive mother for her nine-year-old from Jaipur has drawn indignant reactions from health experts and activists working in the field of HIV/AIDS, who question how anyone could deny a woman's right to motherhood. The very fact that the case has been dragged to court, they say, violates the woman's basic rights.,"With anti-retroviral therapy available today an HIV positive mother can look after herself as well as her child. It is absolutely unfair for the mother to be treated as a child-bearing machine and then denied her right," said Dr Alaka Deshpande who heads the ART (Anti Retroviral Therapy) unit at state-run JJ hospital in Byculla. Deshpande pointed out how several HIV positive mothers who were under treatment at the hospital brought up their children just like any other. ,"Moreover, one must remember that more than 90% of Indian women get infected because of their husbands," she added.,The woman, a war widow, had contracted HIV from her husband who died in 1995. Her in-laws threw her out of the house because of her HIV positive status and denied her the custody of her child.,On Friday, the sessions court stayed the lower court's order. Saying he was happy about the sessions court decision to grant custody to the mother, advocate Anand Grover from the Lawyer's Collective said, "It is astounding that after 27 years of the HIV/AIDS epidemic, the lower courts should have taken such a decision. A mother who is HIV positive and asymptomatic and healthy should be not be denied her right.",Echoing the indignation, Jaya Nair from the Udaan Trust which works in the field of HIV/AIDS said, "We have cases of women living for 20 years after being infected with HIV/AIDS. As per the law, no woman can be denied the custody of her child."

Title: Row over HIV+ man's death
article: HYDERABAD: An HIV-positive patient undergoing treatment for a kidney ailment died on Tuesday, sparking protests by his family members who held a private hospital responsible for his death. The family members alleged that doctors at the hospital failed to diagnose his ailment properly.,According to the Balanagar police, S Babu, 27, was a resident of Indra Nagar in Alwal. He used to work at a car mechanic showroom in Moosapet.,In January, Babu reportedly complained that he was throwing up quite often and approached BBR hospital in Balanagar for treatment. Doctors at the hospital diagnosed that he was suffering from a kidney problem and started treatment on him accordingly.,Raju had blood transfusions on a couple of occasions and he got blood from Chiranjeevi blood bank and Jeevan Dhara. ,However, in September, Raju's health worsened and the doctors advised surgery. Unable to bear the cost, Raju was shifted to Gandhi Hospital where the doctors diagnosed him as being HIV-positive. Raju died on Tuesday morning. His family members staged a protest in front of the private hospital at Balanagar alleging negligence of doctors in diagnosing the disease. They also damaged furniture. Raju's family members also alleged that the victim contracted HIV because of the negligence of the doctors while transfusing blood.,Police said a case under suspicious death was registered and investigations were on. The body was sent for a post-mortem.,In a similar incident, a nine-year-old boy died due to alleged negligence of a doctor at Rein Bazar on Monday.,Police said the boy, Abdul Hamed, of Yakutpura and a class IV student of a private school. Hamed reportedly had fever and was treated by a local doctor. However, his condition worsened and he was shifted to Osmania General Hospital on September 16. The boy died on Monday.,Hamed's parents alleged that the local doctor's negligence led to his death.

Title: HIV cases on the rise in Bhutan
article: THIMPHU: There has been an alarming rise in the number of HIV patients in Bhutan, with the Health Ministry detecting about 20 cases this year. ,During a recent routine screening, seven persons, four of them women, were found infected with HIV, a ministry statement said. ,According to the Director of Public Health Department, Ugen Dophu, almost 90 per cent of HIV infections are through sexual practices such as multiple partners, casual sex, and lesser use of condoms. ,"Despite continuing efforts to curb the spread, people are not changing their sexual behaviour," said Dophu. ,Currently, Bhutan has 101 people living with HIV/AIDS, 55 of whom are women. Twenty-four people have died since the first HIV case was detected in the Himalayan nation in 1993. ,In 2006, 28 HIV\AIDS cases were detected. Dophu said the infected people cuts across all sections of society and is inclusive of government and corporate employees, businessmen, uniformed personnel, monks and even farmers. ,Young people are more vulnerable to the epidemic in Bhutan and currently account for 23 per cent of the infected population, Dophu said. ,Faced with the sudden rise in the number of HIV positive people, the government is initiating a number of drives including awareness and distribution of free condoms among men.

Title: HIV+ in Ahmedabad to run shops
article: AHMEDABAD: It is a challenge to your conscience. Would you go to a shop which is manned by HIV positive patients, or would you prefer to stay miles away from it?,A simple question which may have many ducking. But Amdavadis will soon be faced with this choice as HIV patients are throwing the gauntlet at them, saying that if the city cares for them, let the citizens show it.,HIV + persons will soon open shops selling handicraft products and food items to fight the stigma associated with the disease they are afflicted with.,After living in the shadow of AIDS for many years, Shaun Thomas (name changed), a former textile worker and his family are determined to stay positive in all respects. ,They are filled with hope that life is not hurtling down a dark tunnel with no end. They hope to get customers who would buy their products, knowing they have been made by HIV+ persons and, yet, are quite sure that the products they are buying are not contaminated with the virus.,This is a dream some 800 HIV+ people are nurturing. Whether their dreams can turn real would be evident soon, in the form of two shops in Sabarmati and Bapunagar. The project is being implemented by them with the help of an NGO â€” Aadhar.,Thomas recounts, "In 2005, my wife and my young daughter were detected HIV positive. And, I lost my job. It was a difficult period but now we are striving for a dignified life and these retail outlets will be a step in that direction.",Aadhar activists say the idea would be expanded if the two shops do good business. ,Decorative dandiyas, earthen lamps, candle stands, snacks, torans, hand-stitched clothes and greeting cards â€” all designed and made by HIV+ patients and their children â€” will be on sale here ,Thomas and his spirited friends are already visiting corporate offices, business houses, organisations and individuals to promote the products during the festive season. ,"Our confidence is up because a restaurant which we run in Bapunagar has been doing good business. But at this new outlet, we would prominently display that the shop is run by HIV+ people," said an Aadhar volunteer.

Title: Now, Punjab police faces HIV scare
article: CHANDIGARH: Another bad news is on its way for Punjab police, which is already battling drug addiction and alcoholism amidst its ranks, especially in border districts.,After drugs and alcohol, it's the deadly AIDS which has started taking a toll on Punjab police cops. While last year 24 cops were found to be afflicted with HIV virus in Tarn Taran district alone, this year four more cops have been tested positive, which has prompted senior officers to describe the situation as alarming. The cases were detected during the ongoing annual medical examination camp being organised by Punjab police in Tarn Taran.,Confirming the detection , Tarn Taran SSP PK Rai told TOI that four cops were found positive, out of 1,600 personnel who were examined. ,Rai said the situation was worrying as last year out of 2,600 cops examined, 24 were found to be carrying HIV virus, and this year the number could increase. The SSP said, "It's a matter of great concern and we are trying to spread awareness among cops. Besides holding annual examination camps, we have decided to organise health camps on a regular basis.",Senior police officers said that cops who were found to be HIV+ were being taken care of by the department and the cost of treatment was being borne by the government. Officers said that besides unsafe sex, one of the main reasons behind increasing HIV cases in the force could be increasing drug abuse. ,Officers said the department was also planning to launch a campaign to educate cops. According to Rajesh Kumar, head, School of Public Health, PGI, "In Punjab and in entire northern region HIV+ cases have not seen an alarming growth in the last decade. But rising cases among cops is a cause for worry and the situation demands immediate preventive steps."

Title: SMS project on free HIV test
article: BANGALORE: If you get an SMS reading "free, confidential and reliable HIV test at ICTC'', do not hesitate to do so by walking in to your nearest government hospital.,It is a part of the three-phase National AIDS Control Program undertaken by the National AIDS Control Organisation (NACO) in India to check the country's increasing number of HIV-positive cases.,Integrated counselling and testing centres (ICTC) have been put up at various government hospitals offices, where volunteers will counsel people found HIV positive.

Title: I am HIV+, let's play dandia!
article: AHMEDABAD: In the stigma-ridden society, it takes guts to come out and say 'I am HIV positive'. In fact, even the law prohibits the disclosure of HIV status of any person. Mahesh Parmar, however, is doing just the same, in front of thousands of people, all for a cause.,This is the first time that HIV-affected have hit ,garba, grounds to meet the revellers in person to warn them about the deadly virus and create awareness that HIV is no death warrant. There is life beyond the virus. The HIV positives will interact with ,garba, revellers all the nine nights.,United under the Gujarat State Network of Positive People (GSNP+), and its Ahmedabad unit, two HIV positive people hit the ,garba, grounds of YMCA Club on the Sarkej-Gandhinagar highway.,The first question they are asked is how long they will live. Talking to TOI, Manoj Parmar, an HIV positive, who has a family, said, "I tell them that my life is as uncertain or certain as a normal person's is. People still believe that HIV virus is the death warrant. But an HIV positive person can live an active life, if provided with the right kind of medical and social support".,During his visits to ,garba, venues, Manoj also shares with the youth that he recently married an HIV positive woman and lives a happy married life with his wife and a seven-year-old child.,"Youngsters are shocked when I tell them that I am HIV positive. I want to tell them that we are normal people like them. There is no reason to be secretive if one has contracted the virus. Integration of HIV positives into the society is a must," says Manoj.,Mahesh says, "People still do not know the difference between HIV and AIDS. We tell them how we have known HIV positive people who have lived for over 20 years with the virus.","It was a big step for the HIV positives to go out and face the people. We are doing this so that the youth can safeguard themselves against the virus," said Jitendra Maharaj of Ahmedabad Network of Positive People.

Title: Girl to decide if she wants HIV+ mum
article: JAIPUR: The nine-year-old daughter of an HIV-positive woman who was denied custody of the child, will now decide if she wants to stay with her mother or her grandparents.,The additional district court here has ruled that the girl should be allowed to choose, despite a subordinate court earlier ruling that the she live with her grandparents as her mother was HIV-postive and therefore, would not be able to care for her.,The class V student has been living with her grandparents at Sahar village in Jhunjhunu district of Rajasthan. The girl's father, who was in the army, died of AIDS in 2003. The girl's mother, in her petition, had alleged that her in-laws had thrown her out of the house in 2006 and forcibly taken custody of her daughter.,She sought her custody saying, as her biological mother, she was her natural guardian and also pointed out that her daughter is a minor. ,Her father-in-law, however, contended that since the child's mother was living in an ashram with other HIV positive people, the safety of the child and her health would always be in danger if she lived with her mother.,The father-in-law contended that they be allowed to retain custody of the child in view of her future and health.,Additional district judge Prithviraj said since the girl was nine years old and a student of class V, she was capable of deciding whether she should live with her grandparents or with her mother.,Counsel for the mother, AK Jain, moved a petition against the order of the lower court in the additional district judge's court. The mother had filed a petition against her father-in-law under section 12 of the Domestic Violence Act, alleging that he had forcibly taken custody of her only child.,She contended that the deprivation of the child was punishable under the Domestic Violence Act and she should be handed over the custody of the girl child.,Counsel for the mother, AK Jain, however, said they would appeal against the additional district judge's order in high court as the girl was a minor and wasn't capable of taking a decision. And being a mother, his client should be allowed to keep the child with her.

Title: 'Police can't induct HIV-positive'
article: NEW DELHI: The fight against discrimination of HIV positive persons in employment suffered a serious setback as two key ministries of the Centre â€” home and health â€” took diametrically opposite stands on Wednesday before the Supreme Court on recruitment of such people for government jobs.,The home ministry, in its affidavit to the court, said HIV positive persons could not be considered for appointment in Central police forces.,The health ministry, in its affidavit before the court in August, had said, "It is wrong to deny employment or promotion to anyone just because he is tested positive for HIV. HIV positive persons should be guaranteed equal rights to education and employment like others in society.",Solicitor-general Goolam E Vahanvati, finding the two positions radically different, requested a Bench comprising Justices S H Kapadia and B Sudershan Reddy to decide the issue on merit.,The court had sought the help of the SG and the responses of the ministries on a petition filed by Andhra Pradesh government challenging a High Court order quashing the state's decision to deny promotion to an HIV positive constable to the post of sub-inspector. ,The home ministry said when slight deformities like squint or flat footedness were a disqualification for joining Central police forces, it would be absurd to recruit an HIV positive person.,"The HIV/AIDS affected person, whose immunity system is severely compromised, would not be able to withstand the rigours of training and highly strenuous deployment under adverse conditions on the borders or in militancy affected areas," it said.,Immuno-compromised person may not be able to give his 100% in the high-risk operations tasked to Central police forces .,"Jawans lead a community life in bunkers, barracks and so on with a common barber, a common paramedic etc. The work of Central police forces is such that cuts, bruises, injuries and bleeding wounds are not uncommon," it said, arguing against the health ministry's stand that strict confidentiality should be maintained about the HIV status of a person.,It said, "In most cases, those who respond to wounded personnel are his colleagues who are not medically trained. Attending to HIV/AIDS affected persons would unknowingly expose the colleagues to HIV infections if confidentiality is maintained.",The health ministry, distancing itself from those canvassing for mandatory HIV test, had said, "The government feels that there is no public health rationale for mandatory testing of a person for HIV/AIDS.",Further, it had argued that HIV status of a person should be kept confidential and should not in any way affect his right to employment, position at workplace.

Title: HIV ground for divorce: Court
article: NEW DELHI: Observing that marriage was "anathema" without sex, a local court has held that a person whose spouse is found to be HIV positive is justified in seeking a divorce.,Delivering the judgment, which is bound to kick up a controversy, additional district judge Rajnish Bhatnagar said that a person cannot live "happily" with a spouse who has AIDS or is HIV positive. ,The judge thus granted divorce to a man whose wife is HIV positive, saying her ailment had prevented him from leading a "happy married life" as the disease is sexually communicable.,The court added that sex was an integral part of marriage and in this particular case, the husband was deprived of that enjoyment. "The HIV status of the wife no doubt resulted in non-enjoyment of sexual intercourse between the parties and marriage without sex is anathema," the court said.,The couple from Kerala had married in October 2000 and moved to the capital. Five months after their marriage, the wife was found to be HIV positive in a medical test conducted during her pregnancy. Tests showed the husband hadn't contracted the dreaded virus.,AIDS activists termed the decision to seek divorce as a matter of personal choice but expressed dismay over the negative impact the judgment would have on society's perceptions of HIV positive people. ,Said Dushyant Meher, AIDS programme coordinator of Salaam Balak Trust, "This is a conflict between the rights of an HIVpositive person and a healthy person. In this case, the court has given precedence to the rights of the healthy person."

Title: Estranged women turn HIV+
article: HYDERABAD: So far, promiscuous men have been held largely responsible for fuelling the HIV epidemic in India, but HIV/Aids experts now say men alone cannot be blamed. ,Promiscuity among women is on the rise, they say, with an increasing number of women reporting to be HIV positive while the status of their spouses is negative.,Doctors working closely with HIV/Aids patients at government hospitals say they are seeing more HIV positive women among discordant couples (where one is positive and another negative). Statistics of such cases from state-run maternity hospitals in Hyderabad are perhaps not only a social indicator but also confirm the trend. ,"In discordant couples, women are HIV positive in around 30 per cent cases and the husbands are negative," says Dr G Shailaja, superintendent of the Government Maternity Hospital, Koti, who has been studying the issue closely.,These cases started coming to light over the past two to three years when expectant mothers started undergoing HIV tests. Dr Shailaja says such a high number of HIV positive women among discordant couples was "unexpected." The average age of the infected women is around 30 years.,Doctors also note that most women cite "blood transfusion" as the reason that led to the infection. Globally, 80 per cent of the women are infected with HIV through their spouses or life partners. "But now we are told there are more reported cases of discordant couples with women positive and their partners negative," says K Padmavathi, deputy director of the Andhra Pradesh State Aids Control Society.,Those working in the field of HIV/Aids say such cases are not really city-specific. Doctors working with HIV/Aids cases for over a decade note that if earlier, the percentage of HIV positive men was 90 per cent (among couples who approached them), the percentage has dropped to 65 per cent now. ,"It may have dropped further," says Dr P Balamba, obstetrician and gynaecologist and former additional superintendent of Osmania General Hospital. ,She says the while the trend has been there for some time now, the numbers have started increasing only over the past few years.,Dispelling a myth before it takes form, Dr Balamba says the trend is not as prevalent among working women but is being reported from all walks of life across social classes. ,"From workers to the highly educated," she says, her observations based largely on her experience at the Government Maternity Hospital, Nayapul and now from her private practice. ,"Promiscuity is increasing among girls not just in urban but even in rural areas," she says, adding that perhaps this was being brushed under the carpet and is now coming forth with HIV statistics as the indicator.,Another gynaecologist, who did not wish to be named, said women were more susceptible to the infection (compared to men) given that the concentration of the virus is higher in semen. ,Interestingly, doctors observe that families and husbands in particular have been "considerate and supportive" of their HIV positive wives, but they point out this observation is not really applicable to the more educated class where some cases have ended in divorce. However, in most cases families have been supportive, doctors say.

Title: Widow claims falsehood over HIV+ hubby
article: GURGAON: Months after Divya (name changed) lost her husband, the police on Monday woke up to the unexpected complaint from her father who alleged that his daughter became HIV+ thanks to her husband. In his complaint, Divya's father, a retired Armyman, mentioned that he had proof that his son-in-law had died of related complications.,Divya married Anand (name changed) on April 17, 2006. Her father told the police that Anand had not been keeping well even then. Whenever he tried to find out why, the boy's father, a head constable with Delhi Police, avoided answering. Anand died on April 21, 2007. Police investigating the case said that Divya's father claimed that he had a copy of the medical report which mentioned that Anand was HIV+. "His family members hid the fact. Had we been aware we would not have gone ahead with the marriage," the inconsolable father said.,He added that Anand's family members had told them that he was working with a well-known mobile phone service provider and hence they did not find any reason to reject the marriage proposal. The father also added that when he confronted the boy's father, the head constable assured him that his family would take care of his widowed daughter-in-law. But to his horror, a few months down the line, Anand's family disowned her completely.,It was at this point that the distraught father took his daughter for a medical check-up as she had not been keeping well. The tests confirmed his worst fears as his daughter was also found to be HIV+. The police have registered a case of breach of trust and cheating against the boy's father at Sadar police station. DCP (south) Satheesh Balan said: "We have lodged the FIR based on the complaint. The girl's father claims that he has medical proof of his daughter being HIV+. But it's a complicated case as we need to find out whether the condition was transmitted to the girl by her husband. We are taking all possible medical opinion before taking any further steps."

Title: HIV-positive man dies in prison
article: BANGALORE: Lokesh, a HIV-positive prisoner died on Saturday night at Parappana Agrahara. He was suffering for a while now, officials said.,Serving a 10-year term for murder, Lokesh was transferred to Parappana Agrahara prison recently. After his condition deteriorated, Lokesh was shifted to Victoria Hospital. He hailed from Shikaripura, Shimoga.,Lokesh's relatives have been informed and the post-mortem was conducted on Sunday.

Title: UN says it overstated HIV cases by 6.3 million
article: NEW DELHI: The world now has 6.3 million fewer cases of people estimated to be living with HIV, thanks to India.,According to UNAIDS's latest estimates, there are 33.2 million people living with HIV worldwide. That's 16% less than the 39.5 million it estimated in 2006, clearly showing that the global burden of HIV till now was highly overstated.,Experts, however, said the revision of figures was primarily due to India and five other countries â€” Angola, Kenya, Mozambique, Nigeria and Zimbabwe â€” lowering their prevalence rates from the earlier high numbers.,In July 2006, India announced that there were 2.5 million people living with HIV/AIDS, about 2.7 million fewer cases than previously estimated. India's HIV prevalence figures in the general population also dipped to .36% against .9%, making India the third worst affected country with the deadly disease after South Africa (5.5 million) and Nigeria (2.9 million).,What made the difference was the methodology used by India in 2006 â€” the estimates, referred as "closest to the truth", was reached after studying the data from the country's 1,122 sentinel surveillance sites as against the 155 such sites in 1998. A massive sero-prevalence study, testing 1.5 lakh random blood samples from 29 states, also gave better insight into India's actual burden of HIV.,UNAIDS executive director Peter Piot said, "The single biggest reason for the reduction in global HIV prevalence figures was the recent revision in India after an intensive reassessment of the epidemic in that country. These improved data presents us with a clearer picture of the AIDS epidemic, one that reveals both challenges and opportunities.",However, the revamped estimates still represent a massive human tragedy. AIDS remains the fourth biggest killer worldwide. Every day in 2007, more than 6,800 people were infected with HIV. Women made up half of those infected. Over 5,700 died from it everyday. An estimated 1.7 lakh people died of the disease in India alone last year.,"So many lives lost due to AIDS is not a matter of joke. What's worse, over two-thirds of those infected in India don't know they are HIV positive," Dr Dennis Broun, UNAIDS chief in India, told TOI.,Naco director-general K Sujatha Rao said, "The statistical changes are a result of more accurate surveys all across the world. It's good news that the world has over 6 million fewer HIV cases.",Dr Broun added, "It's nearly impossible to conduct NFHS III like surveys all over the world. Such surveys are high cost with NFHS III HIV study costing nearly $14 million. That's why we have first taken such surveys into account and then mathematical models to come up with new figures." Two-thirds of new infections were recorded in sub-Saharan Africa in 2007. In Asia, there are now 4.9 million cases, up 440,000 from last year. The UN has also changed its estimate on how long it takes to die of AIDS if not treated from nine years to 11 years.

Title: Ray of hope for 5,000 HIV+ people
article: NEW DELHI: Nearly 5,000 HIV positive patients in India, who were facing imminent death because they had become resistant to the first-line Anti-Retroviral Therapy (ART) â€” the only known treatment that suppresses the HIV virus â€” have good news coming their way. For, India has finally decided to roll out the second-line ART from January 2008.,The announcement will be made by health minister A Ramadoss on World Aids Day on December 1.,TOI has learnt that two centres â€” Mumbai's J J Hospital and Chennai's Tambaram ART centre â€” will roll out the treatment from January. Maulana Azad Medical College (Delhi), PGI (Chandigarh) and ART centres in Kolkata, Manipur and Nagaland will introduce it by April 2008. Nearly 3,000 patients, who have become resistant to first-line therapy, will be put on second-line by December 2008.,Ten doctors from these centres are being sent to Thailand to study operational issues relating to second-line therapy in mid-December.,At present, the National Aids Control Programme only provides free first-line drugs to over 1.05 lakh HIV patients in its 127 ART centres. Naco estimates that at least 3% of these patients have become resistant to first-line drugs, thanks to poor adherence to the treatment regimen. If not put on second-line immediately, most of these patients would die within a few years. Health secretary Naresh Dayal said: "We had planned to introduce second-line treatment only after one lakh HIV patients were put on first-line drugs. Now that we have crossed that mark, second-line will be introduced in January in a controlled manner. Only those patients, who have been on first-line drugs in Naco's ART centres and have become resistant, will be eligible for second-line.",Dayal said UNITAID, an international drug purchasing facility, has offered to donate the drugs to India for the first two years. Naco will then tie up with India's generic drug makers to provide them. A health ministry official said: "Ramadoss is yet to decide whether we will accept UNITAID's donation or tie up with pharma companies from the start itself." Under first-line therapy, patients had to consume two tablets a day. When on second-line, the number will increase to almost 10 with more side-effects. ,kounteya.sinha@timesgroup.com

Title: BSF produces film on HIV/AIDS awareness
article: NEW DELHI: Union Home Minister Shivraj Patil on Saturday released a 42 minute film named 'Saavdhan' -a film on AIDS awareness- which has been produced by BSF and UNAIDS.,Patil was at a function of the para-military force's 42nd raising day here.,"The bulk of our force is young and is stationed in far flung areas without their families. These personnel have 'biological compulsions' and hence they tend to go on a wrong path, which we are trying to combat forcefully," Director General BSF A K Mitra said on the sidelines of the function.,There have been 121 deaths and 335 personnel have got infected, Mitra said, adding that the majority of the cases have been reported from the forces posted in the Northeast.,Highlighting the scourge of social-stigma that an AIDS infected person faces, Mitra said that he himself got tested at a recent camp in Delhi to send a message to the rank and file of his force.,The Border Security Force has also joined hands with United Nations Development Programme to provide education and awareness to its personnel and install condom vending machines at all battalions.

Title: Chinese returning from abroad to be tested for HIV
article: BEIJING: Chinese living overseas for more than a year will have to undergo an HIV test on their return as per a new regulation coming in force today, state media reported. ,Likewise, foreigners wishing to live in China for more than a year are also required to take the HIV test and inform the public security departments while applying for a residence certificate. ,The new regulations adopted on the 'World AIDS Day' on Saturday comes close on the heels of government's recent announcement that it is revising 22-year old laws and regulations which ban foreigners with HIV from entering China. ,China had issued Law on Control of the Entry and Exit of Aliens in 1985 which stipulated that foreigners with infectious diseases such as leprosy, HIV/AIDS and venereal diseases were not allowed to enter the country. ,"We are set to revise laws and regulations that ban HIV carriers entry into the country," a Health Ministry spokesman had said earlier this month. ,The new regulation on the cross-border control and prevention of AIDS issued by the General Administration of Quality Supervision, Inspection and Quarantine (GAQSIQ), mandates that Chinese citizens take an HIV test at the border while entering or apply for a HIV test form at the border and take the test at qualified local hospitals within a month. ,Chinese employees with international transport services, such as airlines, cross-border bus and train services would also have to take HIV tests, according to official Xinhua news agency.

Title: HIV+ kid in TN left hanging from tree for 7 hours
article: CHENNAI: Three-year-old Vignesh was tied in a sack and left hanging from a tree for more than seven hours on November 7 at Kaveeripattinam village in Krishnagiri district of Tamil Nadu. He was bought down after passers-by heard his wail. All because he was HIV positive.,Vignesh's isn't the only instance of stigmatisation in Tamil Nadu that is touted as the most "successful state" in India in the battle against AIDS. Indeed, Tamil Nadu's experiment with sex education in schools has gone a long way towards increasing AIDS awareness. But this hasn't stopped the denigration of HIV positive people â€” the situation in this regard in Tamil Nadu is as bad.,Prabha Priya's (name changed) children were thro-wn out of school three months ago after the teacher discovered she was HIV positive. And if you thought that such ostracisation was limited to the rural hinterland, sample this â€” last week, Baskaran, a software engineer, was humiliated in office when the HR manager cancelled his appointment order after he tested HIV positive. In all this, it's the three-year-old Vignesh's story that is the most heart-rending. After being given the short shrift by authorities â€” police sent him to an orphanage and from there he was dispatched to a government hospital â€” the infant was finally sent to his grandmother's home in Coimbatore, ten days later.,"The boy was sent to an orphanage in Hosur, but when they found he was HIV positive, he was sent back to the Krishnagiri district hospital. From there he was moved to the Dharmapuri Government Hospital for treatment. The news was carried in some Tamil papers. That was when his grandmother, Kanchana, came and took him away. She told us that the child had lost his mother and his father had remarried. Vignesh was in his grandmother's custody since then but his father had taken the child away six months ago," said official. ,But, how did the child land in a sack, and who strung him up a tree in a manner that could have killed him? It's shocking that the cops have no answers because they have not bothered to investigate. "Probably his father couldn't afford treatment. Anyway, the child is safe now," the policeman said.
