Title: Beijing steps up random HIV tests of travellers
article: BEIJING: China has stepped up random checking of blood of travellers entering the country as part of the efforts to prevent the spread of HIV. ,Under the new exercise, 312 travellers were found to be HIV positive in the first seven months of this year, up 19% year-on-year, a report said. ,They were among 756,000 travellers on whom random blood checks conducted at border crossings, according to the report compiled by the General Administration of Quality Supervision, Inspection and Quarantine, the quality watchdog. ,The increase in HIV positive cases was mainly due to the rise in the number of people who underwent the checks, a senior official said.

Title: HIV+ prisoner seeks bail
article: PUNE: An HIV-positive inmate serving a life imprisonment term for murder at the Yerawada central prison has filed an application seeking bail on the grounds that the jail lacks adequate treatment facilities. He has also attached a list of 32 HIV positive inmates who have died in the jail from 2001 to 2006 to substantiate his claim.,The application, filed by advocate Rajesh Bindra on behalf of the inmate, was heard by a high court bench comprising justice Ranjana Desai and justice Dhananjay Chandrachud on Friday. ,The bench will further hear the application on September 11 and has directed superintendent and medical officer at the Yerawada prison and the medical officer of the Sassoon general hospital to be present in the court during the process.,In his application, the inmate has said he tested positive for HIV in January 2007, while undergoing treatment for piles. Copies of the test report, reports of the DC4-CDX count issued by the department of micro-biology and a letter to the Sassoon hospital from the chief medical officer, Yerawada central prison, were also attached to the application.,The bail application states that the inmate's health was deteriorating as there were no proper medical facilities either at the prison or at the Sassoon hospital. The inmate also attached a list of 32 HIV positive prisoners who died in jail during 2001-06. This list had been submitted by another inmate to the Supreme Court along with his application in February 2007.,The inmate has pointed out in his application that he has already undergone three years of imprisonment and has not exhibited any criminal behaviour while in jail. He has also said that non-availability of proper medical facilities has questioned his fundamental right as well as natural justice and that no purpose will be served by keeping him in jail, since lack of medical facilities will only endanger his life. ,Being a bona fide citizen of a taluka in the Pune district, he has stated that he has a fixed place of residence and will not jump bail if released.,The inmate has requested the high court to call for records of the Yerawada central prison regarding medical facilities provided to its HIV positive prisoners. The court has also been requested to ask for jail records regarding deaths of male and female prisoners with AIDS.

Title: HIV-positive couple assaulted in Uttar Pradesh
article: MUZAFFARNAGAR: An HIV positive couple, who are undergoing treatment in the district hospital, were allegedly assaulted by seven people for not leaving the village. ,The couple, residents of Rehakra village in the district, were allegedly beaten up on Friday, SSP B D Paulson said, adding they were also threatened with dire consequences if they did not leave the village.

Date: ANI,Sep 14, 2008, 14:48 IST,Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie (AP Photo)
Title: Brangelina set up TB, HIV/AIDS clinic
10 years to the aid of HIV patients
article: BANGALORE: The Karnataka Network for People living with HIV/AIDS celebrated its 10th anniversary on Thursday . The state-level network formed by people living with HIV/AIDS has around 25,000 HIV+ve members with its network spread across the state. ,"Karnataka is the second largest state in country with high risk of HIV. The patients often find it difficult to gain access to medication. We will soon hold a rally in all the districts to create awareness," said N Venkatesh, HR officer of the association. ,Representatives from across the state participated in the event and shared the challenges faced by HIV patients .

Title: HIV+ denied right over husband's property
article: (Names of HIV+ and AIDS victims have been changed)

Title: Ban on gay sex wonâ€™t check spread of HIV: Delhi HC
article: NEW DELHI: The Delhi High Court on Tuesday observed that the menace of HIV cannot be solved by curbing gay sex and pulled up the Centre for seeking the retention of penal provisions against homosexuality mainly on this ground. ,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Please show material, research paper or any document even from other country to show that decriminalisation (of gay sex) would lead to spread of HIV,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ a bench comprising Chief Justice A P Shah and Justice S Muralidhar observed when the government claimed homosexuality spreads the disease.,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½If your argument is correct then spread of HIV should have stopped in the country as the law has been there for many years. But it is not the case as many people continue to die of the dreaded disease,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ the court pointed out, objecting to this stand of Additional Solicitor General P P Malhotra that the home ministryï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s affidavit, on which the government is relying, does not say any thing on this aspect.,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s a strange situation. Your first affidavit (home ministryï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s) is silent. There is not a single word on what you are saying while other affidavit (health ministryï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s) is pointing out that the penal provision leads to marginalization of HIV patients,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ the court remarked. ,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½How would the court decide the matter. Has there been any empirical study done by the government to substantiate its stand?ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ the Bench questioned and said that a special law should be made to provide proper care and treatment to HIV patients like other countries.

Title: An HIV/AIDS awareness programme was organised at Ravindra Bhavan, Margao
article: Infotainment was the buzz word at Ravindra Bhavan, Margao on Monday. , An HIV/AIDS awareness programme was organised jointly by Goa State Commission for Women, Goa State AIDS Control Society and Carmel College for Women, wherein students from 24 colleges from all over the state participated., , The programme, mainly aimed at sensitising the impact of HIV/AIDS among women, who are at a higher risk of contracting the disease than men. People were encouraged to come forth and help HIV positive people. Lectures were delivered by renowned people working for those infectd by the virus. Students organised street plays and musical events to highlight the causes and concerns of AIDS., , Encouraging the students were principal of Carmel College Dr sister Emma Maria, health minister Vishwajeet Rane, chairperson of the Goa State Commission for Women Dr Pramod Salgaonkar and Dr sister Aradhana. Also seen were principal of Damodar College Bhanumurthi, Sushila Naik, Anita Gauns and Shaila D'Souza, all members of the Goa State Commission for Women. ,

Title: Health ministry offers sops to HIV+
article: NEW DELHI: If the National AIDS Control Organisation (NACO) has so far mobilised $700 million to fight the AIDS menace, the health ministry has gone beyond its mandate and requested the concerned ministries for making available free transport, BPL cards and extension of the NREGA scheme to the socially stigmatised 2.5 million HIV positive people.,Even before NACO got the Supreme Courtï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s stamp of approval on Wednesday on its scheme stepping up medical facilities to AIDS patients that included establishing 650 link anti-retroviral therapy (ART) centres, the health ministry has initiated steps on the social and economical fronts to make life easier for people living with HIV/AIDS (PLHA).,In tune with Additional Solicitor General Gopal Subramaniamï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s promise to SC, Health Secretary Naresh Dayal has written to his counterparts in the ministries of railways, transport, food and rural development seeking a slew of concessions and extension of central benevolent schemes to PLHAs.,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½While the Centre was giving free investigation and treatment to eligible HIV/AIDS cases, as majority of affected persons are from poor socio-economic classes, there is considerable economic burden due to indirect expenditures that they incur due to loss of wages, transport cost and limited physical ability,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ said Dayal, explaining the necessity of his communication.,All his letters had an identical line at the end, ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½It is believed that the SC is inclined to accept these (Subramaniamï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s) suggestionsï¿½ï¿½ï¿½, probably to fortify them from any possible legal objections from the recipient ministries. The health secretaryï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s letter to his counterpart in the rural development ministry, Rita Sharma, said Subramaniam had committed to ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½extend the benefits of NREGA scheme to HIV positive persons. I request appropriate orders be issued to state governmentsï¿½ï¿½ï¿½.,The National Rural Employment Guarantee Act (NREGA) promises enhancement of livelihood security of households in rural areas by providing at least 100 days of guaranteed wage employment in every financial year to every household whose adult members volunteer to do unskilled manual labour.,In an identical letter to food secretary T Nanda Kumar, Dayal requested him to help comply with the ASGï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s commitment to the court to extend the Antodaya Anna Yojana (AAY) to HIV positive persons and pass appropriate directions to the state governments, which implement this centrally sponsored scheme. The AAY scheme aims to provide foodgrains at subsidised rates to poor (BPL) families who are unable to manage two square meals a day.,To provide PLHAs free of cost travel from their home to the nearest ART centre for medical help, the health secretary wrote to transport secretary Brahm Dutt and Railway Board chairman K C Jena to take necessary steps.

Title: Scourge of HIV/Aids hits adoptions
article: HYDERABAD: In what is certainly bad news, adoptions have reduced drastically in the city with 60 per cent of the abandoned children turning out to be human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)-positive. According to the records of the women and child welfare department, of the 125 children who were abandoned in the city and the surrounding districts of Ranga Reddy and Nalgonda , and who were potential candidates for adoption, 64 tested HIV-positive . ,Children not adopted are sent to non-governmental organisations (NGOs) and orphanages where medical care is given to them. However, not many are adopted as most families do not want HIV-positive children. ,Due to the stigma related to HIV/Aids, the adoption rate of abandoned children has reduced from 40.3 per cent in 2007 to 36.7 per cent in 2008. "Most couples are not interested to adopt a child with a disease. In most cases, they want healthy babies to be taken into their family fold," an officer from the women and child welfare department told TOI. Children who have diseases are given to organisations which have good medical facilities. Also, most children abandoned are girls whose adoption rate is less than that of the boys. ,"Many parents from abroad demand a health certificate for babies whom they are about to adopt. Such health-conscious people are not receptive to ideas which are related to care for HIV/Aids," one of the clearance officers said. ,The NGOs which are working with HIV-positive children are also worried about the emerging scenario. "Many children who are brought to the organisation do not survive . They die at a very young age. This could be one of the reasons why many people are not coming forward for adoption of HIV-positive babies," founder and care taker of NGO Care and Share, Carol Faiser said. ,Care and Share, Vijayawada , has as many as 60 HIV-positive babies in their charitable homes and get at least 10 every six months. The organisation facilitates adoption of children by Italian nationals. Health experts in the field said once the children survive beyond a certain age, they have a better chance of turning negative. ,"Babies may be born HIV-positive because antibodies are passed on from an HIV-positive mother to the foetus, but they may turn negative either due to anti-retroviral therapy or their bodies develop resistance to the virus," a health expert with Apsacs said. ,But then who is going to explain all this to couples interested in adoption?

Title: HIV can spread through kissing
article: INDORE: A city-based doctor has demanded a ban on all such government-run AIDS awareness advertisements which highlight that using condoms are the only way to prevent the menace. ,He alleged that the government was not focusing enough on other reasons of the HIV infection which include deep kissing as highlighted by some researches. ,Dr Manohar Bhandari said he had already sent a letter to Union Health and Family Welfare Ministry and National AIDS Control Organisation in this regard. ,In the notices sent on September 26, the Doctor claimed that deep kissing can also spread HIV. ,The training module for health workers, however, mentions that hugging and kissing do not spread HIV menace.

Title: Scourge of HIV/Aids hits adoptions
article: HYDERABAD: In what is certainly bad news, adoptions have reduced drastically in the city with 60 per cent of the abandoned children turning out to be human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)-positive. ,According to the records of the women and child welfare department, of the 125 children who were abandoned in the city and the surrounding districts of Ranga Reddy and Nalgonda, and who were potential candidates for adoption, 64 tested HIV-positive.,Children not adopted are sent to non-governmental organisations (NGOs) and orphanages where medical care is given to them. However, not many are adopted as most families do not want HIV-positive children.,Due to the stigma related to HIV/Aids, the adoption rate of abandoned children has reduced from 40.3 per cent in 2007 to 36.7 per cent in 2008. "Most couples are not interested to adopt a child with a disease. In most cases, they want healthy babies to be taken into their family fold," an officer from the women and child welfare department told TOI. Children who have diseases are given to organisations which have good medical facilities. ,Also, most children abandoned are girls whose adoption rate is less than that of the boys.,"Many parents from abroad demand a health certificate for babies whom they are about to adopt. Such health-conscious people are not receptive to ideas which are related to care for HIV/Aids," one of the clearance officers said.,The NGOs which are working with HIV-positive children are also worried about the emerging scenario. "Many children who are brought to the organisation do not survive. They die at a very young age. This could be one of the reasons why many people are not coming forward for adoption of HIV-positive babies," founder and care taker of NGO Care and Share, Carol Faiser said. ,Care and Share, Vijayawada, has as many as 60 HIV-positive babies in their charitable homes and get at least 10 every six months. The organisation facilitates adoption of children by Italian nationals. Health experts in the field said once the children survive beyond a certain age, they have a better chance of turning negative. ,"Babies may be born HIV-positive because antibodies are passed on from an HIV-positive mother to the foetus, but they may turn negative either due to anti-retroviral therapy or their bodies develop resistance to the virus," a health expert with Apsacs said. ,But then who is going to explain all this to couples interested in adoption?

Title: Fewer HIV cases in pregnant women
article: MUMBAI: The prevalence of HIV in pregnant women in Mumbai has come down drastically over the last six years. ,Only .70% of the pregnant women tested till August were found to be HIVpositive as compared to 2002 when the figure stood at 4.10%. These statistics were revealed by the Mumbai District AIDS Control Society (MDACS) on Friday. ,Officials attributed the drop to successful implementation of HIV/AIDS preventive programmes by MDACS. "This was made possible because we increased our scope of workalong with NGOs and corporate sectors-and carried out several prevention programmes successfully, including targeting high-risk groups,'' said MDACS project director Dr Shantaram Kudalkar. ,Over the last two years, MDACS has widened its scope of work by testing all women who come for pregnancy tests for HIV. ,Kudalkar said that various other programmes such as, PPTCT (Prevention of Parent to Child Transmission) started since 1998. "We are definitely seeing a decline, which can be attributed to the massive health awareness which is being created . We have been spreading knowledge for 20 years, and are slowly seeing a change of attitude ,'' said Dr Rekha Daver, who heads the PPTCT centre at JJ Hospital. ,However, sceptics say the statistical shift can't be taken at face value. An HIV/AIDS expert pointed out that in 2002, the HIV test was offered only in government hospitals, thereby there was a selection bias. "We are now testing all pregnant women. Since the denominator is higher, the percentage has automatically come down.''

Title: City tops state in HIV cases
article: AHMEDABAD: After the euphoria about Nano coming to city, comes the bad news ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Ahmedabad has highest number of HIV cases in Gujarat.,According to commissioner health, medical services and medical educationï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s report on its integrated disease surveillance project 2007 released on Tuesday, Ahmedabadï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s urban areas have recorded highest number of HIV cases in state.,The report points out that Ahmedabad has highest number of HIV cases, almost double than the most vulnerable city ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Surat. Urban Ahmedabad had 4,797 HIV patients in 2007, which was higher than 3,382 in 2006. In last one year, number of HIV cases in state has increased at the rate of 118 per cent. ,But Ahmedabad Aids Control Society (AACS) is hardly alarmed. Dr Chirag Shah says, ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½We have maximum number of integrated counselling and testing centres (ICTC) in city. AACS is operating 16 such centres. Many people from outside the city also come here for HIV testing. This has resulted in more number of HIV cases being recorded in city.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Many of them are not from Ahmedabad and since facilities for HIV patients are also better here, records show increase in numbers of HIV cases. We are also opening four more ICTC centres, otherwise the situation is under control,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Shah said.,NGOs argue that when there is more awareness, more people go for such tests and thus the numbers have increased. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½But we still do not have actual number of HIV cases in state because private hospitals or laboratory figures are not reflected here. Only after that data is incorporated can we consider this number or prevalence of HIV. Government should collate this data,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ says sociologist Gaurang Jani.

Title: Provide report on HIV in jails by Nov 10, HC tells state
article: MUMBAI: The Bombay High Court on Wednesday directed the Maharashtra State AIDS Control Society (MSACS) to submit a report on the prevalence of HIV in jails in the state, especially the ones at Amravati and Yerwada. A division bench of Justice F I Rebello and Justice Ashutosh Kumbhakoni gave MSACS time till November 10 to submit the report.,The report will comprise details of the number of prisoners who have tested positive for HIV, the figures of inmates who require HIV anti-retroviral treatment (ART) and those who are undergoing the ART treatment. MSACS has also been asked to list the infrastructure required at the jails for counselling, testing and giving treatment to prisoners as well as the time that would be needed to upgrade the facilities.,The issue first came to light when the high court was hearing a bail application filed by a HIV-positive prisoner serving a life sentence in Punes Yerwada jail. The court was informed that there were around 32 HIV positive convicts who had died in Yerwada jail between 2001 and 2006. Expressing concern at the statistics, the high court appointed advocates Anand Grover and Yug Choudhary as amicus cuirae (friends of the court) to assist the judges in dealing with the issue.,Public prosecutor Satish Borulkar informed the court that the state government had initiated two pilot projects for AIDS awareness in the two central prisons at Yerwada and Amravati. Advocate Grover, however, contended that this was not enough. ,There are no figures as to the exact numbers of HIV positive prisoners languishing in prisons. However, health activists say they constitute a high risk group. ,$##$C

Title: Bangladesh detects 1,207 people as HIV positive
article: DHAKA: A total of 1,207 people across Bangladesh have been found carrying HIV virus, while 12,000 others are believed to be infected with the deadly disease, according to a government study. ,The seventh round of the government's HIV surveillance study, released on Sunday at an AIDS seminar, found that rate of HIV positive among Injecting Drug Users (IDUs) in Dhaka city is seven per cent, which experts called as "very alarming". ,The seminar feared despite being a low prevalence country, Bangladesh could be a fertile ground for rapid spread of HIV/AIDS epidemic with all required factors remaining present in the South Asian country. ,"All sorts of high risk behaviour such as sharing of needles and syringes, resorting to drug use through injection, multiple sex partners and having commercial sex are prevalent among IDUs and make them the most vulnerable to spread infection," HIV expert Dr Yasmin Jahan said. ,The experts called intensifying a campaign for addressing the IDU groups saying HIV turned into a concentrated epidemic among them as the study showed that around 20,000 to 40,000 people across the country are IDUs and of them, 7, 400 are living in the capital Dhaka. ,Experts said HIV in Bangladesh remains at a relatively low level, but its prevalence among IDUs continues to grow. ,Bangladesh earlier was identified as one of the five countries in the Asia-Pacific region where HIV/AIDS infections are rising with campaigners attributing it on human trafficking into prostitution, stigmatisation of those infected, conservative social attitudes and intravenous drug use. ,According to a UNAIDS study, some 10 million youths from 15 to 24 years of age are HIV positive across the globe and every day 6,000 youths are infected with the virus.

Title: Education boost for HIV-afflicted
article: BANGALORE: The Rotary Club of Bangalore Cantonment launched two community projects on Thursday ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ a school to aid HIV/AIDS-afflicted children and a knowledge centre ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ to mark its silver jubilee year. ,The school will be constructed on the premises of Deena Nilaya, a rehabilitation home for HIV/AIDS-afflicted women and children on Hennur Road, near Kothanur. The nursery and primary school will have a capacity to teach over 50 children. Sisters of Deena Nilaya will be the teachers. Club secretary D C Shivdev said the idea is to provide regular education for these children, who otherwise face discrimination. ,The knowledge centre will be located at Rotary House of Learning, Fraser Town. It will impart computer education, career guidance and hands-on training through commercial projects to underprivileged students and school drop-outs aged 15 to 20 years. The training will also include soft skills and English lessons. The proposed cost of setting up the centre is around Rs 20 lakh. ,toiblr.reporter@timesgroup.com

Title: Soldier dismissed for being HIV+ seeks HC's help
article: CHENNAI: In the Indian Army's scheme of things, what is the best way to deal with a soldier who tests positive for HIV? Dismissal from service!,M Madheswaran was a sepoy and a boxer, for nearly 10 years. He participated in five to eight featherweight and lightweight category combats every year. It all ended in 1999, when Madheswaran tested positive for HIV. The military establishment lost no time in declaring him unfit for service and sent him home.,The boxer-soldier has now approached the Madras high court, questioning his discharge from service. Justice K Suguna has ordered notices to the top brass of the Army. In his petition, Madheswaran said the authorities said the infection was "not attributable to military service." The ruling has denied the soldier all employment and pension benefits. ,Madheswaran said that he fought both soldier - and civilian-boxers, who were never subjected to HIV-screening. Reiterating that he never had any illicit relationships, Madheswaran said that several times had been treated for wounds with stitches, followed by injections. ,He said he might have contracted HIV from fellow boxer(s), as the HIV virus can get into one's blood through small cuts and sores in and around the mouth and nose. He said his claim for disability pension was also denied citing that the disease was "due to the individual's own negligence and not related to military service."

Title: â€˜Pension for HIV/Aids patientsâ€™
article: HYDERABAD: HIV/Aids patients are likely to get pension on a par with the disabled. A proposal to this effect has been sent by the AP State Aids Control Society (Apsacs) to the government. The proposal is under consideration. At present, the disabled receive a monthly pension of Rs 500.,According to Apsacs officials, individuals who have reached Aids stage and are receiving anti-retroviral therapy (ART) would be eligible for the pension. To be eligible for the pension, one should have been on ART for a minimum of three months, possesses a white ration card and is not getting any other social welfare pensions given by the government. The Society would issue ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Saharaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ identity cards for them to access the services and benefits from the government.

Title: Doctors transplant HIV+ organ
article: CAPE TOWN: Doctors transplanted HIV-infected kidneys from a single donor into two men in Cape Town recently. ,The operations, which took place in late September at the Groote Schuur hospital, where Christiaan Barnard performed the worldï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s first heart transplant, were not made public until it was clear they had been successful, South Africaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Mail & Guardian weekly newspaper reported on Friday. ,The South African authorities had previously blocked HIV-positive people from receiving transplants and discarded nearly a third of organs because the potential donors were carrying the virus that causes AIDS. But the ban was lifted last year, opening the way for more operations, and possibly giving HIV-positive patients a greater chance of receiving new kidneys than those not infected with the AIDS virus, because there are more potential donors, the report said. ,The surgeon who performed the operations, Dr Elmi Muller, said the condition of both patients was ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½excellentï¿½ï¿½ï¿½, the transplanted kidneys were functioning well and there were no signs of rejection. Muller said that if the kidney transplants were successful in the long term it would open the way to the use of other organs such as livers, which are particularly vulnerable to damage by anti-AIDS drugs, and hearts.,But receiving an HIV-infected organ is not without risks for the patient. In receiving donated organs, they can receive a new strain of HIV. If the strain is a drug-resistant strain, the recipient could also develop resistance to life-prolonging anti-retroviral drugs. Another fear is that the donorï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s organs may have been damaged by the illnessï¿½ï¿½ï¿½a factor that would shorten the life span of the organ.

Date: Stanley G Pinto & Arpit Basu,Oct 29, 2008, 04:13 IST
Title: Airport red tape strangles HIV+ Mizo girl's last wish
article: MANGALORE/KOLKATA: A 22-year-old HIV-positive Mizo girl ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ counting her last breaths ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ tried desperately to reach home to see her parents, but airport red tape strangled her last wish. Mawii died at Kolkata airport on Tuesday after being turned away by Air India officials on Monday.,Mawii was being treated at Bangalore's Bowring Hospital and had taken a fit-to-fly certificate from there, said former Bangalore police commissioner and ex-MP H T Sangliana. But in Kolkata, AI officials wanted another fitness certificate when she tried to catch the connecting flight to Aizawl. "I tried to reason with the airline officials, but to no avail. I again got a medical fitness certificate and faxed it to them, but they still refused to relent," said Sangliana. ,Mawii was booked on a Kolkata-Aizawl Kingfisher flight on Tuesday, but died before she could board the plane. AI officials maintained that they could not bend rules laid down by the Director General of Civil Aviation.,According to Sangliana, who had made Mawii's travel arrangements, she boarded a flight from Bangalore without hassle at 6 am on Monday. The connecting flight from Kolkata to Aizawl was at 11 am. But AI officials wanted a fitness certificate taken in Kolkata before she could board the flight. She went back disheartened.,On Tuesday morning, Mawii returned to take a Kingfisher flight. She was sitting in the domestic lounge, when she suddenly seem-ed to fall asleep. When she could not be roused, two family members called a doctor, who declared her dead. Her body was taken to Mizoram House and is likely to be flown to Aizawl on Wednesday morning.,AI officials in Kolkata said the wheelchair-bound woman was "fit" when she travelled from Bangalore to Kolkata but fell ill later on Monday morning. "Mawii had a through boarding pass and went to the security hold but fell ill. Doctors at Kolkata airport refused to issue her a fit-to-fly certificate and referred her to a nursing home. We took her to a private hospital, where she was advised to take admission. But her family refused and shifted her to Mizoram House instead," said a spokesperson. ,He also claimed that Mawii possessed only a paper that stated "she is ill and be kindly permitted to fly". "It was not a valid certificate as the doctor's registration number was not mentioned. If she had to fly, a doctor should have accompanied her. We acted as per DGCA norms.",A Kingfisher Airlines official in Kolkata said Mawii's relatives had not declared that she was a patient. "If we had found her unwell during boarding, we would have demanded a fit-to-fly certificate as well," he said.,A furious Sangliana lashed out at the airline officials, saying it was "inhuman not to grant a person her last wish". "Now, the body has to be embalmed and sent to her parents, the cost of which they cannot afford. All these inconveniences could have been avoided if the officials had shown a little understanding," he said.

Title: High on HIV but safe in STD
article: AHMEDABAD: Alarm bells are ringing among health workers of the city, for Ahmedabad has highest number of HIV cases in Gujarat. But, there is a strange contradiction: the city has the lowest number of sexually transmitted diseases (STD), as compared to the other major cities of Gujarat. ,Usually, incidents of STD are much more in frequency as compared to AIDS. In fact, the city had a very low occurrence of STD cases in the past three years. Number of STD cases is also an indicator of the HIV-AIDS vulnerability. However, according to commissioner health, medical services and medical educations report on its integrated disease surveillance project 2007 released recently, Ahmedabads urban areas have recorded highest number of HIV cases in state. ,The report points out that Ahmedabad has highest number of HIV cases, almost double compared to the most vulnerable city in Gujarat Surat. But in STD cases, Ahmedabad is in the safe zone. Urban Ahmedabad had 1,096 HIV patients in 2007, which was lower than 1,153 in 2006.,Ahmedabad Aids Control Society (AACS), however, postulates a reason for this sudden jump in AIDS cases. Dr Chirag Shah of AACS says, "We have maximum number of integrated counselling and testing centres (ICTC) in city. AACS is operating 16 such centres. Many patients from outside the city also come here for HIV testing. This has resulted in more number of HIV cases being recorded in city.","Particularly in Ahmedabad, the awareness is very high and people use condoms for safe sex. Secondly, we have five special STD clinics in city, so we are able to prevent STD cases. Through STD clinics, we arrive at definite indicators of HIV prevalence in vulnerable groups. Apart from this, many NGOs working in the area of HIV-AIDS have STD management as their priority. So situation in Ahmedabad is quite in control as far as STD cases are concerned," says Rajesh Gopal, joint director, Gujarat State Aids Control Society.,When STD cases are detected in rural areas they are often treated at nearby hospitals and clinics as the disease does not require upgraded and cutting-edge medical technology, as is required for tackling HIV-AIDS cases. As for AIDS victims, Ahmedabad offers better medical and diagnostic facilities. Thus the number of registered HIV cases is more in Ahmedabad. So the STD cases, which are actually indicators of local status, is less. ,In Gujarat, maximum number of STD cases was registered in Surat 21,020 in 2007. Vadodara came second with 1,573 cases and Bhavnagar with 1,180. Surat, Vadodara and Bhavnagar have more cases of STD than Ahmedabad. ,"NGOs believe that we still do not have actual number of HIV or STD cases in state because private hospitals or laboratory figures are not reflected here. Government should collate this data," says sociologist Gaurang Jani.,CASES ACROSS STATE,Cityï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½HIV STD,Ahmedabad 4,797 1,096,Surat 1,631 21,020,Rajkot 722 482,Vadodara 481 1,573,Jamnagar 278 553,Bhavnagar 4 1,180 ,(Figures for 2007)

Title: â€˜Girls view HIV contraction as stigmaâ€™
article: JAIPUR: Itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s one of the deadliest diseases and, of course, the most talked about one. Yes, you guessed it right, itï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s AIDS (acquired immuno-deficiency syndrome). But interact with them and most of the girls in the city could tell you the least about it. And the piloting slogan of almost all the anti-AIDS campaigns in the country is: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Awareness is preventionï¿½ï¿½ï¿½!,According to a survey conducted in three girlsï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ colleges here, more than 50% students still believe that even a simple physical contact can lead to HIV transmission. Whatï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s more disheartening is the fact that 31% of them believe that the disease is a ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½cause of shameï¿½ï¿½ï¿½.,The survey, aimed at assessing the level of awareness regarding HIV/AIDS among college girls in the city, was conducted by two school girls from Delhi under the guidance of a lecturer in Parekh PG Girlsï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ College.,During the survey, 600 girls in the age group of 15-19 years studying at Parekh PG Girlsï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ College, International College for Girls and Maharani Girlsï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ College in the city were approached between September 15 and October 15. Of them, 537 responded to the queries.,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Prevention of infection is an issue being addressed by the media and awareness-spreading voluntary organizations. But the information peters out at the stage of infection. There is minimal mention of treatment and post-diagnosis measures. The social problems arising with diagnosis are rarely addressed,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ reveals the study.,Even more disappointing is the fact that 22% of the respondents still believe that AIDS patients should be treated in isolation. Gender inequality and lack of availability of authentic sex education turned out to be the biggest challenges, though a rise in the awareness level was observed.,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½It was discovered that the knowledge towards the disease is rising among the youth but when it comes to social and moral consequences of HIV infection, there still prevails a lot of confusion in their mind,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ said Nivedita Singh, one of the student surveyors.,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Our field strategy is structured with young women due to their higher responsiveness and ability to serve as more effective disseminators of information,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ she added.,Still a high school student, she, along with classmate and co-surveyor Niharika Singh, was motivated to conduct the survey and spread AIDS awareness after being appointed as a peer councillor in her school.,Commenting on the findings, a health official said that the awareness level about AIDS is increasing in the state but the study shows just how much more effort is required in this direction.,Jaipur being the state capital and a prominent education centre, students from all over the state with diverse economic backgrounds come here to pursue their studies at the city colleges. Hence, the city was chosen as a suitable place for the survey.

Title: Pak woman dares to marry an HIV-positive person
article: ISLAMABAD: In a daring move, a Pakistani woman has married an HIV-positive man after being inspired by his efforts to create awareness about the disease and the couple now plans to have a test-tube baby.,Former school-teacher Rubina Ashraf, who is in her 30s, married an HIV-positive man Muhammed Asim Ashraf. She learnt about Asimï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s condition a few years ago through a friend who is his relative. At the time, Asim was in a hospital in Lahore. Rubina went to meet him in hospital as she had never seen an AIDS patient before. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½He appeared very weak, but confident,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ she told the Daily Times.,She said she was impressed by Asimï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s courage but the thought of falling in love and marrying him one day did not initially occur to her. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½I wished him good health. I also promised to help him in his cause as soon as he was discharged from hospital,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ she said.,Rubina met Asim again when he was in Multan to start an AIDS awareness campaign. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½To my surprise, he had recovered from his previous ailment and was looking very energetic and handsome. I started helping him to educate the population about the killer disease,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ she said.,She found herself falling in love with Asim and proposed to him. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½However, the proposal was so appalling to everyone and seemed so weird that all people, including our families, were shocked. Asim even fled to Karachi to avoid the marriage, but I convinced him,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ she said.,Rubina said Asim was 19 years old when he was infected with HIV through a syringe. He has been helping AIDS patients and highlighting their plight since then.

Date: ANI,Nov 17, 2008, 09:27 IST,Bone marrow may offer HIV cure (Getty Images)
Title: Bone marrow may offer HIV cure
article: Researchers from Berlin's Charite hospital were successfully able to ward off HIV virus from a patientï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s body with the help of bone marrow transplantation.,According to the doctors, bone marrow transplants are generally used to fight leukaemia, however, during the present study the researchers found that the procedure can also prove effective against HIV virus. The research was conducted by Dr. Gero Huetter over a 42-year-old American man from Berlin who had been infected with the AIDS virus for more than a decade.,However, after the transplantation of genetically selected bone marrow, he no longer showed signs of carrying the virus, reports China Daily. But Dr. Andrew Badley, director of the HIV and immunology research lab at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn, suggests, ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ a lot more scrutiny from a lot of different biological samples would be required to say it's not present.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½,Before the transplant, the patient was asked to take powerful drugs and radiation to kill off his own infected bone marrow cells and disable his immune system. He also stopped the use of important drugs to treat AIDS, anticipating that the new, mutated cells would ward off virus on their own. Huetter revealed that some people carry a genetic mutation called Delta 32 that apparently makes them resistant to HIV infection.,If the mutation is inherited from both parents, it prevents HIV from attaching itself to cells by blocking CCR5, a receptor critical for the spread of AIDS virus. "It helps prove the concept that if somehow you can block the expression of CCR5, maybe by gene therapy, you might be able to inhibit the ability of the virus to replicate," said Fauci.,

Title: Abused boy tests HIV positive
article: PANAJI: Thirteen-year-old Rahul (name changed) could well be one of hundreds of children in Goa, full of dreams and hopes. But, sexual abuse by a neighbour, and testing positive for HIV has clouded the ladï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s plans for the future.,Rahul, a shy smile upon his young face, reveals that his abuser was a smooth-talking neighbour, who lured him with bike rides, money and sweets and then abused him. If Rahul complained, he would be threatened. The illicit liaison, that included brutality, lasted from May to early September this year, when Rahul fell ill and tests revealed he was HIV positive. ,That was when Rahulï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s father lodged a complaint on October 31 with the women and child protection unit alleging that his minor son had been sexually abused by a neighbour.,The accused was arrested and tests at the Goa Medical College and Hospital for STD showed that the accused was HIV positive.,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½We are really hurt. Who could have imagined that a known person would actually abuse our child and threaten him. My sonï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s innocence has been ruined and his life destroyed,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ said the boyï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s father, who had heard of HIV/AIDS but knew no details about the virus until his son tested positive for it.,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½I had heard about HIV but never cared to know much as I never thought that someone in my family could be infected,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ the father said.,Even as the family is beginning to cope with this knowledge, they fear their son may be kidnapped by the abuser or even abused further.,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½While we suffer and live in fear, the accused is out on bail,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ said the boyï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s father. The childrenï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s court released the accused on bail, which has been challenged in the high court of Bombay at Goa by the state. The appeal will be heard this week.,The family of the 13-year-old boy who was sexually abused by his neighbour now fears discrimination against the lad. ,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½At present many sympathize, though a few do taunt. We are scared to let Rahul (name changed) play alone, lest he be stigmatized or kidnapped. None of his friends call him to play. He is an excellent cook, but we donï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t allow him to cook as we are scared that he may cut his finger. We donï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t want to risk his life or anyone elseï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ the father says.,But Rahul doesnï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t understand the fuss around him. He admits he feels angry, sad, scared and anxious, but he wants to play, cook and do exactly as he did before. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½I want to play like other boys but my family members tell me that I should rest. I like to meet my friends and talk with them. But no one comes to play or talk with me. The only time I meet them is in school,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ added Rahul, who goes along with his father and returns with him once classes are over.,For Rahul, life is not all about hope and belief, but about the will to live and live ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½normallyï¿½ï¿½ï¿½. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½I am fine. I just want to study, play and live,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ he added.

Title: HIV patient jumps to death
article: AHMEDABAD: An HIV-positive patient ended his life by jumping from the window of the HIV ward of Civil Hospital late on Monday night. ,The deceased, identified as Mayaram Jhatak, a resident of Nava Vadaj, was diagnosed as HIV-positive two months ago, said Shahibaug police station officials who are investigating the case.,According to Shahibaug police station officials, Mayaram Jhatak, 35, a resident of Railway Colony, Vadaj, was admitted in the hospital on November 11. He was accompanied by his wife and a child. The AIDS department of Civil Hospital diagnosed him HIV positive two months back.,"The hospital authorities said that Jhatak sought to go to toilet and on the way out, he jumped out of the window at 11.52 pm. The windows have no bars. The doctors rushed to the spot and found him lying in a pool of blood. He had died on the spot," said a Shahibaug police station official.,Investigating officials said that they recorded his wife's statement in which she has mentioned that Jhatak had lost interest in everything and wanted to die. "It could have been the reason why he took the extreme step," said officials.

Title: Red Cross to launch HIV/AIDS awareness drive on Dec 1
article: PUNE: The city unit of the Indian Red Cross Society will launch a six-day AIDS awareness campaign mainly targeting the youth on the occasion of World AIDS Day on December 1. ,Addressing a media conference here, R V Kulkarni, honorary secretary of the city unit of the Red Cross, said the drive is part of its HIV/AIDS Youth Peer Education Programme (YPEP). "The programme involves activities like rallies, street plays, lectures, poster exhibitions etc.," he added.,On December 1, the society will spread its message at the Pune railway station through posters, pamphlets, street plays and condom demonstrations. "We will also organise a visit of a group of HIV positive individuals to the All India Radio to see the functioning of the organisation," Kulkarni stated.,An HIV/AIDS awareness session for the inmates of Yerawada jail will be conducted on December 2. On December 3, a fund-raising activity and a programme to raise awareness among college students will be held. A general health check-up camp and street plays on HIV/AIDS are scheduled for December 4 in Jejuri. ,The following day, an HIV/AIDS awareness session and a quiz competition will be organised at the Kasturba Gandhi Ashram School for Girls in Saswad.,December 6 will see performances of street plays on the stigma and discrimination faced by HIV/AIDS patients at the Swargate and Shivajinagar bus stands. ,On the same day, a care and support meeting for service providers at the Integrated Counselling and Testing Centre and NGO members will also be arranged. ,The YPEP is one of the Red Cross's major activities and was launched in 2003, Kulkarni said.

Title: Labelling must in HIV cases?
article: CHANDIGARH: One wrong prick and it changed Savitriï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s (name changed) life. Today sheï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s recognized not by her name but the word, HIV, written on her patient file. ,Braving societyï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s scorn, her day starts with a visit to the PGI for anti-retroviral therapy (ART) and regular check-up. However, each visit is humiliating, as her identity is exposed to all the health workers and the medical stores from where she buys medicines.,Stating that the identity of an HIV patient has to be labelled for cautioning health workers, Ajay Wanchu, in charge of the ART in PGI, noted, ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½The labelling is required so that a health worker takes precautions.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ ,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½An X-ray report was required in my daughterï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s case. The doctor mentioned she was HIV positive on her X-ray requisition slip. For blood tests, it is understandable as the virus spreads through it. But, an X-ray test need not tag her as HI,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ said Prakash Jha from Ambala. ,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½I have been to the skin out patient department in PGI. I approached a doctor and disclosed my HIV status. The doctor immediately wrote down medicines, mentioning HIV on the card. These medicines are sold in medical stores where so many people come. It is embarrassing to be spotted as being different,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ said Pooja Thakur, president, Chandigarh Network of People Living with HIV.,Suvir Saxena, director state AIDS Control Society, UT: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Such discrimination exists and there is a need to educate the masses. We are working in that direction.ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Title: Growing up with HIV
article: PUNE: Reshma was just five month old when her parents brought her to hospital to find out why she had not gained weight. After a clinical examination and laboratory investigation, she was diagnosed as being HIV positive. The parents were also found to be HIV infected. ,The baby was treated with anti-HIV drugs, her health started improving and her immune system normalised within a few months.,Reshma is now seven years old and looks like any other child. "She is enjoying her childhood to the fullest," said paediatrician Jitendra Oswal, head of the paediatric HIV clinic at Bharati Hospital and Research Centre. "She is always happy to meet us and takes her medicine as a part of her diet.",According to Prakash Sabde, state project director of the Maharashtra State AIDS Control Society (MSACS), "Maharashtra has a high number of HIV-infected patients. Mumbai has the most and is followed by Pune and then Sangli," he said.,"Among the total number of HIV positive children, 85 to 90 per cent get the infection from their infected mother. These children are innocent bystanders caught up in this HIV epidemic," said Veda Purandare, senior medical officer at the ART centre at Sassoon General Hospital. ,"The remaining 10 to 15 per cent get the infection from the use of blood. This includes children who require repeated blood transfusion for diseases like thalassemia or haemophilia," said Purandare. ,According to Oswal, a few cases have been documented in which the route of transmission is not known. The only effective way to prevent paediatric HIV is to reduce HIV transmission from pregnant mother to baby. "For this, our national programme of maternal and child health has to be strengthened. Also, it needs to be more effective in order to reach the masses," said Oswal. ,In India, a large number of pregnant women do not receive health care and deliver their babies at home. This puts the children at additional risk. These women should receive counselling and HIV testing, said Oswal. Pregnant mothers who are infected should also receive anti-HIV prophylactic drugs which can prevent HIV transmission to the baby, he added. ,At present, the government of India provides a single dose of Nevirapine (anti-HIV drug) to the mother and baby as prophylaxis. ,"This treatment can bring down the transmission to 47 per cent," said Oswal. "However western countries use more effective regimens consisting of at least three drugs which can bring down the transmission drastically. And the threat of transmission remains just 1 to 2 per cent." The Indian government should also adopt such a regimen, Oswal suggested.,Paediatrician Sanjay Lalwani, head of the department of paediatrics, Bharati Hospital and Research Centre, says 10 to 15 per cent of children who get the infection from their mothers die within the first two years. Eighty to 85 per cent of them develop AIDS between the ages of five and seven and die. These children are often malnourished and 50 per cent of them develop tuberculosis (TB), diarrhoea and other opportunistic infections. ,The progression from HIV infection to AIDS can be prevented by treating these children with anti-HIV drugs (anti-retroviral therapy) when their immune system starts deteriorating. "The treatment may not be of much help if you start it at late stage of infection. At present, the government of India gives the drugs only to those children in the later stages of HIV infection," said Oswal. ,HIV clinics ,There are two paediatric HIV clinics dedicated to the care and treatment of HIV infected children in the state: the B J Wadia hospital for children at Parel in Mumbai and the Bharati hospital and research centre, Pune.,The clinic at Bharati hospital plans to start a research project in which all HIV-infected children will receive free anti-HIV medicine and care as per guidelines of National Aids Control Organisation (NACO). ,ART centres,* There are two antiretroviral therapy (ART) centres in the city at Sassoon general hospital and Yashwantrao Chavan memorial hospital (YCMH), Pimpri. Adult ART began at Sassoon in 2005, while paediatric ART started in 2006. The ART centre at YCMH was started in October 2008.,* HIV positive children at the centre at the ART centre, YCMH, Pimpri: 106 ,Total number of enrolled HIV positive patients on ART treatment: 1,130,* HIV positive children at the ART centre at Sassoon general hospital: 800,Total number enrolled HIV positive patients on ART treatment: 4,138) ,WHO global statistics:,Number of people living with HIV (end of 2007): 33 million,Number of children living with HIV: 2 million,Every day 1,500 children are born with HIV infection,National AIDS Control Organisation (NACO), India:,Number of people living with HIV (end of 2007): 2.5 million,Number of children living with HIV (end of 2007): 70,000

Title: HIV woman driven out of ashram
article: KOLKATA: Campaigns for Aids awareness and pleas for better treatment of HIV positive patients are yet to have an impact big enough to make life easier for them. ,A city woman, who had been rescued from a pavement near the Metro cinema and later detected with HIV, has nowhere to go. ,Now undergoing treatment at the Chittaranjan Hospital, 45-year-old Minati Ray (name changed) has been turned out by an ashram where she had been staying for the last one year. ,With no shelter available for HIV positive women in the state, Minati might have to return to the Chowringhee pavement where she begged with her son till last year. ,Even as the world celebrates Aids Day on Monday, Minati stares helplessly at an uncertain future. Last year, she was found lying unconscious near Metro cinema and taken to the Gurudham Ashram in Kankurgachi. ,Even though the ashram doesn't have a shelter for the destitute, the authorities let Minati stay. It was there that a blood test revealed that she had Aids. ,"They started feeling uncomfortable about it but didn't initially turn her out. We stepped in and arranged for her treatment. It was difficult since she had lost her mental balance and refused medicines. But now, they have refused to take her back and there's no other place where we can keep her. It seems she will have to die on the road," said Biswajit Das of the Bengal Network of Positive People (BNPP) an organisation that assists Aids patients. ,BNPP had approached the Missionaries of Charity but the latter pleaded helplessness since the building that houses their women's shelter is under repairs. The health ministry, which had urged the BNPP to take up the case last year, has been approached. ,Meanwhile, Minati's condition has been deteriorating fast. Apart from Aids and mental imbalance, she is suffering from tuberculosis. "Time is running out for her. We are trying our best to ensure that she receives treatment. But she needs to stay somewhere. Minati has no family so the only option left for her is to return to the pavement from where she had been picked up. It will indeed be extremely unfortunate if that happens," said a member of BNPP. ,Frantic requests are being made to NGOs and charitable organisations. "We shall approach every organisation that deals with Aids patients. We also hope that the health ministry will do something about it," said Farzana Begum, board member of BNPP.

Title: HIV can take life, not love
article: NAGPUR: He was a tall, dark and handsome young bachelor. She was a widow, mother of a seven-year-old son, and HIV-positive. They fell in love while working together in a pharmaceutical company in Nagpur and decided to marry even though both their families were opposed to the idea.,On the occasion of World Aids Day, TOI brings the story of how their love conquered prejudice associated with the disease. Thirty-year-old Sumit, now manager at a private security company in Pune, tied the knot with Sunita (not their real names) despite knowing her health status. Sunita continues to work as a marketing executive in the pharmaceutical company in Nagpur.,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½She broke down confessing her HIV-positive status. I remember it was in April last year at the Japanese Garden, she was sobbing uncontrollably while revealing her past to me. I consoled her. We were too deeply involved with each other to think of anything else. I proposed to marry her after six months. Finally, in November last year we tied the knot,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ said Sumit with whom TOI caught up at a city garden with his wife and adopted son.,Sumit said he had no knowledge of Sunitaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s health status when he was first attracted to her. Sunita claims to be a victim of circumstances. She came to know about her own HIV infection when her first husband started falling sick a few years after their marriage. She had then also married for love. Married in 2000, the couple was blessed with a son a year later. He was HIV-positive and had infected her too. A couple of years later, Sunitaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s husband passed away of AIDS-related complications. ,Sumit claimed he had known Sunita for around three years. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Initially, she did not respond to my enthusiasm for her. Later, we started growing closer,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ he said.

Title: Offices must help spread HIV awareness
article: Bangalore:

Title: Plan to set up shelter home for orphaned HIV+ children
article: PATNA: Bihar is likely to become the first state to have a state-level shelter home for orphaned HIV+ children. Unicef has given in principle consent for giving funds for this project which is a brainchild of Bihar State Aids Control Society (BSACS).,The home would take care of nutritional, medical and educational needs of the children to be lodged here.,"Preliminary discussions with Unicef officials took place recently and they have asked us to submit a detailed project in this regard by the end of this month," BSACS project director Dr B P Yadav told TOI on Thursday.,He said that a ground level survey for assessing the number of such children is already underway and the project would be formulated in accordance with the survey findings.,Yadav also said if things moved according to plans, Bihar will become the first in the country to have such a state-level shelter home for HIV+ children. "Two such homes are being run in Tamilnadu and Maharashtra, but they are based on local initiatives having limited area of influence," he said, adding, "The one proposed for Bihar would cater to the needs of needy children across the state.",Incidentally, the BSACS also recently constituted a body, Greater Involvement of People Living (GIPA) with HIV/Aids (GIPA), for bringing all the HIV/Aids patients under one umbrella.,"For now we are working for setting up network of HIV+ positive people in all the districts so that people carrying this virus could share their problems with each other and also discuss the likely solutions," GIPA co-ordinator Sarita Kumar said and added that such networks were already functional in Purnia, Patna and Katihar districts and process of constituting them in Muzaffarpur and Begusarai districts were in an advanced stage.,She said that these networks would also be of great help to orphan HIV+ children as they would get a platform for taking up their cause.,Sarita also expressed concern over the present state-of-affairs where many HIV+ people were not willing to share information about them fearing social boycott. "GIPA has taken this thing seriously and would work for addressing the issue in a big way so that HIV+ people could get proper treatment and could also assert for their rights," she added.

Title: Expo, rock show to mark end of HIV week today
article: PUNE: An HIV exhibition and a performance by Hindi rock band Agnee will mark the conclusion of the HIV Testing Week at the B J medical grounds on December 6. "The expo will feature an interactive HIV awareness section as well as will showcase NGOs and other organisations working in the field of HIV in the city. The expo is open to all," said Hans Billimoria, campaign coordinator, Wake Up Pune. ,Commenting on the campaign, Jenny McCann, Indian project coordinator, said, "Our joint commitment to the young people this year also recognises that young people are the key and central to the response, recognising that youngsters are taking the lead. We often say youngsters are the leaders of the future, but they are showing their leadership qualities even today." ,Speaking about the campaign, Billimoria said, "Wake Up Pune is about Pune. It is about society coming together to address issues around HIV and AIDS. We need to wipe out the stigma and discrimination associated with the virus and offer real care and support to people living with HIV." ,Highlighting the importance of the corporate world engaging in HIV response, Ashish Patharkar, operating committee member of Satyam Foundation, said, "We need to educate, protect and support our IT professionals. We need to ensure that people living with HIV are not discriminated against in the work place." ,Speaking about sex workers , Nandita Ambike, coordinator , Saheli, a non-profit organisation run by and for sex workers, said, "A lot of efforts in the city are focused on sex workers and focused on blaming them for the spread of the virus, where in fact, sex workers are probably the most educated about safe sex. In reality, we need to educate the customers of sex workers about HIV."

Title: Homosexuality needs to be curbed as it spreads HIV/AIDS: Centre to HC
article: NEW DELHI: Justifying criminalisation of homosexuality in the country, the Centre has pleaded before the Delhi High that it is one of the main reasons for spread of HIV/AIDS and needs to be curbed. ,In a written submission filed by Additional Solicitor General P P Malhotra, the Centre said that legalising Men having sex with Men (MSM), as pleaded by gay rights activists, would lead to spread of the dreaded disease and placed reports of various countries to substantiate its stand. ,"In Zambia, one in three (33%) surveyed men who have sex with men tested HIV-positive. In the Kenyan port city of Mombasa, 43% of men who said they had sex only with other men were found to be living with HIV," the government said, quoting the United Nations report on Global AIDS Epidemic, 2008. ,"In Bangkok, HIV prevalence among men who have sex with men rose from 17% in 2003 to 28% in 2005 and it is estimated that as many as 21% new HIV infections in Thailand in 2005 were attributable to unprotected sex between men," the Centre said. ,The 100-page written submission was filed by the Centre as the court, while reserving the order, had allowed the government to file any additional submission in a written form. ,Centre's response came on a PIL filed by gay rights activists seeking the court's direction to decriminalise gay sex among consenting adults in private. ,At present, homosexuality is an offence in the country and Section 377 of Indian Penal Code provides punishment for up to life imprisonment for engaging in such acts.

Date: ANI,Dec 2, 2008, 11:46 IST,Routine HIV screening can save lives (Getty images)
Title: Routine HIV screening can save lives
article: Experts suggest that routine HIV screening of people older than 13 years can help reduce transmission risk and save numerous lives.,The American College of Physicians (ACP) urged that timely identification of undiagnosed cases of HIV can help prevent further transmission. "The purpose of the guideline is to present the available evidence to physicians as a way to help guide their decisions around screening for HIV in their practice," said Amir Qaseem, MD, PhD, senior medical associate in ACP's Clinical Programs and Quality of Care Department and the lead author of the guideline.,"ACP recommends that physicians adopt a routine screening policy for HIV and encourage their patients to get tested, regardless of their risk factors," he added.,According to the guideline, physicians should offer screening to all patients and should determine the need for repeat screening intervals on a case-by-case basis. Higher risk patients should be retested more frequently than patients who are at average risk.,"The intent of this guideline is to help prevent the unwitting spread of HIV infection,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ said Vincenza Snow, MD, FACP, is the director of clinical programs and quality of care at ACP. "I would tell my patients that it's important to know your HIV status so that you do not risk infecting anyone else.,ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Besides, an AIDS test is very simple and quick and can be performed during a routine exam," he added.

Title: School for HIV+ students in city soon
article: HYDERABAD: Children with HIV/Aids will soon have a school of their own. The Andhra Pradesh State Aids Control Society (Apsacs) and the school education department are planning to start a school exclusively for the students.,Though the location of the school has not yet been finalised, it is likely to function from the premises of a government upper primary school which was closed down recently as part of merging educational institutions.,"These students will later be enrolled in regular schools once they pass out of class VII," an official from the school education department said. The project will start by the start of the new academic year 2009-10. Apsacs will select the students for the new academic year.
